Yoruba: À ń pa ẹ̀kukù, ẹ̀kukù ń rúwé; à ń yan nínú aṣẹro, aṣẹro ń dàgbà; à ń kébòsí Ògún, ara Ògún ń le.

English: We make circles round the mahogany bean tree, but it is too much to handle; we make circles around the baobab tree, but it is too much to handle; we makes circles around the well, but it is nothing to jump into in anger.
Yoruba: À ń pòyì ká apá, apá ò ká apá; à ń pòyì ká oṣè, apá ò ká oṣè; à ń pòyì ká kànga, kò ṣé bínú kó sí.

English: “We know not what God will do” keeps one from committing suicide.
Yoruba: “A ò mọ̀yí Ọlọ́run yó ṣe” kò jẹ́ ká bínú kú.

English: A giant rat is killed on an okra farm and thrown it into a sack containing okra leaves; the giant rat has arrived at its home.
Yoruba: A pa ẹmọ́ lóko ilá, a jù ú sí ọ̀kẹ́ ìlasa; ilé ẹmọ́ lẹmọ́ lọ.

English: The needle will pass before the way of the thread is blocked.
Yoruba: Abẹ́rẹ́ á lọ kí ọ̀nà okùn tó dí.

English: He who summons others to render him communal help seeks enemies.
Yoruba: Abẹ̀wẹ̀ ń wá ọ̀tá fúnra ẹ̀.

English: Nursing mother, enemy of the barren woman; working person, enemy of the idler.
Yoruba: Abiyamọ ọ̀tá àgàn; ẹní ń ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀tá ọ̀lẹ.

English: The pregnant woman delivered; her sides are much eased.
Yoruba: Aboyún bí, ìhá tù ú.

English: Bat, who slept by the orange tree, found no orange to pick, let alone parrot who said it came over very early at dawn.
Yoruba: Àdán tó sùn sídìí ọsàn ò rí he, áḿbọ̀sì oódẹ tó ní òún jí dé.

English: Adékànḿbí is not contesting a title; he is merely asking a question.
Yoruba: Adékànḿbí ò du oyè; ó bèèrè ni.

English: The aftertaste of the bitterleaf is sweet.
Yoruba: Adùn ní ń gbẹ̀yìn ewúro.

English: One's delight in a cloth costing a hundred and forty cowries is over; one spreads it out to show to seven people, one finds seven lice, and on the seventh day it is torn.
Yoruba: Adùn-ún tán lára aṣọ ogóje; a nà án han ẹni méje; a bẹ̀ ẹ́ wò a rí iná méje; ó di ọjọ́ keje ó fàya.

English: He-who-eats-corn-meal-with-bean-fritters does not know the virtues of stew.
Yoruba: A-fàkàrà-jẹ̀kọ́ ò mọ iyì ọbẹ̀.

English: The wind does not blow against the liquid inside a coconut and cause it to spill.
Yoruba: Afẹ́fẹ́ kì í fẹ́ kí omi inú àgbọn dànù.

English: Glaring wildly does not bespeak manliness.
Yoruba: Àfẹjútoto ò mọ ọkùnrin.

English: Blowing from all directions is how one blows at a fire “to kindle it”.
Yoruba: Àfẹ́ká là ń fẹ́ iná.

English: The Catholic missionary is not in the pay of the British administration.
Yoruba: Àgùdà ò jẹ lábẹ̀ẹ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

English: It is an elder who lacks the authority to send a child on an errand who tells the child to go fetch water so they could drink it together.
Yoruba: Àgbà tí kò tó ọmọdéé rán níṣẹ́ ní ńsọ pé kó bu omi wá ká jo mú.

English: A foster child does not become one's own child.
Yoruba: Àgbàbọ́ ò di tẹni.

English: Borrowed trousers, if they are not too tight around the legs, they will be too loose; one's own things fit one exactly.
Yoruba: Àgbàbọ̀ọ ṣòkòtò, bí kò fúnni lẹ́sẹ̀ a ṣoni; rẹ́mú-rẹ́mú ni ohun ẹni ń bani mu.

English: It is completely that smoke fills the forest.
Yoruba: Àgbàká lèéfí ń gba igbó.

English: It is completely that the feet take over a path.
Yoruba: Àgbàká lẹsẹ̀ ńgba ọ̀na.

English: Despite all difficulties, the animal àgbaǹgbá sprouts prominent horns on its head.
Yoruba: Àgbaǹgbá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, ó làwo lórí san-san.

English: It is not the flood that will make away with the river.
Yoruba: Àgbàrá kọ́ ni yó gbèé omi lọ.

English: It is completely that goitre takes over the neck.
Yoruba: Àgbàtán ni gẹ̀gẹ̀ńgba ọ̀fun.

English: A farmer remains on the farm and sees the moon.
Yoruba: Àgbẹ̀ gbóko róṣù.

English: Groaning-internally is how an antelope groans; rumbling-internally is how a leopard rumbles, the grunts of a pig stay inside the pig.
Yoruba: Àgbinsínú legbin ń gbin; àkùnsínú lẹkùn ń kùn; hùn hùn hùn ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ inú ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ní ń gbé.

English: He-who-places-his-hopes-on-inheritance delivers himself to destitution.
Yoruba: Agbójúlógún fi araa rẹ̀ fóṣì ta.

English: Baying-and-surviving is the fate of the deer; whenever a deer bays, on that day its death is averted.
Yoruba: Àgbólà ni tàgbọ̀nrín; ọjọ́ tí àgbọ̀nrín bá gbó ni ọjọ́ ikúu rẹ̀ ń yẹ̀.

English: Not standing still is what is described as dancing.
Yoruba: Àìdúró là ń pè níjó.

English: It is not-having-attained-the-age-for-losing-one's-teeth that makes one cover (the mouth) with one's hand.
Yoruba: Àìtó eyín-ín ká ni à ń fọwọ́ bò ó.

English: A domesticated dog does not know how to hunt.
Yoruba: Ajá ilé ò mọdẹẹ́ ṣe.

English: The snare does not snare a cat's paw.
Yoruba: Àjà kì í jìn mọ́ ológbò lẹ́sẹ̀.

English: A dog that will chew dried corn must be brave; a cat that will eat a frog will dip its face in water.
Yoruba: Ajá tó máa rún ọkà á láyà; ológbò to máa jẹ àkèré á ki ojú bọ omi.

English: It is an agile dog that kills a squirrel.
Yoruba: Ajá wéré-wéré ní ń pa ikún.

English: The dog looks at birds with eyes full of disdain.
Yoruba: Ajá wo ẹyẹ láwòmọ́jú.

English: Wealth throws a person away like a stone.
Yoruba: Ajé sọ ọmọ nù bí òkò.

English: Eating without adverse effects is the vulture's way of consuming sacrificial offerings.
Yoruba: Àjẹgbé nigún ń jẹbọ.

English: You who have fallen into the dungeon, do not be impatient to arrive home; when the toad drops into a pit it cannot be impatient to get out.
Yoruba: Ajìnfìn, má ta ojú ilé; ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ jìnfìn má ta ojú àtijáde.

English: The sit-tight person denies the tentative sitter a place.
Yoruba: A-jókò-ó-kunkun ò jẹ́ kí a-jókòó-jẹ́jẹ́ ó jókòo.

English: Familial obligations do not extend to diseases; let each person look well to his or her arms.
Yoruba: Àjùmọ̀bí ò kan ti àrùn; kí alápá mú apáa rẹ̀ kó le.

English: He-who-plucks-the-African-locustbean-tree-seeds-to-sell spends death's money.
Yoruba: A-ká-ìgbá-tà-á náwó ikú.

English: The arrow for a warthog is a major project; an ordinary poison has no effect on the cat.
Yoruba: Àkànṣe lọfà ìmàdò; jagan oró ò ran èse.

English: Scorpion says that its status transcends what-type-of-insect-is-this?
Yoruba: Àkèekèé ní òún kúrò ní kòkòròo kí nìyí?

English: The scorpion travels accompanied by venom.
Yoruba: Àkèekèé rìn tapó-tapó.

English: For the exceptionally brave person the proper profession is warring; for the gregarious person, trading; the illustrious he-goat, even when it is poor, finds enough to eat.
Yoruba: Akíkanjú-kankan, ogun ní ń lọ; abùwàwà, ọjà ní ń ná; àkànní òbúkọ, bó bá tòṣì a máa rí jẹ.

English: It is completely that goitre takes over the throat.
Yoruba: Àkótán ni gẹ̀gẹ̀ ń kó ọ̀fun.

English: The cock crows, and the lazy person hisses.
Yoruba: Àkùkọọ́ kọ, ọ̀lẹẹ́ pòṣé.

English: The chameleon has given birth to its young; inability to dance is the responsibility of the child.
Yoruba: Alágẹmọọ́ ti bímọọ rẹ̀ ná; àìmọ̀-ọ́jó kù sọ́wọ́ọ rẹ̀.

English: She who borrows a wrapper-skirt to wear is not home free; the owner of the cloth will take it back come tomorrow.
Yoruba: Alágbàró ò yege; aláṣọ á gbà á bó dọ̀la.

English: A person with cross-bows in his eyes cannot kill an animal.
Yoruba: Alákatam̀pò ojú ò lè ta ẹran pa.

English: The lizard that fell from atop the ìrókò tree without breaking its limbs says if no one admires his feat, he will do the admiring himself.
Yoruba: Aláǹgbá tó já látorí ìrókò tí kò fẹsẹ̀ ṣẹ́, ó ní bẹ́nìkan ò yìn un òun ó yinra òun.

English: It is the owner of the body that elevates the body; when a chicken wishes to enter the porch it stoops.
Yoruba: Alára ní ńgbáraá ga; bádíẹ́ bá máa wọ̀ọ̀dẹ̀ a bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: He-who-can-fight-but-cannot-fight-for-long, the equal of a coward.
Yoruba: A-lèjà-má-lè-jà-pẹ́, ẹlẹgbẹ́ ojo.

English: The lump is only the head's visitor.
Yoruba: Àlejò orí ni kókó.

English: One's arms are one's relatives; one's elbows are one's siblings by the same mother.
Yoruba: Apá lará; ìgbọ̀nwọ́ niyèkan.

English: The potsherd lives on the farm but does not decay.
Yoruba: Àpáàdìí gbóko kò rà.

English: Killing-without-recourse is Orò's way of killing trees.
Yoruba: Àpagbé lOrò ń pagi.

English: It is a bald person that may be disdainful of the razor.
Yoruba: Apárí ní ń fojú di abẹ.

English: A person who waits patiently for a long time before eating will not eat unwholesome food.
Yoruba: Apẹ́ẹ́jẹ kì í jẹ ìbàjẹ́.

English: Scooping a spring dry does not stop more water from collecting.
Yoruba: Àpọntán kò wí pé kí odò má sun.

English: A body cannot be too heavy for the owner to lift.
Yoruba: Ara kì í wúwo kí alára má lè gbe.

English: My body can endure chills, and can endure coldness.
Yoruba: Araà mí gba òtútù, ó gba ọ̀nini.

English: The huge sik-cotton tree belittles the axe.
Yoruba: Àràbà ńlá fojú di àáké.

English: A subordinate military officer who is audacious is the equal of his superior.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ àgòrò tó bá gbójú, tòun tolúwa rẹ̀ lẹgbẹ́ra.

English: Having an opportunity to act is also having an opportunity to tell stories.
Yoruba: Àríṣe làríkà.

English: It is only the noise of the whirlwind that reaches heaven.
Yoruba: Ariwo àjìjà ní ń dọ́run.

English: Àro stayed so long on the farm that he forgot how to beat the drum.
Yoruba: Àroó pẹ́ lóko, kò tún mọ ìlùú lù.

English: It is the person in a hurry who studies the complexion of the day.
Yoruba: Asúrétete ní ń wojú ọjọ́.

English: The kite does not snatch chicks in secret, it snatches them openly.
Yoruba: Àṣá ò gbádìẹ níkọ̀kọ̀; gbangba làṣá ń gbádìẹ.

English: The kite cannot swoop down and carry off a goat.
Yoruba: Àṣá ò lè balẹ̀ kó gbéwúrẹ́.

English: The kite looks long at the tortoise; the eagle looks long at the tortoise; what can the hawk, father of the kite, do to the tortoise?
Yoruba: Àṣá wo ahun títí; àwòdí wo ahun títí; idì baba àṣá, kí ló lè fi ahun ṣe?

English: The kite looks slyly at the snail, but its shell stops the bird from snatching it.
Yoruba: Àṣá wo ìgbín kọ̀rọ̀; ìkaraun-un rẹ̀ ò jẹ́ kó gbé e.

English: The kite watches the monkey but has no hands to carry it off.
Yoruba: Àṣá wọ̀bọ kò rọ́wọ́ gbé e.

English: The secrets of the hyena's being will not be revealed through the actions of the dog.
Yoruba: Àṣírí ìkokò, ajá kọ́ ni yó tùú u.

English: One's palm does not deceive one.
Yoruba: Àtẹ́lẹwọ́ ẹni kì í tanni.

English: The space is never so tight that a chicken will not be able to reach its incubating nest.
Yoruba: Àyè kì í há adìẹ kó má dèé ìdí àbaa rẹ̀.

English: The more one peels the bark of the baobab, the fatter it becomes.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ń pa èpo oṣè, ṣe ní ń máaá sanra sí i.

English: If one does not experience enough suffering to fill a basket, one cannot enjoy enough good to fill a cup.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá jìyà tó kún agbọ̀n; a ò lè jẹ oore tó kún ahá.

English: If one does not act like a pig on the way to Ikòròdú one cannot act like Adégbọrọ̀at the king's market.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá ṣe bí ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ lọ́nà Ìkòròdú, a ò lè ṣe bí Adégbọrọ̀ lọ́jà ọba.

English: If a lazy person is suffering from hunger, he/she should be left to die.
Yoruba: Bí ebí bá ń pa ọ̀lẹ, à jẹ́ kó kú.

English: If a poor person's forked stake is not long enough in the morning, it will be long enough at night.
Yoruba: Bí ẹkẹ́ẹ tálákà ò tó lówùúrọ̀, á tó lálẹ́.

English: If a person does not extend greetings to one, God's greetings are worth more than two hundred peoples'.
Yoruba: Bí ẹnìkan ò kíni “Kú-ù-jokòó,” kíkí Ọlọ́run-ún ju ti igba èèyàn lọ.

English: A slave that would eat intestines must begin with the liver.
Yoruba: Bí ẹrú yó bàá jẹ ìfun, ibi ẹ̀dọ̀ níí tí ń bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: When the cub becomes a grown leopard, it kills animals for food.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ̀yá bá dẹkùn, ẹran ní ńpajẹ.

English: If the pedigree is bent, if the pedigree is crooked, each person will play the father in his own home.
Yoruba: Bí ìbí bá tẹ̀, bí ìbí bá wọ́, oníkálukú a máa ṣe baba nílé araa rẹ̀.

English: When day breaks the lazy person will still be asleep.
Yoruba: Bí ilẹ̀ẹ́ bá mọ́, ojú orun lọ̀lẹ ń wà.

English: If lice are not completely gone from one's clothings, one's nails will not be free of blood.
Yoruba: Bí iná kò bá tán láṣọ, ẹ̀jẹ̀ kì í tán léèékánná.

English: If a youth is in the grips of excessive privations, he should go after an elephant; if he kills an elephant his privations will be over; if an elephant kills him, his privations will be over.
Yoruba: Bí ìṣẹ́ bá ń ṣẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ láṣẹ̀ẹ́jù, kó lọ sígbó erin; bó bá pa erin ìṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ a tán; bí erín bá pá a, ìṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ a tán.

English: If one cannot go forward, one will be able to retreat.
Yoruba: Bí iwájú ò bá ṣeé lọ sí, ẹ̀yìn a ṣeé padà sí.

English: However numerous the cattle might be, it is with only one staff that the Fulbe man herds them.
Yoruba: Bí màlúù tó màlúù, ọ̀pá kan ni Fúlàní fi ń dà wọ́n.

English: “If I must die let me die” is what makes a man strong; “I simply will not court death” is what makes a man lazy or cowardly.
Yoruba: “Bí mo lè kú ma kú” lọmọkùrín fi ń lágbárá “N ò lè wáá kú” lọmọkùnrín fi ń lẹ.

English: However long it may take, the stammarer will eventually say, “Father.”
Yoruba: Bí ó pẹ́ títí, akólòlò á pe baba.

English: In time, a sojourner becomes a native.
Yoruba: Bí ó pẹ́ títí, àlejò á di onílé.

English: One practices one's Islam as one pleases; if the Imam wishes he may break his fast with pork.
Yoruba: Bí ó ti wuni là ń ṣe ìmàle ẹni; bó wu Lèmó̩mù a fẹlẹ́dẹ̀ jẹ sààrì.

English: If one is sure of one's Ògún cult object, one taps ones head with it.
Yoruba: Bí Ògún ẹní bá dánilójú, à fi gbárí.

English: If one's eyes do not become as red as camwood stain, one does not come by something as red as brass.
Yoruba: Bí ojú kò pọ́nni bí osùn, a kì í he ohun pupa bí idẹ.

English: If what one bought for one's money does not fill one, the little extra thrown into the bargain will not.
Yoruba: Bí ojú owó ẹni ò yóni, ènì ò lè yóni.

English: When day dawns the cattle egret makes for the home of the dealer in chalk, the blue touraco heads for the home of the indigo dealer, the purple àlúkò bird seeks out the dealer in camwood resin.
Yoruba: Bí ojúmọ́ mọ́ lékèélékèé a yalé ẹlẹ́fun, agbe a yalé aláró, àlùkò a yalé olósùn.

English: If the hand does not cease going down and going to the mouth, satiation results.
Yoruba: Bí ọwọ́ kò sin ilẹ̀, tí kò sin ẹnu, ayo ní ń jẹ́.

English: Even though Ṣango kills the silk-cotton tree and kills the ìrókò tree, no such fate can befall the huge tree.
Yoruba: Bí Ṣàǹgó bá ńpa àràbà, tó ń pa ìrókò, bíi tigi ńlá kọ́.

English: Dàńdógò is not a garment for the young.
Yoruba: Dàńdógó kì í ṣe ẹ̀wù ọmọdé.

English: One should give everything a try; if one's owner dies one goes to claim his wife.
Yoruba: Dídán là ń dán ọ̀ràn wò; bí olówó ẹní kú, à lọ ṣúpó.

English: A perpetually shining appearance is what chracterizes the pigeon even until death.
Yoruba: Dídán lẹyẹlé ń dán kú.

English: It is bit by bit that rats eat leather.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ leku ń jawọ.

English: It is bit by bit that a bird eats an orange.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ lẹyẹ ń mu ọsàn.

English: Gradual efforts complete a task.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ ní ń tánṣẹ́.

English: The talking drum endures all matters without complaint.
Yoruba: Dùndún fọ̀ràn gbogbo ṣàpamọ́ra.

English: A single heap on the farm does not warrant “I am just about done.”
Yoruba: Ebè kan ṣoṣo àkùrọ́ kúrò ní “Mo fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ ṣíwọ́.”

English: It is hunger that will force sense into the imbecile.
Yoruba: Ebi ni yó kọ̀ọ́ wèrè lọ́gbọ́n.

English: The snake is hungry, and the tortoise saunters by.
Yoruba: Ebí ń pa ejò, ahún ń yan.

English: Hunger keeps one from folding one's hands; hunger causes the mouth “or cheeks” to shrink.
Yoruba: Ebi ò jẹ́ ká pa ọwọ́ mọ́; ebí ṣenú papala.

English: Insults do not attach to one's body like pods.
Yoruba: Èébú kì í so.

English: No charm can act upon the day and keep it from dawning.
Yoruba: Èdì kì í mú ọjọ́ kó má là.

English: The masquerader who is accustomed to eating horse heads will not be daunted by ram heads.
Yoruba: Eégún tí ń jẹ orí ẹṣin, orí àgbò ò lè kò ó láyà.

English: Okro that has gone fibrous has delivered itself from the knife.
Yoruba: Èkó ilá gba ara ẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ ọ̀bẹ.

English: Being bothered by sandflies is no misfortune.
Yoruba: Èminrin ń jẹni, kò tó ìyà.

English: An angry curse does not kill an enemy.
Yoruba: Èpè ìbínú ò pa odì.

English: The curses of okro leaves do not affect the deer.
Yoruba: Èpè ìlasa kì í ja àgbọ̀nrín.

English: Creeping weeds cannot kill the silk rubber tree.
Yoruba: Èpò ìbúlẹ̀ kì í pa irẹ́.

English: The elephant forages a long time without cutting its hand on a spear; the buffalo forages a long time without falling into a trap; numerous small birds fly across the sky without colliding with trees.
Yoruba: Erín jẹ̀ jẹ̀ jẹ̀ kò fọwọ́ kọ́ aṣá; ẹ̀fọ́n jẹ̀ jẹ̀ jẹ̀ kò ki ẹsẹ̀ wọ pòòlò; ẹyẹ kékéèké ń fò lókè wọn ò forí gbági.

English: Error does not await the king before it dons a crown; Ogunṣọṣẹ  does not wait for the sun before it dons a bloody cloak; the flower does not wait for the sun before it brightens; brightness comes with the child from its house.
Yoruba: Èṣì ò rọ́ba dádé; Ògúnṣọṣẹ́ ò róòrùn wẹ̀wù ẹ̀jẹ̀; òdòdó ò róòrùn pọ́n; ilé ọmọ lọmọ́ ti pọ́n wá.

English: The fly is procuring wine while the worm is cooking bean-meal, and the sugar-fly asks them to find something to cork the gourd so nothing would enter into it.
Yoruba: Eṣinṣín ń pọntí; ekòló ń ṣú ọ̀lẹ̀lẹ̀; kantí-kantí ní ká wá nǹkan dí agbè lẹ́nu kí nǹkankan má kòó sí i.

English: The locusts are done feeding, the locusts have departed; the locusts have gone to Wata, their home.
Yoruba: Eṣú jẹ oko tán eṣù lọ; eṣú lọ Wata, ilée rẹ̀.

English: As far as the broom is concerned it is taboo: one does not make kindling of broomsticks.
Yoruba: Èèwọ̀ ni tọwọ̀; a kì í figi ọwọ̀ dáná.

English: The African black kite is never killed in a brushfire emergency.
Yoruba: Ewu iná kì í pa àwòdì.

English: The goat is celebrating an event, the sheep is in a procession with drums, and the he-goat asks to be accompanied to its in-law's home.
Yoruba: Ewúrẹ́ ń ṣọdún, àgùtán gbàlù sẹ́yìn, òbúkọọ́ ní ká sin òun lọ sílé àna òun.

English: A goat can in no wise take the fig tree's leaves aloft for any purpose.
Yoruba: Ewúrẹ́ ò lè rí ewé ọdán òkè fi ṣe nǹkan.

English: The bitter-leaf did not become bitter as a result of cowardice.
Yoruba: Ewúro ò fi tojo korò.

English: Whether a person be short or ugly, if there is no debt, there can be no disgrace.
Yoruba: Èèyàn ìbáà kúrú, ìbáà búrẹ́wà, gbèsè ò sí, ìtìjú ò sí.

English: The consumption of sacrificial offerings will not kill the vulture.
Yoruba: Ẹbọ jíjẹ kì í pa igún.

English: A thousand ants cannot lift “a cube of” sugar; they can only mill around it in vain.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀rún eèrà ò lè gbé ṣúgà; wọ́n ó kàn tò yí i ká lásán ni.

English: A thousand fishes will not overload a river.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀rún ẹja ò lè dẹ́rù pa odò.

English: A cat's back never touches the ground.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀yìn ológbò kì í balẹ̀.

English: The lawyer argues other people's cases, much more his own.
Yoruba: Ẹjọ́ ẹlẹ́jọ́, lọ́yà ń rò ó, áḿbọ̀ǹtorí ẹjọ́ araa rẹ̀.

English: An apprehender does not apprehend a masquerader.
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́mùn-ún ò mú eégún.

English: The larkheeled Cuckoo vows that rather than not being delicious in the stew, it will crush its arms and legs in pursuit of that end.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀lúlùú ní kàkà kí òun má dun ọbẹ̀, òun á rúnwọ rúnsẹ̀ sí i.

English: It is the Ẹ̀lukú masquerader without a matchete that is hacked to death by its colleagues.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀lukú tí kò ní èlè lẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ ń ṣá pa.

English: Whoever has a job should not malinger; if Providence smiles on one one can hardly fail.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá ń ṣiṣẹ́ kì í ṣọ̀lẹ; bórí bá túnniṣe a kì í tẹ́ bọ̀rọ̀.

English: Whoever is used to eating full-grown he-goats will eat lambs that have sprouted horns.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá ń jẹ òbúkọ tó gbójú, yó jẹ àgùtàn tó yọ̀wo.

English: The same person who weeds the road to Ìjẹ̀bú without carrying off the weeds will eventually remove them.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá yẹ ọ̀nà Ìjẹ̀bú tì ni yó yẹ̀ ẹ́ tán.

English: The person who takes one's wife cannot stop one's locust bean seeds from fermenting.
Yoruba: Ẹní gbani láya ò ní kírú ẹni má rà.

English: Whoever wishes to eat heartily must lock his door firmly.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa jẹun kunkun a tìlẹ̀kùn kunkun.

English: Whoever wishes to see a crab go to sleep will stay long by its hole.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa rí àtisùn akàn á pẹ́ létí isà.

English: Whoever will eat the honey in a rock does not worry about the edge of the axe.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa jẹ oyin inú àpáta kìí wo ẹnu àáké.

English: Whoever wishes to see ducks go to sleep will go into debt paying for (fuel) oil.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa rí àtisùn-un pẹ́pẹ́yẹ á jẹ gbèsè àdín.

English: Ògún is on the side of the swift.
Yoruba: Ẹní yára lÒgún ń gbè.

English: Whoever is shunned by people should rejoice; whoever is shunned by God should look out.
Yoruba: Ẹni èèyàn ò kí kó yọ̀; ẹni Ọlọ́run ò kí kó ṣọ́ra.

English: Whoever dies from poverty dies a miserable death; whoever dies from work dies a noble death.
Yoruba: Ẹni ọ̀lẹ́ paá re ọ̀run òṣì; ẹni iṣẹ́ paá re ọ̀run ẹ̀yẹ.

English: The person who plants a hundred yam seedlings and says he planted two hundred, after he has eaten a hundred truths, he will come to eat a hundred lies.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gbin ọrún èbù tó pè é nígba, tó bá jẹ ọgọ́rùn-ún òtítọ́ tán, á wá jẹ ọgọ́rùn-ún irọ́.

English: It is for the person who sweeps the floor that the floor is clean.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gbálẹ̀ ni ilẹ̀ ń mọ́ fún.

English: It is the industrious person that wins the spoils.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá ní ìtara ló ní àtètèbá.

English: The person being chased by a masquerader should persevere; just as an earthling tires, so does the being from heaven.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí eégún ń lé kó máa rọ́jú; bó ti ń rẹ ará ayé, bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ń rẹ ará ọ̀run.

English: Whoever dives head first to the ground has made a creditable attempt at suicide.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó forí sọlẹ̀ẹ́ gbìyànjú ikú.

English: A person fed by others is never aware that there is famine.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí à ḿbọ́ ò mọ̀ pé ìyàn-án mú.

English: Whoever leaps up decapitates dance.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó fò sókèé bẹ́ ijó lórí.

English: A person dying from overwork is better than a person dying of destitution.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí iṣẹ́ ń paá yá ju ẹni tí ìṣẹ́ ń pa.

English: Those who arrive late are the ones who find the watery residue of the stew awaiting them.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá pẹ́ lẹ́yìn ni à ń yọ́ omi ọbẹ̀ dè.

English: The man who “claimed to have” killed six people during the Ọla war: people exclaimed in disbelief, “Ha, ha, ha!” He asked them to bring an ayò board, and he won six games. He said, if there were no witnesses for what happened in the secluded forest, aren't there witnesses for what happens in the house?
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó pa mẹ́fà lógun Ọ̀la: wọ́n ní “Háà, hà, háà!” Ó ní kí wọ́n gbé ọpọ́n ayò wá, ó tún pa mẹ́fà; ó ní bí ojú kò tó tẹ̀gi, ojú kò tó tilé?

English: The person digging a grave is the one performing his or her funerary duties; the person crying is merely making a noise.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ń gbẹ́lẹ̀ ní ń sìnkú; ẹni tí ń sunkún ariwo ló ń pa.

English: Only a person who looks at the bride's face knows that the bride is crying.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá wo ojú ìyàwó ní ń mọ̀ pé ìyàwó ń sunkún.

English: Whoever likes fineries should engage in a trade; it is the person blessed by riches that is wise.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ọ̀ṣọ́ bá wù kó ṣòwò; ẹni ajé yalée rẹ̀ ló gbọ́n.

English: Only those whose livelihood depends on Jẹgẹdẹ call him a silk cotton tree.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá ńjẹ lábẹ́ẹ Jẹ́gẹ́dẹ́ ní ńpè é nígi àràbà.

English: Whoever assigns a task to Ìgè Àdùbí assigns it to himself or herself; Ìgè Àdùbí will neither agree to do the task nor will he refuse.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bẹ Ìgè Àdùbí níṣẹ́, araa rẹ̀ ló bẹ̀; Ìgè Àdùbí ò níí jẹ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ni kò níí kọ̀.

English: A person whose greetings do not fill one's stomach cannot cause one to starve by withholding the greetings.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí kíkíi rẹ̀ ò yóni, àìkíi rẹ̀ ò lè pani lébi.

English: It is at one's occupation that one proves oneself an idler.
Yoruba: Ẹnu iṣẹ́ ẹni ni a ti ń mọ ẹni lọ́lẹ.

English: Empty mouths do not make chewing noises.
Yoruba: Ẹnu òfìfo kì í dún yànmù-yànmù.

English: The mouth cooks vegetable stew most expertly; the hand emulating a machete cuts a field most effortlessly.
Yoruba: Ẹnú dùn-ún ròfọ́; agada ọwọ́ dùn-ún ṣánko.

English: The forest knows no fear, and neither does the river know fear; the grind-stone never shows fear in the face of pepper.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù kì í ba igbó, bẹ́ẹ̀ni kì í ba odò; ẹ̀rù kì í ba ọlọ lójú ata.

English: The head is never so frightened that it disappears into the shoulder.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù kì í ba orí kó sá wọnú.

English: Fear of battle never afflicts a warrior.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù ogun kì í ba jagun-jagun.

English: The feet are never so heavy that the owner cannot lift them.
Yoruba: Ẹsẹ̀ kì í wúwo kí ẹlésẹ̀ má lè gbé e.

English: Slowly slowly is the way a snail climbs a tree.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀sọ̀ ẹ̀sọ̀ ni ìgbín fi ń gbà gun igi.

English: One does not refrain from mounting a horse that has thrown one.
Yoruba: Ẹṣin kì í dani kí á má tún gùn ún.

English: A horse does not get loose and stop to free its companion.
Yoruba: Ẹṣin kì í já kó já èkejìi rẹ̀.

English: Disgrace comes upon the shiftless.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀tẹ́ bá ọ̀lẹ.

English: A bird does not tell a bird that a stone is on its way.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹ ò sọ fún ẹyẹ pé òkò ń bọ̀.

English: Leave the hooked stick alone for the leaf plucker; leave the husband alone for the jealous woman.
Yoruba: Fi gọ̀gọ̀ sílẹ̀ fún ọ̀dáwé; fi ọkọ sílẹ̀ fún onílara.

English: It is only because one loves spinach that one calls it a friend of corn loaf; what the dandy has at home is enough food for him or her.
Yoruba: Fífẹ́ la fẹ́ ẹ̀fọ́ tí à ń pèé ní ọ̀rẹ́ ẹ̀kọ ti ilé ogeé tó ogeé jẹ.

English: “Prepare the corn pap and let us eat it together” is an indication that the speaker lacks what it takes to be a husband.
Yoruba: “Fọ́ ẹ̀kọ ká jọ mu ú,” kò tó ọkọlóbìnrin-ín ṣe ni.

English: No carver of mortars can do a thing to the banana stem.
Yoruba: Gbẹ́dó-gbẹ́dó kan ò lè fi ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ṣe nǹkan.

English: Fear of the snake keeps one from stepping on the young of the snake.
Yoruba: Ìbẹ̀rù ejò ò jẹ́ ká tẹ ọmọ ejò mọ́lẹ̀.

English: Every place is hospitable and comfortable for the dove.
Yoruba: Ibi gbogbo ní ń rọ àdàbà lọ́rùn.

English: Every place deserves to be treated with respect and reverence.
Yoruba: Ibi gbogbo nilẹ̀ ọ̀wọ̀.

English: The spot one cautions the gbégbé plant not to inhabit, there it will surely inhabit.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ní kí gbégbé má gbèé, ibẹ̀ ní ń gbé.

English: Wherever one orders wild spinach not to step on, there it will surely trample.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ní kí tẹ̀tẹ̀ má tẹ̀, ibẹ̀ ní ń tẹ̀.

English: How much distance exists between the nose and the mouth? How much distance exists between Làǹlátẹ̀ and Èrúwà?
Yoruba: Ibo ni imú wà sẹnu? Ibo ni Làǹlátẹ̀ẹ́ wà sí Èrúwà?

English: The sword never departs without returning.
Yoruba: Idà kì í lọ kídà má bọ̀.

English: Ease has nothing to do with age.
Yoruba: Ìdẹra ò kan àgbà.

English: A tree does not snap in the forest and kill a person at home.
Yoruba: Igi kì í dá lóko kó pa ará ilé.

English: The vulture rushes at the chicken, but it cannot carry it off.
Yoruba: Igúnnugún pa guuru mádìẹ; kò leè gbe.

English: Two hundred flies will not lie in ambush for a broom.
Yoruba: Igba eṣinṣin kì í dènà de ọwọ̀.

English: Two hundred animals will not lie in ambush for a leopard.
Yoruba: Igba ẹranko kì í dènà de ẹkùn.

English: Is it just morning now? The old man is striving to make two hundred heaps a day.
Yoruba: Ìgbà yí làárọ̀? Arúgbó ń kọgba.

English: Is it just morning now? The old person is grooming himself/herself.
Yoruba: Ìgbà yí làárọ̀? Arúgbó ń ṣoge.

English: The strategy one adopts in acquiring a wife will not do with regard to money.
Yoruba: Ìgbé a gbé ìyàwó kò ṣéé gbé owó.

English: The cry “What shall I eat for supper?” is what kills the lazy person.
Yoruba: Igbe kí-ni-ngó-jẹ-sùn ní ḿpọ̀lẹ.

English: The snail will not fasten unto a tree and fail to climb it.
Yoruba: Ìgbín kì í tẹnu mọ́gi kó má gùn ún.

English: The snail rejects the fate of being swallowed by a snake.
Yoruba: Ìgbín kọ mímì ejò.

English: Fighting knows not who is the elder; it makes a hero of the younger.
Yoruba: Ìjà ò mọ ẹ̀gbọ́n, ó sọ àbúrò dakin.

English: Competition and reward are the inducements for a child to work hard.
Yoruba: Ìje òun oore ní ń mú ọmọ ṣiṣẹ́.

English: The Ìjèṣà (person) does not need matches; it is from the home that the scion of Ọwa takes burning faggots to the farm.
Yoruba: Ìjèṣà ò nídìi ìṣáná; ilé lọmọ Ọwá ti ń fọnná lọ sóko.

English: Careless eating does not kill the worm ahanrandi.
Yoruba: Ìjẹkújẹ kì í pa ahanrandi.

English: The termite can have no adverse effect on a wall.
Yoruba: Ikán ò lè rí ṣe lára ìgànná.

English: The pot that wishes to eat pepper (stew) will first endure a scalded bottom.
Yoruba: Ìkòkò tí yó jẹ ata, ìdí ẹ̀ á gbóná.

English: A snare never catches a snake in the leg.
Yoruba: Ìkọ́ kì í kọ́ ejò lẹ́sẹ̀.

English: It is the messenger who does not know how to deliver a message properly that delivers it seven times over.
Yoruba: Ikọ̀ tí ò mọ iṣẹ́ẹ́ jẹ́ ní ń jẹ́ ẹ lẹ́ẹ̀mejèe.

English: The okro plant is never so much taller than the harvester that he/she cannot bend it to harvest.
Yoruba: Ilá kì í ga ju akórè lọ kó má tẹ̀ ẹ́ ká.

English: A house one is in a position to burn, one does not conceal the torch to set it ablaze.
Yoruba: Ilé tí a tóó kun, a kì í bo ìtùfùu rẹ̀.

English: A house one has the right to sleep in during the day, one does not wait for the cover of night to go sleep in it.
Yoruba: Ilé tí a tó lọ sùn lọ́sàn-án, a kì í tó òru lọ sùn ún.

English: The chicken's boasts are unavailing before the kite.
Yoruba: Ìlérí adìẹ, asán ni lójú àwòdì.

English: Beads remain on the display tray and from there attract the admiration of the feckless person.
Yoruba: Ìlẹ̀kẹ̀ẹ́ gbé orí àtẹ wu ọ̀lẹ.

English: Frogs' eggs do not attract the attention of the thief.
Yoruba: Ìlẹ̀kẹ̀ ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ ò yí olè lójú.

English: The Ilorin person has no god;; his/her mouth is his/her god.
Yoruba: Ìlọrin ò lóòṣà; ẹnu lòòṣà Ìlọrin.

English: Firefly with its rear ablaze; the firefly has never kindled a fire, but it carries fire with it wherever it goes.
Yoruba: Ìmúmúnàá abìdí sembé-sembé; ìmúmúnàá ò dáná rí, tiná-tiná ní ḿbá kiri.

English: Fire does not rage and cause a wall to flee.
Yoruba: Iná kì í jó kí ògiri sá.

English: A fire does not rage and enter the home of the crab.
Yoruba: Iná kì í jó kó wọlé akàn.

English: Our attempt to kill the oṣè tree only makes it fatter.
Yoruba: Ìpa à ń poṣè ara ló fi ńsan.

English: The sap of the violet tree is what the bachelor uses for soap.
Yoruba: Ìpẹ̀ta lọṣẹ àpọ́n.

English: The beginning of wealth is chock-full of filth.
Yoruba: Ìpilẹ̀ ọrọ̀ọ́ lẹ́gbin.

English: A farmer's suffering will not last longer than a year.
Yoruba: Ìpọ́njú àgbẹ̀ ò ju ọdún kan.

English: A child's learning of Ifá is full of privations, but the outcome is a life of ease.
Yoruba: Ìpọ́njú lọmọdé fi ń kọ́Fá, ìgbẹ̀yìn-in rẹ̀ a dẹni.

English: The good my hand cannot reach, I will pull down with a hooked stick.
Yoruba: Ire tí ọwọ́ọ̀ mi ò tó, ma fi gọ̀ǹgọ̀ fà á.

English: The sugar-cane came with its sweetness from heaven.
Yoruba: Ìrèké ti ládùn látọ̀run.

English: Evil sights do not make the eyes go blind.
Yoruba: Ìríkúrìí kì í fọ́ ojú.

English: Four hundred buffaloes with eight hundred horns, twenty Fulbe men and forty shoes; Ògídíolú did not look back until he had chased Adalo into the bush.
Yoruba: Irínwó ẹfọ̀n, ẹgbẹ̀rin ìwo, ogún-un Fúlàní, ójìi bàtà; Ògídíolú ò wẹ̀yìn tó fi lé Adalo lùgbẹ́.

English: Shirking work “is the” father of laziness.
Yoruba: Ìròjú baba ọ̀lẹ.

English: An ìrókò stick with sixteen edges is nothing for an elephant to swallow, much less the melon fruit with a smooth body.
Yoruba: Ìrókò o-nígun-mẹ́rìn-dín-lógún ò tó erin-ín gbémì, áḿbọ̀ǹtorí ìtóò a-lara-boro-boro.

English: Worrying about the wolf is what will kill the dog.
Yoruba: Ìrònú ìkokò ní yó pa ajá.

English: Perseverance is everything; one gets tired daily.
Yoruba: Ìrọ́jú ni ohun gbogbo; ojoojúmọ́ ní ń rẹni.

English: The dregs of wealth is filthy.
Yoruba: Ìsàlẹ̀ ọrọ̀ọ́ lẹ́gbin.

English: Nine days wash the face, thirteen days wash the feet.
Yoruba: Isán ń bọ́jú, ìtàlá ń wẹsẹ̀.

English: Gainful employment is tough, as tough as a supple pole.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ajé le, ó tó ọpa.

English: Destitution is not something to treat with levity; misery is nothing to joke about.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ́ kì í ṣe ohun àmúṣeré; ìyà kì í ṣe ohun àmúṣàwàdà.

English: Work is the antidote for destitution.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ loògùn ìṣẹ́.

English: Destitution grips you and you sit scowling; who will give you the antidote?
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ́ ń ṣẹ́ ọ ò ń rojú; ta ni yó fùn-ún ọ ni oògùn-un rẹ̀?

English: Destitution proposes to trade its services for money; suffering proposes to pawn itself for money; wretchedness proposes to stand surety for them; which of them has anything going for it?
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ́ ní òun ó kòówó; ìyàá ní òun ó singbà; réderèdeé ní òun ó ṣe onígbọ̀wọ́; ta ní jẹ́ rere nínúu wọn?

English: Destitution does not yield to tears; hunger has a claim on the shiftless.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ́ ò gbẹ́kún, ebí jàre ọ̀lẹ.

English: The lazy person knows how to do only things that call for little effort; he/she never seeks out work that demands strength.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ọ̀gẹrọ̀ lọ̀lẹ́ mọ̀ọ́ ṣe; kò jẹ́ wá iṣẹ́ agbára.

English: The poverty that has plagued a child for twenty years, the suffering that has been the fate of a child for thirty months, if it does not kill the child it should leave the child in peace.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ́ tó ṣẹ́ ọmọ lógún ọdún, ìyà tó jẹ ọmọ lọ́gbọ̀n oṣù, bí kò pa ọmọ, a sì lẹ́yìn ọmọ.

English: Gainful-work-does-not-keep-to-the-shade; his/her child is named First-up-at-dawn.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́-ajé-ò-gbé-bòji, ọmọ ẹ̀ Òjíkùtù.

English: The yam one does not stop speaking about will not get burnt; the corn-meal one speaks constantly about does not become too well-done; a chicken that is the subject of constant caution does not get snatched up by a hawk.
Yoruba: Iṣu àtẹnumọ́ kì í jóná; ọ̀kà àtẹnumọ́ kì í mẹrẹ; àwòdì kì í gbé adìẹ à-tẹnu-kunkun-mọ́.

English: One's yam will not because one is only a youth refuse to grow to maturity.
Yoruba: Iṣu ẹni kì í fini pe ọmọdé kó má ta.

English: The yam is in your hand, and the knife is in your hand.
Yoruba: Iṣú wà lọ́wọ́ ẹ; ọ̀bẹ́ wà lọ́wọ́ ẹ.

English: The lazy person's character fills him/her with fear; the lazy person loses all and complains that the world hates him/her.
Yoruba: Ìwà ọ̀lẹ ń ba ọ̀lẹ lẹ́rù; ọ̀lẹ́ pàdánù, ó ní aráyé ò fẹ́ràn òun.

English: “By this time last year my father's water-yam had grown huge”; that is nothing good to reminisce about.
Yoruba: Ìwòyí èṣí ewùràa babaà mí ti ta; ìrègún rere ò sí níbẹ̀.

English: The malaise that afflicts the lazy person is not trifling; one-who-has-arms-that-will-not-work.
Yoruba: Ìyà tó ń jẹ ọ̀lẹ ò kéré; a-lápá-má-ṣiṣẹ́.

English: One simply makes an effort; if one does not make an effort one seems like a shiftless person; one copes with weariness daily.
Yoruba: Ìyànjú là ń gbà; bí a ò gbìyànjú bí ọ̀lẹ là ń rí; ojoojúmọ́ ní ń rẹni.

English: Nimble hands and nimble feet make it possible for a dog to kill a rabbit; the leopard attacks its prey with lightning speed.
Yoruba: Ìyáwọ́, ìyásẹ̀ lajá fi ń pa ehoro; wàrà-wàrà lẹkùn ń gùn.

English: Loading the body down with charms has no effect in a war; war kills even the person carrying fourteen hundred juju gourdlets.
Yoruba: Jagajìgì ò mọ ogun; ogun ń pa elégbèje àdó.

English: Rather than die, the earth will only become bare.
Yoruba: Kàkà kí ilẹ̀ kú, ṣíṣá ni yó ṣàá.

English: When a duty comes to one's turn one does not duck it.
Yoruba: Kì í kan ẹni ká yẹrí.

English: If we go to the river and sleep there, what will the people left at home drink?
Yoruba: Kí a re odò ká sùn; kí ni ará ilé yó mu?

English: Hiding the hoe in the loft and contriving to shirk work; the shin ate its fill and developed a stomach at its back.
Yoruba: Kí á gbé ọkọ́ so sájà ká pète ìmẹ́lẹ́; ojúgun-ún yó tán ó fikùn sẹ́yìn.

English: To be sent on an errand is nothing compared to knowing how to carry it out.
Yoruba: Kí á ránni níṣẹ́ ò tó ká mọ̀ ọ́ jẹ́.

English: Before the child was born, one had someone as a playmate.
Yoruba: Kí á tó bí ọmọdé, ẹnìkan là ń bá ṣeré.

English: Long before the arrival of masqueraders the Alágbaà had been eating corn-meal with steamed bean loaves.
Yoruba: Kí eégún tó dé lAlágbaàá ti ń fọ̀lẹ̀lẹ̀ jẹ̀kọ.

English: The porcupine may tire, but never the quills at its rear.
Yoruba: Kì í rẹ òòrẹ̀ kó rẹ sinsin ìdí ẹ̀.

English: The calabash of camwood is never so empty that one does not find enough in it to rub on a baby.
Yoruba: Kì í tán nígbá osùn ká má rìí fi pa ọmọ lára.

English: What was the masquerader looking at that he did not take advantage of the morning to dance?
Yoruba: Kí ni eégún ń wò tí kò fi òwúrọ̀ jó?

English: What is there in the grave to frighten a corpse?
Yoruba: Kí ní ń bẹ nínú isà tí yó ba òkú lẹ́rù?

English: What will a nestling do for its mother other than becoming mature and flying away?
Yoruba: Kí ni ọmọ ẹyẹ ó ṣe fún ìyá ẹ̀ ju pé kó dàgbà kó fò lọ?

English: Long before the white man came we were wearing clothes.
Yoruba: Kí òyìnbó tó dé la ti ń wọ aṣọ.

English: When the dog dies I will not lick the stew made with it; alive I will not send it on an errand.
Yoruba: Kíkú ajá, n kò ní omitooro ẹ̀ẹ́ lá; àìkú ẹ̀ n kò ní pè é rán níṣẹ́.

English: A lion does not face peril from a leopard.
Yoruba: Kìnnìún ò níí ṣàgbákò ẹkùn.

English: It fears not death: the pigeon that forages among hawks.
Yoruba: Kò ka ikú: àdàbà sùú-sùú tí ń jẹ̀ láàrin àṣá.

English: There is no butcher who slaughters the vulture for sale.
Yoruba: Kò sí alápatà tí ń pa igún.

English: No matter how knotty the bush might be, the elephant will find a way through it.
Yoruba: Kò sí bí igbó ṣe lè ta kókó tó, erin óò kọjá.

English: There is no profit in “Take this money and count it “for me”.”
Yoruba: Kò sí èrè nínúu “Gba owó kà.”

English: There is no danger on the farm except for the sudden noise of partridges taking to the air.
Yoruba: Kò sí ewu lóko, àfi gìrì àparò.

English: There is no one to whom God has not been generous, only those who will say he has not been generous enough.
Yoruba: Kò sí ẹni tí Ọlọ́run ò ṣe fún, àfi ẹni tó bá ní tòun ò tó.

English: There is no place where a fool is not welcome; the world rejects only shiftless people.
Yoruba: Kò sí ibi tí kò gba ọ̀gọ̀; ọ̀lẹ layé ò gbà.

English: There is no place an elephant's trunk cannot reach.
Yoruba: Kò sí ibi tí ọwọ́-ọ̀jà erin ò tó.

English: There is no manner of death that is inconvenient for the chicken.
Yoruba: Kò sí ikú tí kò rọ adìẹ lọ́rùn.

English: There is nothing dropping from above that the earth cannot withstand.
Yoruba: Kò sí ohun tí ń ti òkè bọ̀ tí ilẹ̀ ò gbà.

English: There is no food that nourishes one's body like that one puts in one's own mouth.
Yoruba: Kò sí oúnjẹ tí ń mú ara lókun bí èyí tí a jẹ sẹ́nu ẹni lọ.

English: “May it crash! May it crash!” The silk-cotton tree does not crash; the ìrókò tree is shamed.
Yoruba: Kó wó, kó wó, àràbà ò wó; ojú tìrókò.

English: The sieve says despite all that has been done to it it still manages to sift yam-flour.
Yoruba: Kọ̀ǹkọ̀ṣọ̀ọ́ ní bí a ti ṣe òun tó yìí, òún ṣì ń ku èlùbọ́.

English: Early dawn does not wake one twice; early dawn is the morning; deep darkness is night.
Yoruba: Kùtù-kùtù kì í jíni lẹ́ẹ̀mejì; kùtù-kùtù ní ń jẹ́ òwúrọ̀; biri ní ń jẹ́ alẹ́.

English: The labẹ́labẹ́  plant did not come to the river looking for a fight; the crow did not come to the farm in search of corn gruel.
Yoruba: Labẹ́-labẹ́ ò bá tìjà wá odò; kanna-kánná ò bá ti ẹ̀kọ wá oko.

English: The labẹ́labẹ́ plant is not afraid of a fight.
Yoruba: Labẹ́-labẹ́ ò bẹ̀rù ìjà.

English: The cattle egret borrows wonders to perform, and performs enough for itself and others.
Yoruba: Lékèélékèé gbàràdá, ó gba tẹlòmíràn mọ.

English: It is directly in the eyes that one looks at the subject of the praise poem one is performing.
Yoruba: Lójú-lójú là ń wo ẹni tí a óò kéwì fún.

English: Place not your hopes in inheritance; the product of one's hand labor is what sustains one.
Yoruba: Máà gbíyè lógún; ti ọwọ́ ẹni ní ń tóni.

English: “Pass me not by, dear Redeemer” is not a song one sings on one's knees.
Yoruba: “Má kọjá mi Olùgbàlà” kì í ṣe orin à-kúnlẹ̀-kọ.

English: Palm fronds do not consult with one another before they sprout.
Yoruba: Màrìwò ò wí fúnra wọn tẹ́lẹ̀ tí wọ́n fi ń yọ.

English: Palm fronds look up to no one except God.
Yoruba: Màrìwò ò wojú ẹnìkan, àfi Ọlọ́run.

English: I have become an aged hunter reduced to gathering mushrooms; I have become an old hunter good only for digging palm-weevils; I have become an aged monkey that snatches the gun from the hunter's grip.
Yoruba: Mo di arúgbó ọdẹ tí ńtu olú, mo di àgbàlagbà ọdẹ tí ń wa ògòǹgò láàtàn; mo di ògbólógbòó akítì tí ń gba ìbọn lọ́wọ́ ọdẹ.

English: “I have perished!” is the cry of the hare in the bush; “I have destroyed things worth a lot of money!” is the cry of the partridge in the guinea-corn field.
Yoruba: “Mo kúgbé” lehoro ń dún lóko; “Mo mówó rá” làparò ń dún lábà-a bàbà.

English: “I have completed the job” is what deserves praise; one does not thank people who leave a job only half done.
Yoruba: “Mo ṣe é tán” ló níyì; a kì í dúpẹ́ aláṣekù.

English: High potency upon high potency: the okro that lacks high potency cannot fruit; the bitter tomato that lacks high potency cannot achieve the blood-red complexion.
Yoruba: Múlele múlèle: ilá tí ò mú lele ò léè so; ikàn tí ò mú lele ò léè wẹ̀wù ẹ̀jẹ̀.

English: “I will leave you, I will leave you!” is the threat a woman flings at a man; “If you have a mind to leave, go ahead and leave!” is the retort a man throws at a woman.
Yoruba: “N ó lọ, ng ó lọ!” lobìnrín fi ń dẹ́rù ba ọkùnriń “Bóo lè lọ o lọ” lọkùnrín fi ń dẹ́rù ba obìnrin.

English: In the midst of thorns, in the midst of crooked twigs, the ayò seeds remain smooth.
Yoruba: Ní inú ẹ̀gún, ní inúu gọ̀gọ̀, ọmọ ayò a ṣara bòró.

English: Despite being blown hither and tither in the gale, the fruits of the sausage tree survive to maturity.
Yoruba: Ní inú òfíì àti ọ̀láà, ọmọ páńdọ̀rọ̀ ń gbó.

English: It is out of one's stock of cotton that one takes some for makeweight.
Yoruba: Ní inú òwú la ti ń bù ṣènì òwú.

English: It is on the day of festivities that the lazy person is miserable; instead of going inside his room and emerging again “in other words, fetching gifts for the revelers” he leans his arms against a tree and hisses incessantly.
Yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ eré nìyà ń dun ọ̀lẹ; kàkà kó wọlé kó jáde a fọwọ́ rọ igi, a pòṣé ṣàrà.

English: Erratically, with almost imperceptible forward movement, just so Ṣàngó danced until he was at the market.
Yoruba: Ní teere, ní tèèrè, Ṣàngó ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ ó jó wọjà.

English: One may be diminutive, and one may be bald, but without debt one has not earned ridicule; only one's creditor has grounds to make fun of one.
Yoruba: Ò báà kúrú, ò báà párí, gbèsè ò sí, ẹ̀sín ò sí; onígbèsè ló lè fini ṣẹ̀sín.

English: It is only on the day when the mother's bean fritters do not sell that one knows which child can consume large quantities of corn-meal.
Yoruba: Ó di ọjọ́ tí àkàrà ìyá kùtà ká tó mọ ọmọ tó lè jẹ̀kọ.

English: On hearing about pounded yam he girded himself with cooked melon seeds for stew seasoning; on hearing about farm work he threw his cutlass away.
Yoruba: Ó gbọ́ tiyán sògìrì mọ́dìí; o gbọ́ toko sọ àdá nù.

English: You do not ride a horse by day, you do not ride people by night, and you do not make great exertions to achieve any goal; how could you have a say in saving the world from disaster?
Yoruba: O kò gun ẹṣin lọ́sàn-án, o ò gun èèyàn lóru, o ò du nǹkan kàrà-kàrà; báwo lo ṣe lè ní káyé má fọ̀ọ́?

English: You did not slash the trunk with a cutlass, you did not shoot an arrow at the top of the palm-wine producing palm-tree, you come to the foot of the palm-tree and you raise your open mouth; does it drip all by itself?
Yoruba: O kò ṣá igi lọ́gbẹ́, o ò sọ ògùrọ̀ lọ́fà, o dédìí ọ̀pẹ o gbẹ́nu sókè ò ń retí; ọ̀fẹ́ ní ńro?

English: “I was just on the verge of speaking my mind”: it only makes one into a coward.
Yoruba: “Ó kù díẹ̀ kí n wí”: ojo ní ń ssọni da.

English: It goes some way “in assuaging hunger”, saliva swallowing during a fast.
Yoruba: Ó ní ibi tí ó ń dé, itọ́-dídámì nínú ààwẹ̀.

English: You pray to live as long as Olúàṣo, but can you endure the trials of Olúàṣo?
Yoruba: O ní kí o gbó ogbó Olúàṣo; o lè jìyà bí Olúàṣo?

English: He split the kolanut pod open and also removed the bad among the seeds.
Yoruba: Ó pa obì, ó yọ abidún-un rẹ̀.

English: A woman who would marry a formidable man must have an unwavering mind.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tí yó fẹ̀ẹ́ alágbára, ọkàn kan ní ń mú.

English: A slender woman is the joy of her husband on a day of dancing, but a hefty woman is her husband's joy on the day of yams quartered for planting; after she has totted a hundred yam pieces, she walks smartly “towards the farm” ahead of her husband.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tẹ́ẹ́rẹ́ yẹ ọkọ ẹ̀ níjọ́ ijó, obìnrin gìdìgbà-á yẹ ọkọ ẹ̀ níjọ́ èbù; bó bá ru ọgọ́rùnún èbù tán a kó kébé-kébé níwájú ọkọ.

English: A person's ugliness is the god's doing; the person's lack of clothing is his/her own fault.
Yoruba: Òbúrẹ́wà ẹni, tòrìṣà ni; àìraṣọlò, tolúwarẹ̀ ni.

English: The parrot never dies in the grazing field.
Yoruba: Odídẹrẹ́ kì í kú sóko ìwájẹ.

English: A river does not so swell as to be over the head of the fish.
Yoruba: Odò kì í kún bo ẹja lójú.

English: A river whose source one knows does not carry one away.
Yoruba: Odò tí a bá mọ orísun ẹ̀ kì í gbéni lọ.

English: A river that swells in one's presence does not carry one away.
Yoruba: Odó tó bá tojú ẹni kún kì í gbéni lọ.

English: A magical charm does not work from within its gourdlet.
Yoruba: Oògùn kì í gbé inú àdó jẹ́.

English: War does not rage and destroy the home of the Asẹ́yìn.
Yoruba: Ogun kì í jà kó wọlé Asẹ́yín.

English: An army does not see the rear of an(other) army.
Yoruba: Ogun kì í rí ẹ̀yìn ogun.

English: In all the twenty years that the cameleon has been in the throes of hunger, its dignified gait has not deserted it.
Yoruba: Ogún ọdún tí ebí ti ń pa ọ̀gà, ìrìn-in fàájì ò padà lẹ́sẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀.

English: It is a mighty net that can trip the civet-cat.
Yoruba: Ògbógbó àwọ̀n ní ń bi ajáko.

English: The chicken had something to eat before there was corn.
Yoruba: Ohun kan ladìẹ ń jẹ kágbàdo tó dé.

English: What one plants is what one reaps.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a bá gbìn la ó kàá.

English: Whatever one sows behind one is what one will return to find.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a bá gbìn sẹ́yìn la ó padà bá.

English: Whatever one hands to a warrior to look after is what he looks after.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a fún ẹ̀ṣọ́ ṣọ́ ni ẹ̀ṣọ́ ń ṣọ́.

English: Whatever sent the brown monkey climbing to the top of the thorny acacia tree: unless it sees something even more terrifying it will not climb down.
Yoruba: Ohun tó ṣe ìjímèrè tó fi gungi ẹ̀gẹ̀: bí kò bá rí ohun tó jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ kò ní sọ̀kalẹ̀.

English: Whatever caused the pawned worker to stay away from the creditor's farm, when the two come face to face he will have some explaining to do.
Yoruba: Ohun tó ṣe ìwọ̀fà tí kò fi wá sóko olówó, bójú bá kan ojú yó sọ fún olówóo rẹ̀.

English: The annual egúngún festival is not endless.
Yoruba: Ohun títán lọdún eégún.

English: The shadow has no fear of the gully.
Yoruba: Òjìji ò bẹ̀rù ọ̀fìn.

English: The shadow lacks substance but it never crashes.
Yoruba: Òjìji; ṣe lẹ́gẹ́-lẹ́gẹ́ má wòó.

English: Were it to rain, what would the leper have planted? A leper's palm cannot scoop ten grains of corn.
Yoruba: Òjò ìbá rọ̀, kí ladẹ́tẹ̀ ìbá gbìn? Ọwọ́ adẹ́tẹ̀ ò ká ẹyọ àgbàdo mẹ́wàá.

English: The rain may beat me, and the rain may beat my statue; the rain cannot wash away my good looks.
Yoruba: Òjò pamí, òjò pa èreè mi; òjò ò pa ẹwà araà mi dànù.

English: The rain provides water for the lazy person; but it does not fetch firewood for the lazy person.
Yoruba: Òjò-ó pọnmi fún ọ̀lẹ, kò ṣẹ́gi fún ọ̀lẹ.

English: Rain beats the man carrying pounded yams wrapped in leaves, the pounded yams become water-logged; the wife awaits the pounded yams, the husband sleeps on the farm.
Yoruba: Òjòó pa alágùnúndì, àgúndìí domi; ìyàwó ń retí àgúndì, ọkọ́ sùn sóko.

English: Òjó is victimized without recourse; a bully insults him, he goes to hide in the rafters, and his nemesis follows him there.
Yoruba: Òjó jìyà gbé; alágbáraá bú u, ó gun àjà; a tọ̀ ọ́.

English: Rain beats the parrot and the touraco rejoices, thinking that the parrot's tail feather is ruined; the rain only makes the tail feather brighter.
Yoruba: Òjòó pa odídẹ àlùkò ń yọ̀, àlùkòó rò pé ìkó bàjẹ́; òjó mú ìkó wọṣọ.

English: A lazy person's illness is not soon over; the lazy person finds no way out and prepares a fire to warm his head.
Yoruba: Òjòjò ọ̀lẹ ò tán bọ̀rọ̀; ọ̀lẹ́ bà á tì ó dáná orí.

English: The detractor's eyes glow red, but they cannot light a lamp.
Yoruba: Ojú abanijẹ́ pọ́n, kò lè tan fìtílà.

English: “The look on my parent-in-law's face is baleful”; the worst he/she can do is take his/her daughter back.
Yoruba: “Ojú ànaà mi ò sunwọ̀n”; kò ju kó gba ọmọ ẹ̀ lọ.

English: The Akee apple is never so blighted that one does not find a seed in it.
Yoruba: Ojú kì í pọ́n iṣin ká má bàá wóró nínú ẹ̀.

English: The Akee apple is never so blighted that it does not eventually split open.
Yoruba: Ojú kì í pọ́n iṣin kó má là.

English: One only tries one's best; heroic deeds do not come easy.
Yoruba: Ojú là ń rọ́; ògó ṣòroó ṣe.

English: The crab watches after its head with its eyes.
Yoruba: Ojú lakàn-án fi ń ṣọ́ orí.

English: Ten eyes are not like one's own.
Yoruba: Ojú mẹ́wàá kò jọ ojú ẹni.

English: “We might see each other again” who sells his dog for twenty cowries and spent the money on pounded yams to eat.
Yoruba: “Ojú ò fẹ́rakù” tí ń ta ajá ẹ lókòó; ó fowó ṣíyán jẹ.

English: Other people's eyes will not look after matters for one.
Yoruba: Ojú olójú kì í gba ọ̀ràn fúnni wò.

English: Other people's eyes are nothing like one's owń minders of other people's business are few.
Yoruba: Ojú olójú ò jọ ojú ẹni; a-ṣọ́ràn-deni ò wọ́pọ̀.

English: The eyes go red but do not go blind; the banana goes brilliant yellow but does not rot; a problem rattles one to one's foundations and lets one go; a problem that rattles one will not kill one.
Yoruba: Ojú pọ́n koko má fọ̀ọ́; ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ pọ́n koko má rọ̀; ọ̀rán fini dùgbẹ̀-dùgbẹ̀ yunni nù; ọ̀ràn tí ń finni ò leè pani.

English: The eye looks on a filthy sight and does not go blind: “like” one who sustains a succession of sufferings without wasting away.
Yoruba: Ojú rẹ́gbin kò fọ́: a-jọ̀pọ̀-ìyà-má-rù.

English: The lump that attacks the head is shamed, the boil is shamed, and the hardened tissue on the buttocks is shames also.
Yoruba: Ojú ti kókó, ojú ti eéwo; ojú ti aáràgbá ìdí pẹ̀lú.

English: The suffering that the babaláwo is experiencing is not something that leads to death; the hard times that the babaláwo is going through is one that leads to riches; the vicissitudes that now befall the babaláwo are ones that leave room for taking a bite of kola-nut.
Yoruba: Ojú tí ń pọ́n awo àpọ́nkú kọ́; ìyà tí ń jẹ awo àjẹlà; ìṣẹ́ tí ń ṣẹ́ awo à-ṣẹ́-ṣẹ́-obì-jẹ ni.

English: The eyes that have seen gbẹ̀lẹ̀dẹ́ have seen the ultimate in sights.
Yoruba: Ojú tó ti rí gbẹ̀lẹ̀dẹ́ ti rópin ìran.

English: The eyes that have seen the ocean will not tremble at the sight of the lagoon.
Yoruba: Ojú tó ti rókun ò ní rọ́sà kó bẹ̀rù.

English: Never a day dawns that the hand does not make a trip to the mouth.
Yoruba: Ojúmọ́ kì í mọ́ kí ọwọ́ má yùn-ún ẹnu.

English: The water lettuce always winds up on the surface of the water; the water-lily always wings up on the surface of the stream.
Yoruba: Ojúoró ní ń lékè omi; òṣíbàtà ní ń lékè odò.

English: It is from aloft that the bird sounds off.
Yoruba: Òkè lẹyẹ ń fọhùn.

English: One cannot be bedeviled by two hills; if one ascends a hill, one descends a hill.
Yoruba: Òkè méjì kì í bínú ẹni; bí a bá gun ọ̀kan, à sì máa rọ ọ̀kan.

English: The giant bush rat turns its back at the place where he has a quarrel; after getting to the market it clamps its hands on its head.
Yoruba: Òkété fìjà sẹ́yìn; ó dọ́jà tán ó káwọ́ lérí.

English: A dog's howling will not kill the moon.
Yoruba: Òkìkí ajá kì í pa oṣù.

English: Being widely reputed does not kill the moon; being noised about does not kill the vulture; wherever you please, make a noise about me.
Yoruba: Òkìkí ò poṣù; ariwo ò pagún; ibi ẹ rí ẹ kíbòsíì mi lọ.

English: The chicken is good at cultivating only the soil close by the home.
Yoruba: Oko etílé ladìẹ́ lè ro.

English: Stone, hit a tree, stone retrace your steps and return to whence you came.
Yoruba: Òkò kan igi; òkò padà sẹ́yìn kí o rebi o ti wá.

English: The corpse does not know the cost of the shroud.
Yoruba: Òkú ò moye à ń ràgọ̀.

English: A three-year-old corpse of is no longer a newcomer to the grave.
Yoruba: Òkú ọdún mẹ́ta kúrò ní àlejò sàréè.

English: A lazy person's corpse does not merit a coffin.
Yoruba: Òkú ọ̀lẹ ò ní pósí.

English: The owner of the eyes will not neglect them and watch foreign matter lodge in them.
Yoruba: Olójú kì í fojú ẹ̀ sílẹ̀ kí tàlùbọ́ kó wọ̀ ọ́.

English: The rich person will not give his/her money to a poor person to spend.
Yoruba: Olówó kì í fi owó ẹ̀ fún abòṣì ná.

English: The rich person is an expert at trading.
Yoruba: Olówó mọ òwò.

English: The Olúmọ of the Ègbá territory is impossible to carry.
Yoruba: Olúmọ Ẹ̀gbá ò ṣéé gbé.

English: A stagnant pool cannot carry off a cow.
Yoruba: Omi adágún ò lè gbé màlúù lọ.

English: It is the water that is spilled; the water gourd is not broken.
Yoruba: Omi ló dànù, agbè ò fọ́.

English: There is water in the long-necked calabash.
Yoruba: Omi ń bẹ látọ́.

English: The water from a new spring will not cover a gourd to the top.
Yoruba: Omi ṣẹ́lẹ̀rú ò mu akèrègbè.

English: Water drags the sand about, and yet water lacks hands and lacks legs.
Yoruba: Omí wọ́ yanrìn gbẹrẹrẹ, bẹ́ẹ̀ni omi ò lọ́wọ́, omi ò lẹ́sẹ̀.

English: “It will all end some time today”: a lazy person's motto in a fight.
Yoruba: “Oní ló ń mọ,” ìjà ọ̀lẹ.

English: Today, “I am leaving”; tomorrow, “I am leaving,” prevents the sorjourner from planting awùsá.
Yoruba: Òní, “Mò ń lọ”; ọ̀la, “Mò ń lọ,” kò jẹ́ kí àlejò gbin awùsá.

English: Today, a communal project; tomorrow group work on a somebody's farm; other people's work prevents one from doing one's own.
Yoruba: Òní ọ̀wẹ̀, ọ̀la àáró; iṣẹ́ oníṣẹ́ ò jẹ́ ká ráàyè ṣe tẹni.

English: Detractors of others have no pestles; their mouths are their pestles.
Yoruba: Oníbàjẹ́ ò lódó; ẹnu gbogbo lodóo wọn.

English: It is he who has copper ornaments who must procure oranges; whoever has brass ornaments must procure the herb awẹdẹ.
Yoruba: Oníbànà ní ń tọ́jú òroǹbó; onídẹ ní ń tọ́jú awẹdẹ.

English: The habitual debtor is already dead; except that he ha not yet been buried.
Yoruba: Onígbèsè èèyàn-án ti kú; a ò tíì sìnkú ẹ̀ ni.

English: The Ṣàngó worshipper knows not whose ground corn he is spilling.
Yoruba: OníṢàngó ò mẹni tí òún ń wà lóògì dànù.

English: The owner of a habit will not go on a journey and leave his habit at home; when he goes he takes his habit along with him.
Yoruba: Oníṣe kì í fiṣe ẹ̀ sílẹ̀ re ibi; ó ń re àjò ó mú iṣe ẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ gírígírí.

English: The person who does the trading is in the sun; the person who spends the money is in the shade.
Yoruba: Oníṣòwó wà lóòrùn; náwónáwó wà níbòji.

English: The owner of the yams makes yam pottage out of the yams; the person who eats the yam scrapings off the peels is shamed.
Yoruba: Oníṣú fiṣu ẹ se ẹ̀bẹ; ojú ti atèèpojẹ.

English: The head that wears a cloth cap strives to wear a velvet cap; the one that wears a velvet cap strives to become a king.
Yoruba: Orí adẹ́tù ń pète àrán; orí adáràn-án ń pète àtijọba.

English: It is while at work that a clock dies.
Yoruba: Orí iṣẹ́ laago ń kú lé.

English: A head is never so heavy that the owner cannot carry it.
Yoruba: Orí kì í tóbi kólórí má lè gbé e.

English: A huge head does not go completely bald.
Yoruba: Orí ń lá kì í pá tán.

English: Other people's heads will not carry one's load for one.
Yoruba: Orí olórí kì í báni gbẹ́rù.

English: There is no god that comes to the aid of shiftless people; only one's arms aid one.
Yoruba: Òrìṣà tí ń gbọ̀lẹ ò sí; apá ẹni ní ń gbeni.

English: A crossroads where three roads meet is not afraid of sacrificial offerings.
Yoruba: Oríta mẹ́ta ò kọnnú ẹbọ.

English: Night time is a farmer's time to stretch the back.
Yoruba: Òru ni ìnàyìn àgbẹ̀.

English: The sun has not risen directly above the head; working hands cannot cease their toil.
Yoruba: Oòrùn ò kan àtàrí, ọwọ́ ò dá.

English: The sun does not beat you, the rain does not beat you, and yet you say you are engaged in a gainful pursuit.
Yoruba: Oòrùn ò pa ọ́, òjò ò pa ọ́, o ní ò ń ṣiṣẹ́ ajé.

English: The industrious person is the enemy of the shiftless person.
Yoruba: Òṣìṣẹ́ lọ̀tá ọ̀lẹ.

English: The laborer is in the sun; the person who will reap the fruit is in the shade.
Yoruba: Òṣìṣẹ́ wà lóòrùn; ẹní máa jẹ́ wà níbòji.

English: The farmer's hunger lasts only three months.
Yoruba: Oṣù mẹ́ta lebi ń pàgbẹ̀.

English: A machete's trade does not kill the machet; a hoe's trade does not cause problems for the hoe.
Yoruba: Òwò àdà kì í pa àdá; òwò ọkọ́ kì í yọ ọkọ́ lẹ́nu.

English: Wealth does not know who is the elder; it makes a senior of the younger person.
Yoruba: Owó ò mọ ẹ̀gbọ́n, ó sọ àbúrò dàgbà.

English: Money has no lineage; except for the person who will not work.
Yoruba: Owó ò níran; àfi ẹni tí kò bá ṣiṣẹ́.

English: The trade that one will pursue and that will make one prosper does not leave scars on one.
Yoruba: Òwò tí a bá máa ṣe àṣelà, a kì í rí àpá ẹ̀ lára ẹni.

English: Merchandise that one buys with money, one earns money for.
Yoruba: Òwò tí a fowó rà, owó la fi ń pa.

English: The trade one will pursue is the one one protects; Òjí scratches his body with a razor.
Yoruba: Òwò tí a ó ṣe là ń tọ́jú; Òjí fabẹ họra.

English: Other people's money is what the masquerader spends.
Yoruba: Owó olówó leégún ń ná.

English: The white man is the past master of trading; money is the guarantee of fashionableness.
Yoruba: Òyìnbó baba ọ̀nájà; ajé baba téní-téní.

English: The white man sells merchandise with the name brand still attached; the Ègùn person sells cloth still in its bundle.
Yoruba: Òyìnbó ta ọjà ta orúkẹ; Ègún tajà ta èdìdì.

English: The king who buries coral beads, the king who digs them up, both of then will have their names remembered by posterity.
Yoruba: Ọba tó fi iyùn bọlẹ̀, ọba tó wú u, àwọn méjèèjì la ó máa sọ orúkọọ wọn.

English: The king who turned a forest into a sandy plain, the king who turned a sandy plain into a forest, both of their names will be remembered by posterity.
Yoruba: Ọba tó sọ ẹgàn di erùfù; ọba tó sọ erùfù dẹgàn, àwọn méjèèjì la ó máa sọ orúkọọ wọn.

English: A delicious stew was procured with money.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ̀ tó dùn, owó ló pa á.

English: The stew having cooled, one hollows one's palm to eat it.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ̀ẹ́ tutù tán, a dawọ́ bù ú lá.

English: It is brazenness that gives birth to wealth; it is excessive reticence that gives birth to poverty.
Yoruba: Ọ̀dájú ló bí owó; ìtìjú ló bí gbèsè.

English: It is every year that the farmer receives praise.
Yoruba: Ọdọọdún làgbẹ̀ ń níyì.

English: This year the hunter kills an elephant; the next year the hunter kills a buffalo; two years hence the hunter kills a grass mouse; is his glory increasing or decreasing?
Yoruba: Ọdún yìí ọdẹ́ pa erin; ẹ̀ẹ̀míràn ọdẹ́ pa ẹfọ̀n; ọdún mẹ́fà ọdẹ́ pa òló; ọlá ń rewájú, tàbí ọlá ńrẹ̀yìn?

English: An unripe plantain is not something to eat; a useless child is not something to beat to death.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ dúdú ò ṣéé bùṣán; ọmọ burúkú ò ṣéé lù pa.

English: The white man's wisdom shines even across the seas; what cloth, though, is better than akẹsẹ cloth?
Yoruba: Ọgbọ́n òyìnbó ti ojú òkun là wá; aṣọ kí ni o borí akẹsẹ?

English: One makes money from goods one purchased with money.
Yoruba: Ọjà tí a fowó rà, owó la fi ń pa.

English: One-who-eats-recklessly-and-dies-recklessly is the name one calls a wasteful person.
Yoruba: Ọ̀-jẹ-wọ̀mù-wọ̀mù-kú-wọ̀mù-wọ̀mù lorúkọ tí àpà ń jẹ́.

English: The day one learns laziness is the day one should learn how to endure a painfully empty stomach.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ a bá kọ́ ọ̀lẹ là ń kọ́ inú rírọ́.

English: The day one sees the after-birth is the day it enters the earth.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ a bá rí ìbí nìbí ń wọlẹ̀.

English: It is on the day of relaxation that the lazy person experiences regret.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ eré lọ̀ràn ń dun ọ̀lẹ.

English: The day one gets to the farm is the day one fights over boundaries.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí a dóko là ń jìjà ilẹ̀.

English: The day one learns a trade is the day one learns to be quick at it.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí a ń kọ́ṣẹ́ là ń kọ́ ìyára.

English: Ọ̀kàràkàrà is calling and blood drips from its beaks; it says even if its mouth tears to the occiput it will continue its calling.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kàràkàrà ń ké, ẹnu ẹ̀ ń bẹ́jẹ̀; ó ní bí ẹnu òún ya dé ìpàkọ́, òun ó sàáà máa wí tòun.

English: The lazy person fails at everything, whereupon he becomes an Ifá acolyte.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ bà á tì, ó kó sílé Ifá.

English: The lazy person fails at everything, whereupon he goes to a Quaranic school.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ bà á tì, ó kó sílée kéú.

English: Laziness, father of all diseases.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ, baba àrùn.

English: A lazy person has found no world to come to.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ èèyàn ò rí ayé wá.

English: The lazy person cannot find a disease to contract, he bursts into tears.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ fẹ́ àrùn kù, ó bú pùrù sẹ́kún.

English: The lazy person replies “yes” to all propositions.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ fi ọ̀ràn gbogbo ṣe “hòo.”

English: The lazy person inherits unhappiness, he says he has inherited the fate of his lineage.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ jogún ìbànújẹ́, ó ní òún jogún ìran òun.

English: The lazy person inherits recriminations.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ jogún ìbáwí.

English: The lazy person curls up, and his condition becomes a serious ailment.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ kákò, ó di òjòjò.

English: Laziness lends weariness a hand.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ kún àárẹ̀ lọ́wọ́.

English: The coward knows the preventive for fighting: he says his father has ordered him not to fight on the way to the farm.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ mọ èèwọ̀ ìjà: ó ní bàbá òún ní kóun má jà lọ́nà oko.

English: The lazy person says on the day he dies, he will be happy. Death says he will visit him (the lazy person) with suffering that is out of this world.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ ní ọjọ́ tí ikú bá pa òun, inú òhun á dùn. Ikú ní òun ó jẹ̀ẹ́ kí ojú ẹ̀ rí màbo.

English: The coward says he will rejoice on the day he dies; but what about the woes he will experience before he dies?
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ ní ọjọ́ tí òún bá kú òun ó yọ̀; ohun tí ojú ọ̀lẹ́ máa rí kó tó kú ń kọ́?

English: A lazy person is not something one wants as a child.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ ò yẹẹ́ ní lọ́mọ.

English: The lazy person seeks out an easy task to do.
Yoruba: Ọ̀lẹ́ wáṣẹ́ rírọ̀ ṣe.

English: The wise will not die on a farm for the lazy; if a wise person dies on a farm for the lazy, there must be some explanation.
Yoruba: Ọlọgbọ́n kì í kú sóko ọ̀lẹ; bí ọlọgbọ́n bá kú sóko ọ̀lẹ, ọ̀ràn náà nídìí.

English: Each child must lift its mother's breast by itself.
Yoruba: Ọlọ́mú dá ọmú ìyá ẹ̀ gbé.

English: The Lord will give alms, but not the type one comes upon at crossroads.
Yoruba: Ọlọ́run yó pèsè; kì í ṣe bí èsè oríta.

English: A person that will become exemplary will begin showing precociousness from childhood.
Yoruba: Ọmọ tí yó jẹ̀ẹ́ àṣàmú, kékeré ní ń tií n ṣẹnu ṣámú-ṣámú.

English: It is the child that lifts up its arms that induces people to lift it.
Yoruba: Ọmọ tó káwọ́ sókè ló fẹ́ ká gbé òun.

English: It is the child that lifts its arms to one that one picks up to dance with.
Yoruba: Ọmọ tó ṣípá fúnni là ń gbé jó.

English: A child does not know where the person who carries it on her back is headed with it.
Yoruba: Ọmọdé ò mọ ibi tí à ń pọn òun rè.

English: It is drunkenness that swallows (or drowns) a champion drinker.
Yoruba: Ọ̀mu ní ń gbe ọ̀mu mì.

English: The path does not close on a man carrying a machete.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà kì í dí mọ́ aládàá.

English: An evil event never finds the squirrel at home.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn búburú kì í bá ikún nílé.

English: A problem shakes one up vigorously and lets one go; a problem shakes one up vigorously as though it would never end; the trouble will end, deflating the ill-wishers and also those who will not mind their own business.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn fini dùgbẹ̀-dùgbẹ̀ yinni nù; ọ̀ràn fini dùgbẹ̀-dùgbẹ̀ bí ẹnipé kò ní í tán; ọ̀ràn ń bọ̀ wá tán; ojú á tẹlẹ́gàn, a sì ti ẹni tí ń yọnusọ.

English: The pad placed on the head to soften the friction of the load on the head does not suffer from the weight; the person carrying the load is the one whose neck suffers under the weight.
Yoruba: Ọrùn kì í wọ òṣùká; ẹlẹ́rù lọrùn ń wọ̀.

English: The wind is no match for timber.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ atẹ́gùn ò ká gẹdú.

English: One's own hands are what one uses to mend one's fortune.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ ẹni la fi ńtú ìwà ara ẹni ṣe.

English: One hands are what feed one to satiation.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ ẹni ni yó yòóni.

English: The hands are the agents for grooming the body.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ ní ń tún ara ṣe.

English: It is on an idle hand that one rests one's chin.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ tó dilẹ̀ là ń fi lérán.

English: It is the harmattan that will teach the person who has only a loin cloth a lesson.
Yoruba: Ọyẹ́ ni yó kìlọ̀ fún onítòbí.

English: A sharp report is what accompanies a machete wound; a flying motion is the characteristic of an arrow; if one hits a prey one should go in search of it; if not it becomes meat for maggots.
Yoruba: Pa á ní ń jẹ́ ọgbẹ́, tiiri ní ń jẹ ọfà; bí a bá ta á ṣe là ń wá a; bí a ò bá wá a a dẹran ìdin.

English: A blow to the eye the first time, and a blow to the eye a second time; if the eye does not go blind it will only see dimly.
Yoruba: Pà-pà lójú lẹ́ẹ̀kínní, pà-pà lójú lẹ́ẹ̀kejì; bójú náà ò bá fọ́, bàì-bàì ní ń dà.

English: The fruit of the sausage tree drops, “and” its mother knows relief.
Yoruba: Páńdọ̀rọ̀ọ́ já, ará rọ ìyá ẹ̀.

English: Ṣàngó cannot destroy a huge tree.
Yoruba: Ṣàngó ò lè pa igi ńlá.

English: Work in order that you might have; intentions do not become possessions; no one makes money by magic.
Yoruba: Ṣe kóo ní; àbá ò di tẹni; èèyàn ò ṣoògùn ọrọ̀.

English: Working is difficult; one would rather freeload.
Yoruba: Ṣiṣeé rorò, jíjẹ ọ̀fẹ́.

English: Long trousers do not amount to wealth; being born in Lagos does not ensure riches.
Yoruba: Ṣòkòtò gbọọrọ ò dọlà; abíni lÉkòó ò dowó.

English: The pants that do the work that purchases the velvet fabric stays on the farm.
Yoruba: Ṣòkòtò tí ń ṣiṣẹ́ àrán, oko ní ń gbé.

English: The snare that will capture the lord of the wilderness will stay long in the bush before returning home.
Yoruba: Tàkúté tí yó pa Aláginjù á pẹ́ lóko kí wọ́n tó gbé e wálé.

English: With sac and all is how to remove jiggers; with its wrapping leaves is the way to buy corn meal.
Yoruba: Tàpò-tàpò là ń yọ jìgá; tewé-tewé là ń yán ẹ̀kọ.

English: The prickly spinach was succulent before the rain fell on it.
Yoruba: Tẹ̀tẹ̀ ẹ̀gún ti lómi tẹ́lẹ̀ kójò tó rọ̀ sí i.

English: Facial scarification comes with a great deal of pain; when it heals its beauty becomes one's pride.
Yoruba: Títa ríro là ń kọlà, bó bá jinná a di tẹni.

English: It is with both its eyes and its feathers that the partridge sees.
Yoruba: Tojú tìyẹ́ làparòó fi ń ríran.

English: Day or night, the nose does not rest; if it stops, that means the end.
Yoruba: Tọ̀sán tòru, imú ò gbélẹ̀; bó ba dákẹ́, a jẹ́ pé ó pin.

English: Struggle gives birth to ease; destitution gives birth to struggle.
Yoruba: Wàhálà ló bí ìrọra; òṣì ló bí wàhálà.

English: Only an imbecile carries a heavy load and stops to watch a spectacle; such a heavily-laden spectacle watcher is the sort of spectacle that attracts the attention of imbeciles.
Yoruba: Wèrè èèyàn ní ń ru ẹrù wòran; ẹní ru ẹrù wòran ni wèrè èèyàn ń wò.

English: The cow-itch offers no place to be handled; it stings with its whole body.
Yoruba: Wèrèpè ò níbìkan àgbámú; gbogbo ara ní ń fií jóni.

English: Only by taking a cold shower can one shake off the chill of the harmattan.
Yoruba: Wíwẹ̀ là ń wẹ̀ ká tó jàre ọyẹ́.

English: People asked the partridge, “Why is your clothing so dirty?” He responded, “Why would my clothing not be dirty? Given the time it takes me to make a hundred heaps in the morning, and the time I need to scratch the ground at dawn, what time is left for me to wash my clothes?”
Yoruba: Wọ́n ní, “Àparò aṣọ ẹẹ́ ṣe pọ́n báyìí?” Ó ní ìgbà wo laṣọ òun ò níí pọ́n? Kóun tó kọ igba láàárọ̀, kóun tó họ ilẹ̀ kùrẹ̀-kùrẹ̀ lábùsùndájí. Ìgbà wo lòun ó ràáàyè fọṣọ?

English: Previous Contents
Yoruba: Compare Wọ́n ní “Àwòko, o bú ọba.”

English: One does not call it a burden and also call it an adornment.
Yoruba: A kì í pè é lẹ́rù ká pè é lọ́ṣọ̀ọ́.

English: One does not find a horse on tether.
Yoruba: A kì í rí ẹṣin ní ìso.

English: One does not see a thing and then say one does not see it.
Yoruba: A kì í rí i ká tún sọ pé a ò ri mọ́.

English: One does not wear the ritual loincloth for presiding over a trial-by-ordeal and judge the righteous guilty.
Yoruba: A kì í ró aṣọ ajé sídìí ká dájọ́ òdodo lẹ́bi.

English: One does not tie a goat with another goat and keep one from butting the other to death.
Yoruba: A kì í so ẹran mẹ́ran kó kàn án pa.

English: One does not conspire in secret without the matter eventually causing a public argument.
Yoruba: A kì í sọ̀rọ̀ ìkọ̀kọ̀ kó má diyàn ní gbangba.

English: One does not ask the main litigant, “How about it?”
Yoruba: A kì í ṣe ẹlẹ́jọ́ ní “N gbọ́?”

English: He died in the mire; he died in the mire; let us simply say that the person drowned.
Yoruba: Àbàtá pani; àbàtá pani; ká ṣá sọ pé odòó gbéni lọ.

English: It is bribery that blinds a judge.
Yoruba: Àbẹ̀tẹ́lẹ̀ ní ń fọ́jú onídàájọ́.

English: Cleft-lipped person eating okro; he complains, “Can you believe what a mess the floor is?”
Yoruba: Adánu tí ń jẹ ilá: ó ní “Ẹ ò rí ilẹ̀ báyìí?”

English: It is simply a euphemism for theft to say àfọwọ́rá (literally, causing to disappear through the operations of the hand).
Yoruba: Àdàpè olè ní ń jẹ́ àfọwọ́rá.

English: It is a euphemistic description of stealing to say, “My child's hands are uncontrollably nimble.”
Yoruba: Àdàpè olè ní ń jẹ́ “ọmọọ̀ mi ń fẹ́wọ́.”

English: Riddling makes it impossible for one to know the meanings of names.
Yoruba: Àdàpè ọ̀rọ̀ ò jẹ́ ká mọ ìtumọ̀ orúkọ.

English: The leper said two things, one of them being a lie; he said after he had struck his child with his palm, he also pinched him severely with his fingernails.
Yoruba: Adẹ́tẹ̀ẹ́ sọ̀rọ̀ méjì, o fìkan purọ́; ó ní nígbà tí òún lu ọmọ òun lábàrá, òún ja léèékánná pàtì.

English: Person-who-schemes-to-kill-a-sheep-to-eat, native of Ìlárá, he says that he is afraid of its eyes.
Yoruba: A-dọ́gbọ́n-pàgùntàn-jẹ Ìlárá, ó ní ojú ẹ̀ ń ba òun lẹ́rù.

English: He who would collect rain water in a sieve deceives himself.
Yoruba: Afasẹ́gbèjò ń tan araa rẹ̀ jẹ.

English: One-who-smears-one's-eyes-with-pepper, one's husband's concubine.
Yoruba: Afatarẹ́nilójú, alèe baále.

English: He-who-has-an-affair-with-one's-wife harbors no good will towards one.
Yoruba: Afẹ́nilóbìnrin ò ro ire síni.

English: You-who-steal-in-secret, if an earthly king does not see you, the heavenly king sees you.
Yoruba: Afìkọ̀kọ̀jalè, bí ọba ayé ò rí ọ, tọ̀rún rí ọ.

English: A blind elephant does not know a man from a tree.
Yoruba: Afọ́jú àjànàkú, kò mọ igi, kò mọ èèyàn.

English: Employing-the-hands-to-make-things-disappear is called stealing.
Yoruba: Àfọwọ́rá ní ń jẹ́ olè.

English: The sword cannot tell the smith's head from others.
Yoruba: Agada ò morí alágbẹ̀dẹ.

English: The maize plant is not human; who ever saw children on the back of elephant grass?
Yoruba: Àgbàdo kì í ṣe èèyàn; ta ní ń rí ọmọ lẹ́yìn eèsún.

English: It is completely that a fortification wall encircles a town.
Yoruba: Àgbàká lodi ń gba ìlú.

English: It is completely that the climbing rope encircles the palm-tree.
Yoruba: Àgbàká nigbà ń gba ọ̀pẹ.

English: A farmer stays on the farm and sees the moon.
Yoruba: Àgbẹ̀ gbóko róṣù.

English: He-who-decides-a-case-after-hearing-only-one-side, (is) the dean of wicked persons.
Yoruba: A-gbẹ́jọ́-ẹnìkan-dájọ́, òṣìkà èèyàn.

English: Imperfect understanding of Ègùn (a language to the west of Yoruba) brings nothing but dissension.
Yoruba: Àgbọ́ìgbọ́tán Ègùn, ìjà ní ń dá sílẹ̀.

English: Reluctance-to-extend-hospitality makes one say, “My friend's friend has arrived”; one should simply say, “My friend has arrived.”
Yoruba: Àì-fẹ́-àlejòó-ṣe là ń wí pé “Ọ̀rẹ́ ọ̀rẹ́ẹ̀ mí dé”; ká ṣáà ti wí pé, “Ọ̀rẹ́ẹ̀ mí dé.”

English: It is an alarm that is raised without moderation that finds no helpers.
Yoruba: Àìfẹ̀sọ̀ké ìbòsí ni kò ṣéé gbè.

English: The dog says that if it had never been to a farm it would have thought that okra came from heaven.
Yoruba: Ajá ní òun ìba má dèé oko rí òun ìbá sọ pé ọ̀run ni wọ́n ti ń kálá wá.

English: A dog without ears is no good for stalking prey.
Yoruba: Ajá tí ò létí ò ṣéé dẹ̀gbẹ́.

English: It is a dog in whose speed one has faith that one sics at a hare.
Yoruba: Ajá ti erée rẹ̀ẹ́ bá dánilójú là ń dẹ sí ehoro.

English: Ajala, who whipped you? It is none other than you, isn't it?
Yoruba: Àjàlá, ta ní nà ọ́? Ìwọ náà kọ́ un?

English: The elephant is more than something of which one says, “I caught a fleeting glimpse of something”; if one saw an elephant, one should say so.
Yoruba: Àjànàkú kúro ni “A rí nǹkan fìrí”; bí a bá rérin ká wí.

English: He-who-wakes-in-the-morning-and-eats-nothing; he-“who-”makes-a-worm-er-of-six-loaves.
Yoruba: A-jí-má-jẹ-nǹkan, a-fàkàṣù-mẹ́fà-ṣoògùn-aràn.

English: It is a journey one does not want to make that one consults the oracle about.
Yoruba: Àjò àìwuniíyún là ń dÍfá sí.

English: He-who-carries-a-hunting-bag-but-does-not-hunt, enemy alike of man and beast.
Yoruba: A-kápò-má-ṣọdẹ, ọ̀tá ẹranko, ọ̀tá èèyàn.

English: A ladder rests on the ground and leans on the house; if the person one leans on must remove his support he should warn one.
Yoruba: Àkàsọ̀ faratilẹ̀ faratilé; bí ẹni tí a fẹ̀yìntì óò bá yẹni a wí fúnni.

English: A person that will greet one should greet one, and a person that will betray one should do so; what is the meaning of “Hello, Ìjàyè person!” before Ògúnmọ́lá's house?
Yoruba: Akíni ń jẹ́ akíni; afinihàn ń jẹ́ afinihàn; èwo ni “Ọ kú, ará Ìjàyè!” lójúde Ògúnmọ́lá?

English: A male asín rat does not hear the cry of its young and remain still; a nursing mother does not hear the cry of her baby without responding anxiously.
Yoruba: Akọ asín kì í gbọ́ ohùn ọmọọ rẹ̀ kó dúró; abiyamọ kì í gbọ́ ẹkún ọmọọ rẹ̀ kó má tara ṣàṣà.

English: The user of a cross-bow does not know what type of game he shoots at.
Yoruba: Alákatam̀pò ò mọ irú ẹran.

English: The butcher does not know what type the animal is.
Yoruba: Alápatà ò mọ irú ẹran.

English: People-who-know-the-answer-yet-ask-the-question, natives of Ọyọ, if they see you carrying a water-pot they ask whether you are on your way to the farm or the stream.
Yoruba: Amọ̀rànbini Ọ̀yọ́, bí o bá gbé kete lérí, wọn a ní oko lò ń lọ tàbí odò.

English: The-person-who-kills-and-eats-dogs claims to be afraid of chickens.
Yoruba: Apajájẹẹ́ ní ẹ̀rù adìẹ ń ba òun.

English: A murderer never permits the passage of a sword behind his skull.
Yoruba: Apani kì í jẹ́ ká mú idà kọjá nípàkọ́ òun.

English: The blacksmith manufactures from a description.
Yoruba: Àpèjúwe lalágbẹ̀dẹ ń rọ̀.

English: Ibadan people do not run from war; what they say is, “We will fall back a little.”
Yoruba: Ará Ìbàdàn kì í ságun; à ó rìn sẹ́yìn ni wọ́n ń wí.

English: He-who-eagerly-speaks-of-one's-problems, he covers his own with a huge potsherd.
Yoruba: Arítẹnimọ̀ọ́wí, ó fi àpáàdì ràbàtà bo tirẹ̀ mọ́lẹ̀.

English: Wrapping-from-waist-to-the-floor is the style of the queen's wrapper; digging-down-to-the-deepest-bottom is the requirement of yàrà, the dry moat.
Yoruba: Àrókanlẹ̀ laṣọ ayaba; àwàkanlẹ̀ ni ti yàrà.

English: The old person who incurs debt, he says how much of it will he be around to repay?
Yoruba: Arúgbó oǹdágbèsè, ó ní mélòó ni òun ó dùúró san níbẹ̀?

English: He-who-hurries-after-riches is on his way to battle; He-who-has-in-abundance is off on his travels; By-and-by-“I-will-be-rich” is back in his hut, eating roasted yams.
Yoruba: Asárélówó ń bẹ lọ́nà ogun; Apọ̀ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ń bẹ lọ́nà èrò; Bó-pẹ́-títí-ng-ó-là ń bẹ lábà, ó ń jẹ ẹ̀sun iṣu.

English: Speaking-without-explaining killed the first Elempe who said that calabash was heavier than china.
Yoruba: Àsọ̀rọ̀àìlàdí ló pa Elempe ìṣáájú tó ní igbá wúwo ju àwo.

English: The kite does not snatch chicks in secret, it snatches them openly.
Yoruba: Àṣá ò gbádìẹ níkọ̀kọ̀; gbangba làṣá ń gbádìẹ.

English: The evil doer makes a brisk exit.
Yoruba: Aṣeburúkú tẹsẹ̀ mọ́nà.

English: One-who-is-tight-with-the-right-and-tight-with-left-without-alienating-either; what one will find in that characterization is a lie.
Yoruba: A-ṣọ̀tún-ṣòsì-má-ba-ibìkan-jẹ́; irọ́ la ó bàá níbẹ̀.

English: Seeking-until-finding is how a woman seeks ingredients for stew.
Yoruba: Àwárí lobìnrin ń wá nǹkan ọbẹ̀.

English: Explicitness makes matters clear; it takes three-hundred strings to string six hundred; unless one explains it, no one understands.
Yoruba: Àwíyé ní ń mú ọ̀ràn yéni; ọ̀ọ́dúnrún okùn la fi ń sin ẹgbẹ̀ta; bí a ò bá là á, kì í yeni.

English: Explicitly is the way Ifẹ̀ speaks; it is openly that Orò kills animals.
Yoruba: Àwíyé nIfẹ̀ ń fọ̀; gbangba lorò ń pẹran.

English: The space is never so tight that a chicken will not be able to reach its incubating nest.
Yoruba: Àyè kì í há adìẹ kó má dèé ìdí àbaa rẹ̀.

English: The space is never so tight that a chicken will not be able to reach its incubating nest.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ká okó mọ́ obìnrin nídìí á ní kùkú ni

English: If one engages secretly in treachery, secret disasters befall one.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ń yọ́lẹ̀ dà, ohun abẹ́nú a máa yọ́ni ṣe.

English: Like a needle, like a needle, one compiles falsehood; the day it is as big as the hoe one uses on a farm, that is the day it kills one.
Yoruba: Bí abẹ́rẹ́ bí abẹ́rẹ́ lèèyàn ń ṣèké; ọjọ́ tó bá tóbi tó ọkọ́ tí a fi ń roko ní ń pani.

English: If the mouth has eaten, the eyes shut down.
Yoruba: Bí ẹnú bá jẹ, ojú á tì.

English: When the snail crawls, its shell follows.
Yoruba: Bí ìgbín bá fà, ìkarahun a tẹ̀lé e.

English: If the wicked person states a case, it is not the wicked person that will judge it.
Yoruba: Bí ìkàá bá ń rojọ́, ìkà kọ́ ni yó dàá a.

English: If you hide wickedness inside you and display a kindly disposition, God above will laugh hard at you.
Yoruba: Bí o finú ṣìkà tí o fòde ṣòótọ́, ọba séríkí á rín ọ rín ọ.

English: If you have a great deal of medicine and you are false, it will not work; one's head works better than any herb; one's destiny is far more effective than any medicine.
Yoruba: Bí o ní ọ̀pọ̀ oògùn, tí o ní èké, kò níí jẹ́; orí ẹní jẹ́ ó ju ewé lọ; ìpín jà ó ju oògùn lọ.

English: If you saw it you would say you did not; your husband gave you money and your lover spends it.
Yoruba: Bí o rí i, wà pé o ò rí; ọkọ́ fún ọ lówó, àlé gbà á ná.

English: However long it takes, a truthful person will not wind up in the bed made for the wicked.
Yoruba: Bí ó ti wù kó pẹ́ tó, olóòótọ́ ò níí sùn sípò ìkà.

English: When a woman wishes to engage in mischief, she wears dark clothing.
Yoruba: Bí obìnrín bá máa dán èké wò, a da aṣọ dúdú bora.

English: If eyes no longer see eyes, let the voice not miss the voice.
Yoruba: Bí ojú bá sé ojú; kí ohùn má yẹ ohùn.

English: If an invalid is approaching death, he should not lie about the melon-seed loaf; stew is never bitter.
Yoruba: Bí olókùnrùn yó bàá kú, kó má purọ́ mọ́ àlapà; omitooro kì í korò.

English: Longing for night-time, longing for night-time is the tendency of the person in dark clothing.
Yoruba: Bí òru bí òru ní ń ṣe aláṣọdúdú.
