English: When an elder has exhausted all his wisdom, he turns to another wisdom.
Yoruba: Bí ọgbọ́n bá tán nínú, a tún òmíràn dá.

English: If a youth knows two-hundred-becomes-one-hundred-and-forty, he cannot know traders-refuse-to-come-to-the-market.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé bá mọ igbá-di-ogóje, kò lè mọ èrò-kò-wájà.

English: When a child sees honey, he throws away bean fritters.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé bá ri oyin, a ju àkàrà nù.

English: The treasure one gathers by foul means will not make one rich.
Yoruba: Dúkìa tí a fi èrú kójọ kò mú ká dolówó.

English: “I am hungry” is not a message that whistling can convey.
Yoruba: “Ebí ń pa mí” ò ṣéé fìfé wí.

English: A dog does not eat a bone tied to its neck.
Yoruba: Eegun tí a bá so mọ́ ajá lọ́rùn, kì í ṣán an.

English: Lying Ìbídùn, who greets a masquerader with, “It's been quite a while!”
Yoruba: Èké Ìbídùn, tí ń kí eégún “Kú àtijọ́.”

English: The devious will reap shame in the future.
Yoruba: Èké lojú ó tì bó dọ̀la.

English: The devious person builds a house and it collapses; the treacherous person builds one and it tumbles in ruins.
Yoruba: Èké mọ ilée rẹ̀ ó wó; ọ̀dàlẹ́ mọ tirẹ̀ ó bì dànù.

English: Only a devious person knows what he or she is about; each person alone is privy to what he or she has done.
Yoruba: Elékèé lèké ń yè; oun a bá ṣe ní ń yéni.

English: A person who has children must be responsible; one who does not must know how to behave.
Yoruba: Eléweé ní iyènú; àìní mọ ìwàá hù.

English: You came to buy yam-flour; how did a kid find its way into your calabash?
Yoruba: Èlùbọ́ lo wáá rà; ọmọ ẹrán ṣe dénú igbá?

English: The guest does not pay homage to the chief, only to the host.
Yoruba: Èrò ò kí baálẹ̀, baálé ló ńkí.

English: When flies were eating (biting) the Jagùnnà Àró heard nothing of it and the Ọ̀dọ̀fin knew nothing of it; but when the Jagùnnà began to eat flies Àró heard, and the Ọ̀dọ̀fin knew.
Yoruba: Eṣinṣín ń jẹ Jagùnnà Àró ò gbọ́, Ọ̀dọ̀fin ò mọ̀; ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí Jàgùnnà ń jẹ eṣinṣin Àró gbọ́, Ọ̀dọ̀fin-ín mọ̀.

English: Ear, hear the other side before passing judgement.
Yoruba: Etí, gbọ́ èkejì kí o tó dájọ́.

English: The same ears that heard about the departure will hear about the return.
Yoruba: Etí tó gbọ́ àlọ ni yó gbọ̀ọ́ àbọ̀.

English: The goat says it does not set aside any house as an enemy's; whoever it has offended should ask it why.
Yoruba: Ewúrẹ́ ní òun ò mọlé odì; ẹni òún bá ṣẹ̀ kó bi òun.

English: The ẹgẹ́ trap never misses; whatever passes beneath it it strikes dead.
Yoruba: Ẹgẹ́ ò ṣákìí; ẹní bá bọ́ sábẹẹ rẹ̀, a pa á kú pátá-pátá.

English: Ẹgbẹ̀tàlá: if one does not explain it, no one understands what it means.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀tàlá: bí a ò bá là á, kì í yéni.

English: You-have-not-seen-the-last-of-me, who sold his dog for twenty cowries.
Yoruba: Ẹ-kòì-fẹ́-mi-kù, tó ta ajáa rẹ̀ lókòó.

English: Statements must be clarified; if they are not, they become muddy...
Yoruba: Ẹ̀là lọ̀rọ̀; bí a ò bá là á rírú ní ń rú.

English: Statements must be clarified; if they are not, they become muddy...
Yoruba: Ẹ̀là lọ̀rọ̀; bí a ò bá là á rírú ní ń rú.

English: It is a witness that clears up a case; a witness is not a partisan.
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́rìí ní ń yanjú ẹjọ́; ẹlẹ́rìí kì í ṣe elégbè.

English: The ears of the king hear everything twice.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ẹ̀mejì letí ọlọ́jà ń gbọ́rọ̀.

English: It is a person one does not love whose house is distant in one's estimation.
Yoruba: Ẹni a kò fẹ́ nilée rẹ̀ ń jìnna lójú ẹni.

English: One wakes only those that sleep; one does not wake those pretending to sleep.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá sùn là ń jí, a kì í jí apirọrọ.

English: Whoever conceals a disease is beyond help from a doctor.
Yoruba: Ẹní gbé àrùn pamọ́ kọjá ore oníṣègùn.

English: A person who is hit six times with a club and says only one blow landed; where did the other blows disappear to?
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a nà ní kùmọ̀ mẹ́fà, tó ní ọ̀kan ṣoṣo ló ba òun, níbo nìyókùú sọnù sí?

English: People chase only those who flee.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó sá là ń lé.

English: Whoever wants to be known as Ọ̀ṣákálá should be known as Ọ̀ṣákálá; whoever wants to be known as Òṣokolo should be known as Òṣokolo; what is the meaning of Ọ̀ṣákálá-ṣokolo?
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá máa jẹ́ Ọ̀ṣákálà a jẹ́ Ọṣákálá; ẹni tó bá máa jẹ́ Òṣokolo a jẹ́ Òṣokolo; èwo ni Ọ̀ṣákálá-ṣokolo?

English: Whoever knows what darkness can do must not antagonize the moon; one's actions “sometimes” send one abroad at night; roaming around in the dark is not a becoming habit.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá mọ ìṣe òkùnkùn, kó má dàá òṣùpá lóró; ohun a ṣe ní ń múni-í rìnde òru; òkùnkùn ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn.

English: The person who honors one in one's presence is nothing like the person who honors one in one's absence.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó ṣe ojú kò da bí ẹni tó ṣe ẹ̀yìn.

English: Whoever wishes to die a decent death, let him or her live decently.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó fẹ́ kúure, kó hùwà rere.

English: The person who is asleep but spreads the word that he or she is dead, when he or she awakens whom will he or she tell?
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó sùn tó ní òún kú, tó bá jí, ta ni yó wìí fún?

English: The person who is wise and yet lies, the person who knows the truth and yet dissembles, the person who knows one has nothing and yet asks something of one, which is any good among the three?
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gbọ́n tó ńpurọ́; ẹni tó mọ̀ràn tó ń ṣèké; ẹni tó mọ̀ pé nǹkan ò sí tó ń tọrọ; èwo ló sàn nínú àwọn mẹ́tẹ̀ẹ̀ta?

English: The person who removes oil from the rafter is less a thief than the person who helps him set it on the floor.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gbépo lájà ò jalè bí ẹni tó gbà á sílẹ̀ fún un.

English: When a person slips, the earth may not deny responsibility or knowledge.
Yoruba: Ẹnìkan kì í yọ̀ kí ilẹ̀ ó sẹ́.

English: The liar's mouth does not bleed.
Yoruba: Ẹnu òpùrọ́ kì í ṣẹ̀jẹ̀.

English: His or her mouth is the same one that proposes two hundred and proposes three hundred.
Yoruba: Ẹnuu rẹ̀ ní ń dá igba, tí ń dá ọ̀ọ́dúnrún.

English: Meat that one does not eat, one does not bite into allotments with one's teeth.
Yoruba: Ẹran tí a kì í jẹ, a kì í fi eyín pín in.

English: Deceit is no wisdom.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀tàn kì í ṣe ọgbọ́n.

English: These beans are not delicious, these beans are not delicious, yet the coiffure at the occiput is shaking vigorously.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀wà yí kò dùn, ẹ̀wà yí kò dùn, àáṣó ìpàkọ́ ń mì tìtì.

English: The pigeon says it cannot share its owner's food and drink, and then, when the day of his death arrives, duck its head.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹlé ní òun ò lè bá olúwa òun jẹ, kí òun bá a mu, kí ó di ọjọ́ ikúu rẹ̀ kí òun yẹrí.

English: Hide wickedness in you and affect a benevolent comportment; the one who calls people to account will not forget.
Yoruba: Fi inú ṣìkà, fi òde ṣòótọ́; ẹni tí ḿbini kò níí ṣàì bini.

English: One performs one's great feats in the open; if a horse dies, one buries it in a wide open space.
Yoruba: Gbangba là ń ṣe gbàǹgbà; bẹ́ṣín bá kú, ìta gbangba là ń sin í sí.

English: The hawk always spreads its wings to the fullest.
Yoruba: Gbangba làṣá ń ta.

English: Ògèdèm̀gbé always performs his rituals in the open.
Yoruba: Gbangba lÒgèdèǹgbé ń ṣawo.

English: We all agreed on a hundred and twenty cowries as the value of the bush rat; when the value changes to a hundred and forty, we must all know about it.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa la fòkété san ọgọ́fà; ìgbà tí òkété ó fi di ogóje, ojúu gbogbo wa ni yó ṣe.

English: Even if it is flimsy, the thread of truth never snaps; even though a lie might the girth of an ìrókò tree, it inevitably crashes.
Yoruba: Ìbáà tínrín, okùn òtítọ́ kì í já; bí irọ́ tó ìrókò, wíwó ní ń wó.

English: What one should ask is where the prince was attacked and flogged; one does not ask where the prince got the welts on his side.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ti na ọmọ ọba là ń bèrè, a kì í bèrè ibi tí ọmọ ọbá ti pọ́n lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.

English: It is in the same forest that a hunter hunts (or all hunters hunt).
Yoruba: Igbó kan náà lọdẹ ń dẹ.

English: The oil pot is ever found in a sitting position.
Yoruba: Ìjòkó là ń bá eèbà.

English: The pot is no shelter for the snail; all it does is trap the snail.
Yoruba: Ìkòkò kì í ṣelé ìgbín; ṣe ló dè ìgbín mọ́lẹ̀.

English: The tortoise's house is not large enough for it; the tortoise's porch is not large enough to receive visitors; the tortoise built its house and adds a porch at the rear.
Yoruba: Ilé ahun ò gba ahun; ọ̀dẹ̀dẹ̀ ahun ò gbàlejò; ahún kọ́lé ẹ̀ tán ó yọ ọ̀dẹ̀dẹ̀ níbàdí.

English: The citizenry one goes abroad with is the one in whose ranks one remains.
Yoruba: Ìlú tí a bá rè là ń bá pé.

English: The muslim fasts and swears he did not swallow his saliva; who is to corroborate his story?
Yoruba: Ìmàlé gbààwẹ̀ ó lóun ò gbétọ́ mì; ta ní ń ṣe ẹlẹ́rìí fún un?

English: The muslim says something and thunder rumbles; he says the Almighty is corroborating his statement.
Yoruba: Ìmàlé sọ̀rọ̀ òjó kù, ó ní Ọlọ́run jẹ́rìí òun.

English: Those who enter into a covenant must not betray one another; one person's counsel is not enough by itself.
Yoruba: Ìmùlẹ̀ ò gbọdọ̀ tan ara wọn jẹ; ìmọ̀ ẹnìkan ò yàn.

English: Seven thrifling bottles; fewer than seven and one cannot endure the thought.
Yoruba: Ìpẹ́pẹ́rẹ́ ìgò méje; bí kò bá pé méje ara kì í gbà á.

English: Whichever ìrókò tree becomes involved in treachery gets felled.
Yoruba: Ìrókò tó bá gbàbọ̀dè, bíbẹ́ ni.

English: “Breathe not a word of it to anyone” denotes a lie; “Ask anyone you please” indicates the truth.
Yoruba: Irọ́ ni “Má jẹ̀ẹ́nìkan ó gbọ́”; òótọ́ ni “Ẹni o rí o bi.”

English: “Permit me to perch by you” takes the whole seat; the parasite becomes the host.
Yoruba: “Jẹ́ kí n fìdí hẹ́ ẹ” ẹ́ gbàjòkó; àfòmọ́ di onílé.

English: Just to delay people deliberately, the humpback says when he dies his intestines should be removed from the back.
Yoruba: Kí a baà lè pẹ́ níbẹ̀, abuké ní bí òún bá kú, kí wọ́n ti ẹ̀yìn tú ìfun òun.

English: Sitting and refusing to budge from one's position results from lack of communication.
Yoruba: Kí á gà, kí á gò, èdè ni ò yédè.

English: To see and buy, to buy and not pay; buying without paying “is” the twin of stealing.
Yoruba: Kí á rí ká rà, ká rà ká má san; à-rà-àì-san èkejìolè.

English: Let the purchaser with cash come and let the purchaser on credit come; only buying without “eventually” paying is bad.
Yoruba: Kí olówó wá, kí aláwìn wá; à-rà-àì-san ni ò sunwọ̀n.

English: “I am not upset, I am not upset!” Yet a grown man swears angrily six times because of last night's pounded yam.
Yoruba: “Kò dùn mí, kò dùn mí”; àgbàlagbà ń bú ọpa lẹ́ẹ̀mẹfà nítorí iyán àná.

English: It-is-not-begging-and-it-is-not-stealing who whistles as he harvests corn ears; if he does not come upon me it becomes stealing; if he comes upon me it becomes “the action of” a member of the household.
Yoruba: Kò jọ agbe kò jọ olè tí ń súfèé yàgbàdo; bí kò bá bá mi a di olè; bó bá bá mi a di onílé.

English: There is nothing one cannot do in the dead of night; the light of day alone is what one fears.
Yoruba: Kò sí ohun tí a ò lè fi òru ṣe; ẹ̀rù ọ̀sán là ń bà.

English: Being neither a rat nor a bird keeps àjàò (a bird-like animal) from having to pay poll tax.
Yoruba: Kò ṣeku kò ṣẹyẹ ò jẹ́ kí àjàò sanwó òde.

English: Do not deny your responsibility; that way the problem will be minimized.
Yoruba: Má sẹ̀ẹ́ kí ọ̀ràn má pọ̀.

English: “I met him” is an incomplete statement without further elaboration.
Yoruba: “Mo kò ó” kì í ṣe àìní àpèjúwe.

English: Either sunken or swollen, the cheeks will be one or the other.
Yoruba: Nì palaba, ní wonko, ẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ á ṣèkan.

English: It is when one has come up empty in a scramble for food that one says there is nothing one eats that is not finished sooner or later.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí ọwọ́ ò tẹ ìjàdù là ń ní kò sí ohun tí à ń jẹ tí kì í tán.

English: “He jumped up and stayed aloft almost for ever”: that is a lie.
Yoruba: “Ó fò sókè ó pẹ́ títí,” irọ́ ló ń pa.

English: It may seem like staggering, and it may not seem like staggering, but he is tipping forward on tiptoes.
Yoruba: Ó jọ gàtè, kò jọ gàtè, ó fẹsẹ̀ méjèèjì tiro rìn.

English: You do not spit it out, and yet you do not swallow it.
Yoruba: O kò pọ̀ ọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ni o ò gbé e mì.

English: “It is an exact fit for my hand” leads to thievery.
Yoruba: “Ó mọ́ mi lọ́wọ́” ní ń di olè.

English: You hold corn loaf in your right hand and hold a cudgel in your left hand, and you call to Orímáfọ̀ọ́ to come take the food from you.
Yoruba: O mú oori lọ́wọ́ ọ̀tún, o mú kùmọ̀ lọ́wọ́ òsì, o ní kí Orímáfọ̀ọ́ wá gba oúnjẹ.

English: It wiggles its arms as though it would have one dance with it, and yet it is working its mouth as though it would swallow one.
Yoruba: Ó ń ṣe apá kúlú-kúlú bí ẹni ká gbé e jó, ó sì ń ṣẹnu hàmù-hàmù bí èyí tí yó gbèéni mì.

English: It is mere circumlocution to say “A person has a mouth like a monkey's”; one should rather say, “You, so-and-so, you are a monkey.”
Yoruba: Ó pẹ́ títí ni “A-bẹnu-bí-ẹnu-ọ̀bọ”; ká ṣá sọ pé, “Ìwọ Lámọnrín, ọ̀bọ ni ọ́.”

English: He shot an arrow towards the sky and covers his head with a mortar.
Yoruba: Ó ta ọfà sókè, ó ṣí odó borí.

English: Kolanut dropped from the grips of a monkey and it says it makes a gift of that to ground dwellers; if he does not make a gift of it to ground dwellers would it come down to fetch it?
Yoruba: Obìí bọ́ lọ́wọ́ alákẹdun ó ní òún fún ará ilẹ̀; bí kò fún ará ilẹ̀, yó sọ̀kalẹ̀ wá mú u?

English: A woman who has six lovers: the six lovers never know about one another.
Yoruba: Obìnrin abàlèmẹ́fà: àlè mẹ́fà ò mọ ara wọn.

English: That a woman has had one's child does not mean she cannot kill one; that a woman has not had one's child does not mean she may not kill one.
Yoruba: Obìnrin-ín bímọ fúnni kò pé kó má pani; obìnrin ò bímọ fúnni kò pé kó má pani.

English: A woman tarried too long at the market and returns home with a brazen face.
Yoruba: Obìnrin-ín pẹ́ lọ́jà ó fìgbójú wọlé.

English: A woman goes to her lover's house and uses her mother's home to deceive her husband.
Yoruba: Obìnrin-ín re ilé àlè, ó fi ilé ìyá ẹ̀ tan ọkọ jẹ.

English: The parrot is a bird of the sea, and the kingfisher a bird of the lagoon; even though we might forget that we once partook in the food, let us never forget what we covenanted.
Yoruba: Odídẹrẹ́ ẹyẹ òkun, àlùkò ẹyẹ ọ̀sà; bí a bá jẹun gbé, ká má jẹ̀ẹ́ùn gbé.

English: All we see is shadows, not clarity; but clarity will come, father of all openness.
Yoruba: Òfìífìí là ń rí, a ò rí òkodoro; òkodoro ń bọ̀, baba gbangba.

English: An audacious lie does not trip one in one's closet; it exposes one in a public place.
Yoruba: Ògèdèǹgbé irọ́ kì í dáni síyẹ̀wù; gbangba ní ń dáni sí.

English: It is what one wishes to keep a secret that one does in private.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a ò fẹ́ kéèyàn ó mọ̀ là ńṣe lábẹ́lẹ̀.

English: A little cowardice, a little bravery; all it brings one is trouble.
Yoruba: Ojo díẹ̀, akin díẹ̀; ìyà ní ń kó jẹni.

English: A midnight rain does not beat a decent person; if the person it beats is not a habitual thief he/she will be a habitual “night” wanderer.
Yoruba: Òjò ọ̀gànjọ́ ò pa ẹni rere; bí kò pa jalè-jalè a pa yíde-yíde.

English: It is out in the open that one spreads a huge skin.
Yoruba: Ojú gba-n-gba là ńta awọ gbà-ǹ-gbà.

English: The eyes do not, because they do not see one, engage in evil against one.
Yoruba: Ojú kì í fẹ́nikù kó hu ibi.

English: Women know only the face.
Yoruba: Ojú lobìnrin-ín mọ̀.

English: Discourse is in the eyes.
Yoruba: Ojú lọ̀rọ̀ọ́ wà.

English: It is in the presence and with the knowledge of the kola-nut seller that one receives a gratuitous addition to one's purchase.
Yoruba: Ojú olóbì la ti ń jèrè obì.

English: The eyes that used to recognize one cannot say they no longer recognize one.
Yoruba: Ojú tó ti mọni rí kì í wí pe òun ò mọni mọ́.

English: So, giant bush rat, such is your character; you made a pact with Ifá and you betrayed Ifá.
Yoruba: Òkété, báyìí nìwà ẹ; o báFá mulẹ̀ o daFá.

English: The large bush rat says it knows everyday, but not some other day.
Yoruba: Òkété ní ọjọ́ gbogbo lòún mọ̀, òun ò mọ ọjọ́ mìíràn.

English: The eunuch never has children close by.
Yoruba: Òkóbó kì í bímọ sítòsí.

English: The tattler does not earn six pence; thanks are all he gets.
Yoruba: Olòfòófó ò gbẹ́gbàá; ibi ọpẹ́ ní ń mọ.

English: The honest person in a town is the ogre of the town.
Yoruba: Olóòótọ́ ìlú nìkà ìlú.

English: The honest person will not sleep in the place prepared for the wicked person.
Yoruba: Olóòótọ́ kì í sùn sípò ìkà.

English: Lack of compassion is the elder of back-biting.
Yoruba: Òǹrorò lẹ̀gbọ́n òfófó.

English: “May my head grant that I have a partner” as a woman's prayer is not sincere.
Yoruba: “Orí jẹ́ kí ń pé méjì” obìnrin ò dénú.

English: Truth arrives at the market but finds no buyer; it is with ready cash, though, that people buy falsehood.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ dọ́jà ó kùtà; owó lọ́wọ́ là ń ra èké.

English: The truth does not die to be replaced as king by the lie.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ kì í kú ká fi irọ́ jọba.

English: Truth never goes awry; it is falsehood that earns a gash on the head.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ kì í ṣìnà; irọ́ ní ń forí gbọgbẹ́.

English: Truth is bitter; falsehood is like meat stew.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ korò; bí omi tooro nirọ́ rí.

English: Truthfulness is the chief of attributes.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ lolórí ìwà.

English: It is truth that unpacks the load of the wicked for all to see.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ ní ń tú ẹrù ìkà palẹ̀.

English: Women care only about money.
Yoruba: Owó lobìnrin-ín mọ̀.

English: The stew is delicious, the stew is not delicious; the pounded yams meal is completely gone from the dish.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ̀ẹ́ dùn, ọbẹ̀ ò dùn, iyán tán nígbá.

English: One conducts affairs with one's kin with forthrightness; one enters into covenants (with non-relatives) in secret; as one attends to one's secret compacts, one should also attend to affairs with one's kin; on the day one dies it is one's kin who attend to one's funeral.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánkán là ń ṣe ìbí; ìkọ̀kọ̀ là ń ṣe ìmùlẹ̀; bí a tọ́jú ìmùlẹ̀ tán, ká tọ́jú ìbí pẹ̀lú; bí a bá kú ará ẹni ní ń sinni.

English: The path of deceit soon ends.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà irọ́ kì í pẹ́ẹ́ pin.

English: The sage asks for information; Àjàpá the trickster asks, “About the person who was killed yesterday, is he already dead?”
Yoruba: Ọ̀mọ̀rán bèèrè ọ̀ràn wò; Ìjàpá ní, “Ẹni tí wọ́n pa lánàá, kàà kú tán?”

English: “This matter does not hurt me”: stating it only once suffices.
Yoruba: “Ọ̀ràn yí ò dùn mí”: ẹ̀ẹ̀kanṣoṣo là ń wí i.

English: Secret matters have open exposure as their ultimate destination.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkọ̀kọ̀, ní gbangba ní ń bọ̀.

English: The matter in question does not make a noise.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ò pariwo.

English: One's enemy never kills a huge cane-rat.
Yoruba: Ọ̀tá ẹni kì í pòdù ọ̀yà.

English: The coarse mat enters the town like a corpse; the butterfly enters the bush like a bird.
Yoruba: Pàkìtí ṣe bí òkú wọ̀lú; labalábá ṣe bí ẹyẹ jáko.

English: One's blindness should be absolute, and one's leprosy should pervade the whole body; half-blindness only brings dissensions.
Yoruba: Pátá-pátá; là ń fọ́jú, kùm̀bọ̀-kumbọ là ń dẹ́tẹ̀; ojú à-fọ́-ì-fọ́-tán ìjà ní ń dá sílẹ̀.

English: It is completely that the masquerader covers his head with his shroud.
Yoruba: Pátá-pátá leégún ń faṣọ borí;.

English: Turn your back you and you will discover how the deceitful person behaves; hide and you will find out what the detractor is saying.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀yìndà kí o ríṣe èké, fara pamọ́ kí o rí bí aṣení ti ń sọ.

English: Redness is the glory of brass; efficaciousness is the glory of medicine.
Yoruba: Pípọn niyì idẹ; ẹ̀jẹ́ niyì oògun.

English: Firmly planted and unshakable is the way one finds the city fortification.
Yoruba: Pọ̀ǹgbà-pọngba là ń bá odi.

English: Lie and become renowned; once you have been found out the result is disgrace.
Yoruba: Purọ kóo níyì; bí a bá jáni tán, ẹ̀tẹ́ ní ń dà.

English: Intrigue brought them together and they became friends; it did not take days, let alone months, before the friendship ended.
Yoruba: Rìkíṣí pa wọ́n pọ̀ wọ́n dọ̀rẹ́; kò lọ́jọ́ kò lóṣù ọ̀rẹ́ bàjẹ́.

English: When the intrigue is terminated, and the devious person takes his leave.
Yoruba: Rìkíṣí pin, alábòsí lọ.

English: Alms are the ultimate sacrifice.
Yoruba: Sàráà baba ẹbọ.

English: The earthen idol has no mouth to speak; lies are lying to lies.
Yoruba: Ṣìgìdì ò lẹ́nu fọhùn; irọ́ ń purọ́ fúnrọ́.

English: The earthen idol that does not speak, no one knows whose side it is on.
Yoruba: Ṣìgìdì tí ò sọ̀rọ̀, a ò mẹni tí ń gbè.

English: Whom should one blame, if not the person who delivered a child to a husband in the middle of the night without waiting until daylight.
Yoruba: Ta là bá rí báwí bí ẹní fọmọ fọ́kọ lóru, tí ò jẹ́ kílẹ̀ mọ́?

English: Who is the one on whom water was poured? Who is the one being mounted by the god?
Yoruba: Ta la domi sí lára? Ta lòrìṣà ń gùn?

English: Who else will the flies flock after if not the person with open sores.
Yoruba: Ta leṣinṣin ìbá gbè bí kò ṣe elégbò?

English: Who has tied you down and thus forced you to confess your guilt?
Yoruba: Ta ló dè ọ́ tí ò ń kakọ?

English: Who is concocting a medicine by the river about which the lábẹlábẹ plant is ignorant?
Yoruba: Ta ní ń ṣoògùn lódò tí lábẹ-lábẹ ò gbọ́?

English: “Come join me at my meal.” “Thank you, but no.” Still he eats a hundred mouthfuls, just to taste the stew.
Yoruba: “Wá jẹun.” “N ò jẹ.” Ó fọgọ́rùnún òkèlè tọ́ ọbẹ̀ wò.

English: They said, “Mocking bird, you are accused of insulting the king.” It asked when would it have time to insult the king, seeing that it must sing two hundred songs in the morning, two hundred in the afternoon, and two hundred at night, mixing it all up with some frolicsome notes?
Yoruba: Wọ́n ní,; “Àwòko, o bú ọba.” Ó ní ìgbà wo lòún ráàye bú ọba, kóun tó kọ igba lówùúrọ̀, igba lọ́sàn-án, igba lálẹ́, kóun tó fi àyìndà-yindà lù ú?

English: The old woman is asked to carry a child on her back, and she says but they know she has no teeth; was she asked to eat the child.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ní kárúgbó gba ọmọ pọ̀n, ó ní ṣe bí wọ́n mọ̀ pé òun ò léyín; wọ́n ní kó pa ọmọ jẹ ni?

English: One does not fall from a prone position.
Yoruba: A kì í dùbúlẹ̀ ṣubú.

English: One does not play the rendezvous game without knowing one's way.
Yoruba: A kì í fi àìmọ̀nà dá pàdé-m̀-pàdé.

English: The person who insults one is not as bad as the person who derides one; yet the person who derides one does not know what the future may bring.
Yoruba: Abúni ò tó abẹ̀rín; bẹ́ẹ̀ni abẹ̀rín ò mọ ẹ̀yìn ọ̀la.

English: The chicken lists to one side, we think it has fallen.
Yoruba: Adìẹ́ yẹ̀gẹ̀, a ṣe bí ó ṣubú.

English: There is no disappearing trick better than the availability of a dense forest to disappear into; there is no sacrifice more efficacious than having many people on one's side; there is no “The gods have elevated me” that is higher than the back of a horse.
Yoruba: Àfẹ́ẹ̀rí kan ò ju ká rí igbó ń lá bọ́ sí lọ; ẹbọ kan ò ju ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn lọ; “Òrìṣá gbé mi lé àtète” kan ò ju orí ẹṣin lọ.

English: He-who-neglects-his-affairs-to-care-for-others'-affairs, it is God that takes care of his affairs.
Yoruba: A-fi-tirẹ̀-sílẹ̀-gbọ́-tẹniẹlẹ́ni, Ọlọ́run ní ń ba gbọ́ tirẹ̀.

English: Elder, do a favor and remove your eyes from it.
Yoruba: Àgbà ṣoore má wo bẹ̀.

English: A ram is too much to give; a gelded animal is too much to give; everything is excessive in the sight of a miser.
Yoruba: Àgbò ò ṣéé mú; ọ̀dá ò ṣéé mú; ohun gbogbo ní ń tóbi lójú ahun.

English: It is failure-to-count-anything-as-significant that ruins things.
Yoruba: Àì-fi-ǹ-kan-pe-ǹ-kan ní ń ba nǹkan jẹ́.

English: Lack of resourcefulness and lack of thoughtfulness cause six siblings to die as pawns for only twelve thousand cowries.
Yoruba: Àìmète, àìmèrò, lọmọ ìyá mẹ́fàá fi ń kú sóko ẹgbàafà.

English: Croaking-in-relays is the mark of frogs.
Yoruba: Àjẹ́gbà ni ti kọ̀ǹkọ̀.

English: The person who gathers eggs to eat does not know that the chicken's orifice hurts.
Yoruba: Akẹ́yinjẹ ò mọ̀ pé ìdí ń ro adìẹ.

English: He-who-has-strength-but-lacks-discretion, father of laziness.
Yoruba: A-lágbára-má-mèrò, baba ọ̀lẹ́.

English: The shiftless, thoughtless husband who makes the junior wife's chicken as a sacrifice to the senior wife's head; if the husband is wicked, what about the god?
Yoruba: A-láì-mète-mèrò ọkọ tó fi adìẹ ìyàwó bọ orí ìyálé; bí baálé bá jẹ́ ìkà, èwo ni tòrìṣà?

English: He who purchases the food he eats cares not what the season is; his yams always flourish like trees.
Yoruba: Aláràjẹ ò mọ ọdún; a-biṣu-ú-ta-bí-igi.

English: The old person was once a dandy; the rag was once in fashion.
Yoruba: Arúgbó ṣoge rí; àkísàá lògbà rí.

English: The order from Ọ̀yọ́ never sounds “Gbà” (meaning “Take!”), only “Múwá (meaning “Bring.”)
Yoruba: Àṣẹ Ọ̀yọ́ kì í ró “Gbà”, àfi “Múwá.”

English: The big spender is never disgraced in the presence of the miser.
Yoruba: Àṣíríi náwó-náwó kì í tú lójú ahun.

English: It was an imbecile that gave birth to the mother of the monkey.
Yoruba: Aṣiwèrè ló bí ìyá ọ̀bọ.

English: A-creature-that-applies-other's-circumstances-to-itself, a hunter's dog.
Yoruba: A-ti-ara-ẹni-roni, ajá ọdẹ.

English: Those who cover their heads with mortars and shoot arrows into the sky: God's eyes encompass them all.
Yoruba: Ayídóborí tafà sókè: ojú Olúwaá tó wọn.

English: Bámijókòó (Sit-with-me) is the name one gives an àbíkú; a person who has never had a child does not name a child Ọmọ́láriwo.
Yoruba: Bámijókòó làbíkú ń jẹ́; ẹni tí ò bímọ rí ò gbọdọ̀ sọ Ọmọ́láriwo.

English: When one fells a tree in the forest, one should apply the matter to oneself.
Yoruba: Bí a bá gé igi nígbó, ká fi ọ̀ràn ro ara ẹni wò.

English: If one sees the corpse of a wicked person on the ground and one kicks it, there are then two wicked people.
Yoruba: Bí a bá rí òkú ìkà nílẹ̀, tí a fi ẹsẹ̀ tá; ìkàá di méji.

English: If your deeds are good the benefits return to you; if your deeds are not good they will be apparent to all.
Yoruba: Bí o ṣe rere yó yọ sí ọ lára; bí o kò ṣe rere yó yọ sílẹ̀.

English: As the young of birds hurt, so the young of humans hurt.
Yoruba: Bí ó ti ń dun ọmọ ẹyẹ, bẹ́ẹ̀ ló ń dun ọmọ èèyàn

English: “Traveller, get up early”; “Traveller, wait until light”; it's all out of solicitousness for the traveller's welfare.
Yoruba: “Èrò tètè jí;” “Èrò jẹ́ ilẹ̀ ó mọ́”; tèrò là ń srò.

English: You forbid us to shoot arrows, so with what shall we repel invaders? In the past the Boko were repelled with catapaults.
Yoruba: Ẹ ní ká má tafà; kí ni a ó fi lé ogun? Kànnà-kànnà la fi lé Boko.

English: It is the person who uses his/her money to enjoy life that lives well.
Yoruba: Ẹní fowó lògbà ló káyé já.

English: Whoever has riches should act like a king; what kind of feat can a miser perform with money?
Yoruba: Ẹní lówó kó ṣe bí ọba; àrà wo lahún fẹ́ fi owó dá?

English: It is the person who knows how to use wealth that wealth attaches to.
Yoruba: Ẹní mọ owóó lò lowó ń bá gbé.

English: Whoever would have children of her own must rejoice with those who already have.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá máa bímọ á yọ̀ fọ́lọ́mọ.

English: Whoever has reached the top, let him or her pull his or her friend by the hand; whoever has food to eat, let him or her share it with his or her friend.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gòkè, kó fa ọ̀rẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ lọ́wọ́; ẹni tó rí jẹ, kó fún ọ̀rẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ jẹ.

English: Whoever asks about a matter genuinely wishes to know its causes.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bèèrè ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ ìdíi rẹ̀ ẹ́gbọ́.

English: A person whom one does a favor but who shows no gratitude is like a robber who has stolen one's goods.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a ṣe lóore tí kò dúpẹ́, bí ọlọ́ṣà kóni lẹ́rù ni.

English: The person who adorns herself with beads has done the ultimate in self-beautifying; the person who gives one a child (in marriage) has done the ultimate in favor.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó so ìlẹ̀kẹ̀ parí ọ̀ṣọ́; ẹni tó fúnni lọ́mọ parí oore.

English: Whoever defames others defames himself or herself.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó ṣe ìbàjẹ́ èèyàn-án ṣe ìbàjẹ́ araa rẹ̀.

English: The pigeon hides its own disgrace and goes ridiculing the chicken.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹlé fi ẹ̀sín-in rẹ̀ pamọ́, ó ń ṣe ẹ̀sín adìẹ.

English: The blemish of the yam is the blemish of the knife; whoever besmirches other people's names besmirches his/her own.
Yoruba: Ìbàjẹ́ iṣu nìbàjẹ́ ọ̀bẹ; ẹni tó ṣe ìbàjẹ́ èèyàn-án ṣe ìbàjẹ́ ara ẹ̀.

English: The calabash of a kind-heated person never breaks; the china plate of a kind-hearted person never cracks; both riches and children ever converge in the home of a kind-hearted person.
Yoruba: Igbá olóore kì í fọ́; àwo olóore kì í fàya; towó tọmọ ní ń ya ilé olóore.

English: The calabash belonging to a patient person never breaks; the china plate belonging to a patient person never cracks.
Yoruba: Igbá onípẹ̀lẹ́ kì í fọ́; àwo onípẹ̀lẹ́ kì í fàya.

English: The home of a kind-hearted person never collapses completely; the home of a wicked person always collapses, leaving nothing standing.
Yoruba: Ilé olóore kì í wó tán; tìkà kì í wó kù.

English: To visit the home of a generous person is to be plied with food aplenty; who would think of visiting a miser?
Yoruba: Ilé ọ̀ṣọnú àyàyó; ta ní jẹ́ yalé ahun-káhun?

English: Ill will “is the” medicine that ensures misfortune.
Yoruba: Inú búburú, oògùn òṣì.

English: Good will towards others does not kill; it only gets one into trouble.
Yoruba: Inúure kì í pani, wàhálà ní ń kó báni.

English: “The pounded yam is good and the stew is delicious” killed Akíndélé on his farm at Ìgbájọ́ “God, I will not give you some food to eat” is what killed the priest at Ìkiré.
Yoruba: “Iyán dára, ọbẹ̀ẹ́ dùn” ló pa Akíndélé lóko Ìgbájọ; “Òrìṣà, n kò fún ọ ní èdì jẹ” ló pa abọrìṣà Ìkirè.

English: The wife ate the yam-flour meal and ate the calabash with it.
Yoruba: Ìyàwó jẹ ọkà jẹ igbá.

English: One may slash at it and slash at it, and one may shake the sand from its roots for ever, but nothing affects the eéran grass like being abandoned.
Yoruba: Kí á ṣá a ṣá a, kí á gbọ̀n ọ́n gbọ̀n ọ́n; ká fi oko eéran sílẹ̀ ló dá eéran lára.

English: “This thing is not plentiful; I cannot give you some of it”: the person is a miser.
Yoruba: “Kiní yìí ò pọ̀; n ò lè fún ọ níbẹ̀”: olúwarẹ̀ ahun ni.

English: “This thing that you have given me is not plentiful”: that statement indicates a greedy person.
Yoruba: “Kiní yìí tí o fún mi ò pọ̀”: ahun ní ń jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: He-will-not-bring-what-he-has will not have what one has.
Yoruba: Kò mú ti ọwọ́ ẹ̀ wá ò gba tọwọ́ ẹni.

English: “We have nothing, we have nothing!” Yet their children always have full stomachs.
Yoruba: Kò sí kò sí; bẹ́ẹ̀ni ọmọ wọn ń yó.

English: “There is not much of it” is what turns one into a miser.
Yoruba: Kò tó nǹkan ní ń sọni dahun.

English: “Do not share in my delicious meal,” chases away the animal.
Yoruba: “Má bàá mi jẹ ìdùn,” ẹran ní ń lé lọ.

English: “Just so you won't find my hand empty” roasted popcorn for the masquerader; the masquerader also responded with “Just so you won't find my hands empty” and gave him a wooden doll.
Yoruba: “Má fẹ̀ẹ́ ọwọ́ọ̀ mi kù” tí ń yan gúgúrú fún eégún; eégún náàá ní “Má fẹ̀ẹ́ ọwọ́ọ̀ mi kù”; ó fún un ní ọmọláńgidi.

English: Had I money I would cook bean meal for the Agọ́n masquerader; the brown monkey's raiding of his farm never elicits a complaint from him.
Yoruba: M̀bá-lówó-m̀bá-se-ọ̀lẹ̀lẹ̀-fún-Agọ́n: ìjímèrè kì í jẹ oko ẹ̀ kó sọ̀.

English: “Bring! Bring!” is the sound of the pigeon's wings.
Yoruba: “Mú wá, mú wá” lapá ẹyẹlé ń ké.

English: The big spender is not a prodigal.
Yoruba: Náwó-náwó kì í ṣàpà.

English: There you ate, there you drank, and there you fouled.
Yoruba: O jẹbẹ, o mubẹ, o babẹ jẹ́.

English: “Greetings to you at work” cannot invite people's anger.
Yoruba: “O kú iṣẹ́” ò lè bí aráyé nínú.

English: “Its impression on me is tremendous,” such is Arogun's corn meal; I bought only one, but she gave me two hundred as makeweight (or extra measure).
Yoruba: “Ó kún mi lójú,” ẹ̀kọ Arogun; ọ̀kan ṣoṣo ni mo rà, igba ènì ló fi sí i.

English: A small kolanut is superior to a large stone.
Yoruba: Obì kékeré kọjá òkúta ńlá.

English: A woman who bears a child that requires only cold water for all cures has saved her husband much worry; he will never again go searching for medicinal leaves, nor will he go digging roots.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tó bímọ tó bí olómitútù, wàhálà ọkọ ẹ̀ẹ́ dínkù; kò ní já ewé mọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ni kò ní wa egbò.

English: A woman has a child by you and you still say you do not see her inside “know her mind”; would you have her expose her intestines?
Yoruba: Obínrin-ín bímo fún ọ o ní o ò rínú ẹ̀; o fẹ́ kó o nífun ni?

English: Ògún  does not fashion ivory, the blacksmith does not make shoes; were farming not a difficult pursuit the blacksmith would not manufacture hoes for sale.
Yoruba: Ògún ò rọ ike; àgbẹ̀dẹ ò rọ bàtà; oko ò ṣòroó ro, àgbẹ̀dẹ ò pa ọkọ́ tà.

English: What will help a miser spend his money is right there in his/her pocket.
Yoruba: Ohun tí ń bá ahun náwó ẹ̀ ḿbẹ lápòo ẹ̀.

English: The rain beats the coco-yam leaf; if it will tear, let it tear.
Yoruba: Òjò pa ewée kòkò; bó lè ya kó ya.

English: It is out of regard for onlookers that one sings in praise of the dead; the dead did not prescribe a song before departing this life.
Yoruba: Ojú la rí là ń kọrin òkú, òkú ò forin sáyé kó tó lọ.

English: Eyes are what see look on eyes and fill with kindness.
Yoruba: Ojú ní ń rójú ṣàánú.

English: Only the king of this earth is blind; that of heaven is wide-eyed, watching evil doers.
Yoruba: Ojú ọba ayé ló fọ́; tọ̀rún là kedere, ó ń wo aṣebi.

English: Òkulu asks to whom should he lodge his complaint? Did anybody lodge his complaint with Òkulu?
Yoruba: Òkulú ní ta ni òun ó ro tòun fún? Ta ní wá ro tiẹ̀ fun Òkulu?

English: The goitered person going in front ruins the fortunes of the one coming behind.
Yoruba: Onígẹ̀gẹ̀ ìṣájú ba tìkẹyìn jẹ́.

English: A good deed does not go for nought; a wicked deed is never lost; drowning while doing a favor is what makes the good person lose out on the rewards for his goodness.
Yoruba: Oore kì í gbé; ìkà kì í dànù; à-ṣoore-jindò ní ń múni pàdánù oore.

English: The favor one does a chicken is not for nought; in due course it will make stew to delight one's mouth.
Yoruba: Oore tí a ṣe fádìẹ ò gbé; bó pẹ́ títí a ṣomi tooro síni lẹ́nu.

English: Only a person who thinks of the future commiserates with an orphan; otherwise, who would show kindness to an Ègùn person?
Yoruba: Òrẹ́yìn ní ń ṣe ọmọ òkù pẹ̀lẹ́; ta ní jẹ́ ṣe ọmọ Ègùn lóore?

English: An ill-natured woman will not give birth to twins; only good-natured people give birth to twins.
Yoruba: Òṣónú ò bí èjìrẹ́; onínúure ní ń bí ẹdun.

English: Money is what calls for spending money.
Yoruba: Owó ló ń pe ìná owó.

English: Big shot of Ìwátà towń the locusts do not know who is honest; the locusts arrive and the locusts eat up the good person's farm.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gá Ìwátà, eṣú ò mọ olóòótọ́; eṣú dé, eṣú jẹ oko olóore.

English: The drunkard is not a prodigal; it is his money that he is spending.
Yoruba: Ọ̀mùtí kì í ṣàpà; owó ẹ̀ ló ń ná.

English: There is no compulsion in voluntary work.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn-an-yàn ò sí nínúu iyánrán.

English: Wine stays in the home of the miser until it goes sour.
Yoruba: Ọtí gbélé ahun ó kan.

English: The assignment for an invalid must be different from everybody else's.
Yoruba: Ọ̀tọ̀ niṣẹ́ olókùnrùn.

English: Excessive stinginess is what slams the door of fortune in one's face.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ híhá àhájù ní ń dínà ire mọ́ni.

English: He who derides others steps outside and does not amount to much; it is he who has no basis for bragging that derides others.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀gàn-pẹ̀gàn-án bọ́ sóde kò ní láárí; ẹni tí ò rówó ṣe fújà ní ń pẹ̀gàn ẹni.

English: He who extends kindness beforehand: his goods will not stay long at the frontier.
Yoruba: Ṣe sílẹ̀: ẹrùu ẹ̀ kì í pẹ́ níbodè.

English: The detractor of others does not possess a change of clothing; the garment of the insulter of people is always skimpy.
Yoruba: Ṣẹ̀gàn-ṣẹ̀gàn ò láṣọ méjì; pé-ń-pé laṣọ abúni ḿmọ.

English: The wicked person does a little wickedness to himself or herself.
Yoruba: Ṣìkà-ṣìkà-á fi díẹ̀ ṣe ara ẹ̀.

English: The wicked forgets kinship; the person who hurts others forgets tomorrow.
Yoruba: Ṣìkà-ṣìkà-á gbàgbé àjọbí, adánilóró gbàgbé ọ̀la.

English: The wicked person will never describe himself as wicked.
Yoruba: Ṣìkà-ṣìkà ò jẹ́ pe ara ẹ̀ níkà.

English: Both the leaf and the root take pity on the climbing parasite.
Yoruba: Tewé tegbò ní ń ṣàánú àfòmọ́.

English: Both trees and palms take pity on the climbing plant.
Yoruba: Tigi tọ̀pẹ̀ ní ń ṣàánú àfòmọ́.

English: Both trees and palms extend kindness to the African black pepper plant.
Yoruba: Tigi tọ̀pẹ̀ ní ń sàánú ìyèré lóko.

English: Wickedness or kindness, neither goes for nought.
Yoruba: Tìkà toore, ọ̀kan kì í gbé.

English: Only coolness come out of the fish's mouth.
Yoruba: Tútù ní ń tẹnu ẹja wá.

English: UNIVERSAL DECLARATION OF HUMAN RIGHTS
Yoruba: ÌKÉDE KÁRÍAYÉ FÚN Ẹ̀TỌ́ ỌMỌNÌYÀN

English: Whereas recognition of the inherent dignity and of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé ṣíṣe àkíyèsí iyì tó jẹ́ àbímọ́ fún ẹ̀dá àti ìdọ́gba ẹ̀tọ́ ṭí kò ṣeé mú kúrò tí ẹ̀dá kọ̀ọ̀kan ní, ni òkúta ìpìlẹ̀ fún òmìnira, ìdájọ́ òdodo àti àlàáfíà lágbàáyé,

English: Whereas disregard and contempt for human rights have resulted in barbarous acts which have outraged the conscience of mankind, and the advent of a world in which human beings shall enjoy freedom of speech and belief and freedom from fear and want has been proclaimed as the highest aspiration of the common people,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé àìka àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn sí àti ìkẹ́gàn àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ wọ̀nyí ti ṣe okùnfà fún àwọn ìwà búburú kan, tó mú ẹ̀rí‐ọkàn ẹ̀dá gbọgbẹ́, tó sì jẹ́ pé ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ ìgbé ayé titun, nínú èyí tí àwọn ènìyàn yóò ti ní òmìnira òrọ̀ sísọ àti òmìnira láti gba ohun tó bá wù wọ́n gbọ́, òmìnira lọ́wọ́ ẹ̀rù àti òmìnira lọ́wọ́ àìní, ni a ti kà sí àníyàn tó ga jù lọ lọ́kàn àwọn ọmọ‐èniyàn,

English: Whereas it is essential, if man is not to be compelled to have recourse, as a last resort, to rebellion against tyranny and oppression, that human rights should be protected by the rule of law,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé ó ṣe pàtàkì kí a dáàbò bo àwọn ẹ̀tó ọmọnìyàn lábẹ́ òfin, bí a kò bá fẹ́ ti àwọn ènìyàn láti kọjú ìjà sí ìjọba ipá àti ti amúnisìn, nígbà tí kò bá sí ọ̀nà àbáyọ mìíràn fún wọn láti bèèrè ẹ̀tọ́ wọn,

English: Whereas it is essential to promote the development of friendly relations between nations,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé ó ṣe pàtàkì kí ìdàgbàsókè ìbáṣepọ̀ ti ọ̀rẹ́‐sí‐ọ̀rẹ́ wà láàrin àwọn orílẹ̀‐èdè,

English: Whereas the peoples of the United Nations have in the Charter reaffirmed their faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person and in the equal rights of men and women and have determined to promote social progress and better standards of life in larger freedom,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé gbogbo ọmọ Àjọ‐ìsọ̀kan orílẹ̀‐èdè àgbáyé tún ti tẹnu mọ́ ìpinnu tí wọ́n ti ṣe tẹ́lẹ̀ nínú ìwé àdéhùn wọn, pé àwọn ní ìgbàgbọ́ nínú ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn tó jẹ́ kò‐ṣeé‐má‐nìí, ìgbàgbọ́ nínú iyì àti ẹ̀yẹ ẹ̀dá ènìyàn, àti ìgbàgbọ́ nínú ìdọ́gba ẹ̀tọ́ láàrin ọkùnrin àti obìnrin, tó sì jẹ́ pé wọ́n tún ti pinnu láti ṣe ìgbélárugẹ ìtẹ̀síwájú àwùjọ nínú èyí tí òmìnira ètò ìgbé‐ayé rere ẹ̀dá ti lè gbòòrò sí i,

English: Whereas Member States have pledged themselves to achieve, in cooperation with the United Nations, the promotion of universal respect for and observance of human rights and fundamental freedoms,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Àjọ‐ìsọ̀kan orílẹ̀‐èdè àgbáyé ti jẹ́jẹ̀ẹ́ láti fọwọ́ṣowọ́ pọ̀ pẹ̀lú Àjọ náà, kí won lè jọ ṣe àṣeyege nípa àmúṣẹ àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti òmìnira ẹ̀dá tó jẹ́ kò‐ṣeé‐má‐nìí àti láti rí i pé à ń bọ̀wọ̀ fún àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ náà káríayé,

English: Whereas a common understanding of these rights and freedoms is of the greatest importance for the full realization of this pledge,
Yoruba: Bí ó ti jẹ́ pé àfi tí àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira wọ̀nyí bá yé ènìyàn nìkan ni a fi lè ní àmúṣẹ ẹ̀jẹ́ yìí ní kíkún,

English: Now, therefore,
Yoruba: Ní báyìí,

English: Proclaims this Universal Declaration of Human Rights as a common standard of achievement for all peoples and all nations, to the end that every individual and every organ of society, keeping this Declaration constantly in mind, shall strive by teaching and education to promote respect for these rights and freedoms and by progressive measures, national and international, to secure their universal and effective recognition and observance, both among the peoples of Member States themselves and among the peoples of territories under their jurisdiction.
Yoruba: Àpapọ̀ ìgbìmọ̀ Àjọ‐ìsọ̀kan orílẹ̀‐èdè àgbáyé ṣe ìkéde káríayé ti ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun àfojúsùn tí gbogbo ẹ̀dá àti orílẹ̀‐èdè jọ ń lépa lọ́nà tó jẹ́ pé ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan àti ẹ̀ka kọ̀ọ̀kan láwùjọ yóò fi ìkéde yìí sọ́kàn, tí wọn yóò sì rí i pé àwọn lo ètò‐ìkọ́ni àti ètò‐ẹ̀kọ́ láti ṣe ìgbélárugẹ ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira wọ̀nyí, bákan náà, a gbọdọ̀ rí àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó lè mú ìlọsíwájú bá orílẹ̀‐èdè kan ṣoṣo tàbí àwọn orílẹ̀‐èdè sí ara wọn, kí a sì rí i pé a fi ọ̀wọ̀ tó jọjú wọ àwọn òfin wọ̀nyí, kí àmúlò wọn sì jẹ́ káríayé láàrin àwọn ènìyàn orílẹ̀‐èdè tó jẹ́ ọmọ Àjọ‐ìsọ̀kan àgbáyé fúnra wọn àti láàrin àwọn ènìyàn orílẹ̀‐èdè mìíràn tó wà lábẹ́ àṣẹ wọn.

English: Article 1
Yoruba: Abala kìíní

English: All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyàn ni a bí ní òmìnira; iyì àti ẹ̀tọ́ kọ̀ọ̀kan sì dọ́gba.

English: They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ní ẹ̀bùn ti làákàyè àti ti ẹ̀rí‐ọkàn, ó sì yẹ kí wọn ó máa hùwà sí ara wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọ ìyá.

English: Article 2
Yoruba: Abala kejì

English: Everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth in this Declaration, without distinction of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ànfàní sí gbogbo ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira tí a ti gbé kalẹ̀ nínú ìkéde yìí láìfi ti ọ̀rọ̀ ìyàtọ̀ ẹ̀yà kankan ṣe; ìyàtọ̀ bí i ti ẹ̀yà ènìyàn, àwọ̀, akọ‐n̄‐bábo, èdè, ẹ̀sìn, ètò ìṣèlú tàbí ìyàtọ̀ nípa èrò ẹni, orílẹ̀‐èdè ẹni, orírun ẹni, ohun ìní ẹni, ìbí ẹni tàbí ìyàtọ̀ mìíràn yòówù kó jẹ́.

English: Furthermore, no distinction shall be made on the basis of the political, jurisdictional or international status of the country or territory to which a person belongs, whether it be independent, trust, non-self-governing or under any other limitation of sovereignty.
Yoruba: Síwájú sí i, a kò gbọdọ̀ ya ẹnìkẹ́ni sọ́tọ̀ nítorí irú ìjọba orílẹ̀‐èdè rẹ̀ ní àwùjọ àwọn orílẹ̀‐èdè tàbí nítorí ètò‐ìṣèlú tàbí ètò‐ìdájọ́ orílẹ̀‐èdè rẹ̀; orílẹ̀‐èdè náà ìbáà wà ní òmìnira tàbí kí ó wà lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ilẹ̀ mìíràn, wọn ìbáà má dàá ìjọba ara wọn ṣe tàbí kí wọ́n wà lábẹ́ ìkáni‐lápá‐kò yòówù tí ìbáà fẹ́ dí òmìnira wọn lọ́wọ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí orílẹ̀‐èdè.

English: Article 3
Yoruba: Abala kẹta

English: Everyone has the right to life, liberty and the security of person.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti wà láàyè, ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira àti ẹ̀tọ́ sí ààbò ara rẹ̀.

English: Article 4
Yoruba: Abala kẹrin

English: No one shall be held in slavery or servitude; slavery and the slave trade shall be prohibited in all their forms.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ mú ẹnikẹ́ni ní ẹrú tàbí kí a mú un sìn; ẹrú níní àti ò wò ẹrú ni a gbọdọ̀ fi òfin dè ní gbogbo ọ̀nà.

English: Article 5
Yoruba: Abala karùn‐ún

English: No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ dá ẹnì kẹ́ni lóró tàbí kí a lò ó ní ìlò ìkà tí kò yẹ ọmọ ènìyàn tàbí ìlò tó lè tàbùkù ẹ̀dá ènìyàn.

English: Article 6
Yoruba: Abala kẹfà

English: Everyone has the right to recognition everywhere as a person before the law.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ pé kí a kà á sí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ènìyàn lábẹ́ òfin ní ibi gbogbo.

English: Article 7
Yoruba: Abala keje

English: All are equal before the law and are entitled without any discrimination to equal protection of the law.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyàn ló dọ́gba lábẹ́ òfin. Wọ́n sì ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí àà bò lábẹ́ òfin láìsí ìyàsọ́tọ̀ kankan.

English: All are entitled to equal protection against any discrimination in violation of this Declaration and against any incitement to such discrimination.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyàn ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ààbò tó dọ́gba kúrò lọ́wọ́ ìyàsọ́tọ̀ yòówù tí ìbáà lòdì sí ìkéde yìí àti ẹ̀tọ́ kúrò lọ́wọ́ gbogbo ohun tó bá lè ti ènìyàn láti ṣe irú ìyàsọ́tọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Article 8
Yoruba: Abala kẹjọ

English: Everyone has the right to an effective remedy by the competent national tribunals for acts violating the fundamental rights granted him by the constitution or by law.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan lórílẹ̀‐èdè, ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí àtúnṣe tó jọjú ní ilé‐ẹjọ́ fún ìwà tó lòdì sí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn, tó jẹ́ kò‐ṣeé‐má‐nìí gẹ́gẹ́ bó ṣe wà lábẹ́ òfin àti bí òfin‐ìpìlẹ̀ ṣe là á sílẹ̀.

English: Article 9
Yoruba: Abala kẹsàn‐án

English: No one shall be subjected to arbitrary arrest, detention or exile.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ ṣàdédé fi òfin mú ènìyàn tàbí kí a kàn gbé ènìyàn tì mọ́lé, tàbí kí a lé ènìyàn jáde ní ìlú láìnídìí.

English: Article 10
Yoruba: Abala kẹwàá

English: Everyone is entitled in full equality to a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal, in the determination of his rights and obligations and of any criminal charge against him.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan tí a bá fi ẹ̀sùn kàn ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ tó dọ́gba, tó sì kún, láti ṣàlàyé ara rẹ̀ ní gban̄gba, níwájú ilé‐ẹjọ́ tí kò ṣègbè, kí wọn lè ṣe ìpinnu lórí ẹ̀tọ́ àti ojúṣe rẹ̀ nípa irú ẹ̀sùn ọ̀ràn dídá tí a fi kàn án.

English: Article 11
Yoruba: Abala kọkànlá

English: Everyone charged with a penal offence has the right to be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law in a public trial at which he has had all the guarantees necessary for his defence.
Yoruba: Ẹnìkẹ́ni tí a fi ẹ̀sùn kàn ni a gbọdọ̀ gbà wí pé ó jàrè títí ẹ̀bi rẹ̀ yóò fi hàn lábẹ́ òfin nípasẹ̀ ìdájọ́ tí a ṣe ní gban̄gba nínú èyí tí ẹni tí a fi ẹ̀sùn kàn yóò ti ní gbogbo ohun tí ó nílò láti fi ṣe àwíjàre ara rẹ̀.

English: No one shall be held guilty of any penal offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute a penal offence, under national or international law, at the time when it was committed.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ dá ẹ̀bi ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ fún ẹnìkẹ́ni fún pé ó hu ìwà kan tàbí pé ó ṣe àwọn àfojúfò kàn nígbà tó jẹ́ pé lásìkò tí èyí ṣẹlẹ̀, irú ìwà bẹ́ẹ̀ tàbí irú àfojúfò bẹ́ẹ̀ kò lòdì sí òfin orílẹ̀‐èdè ẹni náà tàbí òfin àwọn orílẹ̀‐èdè àgbáyé mìíràn.

English: Nor shall a heavier penalty be imposed than the one that was applicable at the time the penal offence was committed.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, ìjẹníyà tí a lè fún ẹni tó dẹ́ṣẹ̀ kò gbọdọ̀ ju èyí tó wà ní ìmúlò ní àsìkò tí ẹni náà dá ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ rẹ̀.

English: Article 12
Yoruba: Abala kejìlá

English: No one shall be subjected to arbitrary interference with his privacy, family, home or correspondence, nor to attacks upon his honour and reputation.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ pé kí a má ṣàdédé ṣe àyọjúràn sí ọ̀rọ̀ ìgbésí ayé rẹ̀, tàbí sí ọ̀rọ̀ẹbí rẹ̀ tàbí sí ọ̀rọ̀ ìdílé rẹ̀ tàbí ìwé tí a kọ sí i; a kò sì gbọdọ̀ ba iyì àti orúkọ rẹ̀ jẹ́.

English: Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference or attacks.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ààbò lábẹ́ òfin kúrò lọ́wọ́ irú àyọjúràn tàbí ìbanijẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Article 13
Yoruba: Abala kẹtàlá.

English: Everyone has the right to freedom of movement and residence within the borders of each State.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti rìn káàkiri ní òmìnira kí ó sì fi ibi tó bá wù ú ṣe ìbùgbé láàrin orílẹ̀‐èdè rẹ̀.

English: Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti kúrò lórílẹ̀‐èdè yòówù kó jẹ́, tó fi mọ́ orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀, kí ó sì tún padà sí orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀ nígbà tó bá wù ú.

English: Article 14
Yoruba: Abala kẹrìnlá

English: Everyone has the right to seek and to enjoy in other countries asylum from persecution.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti wá ààbò àti láti jẹ àn fàní ààbò yìí ní orílẹ̀‐èdè mìíràn nígbà tí a bá ń ṣe inúnibíni sí i.

English: This right may not be invoked in the case of prosecutions genuinely arising from non-political crimes or from acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations.
Yoruba: A kò lè lo ẹ̀tọ́ yìí fún ẹni tí a bá pè lẹ́jọ́ tó dájú nítorí ẹ ṣẹ̀ tí kò jẹ mọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú tàbí ohun mìíràn tí ó ṣe tí kò bá ète àti ìgbékalẹ̀ Ajọ‐ìsọ̀kan orílẹ̀‐èdè àgbáyé mu.

English: Article 15
Yoruba: Abala kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún

English: Everyone has the right to a nationality.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀‐èdè kan.

English: No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his nationality nor denied the right to change his nationality.
Yoruba: A kò lè ṣàdédé gba ẹ̀tọ́ jíjẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀‐èdè ẹni lọ́wọ́ ẹnìkẹ́ni láìnídìí tàbí kí a kọ̀ fún ẹnìkẹ́ni láti yàn láti jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀‐èdè mìíràn.

English: Article 16
Yoruba: Abala kẹrìndínlógún

English: Men and women of full age, without any limitation due to race, nationality or religion, have the right to marry and to found a family.
Yoruba: Tọkùnrin tobìnrin tó bá ti bàlágà ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti fẹ́ ara wọn, kí wọ́n sì dá ẹbí ti wọn sílẹ̀ láìsí ìkanilápá‐kò kankan nípa ẹ̀yà wọn, tàbí orílẹ̀‐èdè wọn tàbí ẹ̀sìn wọn.

English: They are entitled to equal rights as to marriage, during marriage and at its dissolution.
Yoruba: Ẹtọ́ wọn dọ́gba nínú ìgbeyàwó ìbáà jẹ́ nígbà tí wọn wà papọ̀ tàbí lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n bá kọ ara wọn.

English: Marriage shall be entered into only with the free and full consent of the intending spouses.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ ṣe ìgbeyàwó kan láìjẹ́ pé àwọn tí ó fẹ́ fẹ́ ara wọn ní òmìnira àtọkànwá tó péye láti yàn fúnra wọn.

English: The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State.
Yoruba: Ẹbí jẹ́ ìpìlẹ̀ pàtàkì àdánidá ní àwùjọ, ó sì ní ẹ̀tọ́ pé kí àwùjọ àti orílẹ̀‐èdè ó dáàbò bò ó.

English: Article 17
Yoruba: Abala kẹtàdínlógún

English: Everyone has the right to own property alone as well as in association with others.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti dá ohun ìní ara rẹ̀ ní tàbí láti ní in papọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn mìíràn.

English: No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his property.
Yoruba: A kò lè ṣàdédé gba ohun ìní ẹnì kan lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀ láìnídìí.

English: Article 18
Yoruba: Abala kejìdínlógún

English: Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; this right includes freedom to change his religion or belief, and freedom, either alone or in community with others and in public or private, to manifest his religion or belief in teaching, practice, worship and observance.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira èrò, òmìnira ẹ̀rí‐ọkàn àti òmìnira ẹ sìn. Ẹtọ́ yìí sì gbani láàyè láti pààrọ̀ ẹ sìn tàbí ìgbàgbọ́ ẹni. Ó sì fún ẹyọ ẹnì kan tàbí àkójọpọ̀ ènìyàn láàyè láti ṣe ẹ̀sìn wọn àti ìgbàgbọ́ wọn bó ṣe jẹ mọ́ ti ìkọ́ni, ìṣesí, ìjọ́sìn àti ìmúṣe ohun tí wọ́n gbàgbọ́ yálà ní ìkọ̀kọ̀ tàbí ní gban̄gba.

English: Article 19
Yoruba: Abala kọkàndínlógún

English: Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmì nira láti ní ìmọ̀ràn tí ó wù ú, kí ó sì sọ irú ìmọ̀ràn bẹ́ẹ̀ jáde; ẹ̀tọ́yìí gbani láàyè láti ní ìmọ̀ràn yòówù láìsí àtakò láti ọ̀dọ̀ ẹnìkẹ́ni láti wádìí ọ̀rọ̀, láti gba ìmọ̀ràn lọ́dọ̀ ẹlòmíràn tàbí láti gbani níyànjú lọ́nàkọ́nà láìka ààlà orílẹ̀‐èdè kankan kún.

English: Article 20
Yoruba: Abala ogún

English: Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira láti pé jọ pọ̀ àti láti dara pọ̀ mọ́ àwọn mìíràn ní àlàáfíà.

English: No one may be compelled to belong to an association.
Yoruba: A kò lè fi ipá mú ẹnìkẹ́ni dara pọ̀ mọ́ ẹgbẹ́ kankan.

English: Article 21
Yoruba: Abala kọkànlélógún

English: Everyone has the right to take part in the government of his country, directly or through freely chosen representatives.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti kópa nínú ìṣàkóso orílẹ̀‐èdè rẹ̀, yálà fúnra rẹ̀ tàbí nípasẹ̀ àwọn aṣojú tí a kò fi ipá yàn.

English: Everyone has the right to equal access to public service in his country.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ tó dọ́gba láti ṣe iṣẹ́ ìjọba ní orílẹ̀‐èdè rẹ̀.

English: The will of the people shall be the basis of the authority of government; this will shall be expressed in periodic and genuine elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret vote or by equivalent free voting procedures.
Yoruba: I fẹ́ àwọn ènìyàn ìlú ni yóò jẹ́ òkúta ìpìlẹ̀ fún à ṣẹ ìjọba; a ó máa fi ìfẹ́ yìí hàn nípasẹ̀ ìbò tòótọ́ tí a ó máa dì láti ìgbà dé ìgbà, nínú èyí tí ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan yóò ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìbò kan ṣoṣo tí a dì ní ìkọ̀kọ̀ tàbí nípasẹ̀ irú ọ nà ìdìbò mìíràn tí ó bá irú ìdìbò bẹ́ẹ̀ mu.

English: Article 22
Yoruba: Abala kejìlélógún

English: Everyone, as a member of society, has the right to social security and is entitled to realization, through national effort and international co-operation and in accordance with the organization and resources of each State, of the economic, social and cultural rights indispensable for his dignity and the free development of his personality.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ̀yà nínú àwùjọ ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìdáàbò bò láti ọwọ́ ìjọba àti láti jẹ́ àn fà ní àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ tí ó bá ọrọ̀‐ajé, ìwà láwùjọ àti àṣà àbínibí mu; àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ tí ó jẹ́ kò‐ṣeé‐má‐nìí fún iyì àti ìdàgbàsókè ẹ̀dá ènìyàn, nípa akitiyan nínú orílẹ̀‐èdè àti ìfọwọ́ṣowọ́ pọ̀ láàrin àwọn orílẹ̀‐èdè ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú ètò àti ohun àlùmọ́nì orílẹ̀‐èdè kọ̀ọ̀kan.

English: Article 23
Yoruba: Abala kẹtàlélógún

English: Everyone has the right to work, to free choice of employment, to just and favourable conditions of work and to protection against unemployment.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti ṣiṣẹ́, láti yan irú iṣẹ́ tí ó wù ú, lábẹ́ àdéhùn tí ó tọ́ tí ó sì tún rọrùn, kí ó sì ní ààbò kúrò lọ́wọ́ àìríṣẹ́ ṣe.

English: Everyone, without any discrimination, has the right to equal pay for equal work.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti gba iye owó tí ó dọ́gba fún irú iṣẹ́ kan náà, láìsí ìyàsọ́tọ̀ kankan.

English: Everyone who works has the right to just and favourable remuneration ensuring for himself and his family an existence worthy of human dignity, and supplemented, if necessary, by other means of social protection.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan tí ó bá ń ṣisẹ́ ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti gba owó oṣù tí ó tọ́ tí yóò sì tó fún òun àti ẹbí rẹ̀ láti gbé ayé tí ó bu iyì kún ènìyàn; a sì lè fi kún owó yìí nípasẹ̀ oríṣìí àwọn ètò ìrànlọ́wọ́ mìíràn nígbà tí ó bá ye.

English: Everyone has the right to form and to join trade unions for the protection of his interests.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti dá ẹgbẹ́ òṣìṣẹ́ sílẹ̀ àti láti dara pọ̀ mọ́ irú ẹgbẹ; bẹ́ẹ̀ láti dáàbò bo àwọn ohun tí ó jẹ ẹ́ lógún.

English: Article 24
Yoruba: Abala kẹrìnlélógún

English: Everyone has the right to rest and leisure, including reasonable limitation of working hours and periodic holidays with pay.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìsinmi àti fàájì pẹ̀lú àkókò tí kò pọ̀ jù lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ àti àsìkò ìsinmi lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ láti ìgbà dé ìgbà tí a ó sanwó fún.

English: Article 25
Yoruba: Abala kẹẹ̀ẹ́dọ́gbọ̀n

English: Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti gbé ìgbé ayé tó bójú mu nínú èyí tí òun àti ẹbí rẹ̀ yóò wà ní ìlera àti àlàáfíà, tí wọn yóò sì ní oúnjẹ, aṣọ, ilégbèé, àti àn fàní fún ìwòsàn àti gbogbo ohun tó lè mú ẹ̀dá gbé ìgbé ayé rere, bákan náà, ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló tún ní ààbò nígbà àìníṣẹ́lọ́wọ́, nígbà àìsà n, nígbà tó bá di aláàbọ̀‐ara, ní ipò opó, nígbà ogbó rẹ̀ tàbí ìgbà mìíràn tí ènìyàn kò ní ọ̀nà láti rí oúnjẹ òò jọ́, tí eléyìí kì í sì í ṣe ẹ̀bi olúwa rẹ̀.

English: Motherhood and childhood are entitled to special care and assistance.
Yoruba: A ní láti pèsè ìtọ́jú àti ìrànlọ́wọ́ pàtàkì fún àwọn abiyamọ àti àwọn ọmọdé.

English: All children, whether born in or out of wedlock, shall enjoy the same social protection.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àwọn ọmọdé yóò máa jẹ àwọn àn fàní ààbò kan náà nínú àwùjọ yálà àwọn òbí wọn fẹ́ ara wọn ni tàbí wọn kò fẹ́ ara wọn.

English: Article 26
Yoruba: Abala kẹrìndínlọ́gbọ̀n

English: Everyone has the right to education.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́.

English: Education shall be free, at least in the elementary and fundamental stages.
Yoruba: Ó kéré tán, ẹ̀kọ́ gbọdọ̀ jẹ́ ọ̀fẹ́ ní àwọn ilé‐ẹ̀kọ́ alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: Elementary education shall be compulsory.
Yoruba: Ẹkọ́ ní ilé‐ẹ̀kọ́ alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀ yìí sì gbọdọ̀ jẹ́ dandan.

English: Technical and professional education shall be made generally available and higher education shall be equally accessible to all on the basis of merit.
Yoruba: A gbọdọ̀ pèsè ẹ̀kọ́ iṣẹ́‐ọwọ́, àti ti ìmọ̀‐ẹ̀rọ fún àwọn ènìyàn lápapọ̀, àn fàní tó dọ́gba ní ilé‐ẹ̀kọ́ gíga gbọdọ̀ wà ní àrọ́wọ́tó gbogbo ẹni tó bá tọ́ sí.

English: Education shall be directed to the full development of the human personality and to the strengthening of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.
Yoruba: Ohun tí yóò jẹ́ ète ẹ̀kọ́ ni láti mú ìlọsíwájú tó péye bá ẹ̀dá ènìyàn, kí ó sì túbọ̀ rí i pé àwọn ènìyàn bọ̀wọ̀ fún ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti àwọn òmìnira wọn, tó jẹ́ kò‐ṣeé‐má‐nìí.

English: It shall promote understanding, tolerance and friendship among all nations, racial or religious groups, and shall further the activities of the United Nations for the maintenance of peace.
Yoruba: E tò ẹ̀kọ́ gbọdọ̀ lè rí i pé ẹ̀mí; ìgbọ́ra‐ẹni‐yé, ìbágbépọ̀ àlàáfíà, àti ìfẹ́ ọ̀rẹ́‐sí‐ọ̀rẹ́ wà láàrin orílẹ̀‐èdè, láàrin ẹ̀yà kan sí òmíràn àti láàrin ẹlẹ́sìn kan sí òmíràn, etò‐ẹ̀kọ́ sì gbọdọ̀ kún àwọn akitiyan Àjọ‐ìsọ̀kan orílẹ̀‐èdè àgbáyé lọ́wọ́ láti rí i pé àlàáfíà fìdí múlẹ̀.

English: Parents have a prior right to choose the kind of education that shall be given to their children.
Yoruba: Àwọn òbí ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ tó ga jù lọ láti yan ẹ̀kọ́ tí wọ́n bá fẹ́ fún àwọn ọmọ wọn.

English: Article 27
Yoruba: Abala kẹtàdínlọ́gbọ̀n

English: Everyone has the right freely to participate in the cultural life of the community, to enjoy the arts and to share in scientific advancement and its benefits.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láìjẹ́ pé a fi ipá mú un láti kópa nínú àpapọ̀ ìgbé ayé àwùjọ rẹ̀, kí ó jẹ ìgbádùn gbogbo ohun àmúṣẹ wà ibẹ̀, kí ó sì kópa nínú ìdàgbàsókè ìmọ̀ sáyẹ́n sì àti àwọn àn fàní tó ń ti ibẹ̀ jáde.

English: Everyone has the right to the protection of the moral and material interests resulting from any scientific, literary or artistic production of which he is the author.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ààbò àn fàní ìmọyì àti ohun ìní tí ó jẹ yọ láti inú iṣẹ́ yòówù tí ó bá ṣe ìbáà ṣe ìmọ̀ sáyẹ́n sì, ìwé kíkọ tàbí iṣẹ́ ọnà.

English: Article 28
Yoruba: Abala kejìdínlọ́gbọ̀n

English: Everyone is entitled to a social and international order in which the rights and freedoms set forth in this Declaration can be fully realized.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ sí ètò nínú àwùjọ rẹ̀ àti ní gbogbo àwùjọ àgbáyé níbi tí àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ òmìnira tí a ti gbé kalẹ̀ nínú ìkéde yìí yóò ti jẹ́ mímúṣẹ.

English: Article 29
Yoruba: Abala kọkàndínlọ́gbọ̀n

English: Everyone has duties to the community in which alone the free and full development of his personality is possible.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní àwọn ojúṣe kan sí àwùjọ, nípasẹ̀ èyí tí ó fi lè ṣeé ṣe fún ẹni náà láti ní ìdàgbàsókè kíkún gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ̀dá ènìyàn.

English: In the exercise of his rights and freedoms, everyone shall be subject only to such limitations as are determined by law solely for the purpose of securing due recognition and respect for the rights and freedoms of others and of meeting the just requirements of morality, public order and the general welfare in a democratic society.
Yoruba: O fin yóò de ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan láti fi ọ̀wọ̀ àti ìmọyì tí ó tọ́ fún ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira àwọn ẹlòmíràn nígbà tí ẹni náà bá ń lo àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira ara rẹ̀,  eyí wà ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú ọ̀nà tó yẹ, tó sì tọ́ láti fi báni lò nínú àwùjọ fún ire àti àlàáfíà àwùjọ náà nínú èyí tí ìjọba yóò wà lọ́wọ́ gbogbo ènìyàn.

English: These rights and freedoms may in no case be exercised contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ lo àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira wọ̀nyí rárá, ní ọ̀nà yòówù kó jẹ́, tó bá lòdì sí àwọn ète àti ìgbékalẹ̀ Ajọ‐àpapọ̀ orílẹ̀‐èdè agbáyé.

English: Article 30
Yoruba: Abala ọgbọ̀n

English: Nothing in this Declaration may be interpreted as implying for any State, group or person any right to engage in any activity or to perform any act aimed at the destruction of any of the rights and freedoms set forth herein.
Yoruba: A kò gbọdọ̀ túmọ̀ ohunkóhun nínú ìkéde yìí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó fún orílẹ̀‐èdè kan tàbí àkójọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn kan tàbí ẹnìkẹ́ni ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti ṣe ohunkóhun tí yóò mú ìparun bá èyíkéyìí nínú àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ àti òmìnira tí a kéde yìí.

English: When immigrants are threatened with roundups, detention and deportations, their employers know that they can be abused, that they can be told that if they fight back, they'll be turned over to ICE.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń dúkokò mọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri pẹ̀lú ìkójọpọ̀, ìtì-mọ́lé àti ìdápadà-sílé, àwọn òṣìṣẹ wọn mọ̀ pé wọ́n lè bú wọn, pé wọ́n lè sọ fún wọn pé tí wọ́n bá jà padà, wọ́n lè fàwón fún ICE.

English: When employers know that they can terrorize an immigrant with his lack of papers, it makes that worker hyper-exploitable, and that has impacts not only for immigrant workers but for all workers.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn agbanisíṣẹ́ bá mọ pé àwọn lè dúkokò mọ́ aṣíkiri pẹ̀lú àìníwè rẹ̀, ó máa ń jẹ́ kí wọ́n lo òṣìṣẹ́ yẹn nílò kulò kọjá àyè, ìyẹn sì ti nípa kìí ṣe fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ aṣíkiri nìkan ṣùgbọ́n fún gbogbo àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.

English: Second, we need to ask questions about responsibility.
Yoruba: Ìkejì, a nílò láti bèrè ìbéèrè nípa ojúṣe.

English: What role have rich, powerful countries like the United States played in making it hard or impossible for immigrants to stay in their home countries?
Yoruba: Kíni ipa tí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó lówó, tó lágbára bíi orílẹ̀-ède United State ń kó láti jẹ́ kó le tàbí kó má ṣe é ṣe fún àwọn aṣíkiri láti dúró sí orílè-èdè abínibí wọn?

English: Picking up and moving from your country is difficult and dangerous, but many immigrants simply do not have the option of staying home if they want to survive.
Yoruba: Ìdìde àti gbígbéra láti orílẹ̀-ède yín nira ó sì léwu, ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aṣíkiri ò ní àǹfààní ìdúró sílé tí wọ́n bá fẹ́ yè.

English: Wars, trade agreements and consumer habits rooted in the Global North play a major and devastating role here.
Yoruba: Ogun, àdéhùn òwò àti ìwa oníbárá tó gbilẹ̀ ní Global North ń kópa pàtàkì àti aléwu níbí.

English: What responsibilities do the United States, the European Union and China -- the world's leading carbon emitters -- have to the millions of people already uprooted by global warming?
Yoruba: Ojúṣe wo ni orílẹ̀-ède United State àti China -- àwọn tí wọ́n ń léwájú níbi ìgbéjáde òyì-èédú lágbàáyé -- ní sí ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ènìyàn tí ìgbóná àgbáyé ti ṣí nídì?

English: And third, we need to ask questions about equality.
Yoruba: Ìkẹ́ta, a nílò láti bèrè ìbéèrè nípa ìdọ́gba.

English: Global inequality is a wrenching, intensifying problem.
Yoruba: Aìdọ́gba àgbáyé jẹ́ ìṣòro tó ń rún nǹkan, t’ó sì lágbára.

English: Income and wealth gaps are widening around the world.
Yoruba: Àlàfo ìpawó-wọlé àti ọrọ̀ ń fẹjú jákèjádò àgbáyé.

English: Increasingly, what determines whether you're rich or poor, more than anything else, is what country you're born in, which might seem great if you're from a prosperous country.
Yoruba: Ní àlékún, nǹkan tó ń sọ bóyá ẹ lówó tàbí tòṣì, ju nǹkan mìíràn lọ, ni orílé-èdè wo ni wọ́n bíi yín sí, tó lè dàbi ẹni pé ó lágbára tí ẹ bá wá láti orílẹ̀-èdè tó làmìlaaka.

English: But it actually means a profoundly unjust distribution of the chances for a long, healthy, fulfilling life.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó túmọ sí ìpín àìṣedédé alágbára àwọn àǹfààní fún ìgbeayé pípẹ́, alálàáfíà, onítẹ́lọ́rùn.

English: When immigrants send money or goods home to their family, it plays a significant role in narrowing these gaps, if a very incomplete one.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn aṣíkiri bá fi owó tàbí ẹrù ránṣẹ́ sílé sí ẹbí wọn, ó máa ń kó ipa tó ṣe pàtàkì níbi ṣíṣe àdínkù àwọn àlàfo wọ̀nyí, tí ó bá jẹ́ èyí tí ò pé.

English: It does more than all of the foreign aid programs in the world combined.
Yoruba: Ó ṣe ju gbogbo àwọn ètò ìrànwọ́ ilẹ̀ òkèèrè ní àgbáríjọpọ̀ àgbáyé lọ.

English: We began with the nativist questions, about immigrants as tools, as others and as parasites.
Yoruba: A bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìbéèrè àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú, nípa àwọn aṣíkiri gẹ́gẹ́ bi irinṣẹ́, gẹ́gẹ́ bi àwọn tó kù àti ajọ̀fẹ́.

English: Where might these new questions about worker rights, about responsibility and about equality take us?
Yoruba: Níbo ni àwọn ìbéèrè tuntun wọ̀nyí nípa ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, nípa ojúṣe àti nípa ìdógba ń múwa lọ?

English: These questions reject pity, and they embrace justice.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí kọ ìkáàánú, wọ́n sì gba ìṣedédé.

English: These questions reject the nativist and nationalist division of us versus them.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí kọ ìpínyà àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn àpapọ̀ nípa àwa kojú àwọn.

English: They're going to help prepare us for problems that are coming and problems like global warming that are already upon us.
Yoruba: Wọn yóò rànwá lọ́wọ́ láti múra sílẹ̀ fún àwọn ìṣòro tó ń bọ̀ àti àwọn ìṣòro bíi ìgbóná àgbáyé t’ó ti wà lórí wa.

English: It's not going to be easy to turn away from the questions that we've been asking towards this new set of questions.
Yoruba: Kò ní rọrùn láti yí kúrò níbi àwọn ìbéèrè tí a ti ń bérè nípa sẹ́ẹ́tì àwọn ìbéèrè tuntun yìí.

English: It's no small challenge to take on and broaden the borders of us.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe ìdojúkọ kékeré láti kojú k’á sì fẹ àwọn enubodè wa.

English: It will take wit, inventiveness and courage.
Yoruba: Ó máa gba ọgbọ́n, ìṣẹ̀dá àti ìgbóyà.

English: The old questions have been with us for a long time, and they're not going to give way on their own, and they're not going to give way overnight.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè àtijọ́ ti wà pẹ̀lu wa fún ìgbà pípẹ́, wọn ò sì ní bìlà fúnra wọn, tí wọn ò sì ní bìlà lọ́sàán-kan óru-kan.

English: And even if we manage to change the questions, the answers are going to be complicated, and they're going to require sacrifices and tradeoffs.
Yoruba: Kódà tí a bá gbìyànjú láti ṣe àyípadà àwọn ìbéèrè náà, àwọn ìdáhùn náà máa jẹ́ àmúdijú, wọ́n sì máa gba ìfarajìn àti ìṣedédé.

English: And in an unequal world, we're always going to have to pay attention to the question of who has the power to join the conversation and who doesn't.
Yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè àgbáyé tí ò dọ́gba, a máà nílò láti fi ọkàn sí ìbéèrè pé ta ló ní agbára láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àsọgbà náà àti eni tí ò ní.

English: But the borders of the immigration debate can be moved.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn enubòdè àríyànjiyàn ìwọlé látókèrè lè di sísún.

English: It's up to all of us to move them.
Yoruba: Ó dọwọ́ gbogbo wa láti sún wọn.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: What I learned about freedom after escaping North Korea
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí mo kò nípa òmìnira lẹ́yìn tí mo sá kúrò ní  orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: I was born in 1993 in the northern part of North Korea, in a town called Hyesan, which is on the border with China.
Yoruba: Wọ́n bí mi ní ọdún 1993 ní apá àríwá orílẹ̀-ède North Korea, ní agbègbè kan tí wọ́n ń pè ní Hyesan, tó wà pààlà pẹ̀lú orílẹ̀-ède China

English: I had loving parents and one older sister.
Yoruba: Mo ní àwọn òbí tí wọ́n nífẹ̀ẹ́ àti ẹ̀gbọ́n obìnrin kan.

English: Before I was even 10 years old, my father was sent to a labor camp for engaging in illegal trading.
Yoruba: Kí n tiẹ̀ tó pé ọmọ ọdún mẹ́wà, wọ́n rán bàbá mi lọ sí ìpàgọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún kíkópa nínú ìṣòwò àìbófinmu.

English: Now, by "illegal trading" -- he was selling clogs, sugar, rice and later copper to feed us.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, pẹ̀lú “ìṣòwò àìbófinmu”-- ó ń ta bàtà, ṣúgà, ìrẹsì lẹ́yìn náà kọ́pà láti fi bọ́ wa.

English: In 2007, my sister and I decided to escape.
Yoruba: Ní ọdún 2007, èmi àti ọmọ ìyá mi lóbìnrin pinnu láti sálọ.

English: She was 16 years old, and I was 13 years old.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́rìn-dín-lógún, èmí sì jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́tàlá.

English: I need you to understand what the word "escape" means in the context of North Korea.
Yoruba: Mo nílò láti jẹ́ kí ẹ mọ nǹkan tí ọ̀rọ̀ yìí “sálọ” túmọ̀ sí ní ní ọ̀gangan ipò orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: We were all starving, and hunger means death in North Korea.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa ni ebi ń pa, ebí sì túmọ̀ sí ikú ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea,

English: So it was the only option for us.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ àǹfààní kan ṣoṣo fún wa.

English: I didn't even understand the concept of escape, but I could see the lights from China at night, and I wondered if I go where the light is, I might be able to find a bowl of rice.
Yoruba: Mi ò ti lẹ̀ lóye nípa èrò sísálọ, ṣùgbọ́n mo máa ń rí àwọn iná náà láti China lálẹ́,  mo sì rò ó pé bóyá tí mo bá lọ síbi tí iná náà wà, mo lè rí abọ́ ìrẹsì kan.

English: It's not like we had a grand plan or maps.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe wí pé a ní ìpinnu alágbára tàbí àwòrán kankan.

English: We did not know anything about what was going to happen.
Yoruba: A ò mọ nǹkankan nípa nǹkan tí yóò ṣẹlẹ̀.

English: Imagine your apartment building caught fire.
Yoruba: Ẹ wòye pé ilé ìgbe yín gbaná.

English: I mean, what would you do?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, kí lẹ máa se?

English: Would you stay there to be burned, or would you jump off out of the window and see what happens?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ máa dùró síbẹ̀ kí ẹ jóná ni, àbi ṣé ẹ máa fò jáde kúrò látojú fèrèsé kí ẹ sì wá wo ohun tí yóó ṣelẹ̀?

English: That's what we did.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí a ṣe nìyẹn.

English: We jumped out of the house instead of the fire.
Yoruba: A fò jáde kúrò nínú ilé náà dípò iná.

English: North Korea is unimaginable.
Yoruba: North Korea jẹ́ ibi tí ẹ ò leè ronú nípa rẹ̀.

English: It's very hard for me when people ask me what it feels like to live there.
Yoruba: Ó máa nira fún mi nígbà tí àwọn ènìyàn bá bi mí bó ṣe rí láti gbé nígbẹ̀.

English: To be honest, I tell you: you can't even imagine it.
Yoruba: Ká sọ tòótọ́, mo sọ fún yín: ẹ ò lè ronú nípa rẹ̀.

English: The words in any language can't describe, because it's a totally different planet, as you cannot imagine your life on Mars right now.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ inú èyíkéyìí èdè ò lè ṣàpèjúwe rẹ̀, nítorí àgbáyé tó yátọ̀ pátápátá ni, bí ẹ ò ṣe lè ronú ìgbésíayé yín nínú Ìsọ̀ngbè-oòrùn-kẹ́rin lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: For example, the word "love" has only one meaning: love for the Dear Leader.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ọ̀rọ yìí “ìfẹ́” ní ìtumọ̀ kan ṣoṣo: ìfẹ́ fún adarí wa ọ̀wọ́n.

English: There's no concept of romantic love in North Korea.
Yoruba: Kò sí èrò ìfẹ́ ẹlẹ́yẹlé ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea

English: And if you don't know the words, that means you don't understand the concept, and therefore, you don't even realize that concept is even a possibility.
Yoruba: Tí ẹ ò bá mọ àwọn ọ̀rọ náà, ìyẹ́n túmọ̀ sí wí pé èrò náà ò ye yín, nítorí náà, ẹ ò ní mọ̀ pé èrò yẹn gan-an jẹ́ a ṣe é ṣe.

English: Let me give you another example.
Yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n fún yín ní àpẹẹrẹ mìíràn.

English: Growing up in North Korea, we truly believed that our Dear Leader is an almighty god who can even read my thoughts.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mò ń dàgbà ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea, a nígbàgbọ́ lódodo wí pé adarí wa ọ̀wọ́n jẹ́ òòṣà tó lágbára tó lè mọ èro ọkàn wa.

English: I was even afraid to think in North Korea.
Yoruba: Èrú tún bàmí láti ronú nípa orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: We are told that he's starving for us, and he's working tirelessly for us, and my heart just broke for him.
Yoruba: Wọ́n sọ fún wa pé ó ń f’ebi panú fún wa, ó sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ láìkáàrẹ̀ fún wa, ọkàn mí sì gbọgbẹ́ fún-un.

English: When I escaped to South Korea, people told me that he was actually a dictator, he had cars, many, many resorts, and he had an ultraluxurious life.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo sálọ sí orílẹ̀-ède South Korea, àwọn ènìyán sọ fún mi wí pé apàṣẹ wàá ni, ó ní àwọn ọkọ̀, oríṣiríṣi ilé-ìgbafẹ́, ó sì ń gbé ìgbeayé olówó ńlá.

English: And then I remember looking at a picture of him, realizing for the first time that he is the largest guy in the picture.
Yoruba: Nígbà náà ni mo bá rántí wíwo àwòran rẹ̀ kan, mímọ̀ fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ pé òun lẹni tó tóbi jù nínú àwòrán náà.

English: And it hit me.
Yoruba: Ló bá yémi.

English: Finally, I realized he wasn't starving.
Yoruba: Nígbẹ́yìn, mo mọ̀ wí pé ebi ò pa á.

English: But I was never able to see that before, until someone told me that he was fat.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mi ò ní àǹfààní láti rí èyí tẹ́lẹ̀, àyàfi ìgbà tí ẹnìkan sọ fún mi wí pé òún sanra.

English: Really, someone had to teach me that he was fat.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, ẹnìkán ní láti kọ́ mi pé òún sanra.

English: If you have never practiced critical thinking, then you simply see what you're told to see.
Yoruba: Tí ẹ ò bà tíì ṣe ìfikọ́ra ìrònú jinlẹ̀ rí, nǹkan tí wọ́n bá ní kí ẹ rí lẹ máa rìí.

English: The biggest question also people ask me is: "Why is there no revolution inside North Korea?
Yoruba: Ìbéèrè tó tóbi jù tí àwọn èniyàn máa ń bi mí ni: “Kí ló dé tí ò sí ìjàngbara nínú orílẹ̀-ède North Korea?

English: Are we dumb?
Yoruba: Ṣé odi niwá ni?

English: Why is there no revolution for 70 years of this oppression?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí ò sí ìjàngbara fún ìnira àádọ́rin ọdún yìí

English: " And I say: If you don't know you're a slave, if you don't know you're isolated or oppressed, how do you fight to be free?
Yoruba: “ Ti mo bá sọ wí pé: tí ẹ ò bá mọ̀ wí pé ẹrú niyín, tí ẹ ò bá mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n yà yín sọ́tọ̀ tàbí wọ́n ń fara niyín, báwo lẹ ṣe fẹ́ jà láti gba ìtúsílẹ̀?

English: I mean, if you know you're isolated, that means you are not isolated.
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, tí ẹ bá mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n yà yín sọ́tọ̀, ó túmọ̀ sí wí pé wọn ò yà yín sọ́tọ̀.

English: Not knowing is the true definition of isolation, and that's why I never knew I was isolated when I was in North Korea.
Yoruba: Àìmọ̀ ni ìtumọ̀ ìyanisọ́tọ̀ lódodo, ìdí nìyẹn tí mi ò fi mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n yàmí sọ́tọ̀ ni nígbà tí mo wà ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: I literally thought I was in the center of the universe.
Yoruba: Mo rò wí pé mo wà láàrín-gbùgbun àgbáyé ni.

English: So here is my idea worth spreading: a lot of people think humans inherently know what is right and wrong, the difference between justice and injustice, what we deserve and we don't deserve.
Yoruba: Èrò mi tó yẹ fún ìfọ́nká rè é: ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyán rò wí pé ọmọ ènìyàn mọ nǹkan tó yẹ àti èyí tó burú jáì, ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàárín ìṣedédé àti àìṣedédé, nǹkan tó tọ́ síwa àti nǹkan tí ò tọ́ síwa.

English: I tell them: BS.
Yoruba: Mo sọ fún wọn: BS.

English: Everything, everything must be taught, including compassion.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ẹ̀, gbogbo ẹ̀ gbọ́dọ̀ di kíkọ́, tó fi kan àánú.

English: If I see someone dying on the street right now, I will do anything to save that person.
Yoruba: Bí mo bá rí enìkan tó ń kú lọ láàárín adúgbò nísìyìí, mà á ṣe ohun-kóhun láti dóòlà ẹni náà.

English: But when I was in North Korea, I saw people dying and dead on the streets.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà ti mo wà ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea, mo rí àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń kú àti òkú káàkiri àdúgbò.

English: I felt nothing.
Yoruba: Mi ò ní ìmọ̀lára kankan.

English: Not because I'm a psychopath, but because I never learned the concept of compassion.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe nítorí mo jẹ́ ọlọ́dẹ-orí, ṣùgbọ́n nítorí mi ò kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa èrò ìkáànú rí.

English: Only, I felt compassion, empathy and sympathy in my heart after I learned the word "compassion" and the concept, and I feel them now.
Yoruba: Mo ní ìmọ̀láa àánú, ìbánikẹ́dùn àti ìkáànú nínú ọkàn mi lẹ́yìn ìgbà tí mo kọ́ nípa ọ̀rọ̀ yìí “àánú” àti èro rẹ̀ nìkan, mo sì ní ìmọ̀lára wọn báyìí.

English: Now I live in the United States as a free person.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí mò ń gbé ní orílẹ̀-ède United State gẹ́gẹ́ bi olómìnira ènìyàn.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: And recently, the leader of the free country, our President Trump, met with my former god.
Yoruba: Láìpẹ́ yìí, àwọn adarí orílẹ̀-èdè olómìnira, Ààrẹ wa Trump, ṣe ìpàdé pẹ̀lú òòsa mi tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: And he decided human rights is not important enough to include in his agendas, and he did not talk about it.
Yoruba: Ó sì pinnu pé ẹ̀tọ ọmọ ènìyàn ò ṣe pàtàkì tó láti fi kún ìpinnu rẹ̀, kò sì sọ̀rọ̀ nípa rẹ̀.

English: And it scares me.
Yoruba: Ó bà mí lẹ́rù.

English: We live in a world right now where a dictator can be praised for executing his uncle, for killing his half brother, killing thousands of North Koreans.
Yoruba: Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí à ń gbé nínú ayé níbi tí wọ́n ti lè gbóríyìn fún apàṣe-wàá kan pé ó pa ọmọ ìya bàba rẹ̀ lọ́kùrin, fún pípa ọmọ ìyàwo bàba rẹ̀, pípa ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède North korea.

English: And that was worthy of praise.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn sì tó nǹkan à ń gbóríyìn fún.

English: And also it made me think: perhaps we all need to be taught something new about freedom now.
Yoruba: Bákan náà ó múmi ronú: bóyá gbogbo wa la nílò láti kọ́ nǹkan tuntun nípa òmìnira báyìí.

English: Freedom is fragile.
Yoruba: Nǹkan ẹlẹgẹ́ ni òmìnira

English: I don't want to alarm you, but it is.
Yoruba: Mi ò fẹ́ fun yín lára, ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ ni.

English: It only took three generations to make North Korea into George Orwell's "1984.
Yoruba: Ìran mẹ́ta péré ló gbà láti sọ orílẹ̀-ède North Korea di “1984 ti Goorge Orwell

English: " It took only three generations.
Yoruba: Ìran mẹ́ta péré ló gbà.

English: If we don't fight for human rights for the people who are oppressed right now who don't have a voice, as free people here, who will fight for us when we are not free?
Yoruba: Bí a ò bá jà fún ètọ ọmọnìyàn fún àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń fìyà jẹ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí tí wọn ò lè fohùn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n lómìnira níbí, ta ló máa jà fún wa nígbà tí a ò bá ní òmìnira?

English: I don't know.
Yoruba: Mi ò mọ̀.

English: I think it's wonderful that we care about climate change, animal rights, gender equality, all of these things.
Yoruba: Mo rò wí pé ó dára pé a káràmásìkí mọ́ àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́, ẹ̀tọ́ ẹranko, ìṣedédé láàárín akọ àti abo, gbogbo àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí.

English: The fact that we care about animals' rights, that means that's how beautiful our heart is, that we care about someone who cannot speak for themselves.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ pé a káràmásìki nípa ẹ̀tọ́ ẹranko, ìyẹ́n túmọ̀ sí wí pé bí ọkàn wa ṣe rewà sí nìyẹn, pé a káràmásìkí nípa enìkan tí ò le fi ẹnu arawọn sọ̀rọ̀.

English: And North Koreans right now cannot speak for themselves.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ North Korea ò lè fi ẹnu arawọn sọ̀rọ̀ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: They don't have internet in the 21st century.
Yoruba: Wọn ò ní ẹ̀rọ-ayélukára-bí-ajere ní ọ̀rún ọdún kọkàn-lé-lógún.

English: We don't have electricity, and it is the darkest place on earth right now.
Yoruba: A ò ní iná mọ̀nàmọ́ná, òhun sì ni àyè tó ṣókùnkùn jù lórí ilẹ̀ eèpẹ̀ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: Now I want to say something to my fellow North Koreans who are living in that darkness.
Yoruba: Báyìí mo fẹ́ sọ nǹkankan fún àwọn tí a jìjọ jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ North Korea tí wọ́n ń gbé nínú òkùkùn yẹn.

English: They might not believe this, but I want to tell them that an alternative life is possible.
Yoruba: Wọ́n lè má gba èyí gbọ́, ṣùgbọ́n mo fẹ́ sọ fún wọn pé ìpààrọ ìgbésí-ayé ṣe é ṣe.

English: Be free.
Yoruba: Ẹ gba ìtúsílẹ̀
