English: From my experience, literally anything is possible.
Yoruba: Látara ìrírí mi, gbogbo nǹkan ló ṣe é ṣe.

English: I was bought, I was sold as a slave.
Yoruba: Wón rà mí, wọ́n tà mí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹrú.

English: But now I'm here, and that is why I believe in miracles.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní báyìí mo ti wà níbí, ìyẹn ló sì fà á tí mo fi nígbàgbọ́ nínú iṣẹ́-ìyanu.

English: The one thing that I learned from history is that nothing is forever in this world.
Yoruba: Nǹkan kan tí mo kọ́ nínú ìtàn ni wí pé kò sí nǹkankan tó lọ títí nínú ayé yìí.

English: And that is why we have every reason to be hopeful.
Yoruba: Ìdí nìyẹn tí a fi ní gbogbo ẹ̀tọ́ láti ní ìrètí.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: Medical tech designed to meet Africa's needs
Yoruba: Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ìṣègùn tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀dá láti pèse ohun tí ilẹ̀ Adúláwò nílò.

English: Like every passionate software engineer out there, I closely follow technology companies in Silicon Valley, pretty much the same way soccer fans follow their teams in Europe.
Yoruba: Bíi gbogbo onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ nípa ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn tí wọ́n wà níta níbẹ̀ yẹn, mo máa ń tẹ̀lé alwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ní Silicon Valley típẹ́-típẹ́, ní ọ̀nà kan náà tí àwọn olólùfẹ́ eré bólù aláfẹsẹ̀gbá ṣe ń tẹ̀lé ikọ̀ wọn nílẹ̀ Europe.

English: I read articles on tech blogs and listen to podcasts on my phone.
Yoruba: Mo máa ń ka àròkọ lórí ìkànnì ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ mo sì máa ń tẹ́ti sí àkáálẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ-agbagbe lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ mi.

English: But after I finish the article, lock my phone and unplug the headphones, I'm back in sub-Saharan Africa, where the landscape is not quite the same.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn tí mo bá parí átíkù náà, tí mo ti ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ mi tí mo sì yọ àgbékarí, mo ti padà sí ìwò oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwò, níbi ti ààla-ilẹ̀ ò ti jọra wọn.

English: We have long and frequent power outages, low penetration of computers, slow internet connections and a lot of patients visiting understaffed hospitals.
Yoruba: Iná máa ń lọ fún ìgbà pípé lọ́pọ̀-ìgbà, àìlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá púpọ̀, ìkàni ayélukára tí ò yára àti ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aláìsàn tí wọ́n lọ sílé ìwòsàn tí kò sí òṣìṣẹ́ púpọ̀.

English: Since the HIV epidemic, hospitals have been struggling to manage regular HIV treatment records for increasing volumes of patients.
Yoruba: Látìgbà àjàkálẹ̀ àrun kòkòro apa òkì àjẹsára àìfààyègba-àìsàn ara, àwọn ilé ìwòsàn tí ń tiraka láti ṣàmójútó àkọsílẹ̀ ìtọ́jú kòkòro apa sójà ara lóòrèkóòrè fún àlékún abala àwọn aláìsàn.

English: For such environments, importing technology systems developed elsewhere has not worked, but in 2006, I joined Baobab Health, a team that uses locally based engineers to develop suitable interventions that are addressing health care challenges in Malawi.
Yoruba: Fún irú àwùjọ bẹ́ẹ̀, gbigbé èto ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀dá níbòmíràn ò tíì ṣiṣẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n ní ọdún 2006, mo darapọ̀ mọ́ Baoba Health, ikọ̀ kan tó máa ń lo àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lábẹ́lé láti ṣẹ̀da àwọn ìdásí tó yẹ tí wọ́n ń yanjú àwọn ìdojúkọ ajẹmọ ìtọ́jú ní orílẹ̀-ède Malawi

English: We designed an electronic health record system that is used by health care workers while seeing patients.
Yoruba: A ṣẹ̀da ẹ̀rọ tó ń ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ ìlera onínọ́ tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera ń lò nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń rí àwọn aláìsàn.

English: And in the process we realized that we not only had to design the software, we had to implement the infrastructure as well.
Yoruba: Nínú ìgbésẹ̀ náà a mọ̀ pé a ò ní láti ṣẹ̀da ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn nìkan, a ní láti ṣàmúlò ohun amáyédẹrùn náà bákan náà.

English: We don't have enough medical staff to comprehensively examine every patient, so we embedded clinical guidelines within the software to guide nurses and clerks who assist with handling some of the workload.
Yoruba: A ò ní àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera tó tó láti ṣe àyèwò tó péye fún gbogbo aláìsàn, nítorí náà a ṣe àfibọ̀ ìlànà-ìtọ́sánà ajẹmọ́ ìtọ́jú sínu ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn náà láti ṣe ìtọ́sánà àwọn olùtọ́-ilé-ìwòsàn àti àwọn akọ̀wé tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ pẹ̀lú ìmójútó díẹ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́ náà.

English: Everyone has a birthday, but not everyone knows their birthday, so we wrote algorithms to handle estimated birthdates as complete dates.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa la ní ọjọ́ ìbí, ṣùgbọ́n kìí ṣe gbogbo ènìyàn ló mọ ọjọ́ ìbi wọn, nítorí náà a kọ àwọn ètò láti mójútó àpapọ̀ àwọn ọjọ́ ìbí gẹ́gẹ́ bi déétì tó pé.

English: How do we follow up patients living in slums with no street and house numbers?
Yoruba: Báwo la ó ṣe ṣe ìtẹ̀lé àwọn aláìsàn tí wọ́n ń gbé ní àdúgbò elérò tí ò ní nọ́mbà àdúgbò àti ilé?

English: We used landmarks to approximate their physical addresses.
Yoruba: A lo ààla-ilẹ̀ láti ṣe àròpọ̀ àdírẹ́sì àfojúrí wọn.

English: Malawi had no IDs to uniquely identify patients, so we had to implement unique patient IDs to link patient records across clinics.
Yoruba: Orílẹ̀-ède Malawi ò ní ID láti ṣe ìdánimọ̀ àwọn aláìsàn yàtọ̀, nítorí náà a ní láti ṣàmúlò ID àwọn aláìsàn tó yátọ̀ láti ṣe àsopọ̀ àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn aláìsàn jákèjádò àwọn ilé ìtọ́jú.

English: The IDs are printed as barcodes on labels that are stuck on personal health booklets kept by each patient.
Yoruba: A ṣe àtẹ̀jáde àwọn ID náà gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹ̀nà onílà òòró tí wọ́n lè mọ́ àwọn ìwé ìlera àdáni tí aláìsàn kọ̀ọ̀kan ń tọ́jú.

English: With this barcoded ID, a simple scan with a barcode reader quickly pulls up the patient's records.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ID tó ní ẹ̀nà onílà òòró yìí, ìfojúwò gara tíò le pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rọ tó ń ka ẹ̀nà onílà òòró yóò tètè gbé àkọsílẹ̀ aláìsàn náà síta.

English: No need to rewrite their personal details on paper registers at every visit.
Yoruba: Wọn ò nílò láti ṣe àtúnkọ àlàyé nípa ara wọn sóri ewé ìforúkọsílẹ̀ ní gbogbo ìgbà tí wọ́n bá wá.

English: And suddenly, queues became shorter.
Yoruba: Lójijì, àwọn ilà-ìtò bá di kúkurú

English: This meant patients, typically mothers with little children on their backs, had to spend less time waiting to be assisted.
Yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn aláìsàn, àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n lọ́mọ lẹ́yìn wọn nìkan, yóò lo àsìkò díẹ̀ ní ìdúró de ìrànlọ́wọ́

English: And if they lose their booklets, their records can still be pulled by searching with their names.
Yoruba: Bí wọ́n bá ṣe àfẹ́kù ìwe wọn, àkọsílẹ̀ wọn ṣì lè di gbígbà pẹ̀lú wíwá orúkọ wọn.

English: Now, the way we pronounce and spell names varies tremendously.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ònà tí à ń gbà pè àti kọ orúkọ yátọ̀ gidi gan-an.

English: We freely mix R's and L's, English and vernacular versions of their names.
Yoruba: A ṣe àdàpọ̀ R àti L láìsídìwọ́, ẹ̀dà ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì àti ède abínibí àwọn orúkọ wọn.

English: Even soundex, a standard method for grouping words by how similar they sound, was not good enough.
Yoruba: Kódà ìjọra-ìró, ìlànà àwòkọ́ṣe fún ìpín-sísọ̀rí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú bí wọ́n ṣe jọra ní ìró, kò dára tó.

English: So we had to modify it to help us link and match existing records.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà a ní láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí i láti lè bá wa ṣe àsopọ̀ àti ìbámu àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ tó ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: Before the iPhone, software engineers developed for personal computers, but from our experience, we knew our power system is not reliable enough for personal computers.
Yoruba: Ṣíwájú iPhone, àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ nípa ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn ṣẹ̀da rẹ̀ fún ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àdáni, ṣùgbọ́n látara ìrírí wa, a mọ̀ pé èto agbára wa ò ṣe é gbáralé fún ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àdáni.

English: So we repurposed touch screen point-of-sale terminals that are meant for retail shops to become clinical workstations.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà a ṣe àmúyẹ àwọn ẹ̀rọ ibi-ìtajà agbàwòrán-tàn-aláfọwọ́tẹ̀ tí wọ́n wà fún àwọn ìsọ̀ alárà-tún-tà láti di ẹ̀rọ-iṣẹ́ ajẹmọ́wòsàn.

English: At the time, we imported internet appliances called i-Openers that were manufactured during the dot-com era by a failed US company.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò náà, a ṣe ìkówọlé àwọn ohun-èlò ayélukára-bí-ajere tí wọ́n pè ní i-Opener tí wọ́n ṣe sànmání ìtakùn ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àmì ti ìṣe òwò ní ilé-iṣẹ́ kan tí ó fìdí rẹmi ní orílẹ̀-ède US.

English: We modified their screens to add touch sensors and their power system to run from rechargeable batteries.
Yoruba: A ṣe àtúnṣe àtẹ agbàwòrán tàn wọn láti ṣe àfikún iyè ìfọwọ́kàn àti èto agbára-mànàmáná wọn láti lè ṣiṣẹ́ lára òkúta-agbagbará-iná-àsọdọ̀tun.

English: When we started, we didn't find a reliable network to transmit data, especially from rural hospitals.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí a bẹ̀rẹ̀, a ò rí ojú-òpó-ìsopọ̀ ayélukára-bí-ajere tó ṣe é gbáralé láti ta àtagbà ìwífún-alálàyé, pàápàá jùlọ láti àwọn ilé-ìwòsàn tí wọ́n wà ní ìgbèríko.

English: So we built our own towers, created a wireless network and linked clinics in Lilongwe, Malawi's capital.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà a kọ́ ilé-agbára tiwa, a ṣẹ̀dá àwọn òpó-ìsopọ̀ ayélukára-bí-ajere àìlokùn-agbé-òyì-iná tí a sì so ilé-ìwòsàn alábọ́dé ní Lilongwe, olú ìlu orílẹ̀-ède Malawi pọ̀.

English: With a team of engineers working within a hospital campus, we observed health care workers use the system and iteratively build an information system that is now managing HIV records in all major public hospitals in Malawi.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ikọ̀ àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ láàárín ọgbà ilé-ìwòsàn kan, a ṣe àkíyèsí wí pé àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera ń lo ètò náà wọ́n sì ń ṣẹ̀da ètò ìfitóni t’ó ń ṣe àmójútó àkọsílẹ̀ HIV báyìí ní gbogbo àwọn ilé-ìwòsàn gbogbogbò t’ó tóbi jù ní orílẹ̀-ède Malawi.

English: These are hospitals serving over 2,000 HIV patients, each clinic.
Yoruba: Àwọn wọ̀nyí ni ilé-ìwòsàn tí ń ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn aláìsan HIV tí ó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì, ní ibi ilé-ìwòsàn kọ̀ọ̀kan.

English: Now, health care workers who used to spend days to tally and prepare quarterly reports are producing the same reports within minutes, and health care experts from all over the world are now coming to Malawi to learn how we did it.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera tí wọ́n máa lo àìmọye ọjọ́ láti ṣe àpapọ̀ àti láti ṣèto ìjábọ̀ olóṣù mẹ́ta-mẹ́ta ń ṣe ìjábọ̀ kan náà láàárín ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀, àwọn àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ oníṣẹ́-ìlera káàkiri àgbáyé ti ń wá sí orílẹ̀-ède Malawi láti kọ́ nípa bí a ṣe ṣe é.

English: It is inspiring and fun to follow technology trends across the globe, but to make them work in low-resourced environments like public hospitals in sub-Saharan Africa, we have had to become jacks-of-all-trades and build whole systems, including the infrastructure, from the ground up.
Yoruba: Ó máa wúni lórí ó sì máa ń dùn mọ́ni láti tẹ̀ sí ibi tí àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ń tẹ̀ sí káàkiri àgbáyé, ṣùgbọ́n láti lè jẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣiṣẹ́ ní àwọn agbègbè bíi Gúúsù aṣálẹ̀ Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ tí wọn ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ohun èlò ilé-ìwòsan gbogbogbò, a ní láti di gbogbo-lòwò k’á sì kọ́ ṣe àwọn ètò gbogbo, t’ó fi kan ohun amáyédẹrùn náà, láti ilẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: What's missing from the American immigrant narrative
Yoruba: Kí ló sọnù nínú ìtan àwọn aṣíkiri-lọ-sí-ìlú-mìíràn ilẹ̀ America

English: Hi, everyone, my name is Elizabeth, and I work on the trading floor.
Yoruba: Ẹ ǹlẹ́, gbogbo ènìyàn, orúkọ mi ni Elizabeth, mo sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní àjà ìṣòwò.

English: But I'm still pretty new to it.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ojú mi ò tíì ṣálẹ̀ sí i dáadáa.

English: I graduated from college about a year and a half ago, and to be quite honest, I'm still recovering from the recruiting process I had to go through to get here.
Yoruba: Mo kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde nílé-ẹ̀kọ́ ní bíi odún kan àbọ̀ sẹ́yìn, k’á sì sọ òtítọ́, mo sì ń padà bọ̀ sípò látàrí ìgbésẹ̀ ìgbaniwọlé tí mo ní láti là kọjá láti débí.

English: Now, I don't know about you, but this is the most ridiculous thing that I still remember about the whole process, was asking insecure college students what their biggest passion was.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, mi ò mọ tiyín, ṣùgbọ́n èyí ni nǹkan tó burú jù tí mo ṣì ń rántí nípa gbogbo ìgbésẹ̀ náà, mò ń bèrè lọ́wọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ọkàn wọn ò balẹ̀ ohun tí ìfẹ́ gidigidi wọn t’ó tóbi jù jẹ́.

English: Like, do you expect me to have an answer for that?
Yoruba: Bíi, ṣé e ń retí kí n ní ìdáhùn fún ìyẹn?

English: Of course I did.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ni mo níi.

English: And to be quite honest, I really showed those recruiters just how passionate I was by telling them all about my early interest in the global economy, which, conveniently, stemmed from the conversations that I would overhear my immigrant parents having about money and the fluctuating value of the Mexican peso.
Yoruba: Kín ṣọ òtítọ́, mo fi han àwọn agbaniwọlé wọ̀nyẹn irú ìfẹ́ tí mo ní pẹ̀lú sísọ fún wọn nípa ìfẹ́ àtilẹ̀wá mi nínú ọrọ̀-ajé àgbáyé, tí, pẹ̀lú ìrọ̀rùn, ó ṣẹ́yọ látara àsọgbà tí mo máa ń gbọ́ tí àwọn òbí mi tí wọ́n jẹ́ aṣíkiri máa ń ṣe nípa owó àti àìṣedédé ìwúlò owó peso orílẹ̀-ède Mexico.

English: They love a good personal story.
Yoruba: Wọ́n fẹ́ràn ìtan ara ẹni t’ó dára.

English: But you know what?
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣé ẹ mọ nǹkan?

English: I lied.
Yoruba: Mo parọ́.

English: And not because the things I said weren't true -- I mean, my parents were talking about this stuff.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe nítorí àwọn nǹkan tí mo sọ kì í ṣe ododo -- mò ń sọ nípa pé, àwọn òbí mi ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa kiní yìí.

English: But that's not really why I decided to jump into finance.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan t’ó mú mi pinnu láti ta kọ́sọ́sọ́ sí ìsúná gangan kọ́ nìyẹn.

English: I just really wanted to pay my rent.
Yoruba: Mo kọ̀ fẹ́ san owó ilé mi lásán ni.

English: And here's the thing.
Yoruba: Nǹkan náà rèé.

English: The reality of having to pay my rent and do real adult things is something that we're rarely willing to admit to employers, to others and even to ourselves.
Yoruba: Òótọ́ nípa sísan owó ilé mi kín sì ṣe àwọn nǹkan agbàlagbà tòótọ́ jẹ́ nǹkan tí a ò férẹ̀ nífẹ̀ sí láti sọ fún àwọn olùgbanisíṣẹ́, fún àwọn tókù àti fún ara wa bákan náà.

English: I know I wasn't about to tell my recruiters that I was there for the money.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ wí pé mi ò ṣetán láti sọ fún olùgbanisíṣẹ́ mi pé torí owó ni mo ṣe wá síbẹ̀.

English: And that's because for the most part, we want to see ourselves as idealists and as people who do what they believe in and pursue the things that they find the most exciting.
Yoruba: Ìdi rẹ̀ sì ni wí pé fún ẹ̀yà tó pọ́jù, a fẹ́ rí ara wa gẹ́gẹ́ bi oníròrí àti bí ènìyàn tó mọ nǹkan tó nígbàgbọ́ nínú rẹ̀ tó sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ tọ àwọn nǹkan tó máa ń dùn wọ́n nínú jù.

English: But the reality is very few of us actually have the privilege to do that.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n òtítọ́ ni wí pé díẹ̀ nínú wa ló ní àǹfààní láti ṣe ìyẹn.

English: Now, I can't speak for everyone, but this is especially true for young immigrant professionals like me.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, mi ò le sọ ti gbogbo ènìyàn, ṣùgbọ́n èyí jẹ́ pàáp̀àá òtítọ́ fún ọ̀dọ́ akọṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ aṣíkiri bíi tèmi.

English: And the reason this is true has something to do with the narratives that society has kept hitting us with in the news, in the workplace and even by those annoyingly self-critical voices in our heads.
Yoruba: Ìdí tí èyí fi jẹ́ òdodo ní nǹkan ṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn ìtàn tí àwùjọ ti fín gbá wa nínú ìròyìn, níbi iṣẹ́ àti àwọn ohùn líle tó ń bíni nínú wọ̀nyẹn nínú orí wa.

English: So what narratives am I referring to?
Yoruba: Torí náà ìtàn wo ni mò ń tọ́ka sí?

English: Well, there's two that come to mind when it comes to immigrants.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, awọn méjì kan máa ń wá sórí ẹ̀mí tí ó bá di ọ̀rọ̀ àwọn aṣíkiri.

English: The first is the idea of the immigrant worker.
Yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́ ni èrò nípa àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ aṣíkiri.

English: You know, people that come to the US in search of jobs as laborers, or field workers, dish washers.
Yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n máa ń wá iṣẹ́ wá sí orílẹ̀-ède US gẹ́gẹ́ bi lébírà, tàbí òsìṣẹ́ orí oko, afọbọ́.

English: You know, things that we might consider low-wage jobs but the immigrants?
Yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, àwọn nǹkan tí àwá lè rí gẹ́gẹ́ bi iṣẹ́ tí owó-iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ kéré ṣùgbọ́n àwọn aṣíkiri?

English: That's a good opportunity.
Yoruba: Àǹfààní gidi nìyẹn.

English: The news nowadays has convoluted that whole thing quite a bit.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìròyìn lásíkò yìí ti sọ gbobo nǹkan yẹn di àmúdijú díẹ̀.

English: You could say that it's made America's relationship with immigrants complicated.
Yoruba: Ẹ lè sọ wí pé ó ti jẹ́ kí àjọṣepọ̀ láàárín àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America àti àwọn aṣíkiri di àmúdijú.

English: And as immigrant expert George Borjas would have put it, it's kind of like America wanted workers, but then, they got confused when we got people instead.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nípa àwọn aṣíkiri George Borjas yóò ti ṣe sọ ọ́, ó dàbi ẹni pé ilẹ̀ America fẹ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n síbẹ̀, ó dàrú mọ́wọn lójú nígbà tí wọ́n rí àwọn ènìyàn dípò bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: I mean, it's natural that people want to strive to put a roof over their heads and live a normal life, right?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, abínibí ni pé àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ tirika láti nílé lórí kí wọ́n sì gbé ìgbeayé gidi, àbí?

English: So for obvious reasons, this narrative has been driving me a little bit crazy.
Yoruba: Fún àwọn ìdí tó fojú hàn, ìtàn yìí ti ń sín mi níwín díẹ̀.

English: But it's not the only one.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe òhun nìkan.

English: The other narrative that I'm going to talk about is the idea of the superimmigrant.
Yoruba: Ìtàn mìíràn tí màá sọ nípa rẹ̀ jẹ́ nípa èrò àwọn aṣíkíri-alágbára.

English: In America, we love to idolize superimmigrants as the ideal symbols of American success.
Yoruba: Ní ilẹ̀ America, a fẹ́ràn láti sọ àwọn aṣíkiri-alágbára di òòṣà-àkúnlẹ̀bọ gẹ́gẹ́ bi àrokò tó yẹ fún àṣeyọrí ilẹ̀ America.

English: I grew up admiring superimmigrants, because their existence fueled my dreams and it gave me hope.
Yoruba: Mo dagbà lẹ́ni tó ń nífẹ̀ sí àwọn aṣíkiri-alágbára, nítorí ìṣẹ̀mi wọn ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún àlá mi ó sì fúnmi nírètí.

English: The problem with this narrative is that it also seems to cast a shadow on those that don't succeed or that don't make it in that way, as less than.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro tó wà pẹ̀lú ìtàn yìí ni wí pé ó tún dàbi ẹni pé wọ́n ń ṣọ́ àwọn tí wọn ò láṣeyọrí tàbí tí wọn ò rí ṣe lọ́nà yẹn.

English: And for years, I got caught up in the ways in which it seemed to celebrate one type of immigrant while villainizing the other.
Yoruba: Fún àìmọye ọdún, mo bára mi ní àwọn ọ̀nà tó dàbi ẹni pé wọ́n ń gbóríyìn fún aṣíkiri kan nígbà tí wọ́n sọ ìkejì dí aṣebi.

English: I mean, were my parents' sacrifices not enough?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, ṣé ìfarajìn àwọn òbí mi ò tó ni?

English: Was the fact that my dad came home from the metal factory covered in corrosive dust, was that not super?
Yoruba: Ṣé ọ̀títọ́ pé bàbá mi wálé láti ilé-iṣọ̀pọ̀ àlùrọ tí eruku àlùrọ bòó, ṣé ìyẹn ò lágbára tó?

English: Don't get me wrong, I've internalized both of these narratives to some degree, and in many ways, seeing my heroes succeed, it has pushed me to do the same.
Yoruba: Ẹ má ṣìmí gbọ́, mo ti ro ìtàn méjééjì dé ìpele kan, ní ọ̀nà tó pọ̀, rírí àṣeyọrí àwọn akọni mi, ó ti tìmí láti ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: But both of these narratives are flawed in the ways in which they dehumanize people if they don't fit within a certain mold or succeed in a certain way.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ìtàn méjéjì yìí ní akùdé ní àwọn ọ̀nà tí wọ́n fi ń ba ìjẹ́ ọmọ ènìyàn àwọn èyàn jẹ́ tí wọn ò bá yẹ ní ìmọ kan tàbí ní àwọn ọ̀nà kan

English: And this really affected my self-image, because I started to question these ideas for who my parents were and who I was, and I started to wonder, "Am I doing enough to protect my family and my community from the injustices that we felt every day?
Yoruba: Èyí sì ti ṣàkóbá fún àwòran ara mi, nítorí mo bẹrẹ̀ síní tako àwọn èrò wọ̀nyí nítorí irú ẹnìyàn tí àwọn òbí mi jẹ́ àti ẹni tí mo jẹ́, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní rò ó, “Ṣé mò ń ṣe tó láti dáààbòbo ẹbí mi àti àwùjọ mi lọ́wọ́ àìṣedédé tí à ń ní lójoojúmọ́?

English: " So why did I choose to "sell out" while watching tragedies unfold right in front of me?
Yoruba: “ Kí ló dé tí mo yàn láti “tà” nígbà tí mò ń wo wàhálà bó ṣe ń ṣẹlẹ̀ níwájú mi?

English: Now, it took me a long time to come to terms with my decisions.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ó gbàmí lásíkò púpọ̀ láti ṣe àdéhùn pẹ̀lú ìpinnu mi.

English: And I really have to thank the people running the Hispanic Scholarship Fund, or HSF, for validating this process early on.
Yoruba: Mo ní láti dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń ṣe agbátẹrù Etò Ẹ̀kọ́ Òfẹ́ Hispanic, tàbí HSF, fún ìfọwọ́sí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: And the way that HSF -- an organization that strives to help students achieve higher education through mentorship and scholarships -- the way that they helped calm my anxiety, it was by telling me something super familiar.
Yoruba: Àti ọ̀nà tí HSF -- àjọ kan tó ń tiraka láti ran àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti ṣe àṣeyọrí ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga nípasẹ̀ ìgbani nímọ́ràn àti ètò ẹ̀kọ́ ọ̀fẹ́ -- ọ̀nà tí wọ́n ti gbà láti ṣe ìsilẹ̀ ààbalẹ̀-ọkàn, pẹ̀lú sísọ nǹkan tó tó jọ ọ́ gidi gan-gan.

English: Something that you all probably have heard before in the first few minutes after boarding a flight.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí ẹ lérò pé ẹ ti gbọ́ tẹ́lẹ̀ ní ìṣẹ̀jú díẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́ lẹ́yìn tí ẹ ti wọ ọkọ̀ òfuurufú.

English: In case of an emergency, put your oxygen mask on first before helping those around you.
Yoruba: Fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ pàjáwírì, ẹ kọ́kọ́ wọ ìbòjú èémí-àmísínú yin ná kí ẹ tó máa ran àwọn tí wọ́n rọkiriká yín lọ́wọ́.

English: Now I understand that this means different things to different people.
Yoruba: Báyìí ó yémi pé èyí túmọ̀ sí oríṣiríṣi nǹkan sí oríṣiríṣi ènìyàn.

English: But for me, it meant that immigrants couldn't and would never be able to fit into any one narrative, because most of us are actually just traveling along a spectrum, trying to survive.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n fún èmi, ó túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn aṣíkiri ò lè wọn ò sì ní yẹ nínú ìtàn Kankan láyéláye, nítorí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wa kọ̀ ń bá afẹ́fẹ́ rìn ni, à sì ń gbìyànjú láti yè.

English: And although there may be people that are further along in life with their oxygen mask on and secured in place, there are undoubtedly going to be others that are still struggling to put theirs on before they can even think about helping those around them.
Yoruba: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé àwọn ènìyàn lè wà tí wọ́n ti lọ síwájú láyé pẹ̀lú ìbòjú èémí-àmísínú wọn tí wọ́n sì farapamọ́ sáyè kan, ó dájú wí pé àwọn mìíràn yóò wà tí wọ́n ṣì ń tiraka láti wọ tiwọn kí wọ́n tiẹ̀ tó ronú nípa ríran àwọn tí wọ́n rọkiriká wọn lọ́wọ́.

English: Now, this lesson really hit home for me, because my parents, while they wanted us to be able to take advantage of opportunities in a way that we wouldn't have been able to do so anywhere else -- I mean, we were in America, and so as a child, this made me have these crazy, ambitious and elaborate dreams for what my future could look like.
Yoruba: Báyìí, ẹ̀kọ́ yìí ṣiṣẹ́ fún mi, nítorí awọn òbí mi, nígbà tí àwọ́n ń fẹ́ kí a lè ṣàmúlò àwọn àǹfààní ní ọ̀nà tí a ò ní àǹfààní láti ṣe irú rẹ̀ rí nibò mìíràn -- mò ń sọ nípa pé, a wà ní ilẹ̀ America, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọdé, èyí ń jẹ́ kí n ní àwọn àlá asíni níwín, onípinnu tó tóbi fún bí ọ̀jọ́ iwájú mi yóò ṣe rí.

English: But the ways in which the world sees immigrants, it affects more than just the narratives in which they live.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀nà tí gbogbo àgbáyé ń gbàá rí àwọn aṣíkiri, ó ń ṣàkóbá púpọ̀ ju àwọn ìtàn tí wọ́n ń gbé nínú rẹ̀ lọ.

English: It also impacts the ways laws and systems can affect communities, families and individuals.
Yoruba: Ó tún nípa lára ọ̀nà tí òfin àti àwọn ètò lè sàkóbá fún àwọn àwùjọ, àwọn ẹbí àti àwọn ènìyàn.

English: I know this firsthand, because these laws and systems, well, they broke up my family, and they led my parents to return to Mexico.
Yoruba: Mo mọ eléyìí tààrà, nítorí àwọn òfin àti ètò wọ̀nyí, ó dáa, wọ́n máa ń tú ẹbí ká, wọ́n sì mú kí àwọn òbí mi padà sí orílẹ̀-ède Mexico.

English: And at 15, my eight-year-old brother and I, we found ourselves alone and without the guidance that our parents had always provided us with.
Yoruba: Ní ọmọ odún mẹ́ẹ̀dógún, èmi àti àbúrò mi ọkùnrin ọmọ ọdún mẹ́jọ, a bárawa ní  àwa nìkan láaìsí ìtọ́sọ́nà tí àwọn òbi wa máa ń fún wa ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: Despite being American citizens, we both felt defeated by what we had always known to be the land of opportunity.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú pé a jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ America, àwa méjééjì dàbi ẹni tó rí ìjákulẹ̀ pẹ̀lú nǹkan ti a ti mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀ pé ilẹ̀ àǹfààní ni.

English: Now, in the weeks that followed my parents' return to Mexico, when it became clear that they wouldn't be able to come back, I had to watch as my eight-year-old brother was pulled out of school to be with his family.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ní ọ̀sẹ̀ tó tẹ̀lé èyí tí àwọn òbí mi padà sí orílẹ̀-ède Mexico, nígbà tí ó hàn kedere pé wọn ò nílè padà wá, mo ní láti máa wo bí àbúrò mi ọmọ ọdún mẹ́jọ ṣe kúrò nílé-ẹ̀kọ́ kó lè wà pẹ̀lú ẹbí rẹ̀.

English: And during this same time, I wondered if going back would be validating my parents' sacrifices.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò yìí kan náà, mò ń rò ó bóyá pípadà yóò ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún ìfarajìn àwọn òbí mi.

English: And so I somehow convinced my parents to let me stay, without being able to guarantee them that I'd find somewhere to live or that I'd be OK.
Yoruba: Mo ṣáà yí àwọn òbí mi lọ́kàn padà pé kí wọ́n jẹ́ kí n dúró, láìlè fún wọn ní ìdánilójú pé màá rí ibìkan láti gbé tàbí pé màá wà lálàáfíà.

English: But to this day, I will never forget how hard it was having to say goodbye.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n di òní, mi ò ní gbàgbe bó ṣe le tó láti sọ pé ó dábọ̀ láyéláyé.

English: And I will never forget how hard it was watching my little brother crumble in their arms as I waved goodbye from the other side of steel grates.
Yoruba: Mi ò sì ní gbàgbe bó ṣe le tó láti máa wo àbúrò mi bó ṣe ń yọ́bọ́rọ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn bí mo ṣe ń juwọ́ síwọn láti ẹ̀gbé kejì ilẹ̀kùn onírin.

English: Now, it would be naive to credit grit as the sole reason for why I've been able to take advantage of so many opportunities since that day.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, kò ní mópọlọ dání láti gbóríyìn fún àfojúsùn gẹ́gẹ́ bi èrèdí kan ṣoṣo tí mo fi ṣàmúlò ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àǹfààní láti ọjọ́ náà.

English: I mean, I was really lucky, and I want you to know that.
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, mo lórí lọ́wọ́ ni, mo sì fẹ́ kí ẹ mọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Because statistically speaking, students that are homeless or that have unstable living conditions, well, they rarely complete high school.
Yoruba: Nítorí ká sọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìṣirò, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ò nílé tàbí tí wọ́n gbé ìgbeayé tí ò ṣe déédéé, ó dáa, wọn kìí fi bẹ́ẹ̀ figa-gbága ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga.

English: But I do think that it was because my parents had the trust in letting me go that I somehow found the courage and strength to take on opportunities even when I felt unsure or unqualified.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo máa ń rò ó wí pé nítorí àwọn òbí mi nígbàgbọ́ láti fimí sílẹ̀ ló jẹ́ kín nígboyà àti agbára láti ṣàmúlò àǹfààní kódà nígbà tí kò dámilójú tàbi pé mi ò peregedé.

English: Now, there's no denying that there is a cost to living the American dream.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, a ò lè parọ́ pé kò sí ẹ̀jẹ́ fún gbígbé ìgbeayé àla ilẹ̀ America.

English: You do not have to be an immigrant or the child of immigrants to know that.
Yoruba: Ẹ ò nílò láti jẹ́ aṣíkiri tàbí ọmọ aṣíkiri láti mọ ìyẹn.

English: But I do know that now, today, I am living something close to what my parents saw as their American dream.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo mọ ìyẹn báyìí, mò ń gbé nǹkan tó súnmọ́ nǹkan tí àwọn òbí mi rí gẹ́gẹ́ bi àla America wọn.

English: Because as soon as I graduated from college, I flew my younger brother to the United States to live with me, so that he, too, could pursue his education.
Yoruba: Nítorí bí mo ṣe ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́, mo gbé àbúrò mi wá sí orílẹ̀-ède United States láti gbé pẹ̀lú mi, kí ohun náà, bákan náà, lè ṣiṣẹ́ tọ ẹ̀kọ rẹ̀.

English: Still, I knew that it would be hard flying my little brother back.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, mo mọ̀ wí pé gbígbé àbúrò mi padà wá máa le.

English: I knew that it would be hard having to balance the demands and professionalism required of an entry-level job while being responsible for a child with dreams and ambitions of his own.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ wí pé yóò le láti ṣe ìdọ́gba àwọn ìbéèrè àti ìwa-akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń retí  látọ̀dọ onísẹ́ ipele-ìwọlé àti ṣíṣẹ̀tọ́ fún ọmọ kan tó ní àlá àti ìpinnu tirẹ̀.

English: But you can imagine how fun it is to be 24 years old, at the peak of my youth, living in New York, with an angsty teenage roommate who hates doing the dishes.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí ẹ bá lè ronú bóṣe dùn tó láti jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́rìn-lé-lógún, tí mo wa ní òpin ìjẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ mi, tí mò ń gbé ní New York, pẹ̀lú alájọgbé tó ń bẹ lábẹ́ ogún ọdún oníbẹ́rù tó kórìra abọ́ fífọ̀.

English: The worst.
Yoruba: Èyí tó burú jù.

English: But when I see my brother learning how to advocate for himself, and when I see him get excited about his classes and school, I do not doubt anything.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí mo rí àbúrò mi tó ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ láti jẹ́ agbenusọ fún ara rẹ̀, nígbà ti mo ri pé inú rẹ̀ ń dùn nípa kílásì rẹ̀ àti ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ rẹ̀, mi ò ṣeyèméjì kankan.

English: Because I know that this bizarre, beautiful and privileged life that I now live is the true reason for why I decided to pursue a career that would help me and my family find financial stability.
Yoruba: Torí mo mọ̀ pé ìgbeayé tó yátọ̀, tó rewà tó sì jẹ́ àǹfààní tí mò ń gbé lọ́wọ́ yìí ni ìdí tóòtọ́ tí mo fi pinnu láti ṣiṣẹ́ tọ iṣẹ́ kan tí yóò bá èmi àti ẹbí mi wá owó geere.

English: I did not know it back then, but during those eight years that I lived without my family, I had my oxygen mask on and I focused on survival.
Yoruba: Mi ò mọ̀ nígbà náà, ṣùgbọ́n láàárín odún mẹ́jọ tí mo fi gbé láìsí ẹbi mi yẹn, mo wọ ìbòjú èémí-amísínú mi mo sì gbájúmọ́ ìmóríbọ́.

English: And during those same eight years, I had to watch helplessly the pain and hurt that it caused my family to be apart.
Yoruba: Láàárín ọdún mẹ́jọ yẹn, mo ní láti máa wo ìnira àti ọgbé tó fà fún ẹbí mi láti pínyà láìlè ṣe nǹkankan.

English: What airlines don't tell you is that putting your oxygen mask on first while seeing those around you struggle -- it takes a lot of courage.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí àwọn ọkọ̀-òfuurufú ò ní sọ fún yín ni wí pé wíwọ ìbòjú èémí-amísínú yín lákọ̀kọ́ nígbà tí ẹ bá ń wo àwọn tí wọ́n rọkiriká yín tí wọ́n ń tiraka -- ó gba ìgboyà.

English: But being able to have that self-control is sometimes the only way that we are able to help those around us.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kí ènìyán lè ní ìmáradúró nígbà mìíràn ni ọ̀nà kan ṣoṣo tí a lè fi ran àwọn tí wọ́n rọkiriká wa lọ́wọ́.

English: Now I'm super lucky to be in a place where I can be there for my little brother so that he feels confident and prepared to take on whatever he chooses to do next.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí orí mi sọre pé mo wà ní àyè kan ti mo lè ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún àbúrò mi kó lè ní ìgboyà kó si gbaradì láti kojú ohun-kóhun tó bá yàn láti ṣe léyìn ẹ̀.

English: But I also know that because I am in this position of privilege, I also have the responsibility to make sure that my community finds spaces where they can find guidance, access and support.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo tún mọ̀ wí pé mo wà nípò àǹfààní yìí, mo sì tún ní ojúṣe láti ríi dájú pé àwùjọ mi rí àyè níbi ti wọ́n ti lè rí ìtọ́sọ́nà, àǹfààní àti ìrànlọ́wọ́.

English: I can't claim to know where each and every one of you are on your journey through life, but I do know that our world is one that flourishes when different voices come together.
Yoruba: Mi ò lè sọ wí pé mo mọ ibi tí ìkọ̀ọ̀kan nínú yín wà nínú ìrìnàjo yín nínú ayé, ṣùgbọ́n mo mọ̀ wí pé àgbáyé wa jẹ́ èyí tí yóò dàgbàsókè nigbà tí oríṣiríṣi ohùn bá parapọ̀.

English: My hope is that you will find the courage to put your oxygen mask on when you need to, and that you will find the strength to help those around you when you can.
Yoruba: Ìrètí mi ni wí pé ẹ máa rí ìgboyà láti wọ ìbòjú èémí-amísínú yín nígbà tí ẹ bá nílò rẹ̀, pé ẹ ó sì rí agbára láti ran àwọn tó wà láyìká yín lọ́wọ́ tí ẹ bá lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: A hospital tour in Nigeria
Yoruba: Irìnàjo afẹ́ sí ilé-ìwòsàn ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria.

English: Just to put everything in context, and to kind of give you a background to where I'm coming from, so that a lot of the things I'm going to say, and the things I'm going to do -- or things I'm going to tell you I've done -- you will understand exactly why and how I got motivated to be where I am.
Yoruba: Láti fi gbogbo rẹ̀ sí ọ̀gangan ipò, àti láti fún yín ní ìpìlẹ ibi tí a ti ń bọ̀, kí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nkan tí mo máa sọ, àti àwọn nǹkan tí mo máa ṣe -- tàbí àwọn nǹkan tí mo máa sọ fún yín pé mo ti ṣe -- ẹ ó mọ ìdí àti bí mo ṣe rí ìwúrí láti dé ibi tí mo wà.

English: I graduated high school in Cleveland, Ohio, 1975.
Yoruba: Mo kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ mẹ́wàá Cleveland, Ohio, ọdún 1975

English: And just like my parents did when they finished studying abroad, we went back home.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwọn òbí mi ṣe ṣe nígbà tí wọ́n parí ẹ̀kọ́ nílẹ̀-òkèèrè, a padà sílé.

English: Finished university education, got a medical degree, 1986.
Yoruba: Mo parí ẹ̀kọ fásitì, mo gba oyè àkọ̀kọ́ nínú ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn, ọdún 1986.

English: And by the time I was an intern house officer, I could barely afford to maintain my mother's 13-year-old car -- and I was a paid doctor.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo máa fi di akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nídìí iṣẹ́, tipátipá ni mo fi lè ṣàmójútó ọkọ̀ ọlọ́dún mẹ́tàlá ìyá mi -- mo sì jẹ́ oníṣègùn-òyìnbó tó ń gbowó.

English: This brings us to why a lot of us, who are professionals, are now, as they say, in diaspora.
Yoruba: Èyí l’ó mú wa dé ìdí tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wa, tí a jẹ́ akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́, ní báyìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bí wọ́n ṣe sọ, wà nílẹ̀ òkèèrè

English: Now, are we going to make that a permanent thing, where we all get trained, and we leave, and we don't go back?
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ṣé a ó sọ ìyẹn di nǹkan aláìyípadà ni, níbi tí wọ́n ti kọ́ wa, a sì kúrò, a ò sì padà?

English: Perhaps not, I should certainly hope not -- because that is not my vision.
Yoruba: Bóyá bẹ́ẹ̀kọ́, kí n lérò wí pé kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ -- nítorí kì í ṣe ìran tèmi nìyẹn.

English: All right, for good measure, that's where Nigeria is on the African map, and just there is the Delta region that I'm sure everybody's heard of.
Yoruba: Ó dára, fún òdiwọ̀n tó dára, ibi tí orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria wà lórí àwòran ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ nìyẹn, níbẹ̀ yẹn ni agbègbe Delta tó dámilójú pé gbogbo wa lati gbọ́ nípa rẹ̀.

English: People getting kidnapped, where the oil comes from, the oil that sometimes I think has driven us all crazy in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń jí àwọn ènìyàn gbé, níbi tí epo ti ń wá, epo tó ṣe wí pé nígbà mìíràn mo rò wí pé ó ti sínwa níwín.

English: But, critical poverty: this slide is from a presentation I gave not that long ago.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n, òṣì alágbára: ìdàndán àsúnsí yìí jẹ́ ti ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kan tí mo ṣe ní kòpẹ́ yìí.

English: org tells the story of the gap between Africa and the rest of the world in terms of health care.
Yoruba: org ń sọ ìtàn nípa àlàfo tó wà láàárín ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti àwọn tókù lágbàyé nípa ìtọ́jú ìlera.

English: Very interesting.
Yoruba: Ó panilẹ́rìn gidi gan-an.

English: How many people do you think are on that taxi?
Yoruba: Ènìyàn mélòó lẹ lérò pé ó wà nínú kabúkabú yẹn?

English: And believe it or not, that is a taxi in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Ẹ gbà á gbọ́ tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́, ọkọ̀-akérò kan nìyẹn lórílẹ̀-ède Nigeria.

English: And the capital -- well, what used to be the capital of Nigeria -- Lagos, that's a taxi, and you have police on them.
Yoruba: Olú ìlú náà -- ó dáa, ibi tó jẹ́ olú-ìlu orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria tẹ́lẹ̀ -- Èkó, kabúkabú kan nìyẹn, ọlọ́pàá sì wà nínú wọn.

English: So, tell me, how many policemen do you think are on this taxi?
Yoruba: Torí náà, ẹ sọ fún mi, ọlọ́pàá mélòó lẹ lérò pé ó wà nínú kabúkabú yìí?

English: And now?
Yoruba: Báyìí ńkọ́?

English: So, when these kind of people -- and, believe me, it's not just the police that use these taxis in Lagos.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà, nígbà tí irú àwọn ènìyàn báyìí -- àti, ẹ gbà mí gbọ́, kì í ṣe ọlọ́pàá nìkan ni wọ́n ń lo àwọn kabúkabú wọ̀nyí ní Èkó.

English: We all do.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa ni.

English: I've been on one of these, and I didn't have a helmet, either.
Yoruba: Mo ti wà nínú ọ̀kan nínú àwọn wọ̀nyí rí, mi ò sì ní akoto, bákan náà.

English: And it just reminds me of the thought of what happens when one of us on a taxi like this falls off, has an accident and needs a hospital.
Yoruba: Ó sì ránmi léti nípa èrò nǹkan tó sẹlẹ̀ nígbà tí ọ̀kan nínú wa lórí ọkọ̀-akérò bí èyí jábọ́, ó ní ìjàmbá ó sì nílò ilé ìwòsàn.

English: Believe it or not, some of us do survive.
Yoruba: Ẹ gbà á gbọ́ tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́, àwọn kan nínú wa máa ń móríbọ́.

English: Some of us do survive malaria; we do survive AIDS.
Yoruba: Àwọn kan nínú wa máa ń bọ́ nínú ewu ibà-ìgbóná; a máa ń móríbọ́ nínú àrùn kògbóògùn AIDS.

English: And like I tell my family, and my wife reminds me every time, "You're risking your life, you know, every time you go to that country.
Yoruba: Bí mo ṣe máa ń sọ fún ẹbí mi, tí ìyàwó mi ṣe máa ń ránmi léti ní gbogbo ìgbà, “ò ń fi ẹ̀mi araà rẹ wéwu, ṣé o mọ̀, ní gbogbo ìgbà tí o bá lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè yẹn.

English: " And she's right.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ l’ó sì sọ.

English: Every time you go there, you know that if you actually need critical care -- critical care of any sort -- if you have an accident -- of which there are many, there are accidents everywhere -- where do they go?
Yoruba: Nígbà gbogbo tí ẹ bá lọ síbẹ̀, ẹ mọ̀ pé tí ẹ bá nílò ìtójú tí ó ṣe pàtàkì -- èyíkéyìí ìtọ́jú tí ó nílò ìdáhùn sí pàtàkì -- tí ẹ bá ní ìjàmbá – tó ṣe wí pé wọ́n pọ̀, ìjàmbá wà níbi gbogbo -- níbo ni wọ́n máa ń lọ?

English: Where do they go when they need help for this kind of stuff?
Yoruba: Níbo ni wọ́n máa ń lọ nígbà tí wọ́n bá nílò ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún irú nǹkan báyìí?

English: I'm not saying instead of, I'm saying as well as, AIDS, TB, malaria, typhoid -- the list goes on.
Yoruba: Mi ò sọ wí pé dípò kí, mò ń sọ wí pé àti, àrùn AIDS, ikọ́-àwúgbẹ, ibà ọ̀rẹ̀rẹ̀, ibà pọ́njúpọ́ntọ̀ -- oǹkà rẹ̀ tẹ̀síwájú.

English: I'm saying, where do they go when they're like me?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ wí pé, níbo ni wọ́n ń lọ nígbà tí wọ́n dà bíi tèmi?

English: When I go back home -- and I do all kinds of things, I teach, I train -- but I catch one of these things, or I'm chronically ill with one of those, where do they go?
Yoruba: Bí mo bá padà lọ sílé -- tí mo sì ń ṣe oríṣiríṣi nǹkan, mo ń ṣe olùkọ́ni, mo ń gbaradì -- ṣùgbọ́n mo kó ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí, tàbí ọ̀kan nínú àwọn wọ̀nyí dá mi gúnlẹ̀, níbo ni wọ́n máa lọ?

English: What's the economic impact when one of them dies or becomes disabled?
Yoruba: Kíni ipa ọrọ̀-ajé nígbà tí ọ̀kan nínú wọn bá kú tàbí di aláàbọ̀-ara?

English: I think it's quite significant.
Yoruba: Mo rò wí pé ó ṣe pàtàkì.

English: This is where they go.
Yoruba: Ibi tí wọ́n máa ń lọ nìyí.

English: These are not old pictures and these are not from some downtrodden -- this is a major hospital.
Yoruba: Àwọn wọ̀nyí ò kí ń ṣe àwòrán àtijọ́ wọn ò sì kí ń ṣe láti àwọn àyè tí wọ́n ti lò bàjẹ́ -- ilé-ìwòsàn ńlá lèyí.

English: In fact, it's from a major teaching hospital in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Ní tòótọ́, láti ilé-ìwòsàn ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ ìṣègùn ńlá kan ní orílẹ̀ ède Nigeria ló ti wá.

English: Now that is less than a year old, in an operating room.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn ò tíì pé ọdún kan, nínú yàrá iṣẹ́ abẹ.

English: That's sterilizing equipment in Nigeria.

Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ gẹ́lẹ́ la ṣe ṣe ìṣelọ́jọ̀ àwọn ilé-ìtajà náà.

English: Yes, it will take a solar panel.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ni, ó máa gba pátákó-igun-mẹ́rin agbára ìtànṣán-oòrùn.

English: Yes a solar panel will charge it.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ni pátákó-igun-mẹ́rin agbára ìtànsán-oòrùn máa fún-un lágbára.

English: But if you've got mains as well, it will charge the batteries in there.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí ẹ bá ní okùn-agbéná mànà-máná bákan náà, ó máa fún àwọn òkúta-agbanására t’ó wà nínú ibẹ̀ yẹn lágbára.

English: And guess what?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ mọ nǹkan?

English: We have a little pedal charger too, just in case.
Yoruba: A ní àwọn agbagbára-iná-sára àfẹsẹ̀tẹ̀ kékeré náà, tí ẹ bá fẹ́.

English: And guess what, if it all fails, if you can find a car that's still got a live battery and you stick it in, it will still work.
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ mọ nǹkan, tí gbogbo rẹ̀ ò bá ṣiṣẹ́, tí ẹ bá lè wá ọkọ̀ tí òkúta-agbanására rẹ̀ ṣì ń ṣiṣẹ́ tí ẹ sì tì í bọ̀ ọ́, yóó sì ṣiṣẹ́.

English: Then you can customize it.
Yoruba: Ẹ wá lè ṣe àtúnṣe sí i.

English: Is it dental surgery you want?
Yoruba: Ṣé iṣẹ́-abe eyín ni ẹ fẹ́?

English: General surgery you want?
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́-abẹ àpapọ̀ lẹ fẹ́?

English: Decide which instruments, stock it up with consumables.
Yoruba: Pinnu irú àwọn irinṣẹ́ tí ó tọ́, ṣe ìkópamọ́ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn alálò-túnlò.

English: And currently we're working on oxygen -- oxygen delivery on-site.
Yoruba: Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí à ń ṣiṣẹ́ lórí èémí amísíta -- àgbékalẹ̀ èémí-àmísíta sí àye rẹ̀.

English: The technology for oxygen delivery is not new.
Yoruba: Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ fún àgbékalẹ̀ èémí-amísíta ò jẹ́ tuntun.

English: Oxygen concentrators are very old technology.
Yoruba: Àkójọpọ̀ èémí-àmísíta ti di ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àtijọ́.

English: What is new, and what we will have in a few months, I hope, is that ability to use this same renewable energy system to provide and produce oxygen on site.
Yoruba: Kíni tuntun, àti nǹkan tí a máa ní ní oṣù díẹ̀, mo lérò, ni ìníkàpá láti lo àwọn ẹ̀rọ agbára ìsọdọ̀tun kan náà yìí láti pèsè àti láti ṣẹ̀da èémí-amísíta sí àyè náà.

English: Zeolite -- it's not new -- zeolite removes nitrogen from air and nitrogen is 78 percent of air.
Yoruba: Síóláítì -- kìí ṣe tuntun -- síólítì máa ń yọ òyì-ilẹ̀ kúrò nínú atẹ́gùn òyi-ilẹ̀ sì jẹ́ ìdá méjì-dín-lọ́gọ́rin atẹ́gùn.

English: If you take nitrogen out, what's left?
Yoruba: Bí ẹ bá yọ òyì-ilẹ̀ kúrò, kí ló kù?

English: Oxygen, pretty much.
Yoruba: Èémí- àmísíta, ó súmọ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: So that's not new.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà ìyẹn ò jẹ́ tuntun.

English: What we're doing is applying this technology to it.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí à ń ṣe ni ìṣàmúlò ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ yìí sí i.

English: These are the basic features of my device, or our device.
Yoruba: Àwọn àwòmọ́ ìpìlẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ mi nìyìí, tàbí ẹ̀rọ wa.

English: This is what makes it so special.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tó mú u yàtọ̀ ni nìyí.

English: Apart from the awards it's won, it's portable and it's certified.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ sí àwọn àmì-ẹ̀yẹ tí a gbà, ó mọ níwọ̀n wọ́n sì fi ọwọ́ rẹ̀ sànyà.

English: It's registered, the MHRA -- and the CE mark, for those who don't know, for Europe, is the equivalent of the FDA in the U.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ṣe ìforúkọsílẹ̀ rẹ̀, MHRA -- àti àmi CE, fún àwọn tí ò mọ̀, fún ilẹ̀ Europe, ó ṣe déédé pẹ̀lú FDA ní orílẹ̀-ède US.

English: If you compare it with what's on the market, price-wise, size-wise, ease of use, complexity.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ bá ṣe àfiwé rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn nǹkan tó wà lọ́jà, ní ti owó, ní ti títóbi, rírọ̀rùn láti lò, àmúdijú.

English: This picture was taken last year.
Yoruba: Ọdún tó kọjá ni wọ́n ya àwòrán yìí.

English: These are members of my graduating class, 1986.
Yoruba: Àwọn yìí ni àwọn àwọn tí a jọ kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde, ọdún 1986.

English: It was in this gentleman's house in the Potomac, for those of you who are familiar with Maryland.
Yoruba: Ilé arákùrin yìí ní Potomac ni, fún àwọn tí wọ́n mọ Maryland dijú.

English: There are too many of us outside and everybody, just to borrow a bit from Hans -- Hans Rosling, he's my guy -- if the size of the text represents what gets the most attention, it's the problems.
Yoruba: Àwa tí a wà níta pọ̀ gbogbo wa, láti yá díẹ̀ lọ́wọ Hans -- Hans Rosling, ènìyàn mi ni -- tí ìwọn àyọkà náà bá jẹ́ aṣojú nǹkan tó máa ń pe àkíyèsí jù, òun ni wàhálà.

English: But what we really need are African solutions that are appropriate for Africa -- looking at the culture, looking at the people, looking at how much money they've got.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan tí a nílò nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni ọ̀nà-àbáyọ tó yẹ fún ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ -- tí a bá wo àṣa, tí a bá wo àwọn ènìyàn, tí a bá wo iye owó tí wọ́n ti gbà.

English: African people, because they will do it with a passion, I hope.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, nítorí wọ́n máa fi ẹ̀mí ṣe é, mo rò bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: And lots and lots of that little bit down there, sacrifice.
Yoruba: àìmọyẹ àti àìmọye díẹ̀ tó wà nísálẹ̀ yẹn, ìfarajìn ni.

English: You have to do it.
Yoruba: Ẹ ní láti ṣe é.

English: Africans have to do it, in conjunction with everyone else.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní láti ṣe é, pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ gbogbo àwọn ènìyàn tókù.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: How fake news does real harm
Yoruba: Bí ìròyìn òfegè ṣe ń ṣọṣẹ́ gidi.

English: I want to tell you a story about a girl.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ sọ ìtàn kan fún yín nípa ọmọdébìnrin kan.

English: But I can't tell you her real name.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mi ò lè sọ orúkọ rẹ̀ gangan fún yín.

English: So let's just call her Hadiza.
Yoruba: Torí náà ẹ jẹ́ ká pè é ní Hadiza

English: Hadiza is 20.
Yoruba: Hadiza jẹ́ ọmọ ogún ọdún.

English: She's shy, but she has a beautiful smile that lights up her face.
Yoruba: Ó lójútì, ṣùgbọ́n ẹlẹ́rìín ẹ̀yẹ ni tó sì máa ń mú kí ojú rẹ̀ gún régé.

English: But she's in constant pain.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó wà nínú ìnira àtìgbàdégbà.

English: And she will likely be on medication for the rest of her life.
Yoruba: Ó sì ṣe é ṣe kó jẹ́ wí pé yóó ma lògùn fún èyí tó kù nínú ìgbésí-ayé rẹ̀ ni.

English: Do you want to know why?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ fẹ́ mọ ìdí rẹ̀?

English: Hadiza is a Chibok girl, and on April 14, 2014, she was kidnapped by Boko Haram terrorists.
Yoruba: Hadiza jẹ́ ọmọdébìnrin Chibok, ní ọjọ́ kẹrìnlá oṣù Igbe ọdún 2014, àwọn agbésùmọ̀mí Boko Haram jí i gbé.

English: She managed to escape, though, by jumping off the truck that was carrying the girls.
Yoruba: Ó ráyè láti sá, bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé, pẹ̀lú fífò látinú ọkọ̀-akẹ́rù tó ń gbé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin náà ni.

English: But when she landed, she broke both her legs, and she had to crawl on her tummy to hide in the bushes.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tó lulẹ̀, ó kán ara rẹ̀ lẹ́sẹ̀ méjééjì, ó ni láti wọ́ pẹ̀lu ikùn rẹ̀ láti sápamọ́ sínú ìgbo.

English: She told me she was terrified that Boko Haram would come back for her.
Yoruba: Ó sọ fún mi pé ẹ̀rú bà òun wí pé àwọn Boko Haram máa padà wá fún òun

English: She was one of 57 girls who would escape by jumping off trucks that day.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn ọmọ mẹ́tà-dín-lọ́gọ́ta tí wọn yóò sá pẹ̀lu fífò bọ́lẹ̀ nínú àwọn ọkọ̀ akẹ́rù lọ́jọ́ yẹn

English: This story, quite rightly, caused ripples around the world.
Yoruba: Ìtàn yìí, bó ṣe yẹ, ti fa rúkèrúdò káàkiri àgbáyé.

English: People like Michelle Obama, Malala and others lent their voices in protest, and at about the same time -- I was living in London at the time -- I was sent from London to Abuja to cover the World Economic Forum that Nigeria was hosting for the first time.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn bíi Michelle Obama, Malala àti àwọn tí wọ́n ti fohùn síta ní ìfẹ̀hónúhàn, ní bíi àsìkò kan náà -- mò ń gbé ní ìlu London lásíkò náà -- wọn rán mi láti ìlu London lọ sí Abuja láti gbé Àpérò Ọrọ̀-Ajé Àgbáyé tí orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria ń gbàlejo rẹ̀ fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́.

English: But when we arrived, it was clear that there was only one story in town.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí a dé, ó hàn gbangba pé ìròyìn kan ṣoṣo ló wà nígboro.

English: We put the government under pressure.
Yoruba: A ò fi ìjọba náà lára balẹ̀.

English: We asked tough questions about what they were doing to bring these girls back.
Yoruba: A bèrè àwọn ìbéèrè tó lágbára nípa nǹkan tí wọ́n ń ṣe láti gba àwọn ọmọdébìnrin wọ̀nyí padà.

English: Understandably, they weren't too happy with our line of questioning, and let's just say we received our fair share of "alternative facts.
Yoruba: Ó yé wa, inú wọn ò dùn pẹ̀lú àwọn ìbéèrè tí à ń bérè, e jẹ́ká kọ̀ sọ wí pé a gba ìpin tiwa nínú “arọ́pò òdodo.

English: Influential Nigerians were telling us at the time that we were naive, we didn't understand the political situation in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Nigeria tí wọ́n nífọ̀n-léèkán ná ń sọ fún wa ní àsìkò náà pé aláìmọ̀kan niwa, a ò ní òye òṣèlú tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria.

English: But they also told us that the story of the Chibok girls was a hoax.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n tún sọ fún wa pé ète ni ìròyìn nípa àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà.

English: Sadly, this hoax narrative has persisted, and there are still people in Nigeria today who believe that the Chibok girls were never kidnapped.
Yoruba: Ó bani nínú jẹ́, ìtàn ète yìí ń tẹ̀ síwájú, àwọn ènìyàn sì wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria lónì tí wọ́n gbágbọ́ pé wọn ò jí àwọn ọmọdẹ́bìnrin Chibok náà gbé rárá.

English: Yet I was talking to people like these -- devastated parents, who told us that on the day Boko Haram kidnapped their daughters, they ran into the Sambisa Forest after the trucks carrying their daughters.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀ mò ń bá àwọn ènìyàn báyìí sọ̀rọ̀ -- àwọn òbí tí wọ́n ń banújẹ́, tí wọ́n sọ fún wí pé ọjọ́ tí àwọn Boko Haram wá jí àwọn ọmọbìnrin wọn gbé, àwọ́n sá tẹ̀lé ọkọ̀-akẹ́rù tó gbé àwọn ọmọbìnrin wọn wọnú igbó Sambisa.

English: They were armed with machetes, but they were forced to turn back because Boko Haram had guns.
Yoruba: Wọ́n dìhá ogun pẹ̀lú àdá, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ní láti padà ní tipátipá nítorí àwọn Boko Haram náà níbọn.

English: For two years, inevitably, the news agenda moved on, and for two years, we didn't hear much about the Chibok girls.
Yoruba: Fún ọdún méjì, láìyẹ̀, ìpinnu ìròyìn náà tẹ̀síwájú, fún odún méjì, a ò gbọ́ nípa àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà.

English: Everyone presumed they were dead.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyán lérò wí pé wọ́n ti kú ni.

English: But in April last year, I was able to obtain this video.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní oṣù Igbe ọdún tó kọjá, mo gba fọ́rán aláwòrán yìí.

English: This is a still from the video that Boko Haram filmed as a proof of life, and through a source, I obtained this video.
Yoruba: Àwòrán kan rèé lára fọ́rọ́n aláwòrán tí Boko Haram yà gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹ̀rí ẹ̀mí, nípasẹ̀ orísun kan, mo gba fọ́rán yìí.

English: But before I could publish it, I had to travel to the northeast of Nigeria to talk to the parents, to verify it.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kín tó ṣe ìtẹ̀jáde rẹ̀, mo ní láti rin irìnàjò lọ sí àríwá-ìlà-oòrun ilẹ̀ Nigeria láti bá àwọn òbí náà sọ̀rọ̀, láti fìdí ẹ̀ múlè.

English: I didn't have to wait too long for confirmation.
Yoruba: Mi ò ní láti dúró pẹ́ fún ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ rẹ̀.

English: One of the mothers, when she watched the video, told me that if she could have reached into the laptop and pulled our her child from the laptop, she would have done so.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìyá náà, nígbà tó wo fọ́rán náà, sọ fún mi pé tí òun bá lè wọnú ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àgbélétan náà kí òun sì fa ọmọ rẹ̀ jáde láti inú ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá alágbèlétan ni, òun ìbá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: For those of you who are parents, like myself, in the audience, you can only imagine the anguish that that mother felt.
Yoruba: Fún ẹ̀yin tí ẹ jẹ́ òbí, bíi tèmi, nínú ẹ̀yin olùgbọ́, ẹ kọ̀ lè wòye ìbànújẹ́ tí ìyá yẹn ti ní.

English: This video would go on to kick-start negotiation talks with Boko Haram.
Yoruba: Fọ́rán yìí máa tẹ̀síwájú láti bẹ̀rẹ ìdúnàdúrà pẹ̀lú Boko Haram

English: And a Nigerian senator told me that because of this video they entered into those talks, because they had long presumed that the Chibok girls were dead.
Yoruba: Aṣòfin kan ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria sọ fún mi pé nítorí fọ́rán yìí ni àwọn ṣe ń ṣe afọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn, nítorí tipẹ́ làwọ́n ti gbà wí pé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà ti kú.

English: Twenty-one girls were freed in October last year.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọdébìnrin mọ́kànlé-lógún ni wọ́n tú sílẹ̀ ní oṣù Ọ̀wàrà odún tó kọjá.

English: Sadly, nearly 200 of them still remain missing.
Yoruba: Ó bani nínú jẹ́, ó súmọ́ igba nínú wọn tí wọ́n ṣì ń wá báyìí.

English: I must confess that I have not been a dispassionate observer covering this story.
Yoruba: Mo gbọ́dọ̀ jẹ́wọ́ wí pé mi ò tíì jáwọ́ àkíyèsí bí mo ṣe ń  gbéróyìn yìí.

English: I am furious when I think about the wasted opportunities to rescue these girls.
Yoruba: Inú ń bími nígbà tí mo bá ronú nípa àwọn àǹfààní láti gba àwọn ọmọdébìnrin wọ̀nyí padà tó ti ṣòfò

English: I am furious when I think about what the parents have told me, that if these were daughters of the rich and the powerful, they would have been found much earlier.
Yoruba: Inú ń bími nígbà tí mo bá ronú nípa nǹkan tí àwọn òbí náà ti sọ fún mi, pé tí àwọn wọ̀nyí bá jẹ́ àwọn ọmọbìnrin olówó àti alágbára ni, wọn ò bá ti ríwọn tipẹ́.

English: And I am furious that the hoax narrative, I firmly believe, caused a delay; it was part of the reason for the delay in their return.
Yoruba: Inú ń bími pé ìtàn ète náà, mo nígbàgbọ́ tó rinlẹ̀, máa ń fa ìdádúró; ó wà lára okùnfa fún ìdádúró nínú ìpadàbọ wọn.

English: This illustrates to me the deadly danger of fake news.
Yoruba: Èyí ń ṣàpèjúwe ewu aṣekúpani ìròyìn òfegè fúnmi.

English: So what can we do about it?
Yoruba: Nítorí náà kíni a lè ṣe nípa rẹ̀?

English: There are some very smart people, smart engineers at Google and Facebook, who are trying to use technology to stop the spread of fake news.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n ènìyán kan wà, àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí wọ́n gbọ́n ní Google àti Facebook, tí wọ́n ń gbìyànjú láti fi ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ dá ìròyìn òfegè dúró.

English: But beyond that, I think everybody here -- you and I -- we have a role to play in that.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ju bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, mo rò wí pé gbogbo wa níbí -- ìwọ àti èmi -- a nípa láti kó nínú ìyẹn.

English: We are the ones who share the content.
Yoruba: Àwa ni a máa ń ṣe àtagbà àwọn àkóónú náà.

English: We are the ones who share the stories online.
Yoruba: Àwa la máa ń ṣe àtagbà àwọn ìròyìn náà lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára.

English: In this day and age, we're all publishers, and we have responsibility.
Yoruba: Ní ìgbà àti àkókò yìí, gbogbo wa ni atẹ̀wétà, a sì ní ojúṣe.

English: In my job as a journalist, I check, I verify.
Yoruba: Nínú iṣẹ́ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bi akọ̀ròyìn, mo máa ń ṣáyẹ̀wò, mo máa ń ṣe ìfesẹ̀múlẹ̀.

English: I trust my gut, but I ask tough questions.
Yoruba: Mo jẹ́ri ìgboyà mi, ṣùgbọ́n mo béére àwọn ìbéèrè alágbára.

English: Why is this person telling me this story?
Yoruba: Kíló dé tí ẹni yìí ń sọ ìtàn yìí fún mi?

English: What do they have to gain by sharing this information?
Yoruba: Kíni wọ́n fẹ́ jẹ lérè pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe àtagbà ìfitónilétí yìí?

English: Do they have a hidden agenda?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ ní ipinnu Kankan tí ẹ fi ń pamọ́?

English: I really believe that we must all start to ask tougher questions of information that we discover online.
Yoruba: Mo nígbàgbọ́ gidi gan-an wí pé a gbogbo wá gbọ́dọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ síni béérè ìbéèrè alágbára nípa àwọn ìfitóniléti tí a bá ṣàwárí rẹ̀ lórí òpo ayélukára.

English: Research shows that some of us don't even read beyond headlines before we share stories.
Yoruba: Ìwádìí fi hàn pé àwọn kan nínú wa ò kí ń kà ju àkòrí lọ kí a tó ṣe àtagbà awọn ìròyìn.

English: Who here has done that?
Yoruba: Ta ni ẹni náà níbí tó ti ṣe ìyẹn?

English: I know I have.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ mo ti ṣe é.

English: But what if we stopped taking information that we discover at face value?
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí a bá jáwọ́ mínú àwọn ìfitóniléti tí a ṣàwárí pẹ̀lú ìṣojúlọ́yìn ńkọ́?

English: What if we stop to think about the consequence of the information that we pass on and its potential to incite violence or hatred?
Yoruba: Bí a bá dúró láti ronú nípa ìpadàbọ àwọn ìfitónilétí tí à ń tì síwájú àti ìkápá rẹ̀ láti fa rògbòdìyàn tàbí ọ̀tá ńkọ́?

English: What if we stop to think about the real-life consequences of the information that we share?
Yoruba: Bí a bá dúró láti ronú nípa àwọn ìpadàbọ ojú aye àwọn afitóni tí à ń ṣe àtagbà rẹ̀ ńkọ́?

English: Thank you very much for listening.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun gidi gan-an fún ìtẹ́tíi yín.

English: How we can stop Africa's scientific brain drain?
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe lè dèna ìgbọ́ngbẹ ọpọlọ ìmọ-ìjìnlẹ̀ nílẹ̀ Adúláwò.

English: So many of us who care about sustainable development and the livelihood of local people do so for deeply personal reasons.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nínú wa tó nífẹ̀ sí ìdàgbàsókè alálòpẹ́ àti ìgbáyégbádùn àwọn enìyàn ìgbèríko ń ṣe é fún àǹfààní ara ẹni ni.

English: I grew up in Cameroon, a country of enchanting beauty and rich biodiversity, but plagued by poor governance, environmental destruction, and poverty.
Yoruba: Mo dàgbà ní orílẹ̀-ède Cameroon, orílẹ̀-èdè tó kún fún ẹwà àti oríṣiríṣi ojúlówó àṣà, ṣùgbọ́n tó ń ṣàìsàn pẹ̀lú ìṣèjọba tí ò da, bíba àwùjọ jẹ́, àti òṣì.

English: As a child, like we see with most children in sub-Saharan Africa today, I regularly suffered from malaria.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọde, bí a ṣe ń rí pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọmọ ní ìwò oòrun ilẹ̀ adúláwò lónì, mo máa ń ní iba ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: To this day, more than one million people die from malaria every year, mostly children under the age of five, with 90 percent occurring in sub-Saharan Africa.
Yoruba: Títí di òní, ó lé ní àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ kan àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń kú látara ibà lọ́dọọdún, pàápàá jùlọ àwọn ọmọdé lábẹ́ ọdún márùn-ún, tí ìdá àádọ́rùn sì ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ìwọ̀ oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀

English: When I was 18, I left Cameroon in search of better educational opportunities.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọ ọdún méjì-dín lógún, mo fi orílẹ̀-ède Cameroon sílẹ̀ léni tó ń wá àǹfààní ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tó dára.

English: At the time, there was just one university in Cameroon, but Nigeria next door offered some opportunities for Cameroonians of English extraction to be trained in various fields.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò náà, fásitì kan ṣoṣo ló wà ní Cameroon níbẹ̀, Sùgbọ́n orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà  tí ó jẹ́ amúlétì wọn fún àwon ọmò Kamẹrúùnù tí wọn gbọ́ ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì ní ànfàní láti gba orísìrísì ìdánilẹ́ẹ̀kọ́

English: So I moved there, but practicing my trade, upon graduation as an ecologist in Nigeria, was an even bigger challenge.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣíṣe òwò mi, lẹ́yìn tí mo kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde gẹ́gẹ́ bí onímọ̀ nípa ọjọ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria, tún jẹ́ ìdojúkọ tó tún tóbi.

English: So I left the continent when I was offered a scholarship to Boston University for my PhD.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà mo fi ẹkùn náà sílẹ̀ nígba tí wọ́n fún mi ní ẹ̀kọ́ ọ̀fẹ́ sí Fásitì Boston fún oyè ọ̀mọ̀wé mi.

English: It is disheartening to see that, with all our challenges, with all the talents, with all the skills we have in Africa as a continent, we tend to solve our problems by parachuting in experts from the West for short stays, exporting the best and brightest out of Africa, and treating Africa as a continent in perpetual need of handouts.
Yoruba: Ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́ láti ríi pé, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ìdojúkọ wa, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ẹ̀bun wa, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tí a ní nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹkùn kan, a ń yanjú àwọn ìṣòro wa pẹ̀lú mímú àwọn òjìnì wọlé láti ilẹ̀ aláwọ̀ funfun fún ìgbà díẹ̀, àti gbígbé àwọn tó dára tó sì lọ́pọlọ kúrò nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, àti ṣíṣe ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ bíi ẹkùn tó nílò owó ìrànwọ́.

English: After my training at Boston University, I joined a research team at the University of California's Institute of the Environment and Sustainability because of its reputation for groundbreaking research and the development of policies and programs that save the lives of millions of people the world over, including in the developing world.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ẹ̀kọ́ mi ní fásiti Boston, mo darapọ̀ mọ́ ikọ̀ oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí kan ní Ilé-ẹ̀kọ Àwùjọ àti Ìmúdúró ní Fásitì California nítorí ìdánimọ̀ rẹ̀ fún ìwádìí alágbára àti ìdàgbàsókè àwọn ìpinnu àti àwọn ètò tó ń gba èmi àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ àwọm enìyàn là káàkiri àgbáyé, pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó ń dágbàsókè.

English: And it has been shown that for every skilled African that returns home, nine new jobs are created in the formal and informal sectors.
Yoruba: Ó sì ti fi hàn pé fún gbogbo ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tó padà sílé, iṣẹ́ tuntun mẹ́sàn yóò di dídásílẹ̀ ní ẹ̀ka gbẹ̀fẹ́ àti àìgẹ̀fẹ́.

English: So as part of our program, therefore, to build a sustainable Africa together, we are leading a multi-initiative to develop the Congo Basin Institute, a permanent base where Africans can work in partnership with international researchers, but working out their own solutions to their own problems.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀kan lára èto wa, fún ìdí èyí, láti kọ́ ilẹ̀-adúláwò alálòpẹ́ lápapọ̀, à ń léwájú àgbékalẹ̀-ọlọ́pọ̀ láti ṣe ìdàgbàsókè ilé-ẹ̀kọ Congo Basin, àyè aláìyípadà níbi tí àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lè ṣiṣẹ́ ní àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníṣẹ́-ìwádìí ilẹ̀-òkèèrè, ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn yóò ma wá ònà àbáyọ tiwọn sí àwọn ìṣòro wọn.

English: We are using our interdisciplinary approach to show how universities, NGOs and private business can partner in international development.
Yoruba: À ń lo ọnà ìmúṣe oríṣiríṣi ẹ̀ka láti ṣàfihan bí àwọn fásitì, àjọ tí kìí ṣe ti ìjọba àti àwọn òwò aládàni lè ní àjọṣepọ̀ nínú ìdàgbàsókè ilẹ̀-òkèèrè.

English: So instead of parachuting in experts from the West for short stays, we are building a permanent presence in Africa, a one-stop shop for logistics, housing and development of collaborative projects between Africans and international researchers.
Yoruba: Dípò gbígbé àwọn òjìnì láti ọ̀dọ̀ awọn aláwọ̀ funfun fún ìgbà díẹ̀, à ń pèse ìdúró aláìyípadà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ìsọ̀ kan ṣoṣo fún ohun-èlò, ilé-ìgbé àti ìdàgbàsókè àwọn iṣẹ́-àkànṣe alájọṣepọ̀ láàárín àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí ilẹ̀ òkèèrè.

English: So this has allowed students like Michel to receive high-quality training in Africa.
Yoruba: Èyí ti jẹ́ kí àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ó gba ojúlówó ẹ̀kọ́ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: Michel is currently working in our labs to investigate the effects of climate change on insects, for his PhD, and has already secured his post-doctorate fellowship that will enable him to stay on the continent.
Yoruba: Michel ń ṣiṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ ní àyè fún ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ wa láti ṣe ìwádìí àkóbá àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ lára kòkòrò, fún oyè ọ̀mọ̀we rẹ̀, ó sì ti gba ìwé-ẹ̀rí oyè ọ̀mọ̀we rẹ̀ tí yóò fun ní àǹfààní láti dúró sí ẹkùn náà.

English: Also through our local help program, Dr. Gbenga Abiodun, a young Nigerian scientist, can work as a post-doctoral fellow with the Foundation for Professional Development in the University of Western Cape in South Africa and the University of California at the same time, investigating the effects of climate variability and change on malaria transmission in Africa.
Yoruba: Bákan náà nípasẹ̀ ètò ìrànwlọ́wọ́ agbègbe wa, Ọ̀mọ̀wé Gbenga Abiodun, ọ̀dọ́modé onímọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ ọmọ Nigeria, lè ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ọ̀mọ̀wé pẹ̀lú Ìdásílẹ̀ fún Ìdàgbàsókè Akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ ní fásitì Western Cape ní orílẹ̀-ède South Africa àti fásitì California lásíkò kan náà, ṣíṣe ìwádìí àkóbá àìṣedédé ojú ọjọ́ àti àyípada lára àkóràn ibà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: Indeed, Gbenga is currently developing models that will be used as an early warning system to predict malaria transmission in Africa.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, Gbenga ń ṣe àwòṣe tí wọn yóò lò gẹ́gẹ́ bi ètò ìkìlọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ láti sọ àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ àkóràn ibà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: So rather than exporting our best and brightest out of Africa, we are nurturing and supporting local talent in Africa.
Yoruba: Dípò ka máa gbé àwọn tó dára àtí àwọ́n ọlọpọlọ wa kúrò nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, à ń rè a sì ń ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn ẹ̀bùn abẹ́lé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: For example, like me, Dr. Eric Fokam was trained in the US.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, bí èmi náà, orílẹ̀-ède US ni Ọ̀mọ̀wé Eric Fokan ti gba ìkọ́ni.

English: He returned home to Cameroon, but couldn't secure the necessary grants, and he found it incredibly challenging to practice and learn the science he knew he could.
Yoruba: Ó padà sílé ní Cameroon, ṣùgbọ́n kò rí owó ìrànwọ́ tó ṣe pàtàkì gbà, ó sì ríi gẹ́gẹ́ bi ìdojúkọ tó lágbára láti ṣe àti láti mọ ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ tó mọ̀ pé òún lè ṣe.

English: So when I met Eric, he was on the verge of returning to the US.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo pàde Eric, ó ń múra láti padà sí orílẹ̀-ède US ni.

English: But we convinced him to start collaborating with the Congo Basin Institute.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a yí ọkàn rẹ̀ padà láti bẹ̀rẹ àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ Congo Basin.

English: Today, his lab in Buea has over half a dozen collaborative grants with researchers from the US and Europe supporting 14 graduate students, nine of them women, all carrying out groundbreaking research understanding biodiversity under climate change, human health and nutrition.
Yoruba: Lónìí, àyè ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n-ìjìlẹ̀ rẹ̀ ní Buea ní tó owó ìrànwọ́ àjọni mẹ́fà pẹ̀lú àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí láti orílẹ̀-ède US àti ilẹ̀ Europe tí wọ́n ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́-jáde 14, mẹ́sàn-án nínú wọn jẹ́ obìnrin, tí gbogbo wọn ń ṣe àwọn ìwádìí alágbára láti ní òye oríṣiríṣi ọ̀wọ́ lábẹ́ àyípadà ojú ọjọ́, ìlera ọmọ ènìyàn àti ohun tí ń fúnni ní okun.

English: So rather than buy into the ideas of Africa taking handouts, we are using our interdisciplinary approach to empower Africans to find their own solutions.
Yoruba: Dípò kí a gba èro kí ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ máa gba owó ìrànwọ́, à ń lo ònà ìmúṣe oríṣiríṣi-ẹ̀ka láti ró àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lágbára láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ tiwọn.

English: Right now, we are working with local communities and students, a US entrepreneur, scientists from the US and Africa to find a way to sustainably grow ebony, the iconic African hardwood.
Yoruba: Lásíkò yìí, à ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn àwùjọ àti àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́, oníṣòwò US kan, àwọn onímọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ láti orílẹ̀-ède US àti ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ láti wá ọ̀nà láti gbin kanran alálòpẹ́, akọni igi-líle nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: Ebonies, like most African hardwood, are exploited for timber, but we know very little about their ecology, what disperses them, how they survive in our forest 80 to 200 years.
Yoruba: Àwọn kanran, bíi ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn igi-líle ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ, ni wọ́n ń lò fún gẹdú, ṣùgbọ́n díẹ̀ la mọ̀ nípa àjọṣepọ̀ wọn, nǹkan tó ń pín wọn ká, bí wọ́n ṣe ń yè nínú igbó wa fún ọgọ́rin sí igba ọdún.

English: This is Arvin, a young PhD student working in our labs, conducting what is turning out to be some cutting-edge tissue culture work.
Yoruba: Arvin rè é, ọdọ́mọdé akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ oyè ọ̀mọ̀wé t’ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní yàrá ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n-ìjìlẹ̀ wa, tó ń ṣe nǹkan tó ti di iṣẹ́ àṣà pádi-ààyè tó ń léwájú báyìí.

English: Arvin is holding in her hands the first ebony tree that was produced entirely from tissues.
Yoruba: Igi kanran àkọ́kọ́ tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀dá látara pádi-ààyè ni Arvin mú lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: This is unique in Africa.
Yoruba: Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ nìkan l’ó ní èyí.

English: We can now show that you can produce African timber from different plant tissues -- leaves, stems, roots -- in addition from generating them from seeds, which is a very difficult task.
Yoruba: A wá lè ṣe àfihàn pé ẹ lè hu àwọn igi gẹdú ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ látara pádi-ààyè oríṣiríṣi nǹkan ọ̀gbìn -- ewé, ìtí, gbòngbò -- ní àfikún sí ìdásílẹ̀ wọn látara èso, èyí tó jẹ́ iṣẹ́ t’ó le gidi gan-an.

English: So other students will take the varieties of ebony which Arvin identifies in our lab, graft them to produce saplings, and work with local communities to co-produce ebony with local fruit tree species in their various farms using our own tree farm approach, whereby we invite all the farmers to choose their own tree species they want in their farms.
Yoruba: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ t’ó kù máa mú oríṣìiríṣìi kanran tí Arvin tọ́ka rẹ̀ ní ile-ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n-ìjìlẹ̀ wa, lílọ́-ẹ̀ka-wọ́n-sínú-igi-mìíràn láti ṣẹ̀da àwọn igi kékeeké tuntun, kí wọ́n sì ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn agbègbè ìgbèríko láti jọ pèsè kanran pẹ̀lú àwọn igi eléso ọ̀wọ́ ọ̀tọ̀ ní àwọn oko wọn pẹ̀lú lílo ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe oko igi tiwa gangan, níbi tí a ti máa pe gbogbo àwọn àgbẹ̀ láti yan ọ̀wọ́ igi tiwọn tí wọ́n fẹ́ lórí oko wọn.

English: So in addition to the ebony, the species which the farmers choose themselves will be produced using our modern techniques and incorporated into their land-use systems, so that they start benefiting from these products while waiting for the ebony to mature.
Yoruba: Ní àfikún sí kanran, àwọn ẹ̀yà ọ̀wọ́ tí àwọn àgbẹ̀ yan fúnra wọn yóò di ṣíṣe pẹ̀lú lílo àwọn ọgbọ́n òde-òní wa a ó sì ṣàfikún rẹ̀ sínú èto lílo-ilẹ̀ wọn, kí wọ́n lè bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í jẹ àǹfààní látara àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń dúró de kanran náà láti dàgbà.

English: Today we are planting 15,000 ebony trees in Cameroon, and for the first time, ebony won't be harvested from the middle of a pristine forest.
Yoruba: Lónìí à ń gbin ẹgbẹ̀rún 15 igi kanran ní orílẹ̀-ède Cameroon, fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́, wọn ò ní kórè igi kanran láti àárín gbùngbun igbó.

English: This is the model for our African hardwoods, and we are extending this to include sapele and bubinga, other highly prized hardwoods.
Yoruba: Àwòṣe fún àwọn igi-líle ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ wa rè é, a sì ń fa èyí lọ títí láti ṣàfikún igi gẹdú sápẹ́lẹ́ àti igi bubíńga, àwọn igi-líle mìíràn t’ó lówó lórí gidi gan-an.

English: So if these examples existed when I was 18, I would never have left, but because of initiatives by the Congo Basin Institute, I am coming back, but I'm not coming back alone.
Yoruba: Bí àwọn àpẹẹrẹ wọ̀nyí bá ti wà nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọdún méjì-dín-lógún, mi ò ní kúrò rárá, ṣùgbọ́n nítorí ọgbọ́n àtinúdá ilé-ẹ̀kọ Agbègbè-adágúndò Congo, mò ń padà bọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n mi ò ní padà wá lémi nìkan.

English: I'm bringing with me Western scientists, entrepreneurs and students, the best science from the best universities in the world, to work and to live in Africa.
Yoruba: Mò ń kó àwọn onímọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ ènìyàn Aláwọ̀-funfun, àwọn olókòwò kékèèké àti àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́, àwọn ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ t’ó dára jù lo láti àwọn fásitì t’ó dárajù lágbàyé bọ̀ pẹ̀lú mi, láti ṣiṣẹ́ àti gbé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: But we all need to scale up this local, powerful and empowering approach.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n gbogbo wá nílò láti ṣe àfikún ọ̀nà-ìgbésẹ̀ agbègbè, alágbára àti arónilágbára yìí.

English: So far we have half a dozen universities and NGOs as partners.
Yoruba: Di àsìkò yìí a ti ní àwọn fásitì àti àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́-tí-kìí-ṣe-ti-ìjọba mẹ́fà gẹ́gẹ́ bí alájọṣe.

English: We are planning to build a green facility that will expand on our existing laboratory space and add more housing and conference facilities to promote a long-term disciplinary approach.
Yoruba: À ń gbèrò láti kọ́ àwọn ilé tí yóò dẹ́kun ipa búburú àyípadà ojú ọjọ́ tí yóò fẹ àwọn ilé ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n ìjìnlẹ̀ wa lójú tí yóò sì ṣe àfikún àwọn ilé-gbèé àti ohun-èlò àpérò láti ṣe ìgbédìde ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe ìbáwí ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́.

English: I want it to offer more opportunities to young African scholars, and would scale it up by leveraging the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture's existing network of 17 research stations across sub-Saharan Africa.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ kó fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ọmọwé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní àǹfààní sí i, yóó sì ṣe ìgbéfúkẹ́ rẹ̀ sí i nípa títẹpẹlẹ mọ́ àǹfààní ìsopọ̀ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìwádìí 17 ti Ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ Ilẹ̀-òkèèrè ti Iṣẹ́-Àgbẹ̀ Agbègbè Ìgbóná-Oòrùn t’ó ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀ káàkiri Gúúsù-aṣálẹ̀ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: The tables are starting to turn and I hope they keep turning, to reach several African nations like Côte d'Ivoire, Tanzania and Senegal, among the top fastest growing economies that can attract several opportunities for private-sector investment.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìyípadà rere náà ti ń dé mo sì lérò pé wọn yóò tẹ̀síwájú, kí ó dé ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ bi Côte d'Ivoire, Tanzania àti Senegal, lára àwọn tí ìdágbàsókè ètò ọrọ̀-ajé wọ́n wà lókè ténté t’ó lè ṣe ìgbàmọ́ra àǹfààní tó pọ̀ fún ìdókòwò ẹ̀ka-aládàni.

English: We want to give more opportunities to African scholars, and I long to see a day when the most intelligent Africans will stay on this continent and receive high-quality education through initiatives like the Congo Basin Institute, and when that happens, Africa will be on the way to solving Africa's problems.
Yoruba: A fẹ́ fún àwọn ọ̀mọ̀wé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní àǹfààní síi, mo sì ń fojú sọ́nà láti rí ọjọ́ kan tí ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó lọ́pọlọ jù máa dúró sí ẹkùn náà láti gba ẹ̀tò-ẹ̀kọ́ tó jẹ́ ojúlówó nípasẹ̀ àgbékalẹ̀ bíi ilé-ẹ̀kọ Congo Basin, nígbà tí ìyẹn bá ṣẹlẹ̀, Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ yóò wà lójú ọ̀nà láti yanjú àwọn ìṣòro Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

English: On May 25 and 26, 2019, the “Be Strong!” circuit assembly program in the Lingala and Tshiluba languages was held within the Lóvua refugee camp.

English: This camp is 1,022 kilometers (635 mi) from Angola’s capital, Luanda.
Yoruba: Ibùdó yìí fi kìlómítà ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àti méjìlélógún (1,022) jìn sí Luanda, tó jẹ́ olú ìlú Àǹgólà.

English: At the time of the program, there were 177 publishers and their families living in the Lóvua camp.
Yoruba: Nígbà tá a ṣe àpéjọ yẹn, akéde ọgọ́rùn-ún kan àti mẹ́tàdínlọ́gọ́rin (177) tó fi mọ́ àwọn ìdílé wọn ló wà ní ibùdó Lóvua.

English: Yet, some 380 people attended the Lingala-language program with 3 baptized, and 630 people attended the Tshiluba-language program with 6 baptized.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́ta àti ọgọ́rin (380) èèyàn ló gbádùn àpéjọ tá a ṣe ní èdè Lingala, àwọn mẹ́ta sì ṣe ìrìbọmi, nígbà tó jẹ́ pé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́fà àti ọgbọ̀n (630) èèyàn ló gbádùn ìtòlẹ́sẹẹsẹ tá a ṣe ní èdè Tshiluba, àwọn mẹ́fà sì ṣe ìrìbọmi.

English: Most of the brothers who fled to Lóvua did so because of violent unrest in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará wa tó sá wá sí Lóvua ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ torí ìwà ipá tí ò mú kí ìlú fara rọ ní orílẹ̀-èdè Kóńgò.

English: Our brothers in Lóvua are unable to attend spiritual events in other cities, due to camp travel restrictions.
Yoruba: Àwọn ará wa tó wà ní Lóvua ò lè lọ́ sí àwọn ìlú míì láti ṣe ìpàdé, torí wọ́n fòfin de àwọn tó wà ní ibùdó láti rìnrìn àjò.

English: Therefore, the branch arranged to hold the assemblies within the camp and also constructed two temporary Kingdom Halls.
Yoruba: Torí náà, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ṣètò pé kí wọ́n ṣe àpéjọ yẹn nínú ibùdó náà, wọ́n sì tún kọ́ Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba méjì tó ṣe é lò fúngbà díẹ̀.

English: These Kingdom Halls accommodate four congregations—three Tshiluba and one Lingala.
Yoruba: Ìjọ mẹ́rin ló ń lo Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba méjèèjì yìí, mẹ́ta ní èdè Tshiluba àti ọ̀kan ní èdè Lingala

English: On May 24, 2019, the circuit overseer and a branch representative traveled to the Lóvua camp to help set up the sound and stage equipment.
Yoruba: Ní May 24, 2019, alábòójútó àyíká àti aṣojú láti ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì rìnrìn àjò lọ sí ibùdó Lóvua kí wọ́n lè rí i pé pèpéle àti ẹ̀rọ tá a fi ń gbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ wà létòlétò.

English: Despite our brothers’ challenges as refugees, they contributed tarpaulins, poles, rope, nails, and other needed materials.
Yoruba: Láìka àwọn ìpèníjà tí àwọn ara wa tó wà ni ibùdó àwọn tó ń wà ibi ìsádi ń kojú sí, síbẹ̀ wọ́n fi àwọn nǹkan bíi tapólì, òpó, okùn, ìṣó àtàwọn ohun èlò míì tí wọ́n nílò ṣètìlẹ́yìn.

English: After the program, Honoré Lontongo, a ministerial servant in one of the Tshiluba congregations in the refugee camp, commented:
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìtòlẹ́sẹẹsẹ náà, arákùnrin Honoré Lontongo, tó jẹ́ ìránṣẹ́ iṣẹ́ òjíṣẹ́ nínú ọ̀kan lára àwọn ìjọ tó wà ní Tshiluba nínú ibùdó àwọn tó ń wà ibi ìsádi náà, sọ pé:

English: “Seeing the assemblies held here inside the refugee camp, despite the difficult conditions, makes us feel Jehovah’s love not only for us as a group but for us as individuals.”
Yoruba: “Bí a ṣe rí àwọn àpéjọ tá a ṣe nínú ibùdó àwọn tó ń wà ibi ìsádi yìí, láìka àwọn ipò tí kò rọrùn rárá tá a wà sí, jẹ́ ká rí i pé Jèhófà nífẹ̀ẹ́ wa, kì í ṣe àwùjọ wa lódindi nìkan ló nífẹ̀ẹ́, àmọ́, ó tún nífẹ̀ẹ́ wa lẹ́nì kọ̀ọ̀kan pẹ̀lú.”

English: I am so happy!
Yoruba: Inú mi dùn gan-an!

English: Some 50 Bethelites serve full-time in the city of Douala, Cameroon.
Yoruba: Àádọ́ta (50) ni àwọn tó ń fi gbogbo àkókò wọn ṣiṣẹ́ ní Bẹ́tẹ́lì tó wà nílùú Douala, lórílẹ̀-èdè Kamẹrúùnù.

English: They will soon be able to enjoy a new branch facility, as the offices that are currently located in the Bonabéri quarter of the city will be replaced by a newly constructed facility in the Logbessou quarter.
Yoruba: Láìpẹ́, wọ́n máa ní ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tuntun, torí pé a máa tó kọ́ ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tuntun sí àdúgbò Logbessou, èyí tó máa rọ́pò àwọn ọ́fíìsì tí wọ́n ń lò lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí ní àdúgbò Bonabéri.

English: The construction of a new branch office is indicative of the expanding theocratic activity in Cameroon, a country in which the Memorial of Christ’s death was attended by over 100,000 people in 2017, over twice the number of publishers.
Yoruba: Ti pé a fẹ́ kọ́ ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tuntun fi hàn pé ìlọsíwájú ń bá ọ̀rọ̀ ìjọsìn Ọlọ́run lórílẹ̀-èdè Kamẹrúùnù. Lọ́dún 2017, ó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún (100,000) èèyàn tó wá síbi Ìrántí Ikú Kristi, iye yẹn sì ju ìlọ́po méjì àwọn akéde lọ.

English: Our brothers installing lightning protection.
Yoruba: Àwọn ará wa ń ri ohun tí kò ní jẹ́ kí mànàmáná ṣọṣẹ́.

English: The construction site is beside an already existing Assembly Hall.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀gbẹ́ Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ kan ni ibi tá a ń kọ́ ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì náà sí wà.

English: The work has begun in earnest with the excavation of the foundations.
Yoruba: Àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í ṣètò ìpìlẹ̀ ilé náà.

English: When the project is complete, the final design will be in the style of apartments commonly available in the area with a separate office building, as shown in the rendering above.
Yoruba: Tá a bá ti kọ́ ilé náà tán, àwọn ilé gbígbé tó wà níbẹ̀ máa rí bíi tàwọn ilé tó wọ́pọ̀ ládùúgbò náà, àwọn ọ́fíìsì sì máa wà lọ́tọ̀ bó ṣe wà nínú fọ́tò tó wà lókè yìí.

English: According to current projections, the Bethel family will be able to move in at the end of 2019.
Yoruba: Ètò tá a ṣe lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí ni pé, títí ìparí ọdún 2019, ìdílé Bẹ́tẹ́lì máa lè kó lọ síbẹ̀.

English: Some of the over 2,800 brothers and sisters who attended a special meeting to learn how they can support the construction of the branch.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀ lára àwọn ará lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin tó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì àti ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ (2,800) tó wá síbi àkànṣe ìpàdé tí wọ́n ti kọ́ bí wọ́n ṣe lè ṣèrànwọ́ lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ ìkọ́lé náà.

English: “It is impressive to see thousands of our brothers and sisters who have volunteered to help with the construction displaying the Isaiah-like spirit,” states Gilles Mba, a member of the Cameroon Bethel family who works with the Public Information Desk. (Isaiah 6:8)
Yoruba: Gilles Mba, tó jẹ́ ara ìdílé Bẹ́tẹ́lì ní Kamẹrúùnù, tó ń bá Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Gbéròyìn Jáde ṣiṣẹ́, sọ pé, “Ó wú wa lórí láti rí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ará wa lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin tí wọ́n ti yọ̀ǹda ara wọn láti ṣèrànwọ́ lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ ìkọ́lé náà, táwọn náà ní irú ẹ̀mí tí Aísáyà ní.” (Aísáyà 6:8)

English: He adds, “This bustling activity has energized all of us who work at the branch.
Yoruba: Ó fi kún un pé, “Bí iṣẹ́ ṣe ń lọ ní pẹrẹu yìí jẹ́ kóríyá fún gbogbo àwa tá à ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì láti tẹra mọ́ṣẹ́.

English: We are eager and ready to use the new offices for their dedicated purpose—to honor Jehovah’s name.”
Yoruba: Ara wa ti wà lọ́nà láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í lo àwọn ọ́fíìsì tuntun tá à ń kọ́ yìí fún ète tá a fi ń kọ́ ọ, ìyẹn láti bọlá fún orúkọ Jèhófà.”

English: Over the past year, construction of the new branch facility in Cameroon has been underway.
Yoruba: Lọ́dún tó kọjá, iṣẹ́ bẹ̀rẹ̀ lórí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tuntun lórílẹ̀-èdè Kamẹrúùnù.

English: As shown in the photo above, partial structures of the four residences and office building are now in place.
Yoruba: Bó ṣe wà nínú àwòrán tó wà lókè yìí, iṣẹ́ ti ń lọ lórí àwọn ilé gbígbé mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin àtàwọn ọ́fíìsì.

English: The new branch will accommodate 60 people and the office will have 71 workspaces.
Yoruba: A retí pé ọgọ́ta (60) èèyàn láá máa gbé ní ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tuntun yìí, ó sì máa ní àyè tó gba àwọn mọ́kànléláàádọ́rin (71) láti ṣiṣẹ́.

English: Current projections indicate that the facility will be ready for use near the end of December 2019.
Yoruba: Ètò tó wà nílẹ̀ fi hàn pé iṣẹ́ máa parí lórí àwọn ilé náà títí ìparí oṣù December 2019.

English: The following photo gallery provides an update on the progress of the work. A rendering of the proposed branch facility.
Yoruba: Àwọn fọ́tò tó tẹ̀ lé e yìí máa jẹ́ kẹ́ ẹ rí ibi tí iṣẹ́ náà dé. Àwòrán bí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì náà ṣe máa rí tíṣẹ́ bá parí.

English: Jehovah’s Witnesses released the Bassa-language edition of the New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures at a regional convention in Douala, Cameroon, on August 2, 2019.
Yoruba: Àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà mú Ìwé Mímọ́ Kristẹni Lédè Gíríìkì ní Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lédè Bassa ní àpéjọ agbègbè tó wáyé nílùú Douala, lórílẹ̀-èdè Kamẹrúùnù ní August 2, 2019.

English: The release of the Greek Scriptures was the culmination of an 18-month endeavor.
Yoruba: Ó gbà tó oṣù méjìdínlógún (18) kí iṣẹ́ tó parí lórí iṣẹ́ ìtumọ̀ Ìwé Mímọ́ yìí.

English: This is the first time that Jehovah’s Witnesses have translated a Bible into a language native to Cameroon.
Yoruba: Ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ sì nìyí tí àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà máa tú Bíbélì sí èdè tí àwọn èèyàn Kamẹrúùnù ń sọ.
