English: rother Peter Canning, a member of the Cameroon Branch Committee, released the Bible on the first day of the regional convention at the Logbessou Assembly Hall to an audience of 2,015.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Peter Canning, tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Kamẹrúùnù ló mú Bíbélì yìí jáde ní ọjọ́ àkọ́kọ́ àpéjọ agbègbè tó wáyé ní Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ tó wà ní Logbessou. Ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì ó lé mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dógún (2,015) èèyàn ló wà níbẹ̀.

English: Prior to the release of the Greek Scriptures, our Bassa-speaking brothers and sisters had to rely on a costly translation that was hard to understand.
Yoruba: Ṣáájú ká tó mú Ìwé Mímọ́ Kristẹni Lédè Gíríìkì yìí jáde, Bíbélì tí wọ́nwó, tó sì ṣòro lóye ní àwọn arákùnrin àti arábìnrin wa tó ń sọ èdè Bassa ń lò.

English: One of the translators on the Bassa project explains: “This newly released translation will help publishers to more readily understand the Bible.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè tó ṣiṣẹ́ lórí ìtumọ̀ Bíbélì yìí sọ pé: “Ìtumọ̀ Bíbélì tí a ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ mú jáde yìí máa ran àwọn akéde lọ́wọ́ láti lóye Bíbélì dáadáa.

English: It will increase their love for Jehovah and his organization.”
Yoruba: Ó tún máa fi kún ìfẹ́ tí wọn ní fún Jèhófà àti ètò rẹ̀.”

English: An estimated 300,000 people speak the Bassa language in Cameroon.
Yoruba: Àwọn tó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́ta (300,000) ló ń sọ èdè Bassa ní Kamẹrúùnù.

English: There are 1,909 Bassa-speaking publishers serving in the Cameroon branch territory.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀rún kan, ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́sàn-án àti mẹ́sàn-án (1,909) akéde tó ń sọ èdè Bassa ló wà ní Kamẹrúùnù.

English: Since December 2017, internal conflicts between the Hema and Lendu communities in the Ituri province of the Democratic Republic of the Congo have resulted in numerous deaths and the displacement of tens of thousands of people.
Yoruba: Láti December 2017, ìjà abẹ́lé tó ń wáyé láàárín àwọn Hema àti Lendu lágbègbè Ituri ní Orílẹ̀-èdè Olómìnira ti Kóńgò ti yọrí sí ikú ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún èèyàn ni ò sì nílé lórí mọ́.

English: Many of our brothers and sisters are among those who have been affected by the escalating violence.
Yoruba: Ṣe ni ìjà yìí ń le sí i, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará wa lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin sì wà lára àwọn tó ń fara gbá àbájáde rẹ̀.

English: Thousands of Congolese refugees have fled to Uganda to escape the turmoil, including 192 publishers who are living in two refugee camps near the Congo border.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn tí ogun lé wá sí Kóńgò, tó fi mọ́ àwọn akéde igba ó dín mẹ́jọ (192) tó ń gbé ní ibùdó méjì nítòsí ààlà Kóńgò, ti sá lọ sí Ùgáńdà láti forí ara wọn pa mọ́.

English: As of June 2018, an additional 1,098 Witnesses have fled the conflict zone to Bunia, the provincial capital of Ituri.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó fi máa di June 2018, ẹgbẹ̀rún kan ó lé méjìdínlọ́gọ́rùn-ún (1,098) Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ló ti sá kúrò níbi táwọn èèyàn ti ń jà lọ sí Bunia, tó jẹ́ olú-ìlú Ituri.

English: Sadly, a married couple as well as three young children whose parents are baptized publishers died because of health complications.
Yoruba: Ó dùn wá pé tọkọtaya kan àtàwọn ọmọ kékeré mẹ́ta táwọn òbí wọn ti ṣèrìbọmi ṣaláìsí, torí pé wọ́n ṣàìsàn.

English: However, none of our brothers and sisters have been killed in the brutal fighting.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ àwọn tó ń para wọn nípakúpa náà ò rí ìkankan nínú àwọn ará wa lọ́kùnrin àti lóbìnrin pa.

English: Brothers and sisters who have fled from various parts of Ituri pictured on the Assembly Hall grounds in Bunia.
Yoruba: Àwọn ará lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin tó sá kúrò láwọn agbègbè lóríṣiríṣi nílùú Ituri rèé nínú àyíká Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ ní Bunia.

English: The homes of many brothers who have fled from the conflict have been looted or burned to the ground.
Yoruba: Àwọn jàǹdùkú ti fọ́ ilé ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará tó sá lọ, ṣe ni wọ́n tiẹ̀ jó àwọn ilé kan kanlẹ̀.

English: Additionally, many of the crops that the brothers cultivated for their livelihood were destroyed.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, wọ́n ba ọ̀pọ̀ irè oko àwọn ará náà jẹ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ torí kí wọ́n lè fi gbọ́ bùkátà ni wọ́n ṣe gbìn wọ́n.

English: From the time the fighting began, publishers outside the conflict zone have provided practical help to their affected brothers.
Yoruba: Àtìgbà tí ìjà náà ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ làwọn akéde tí kò sí níbi tí wọ́n ti ń jà ti ń ṣèrànwọ́ fáwọn ará wọn tọ́rọ̀ yìí kàn.

English: Some loaned their vehicles to evacuate publishers to safety (see lead image).
Yoruba: Àwọn kan gbé ọkọ̀ wọn sílẹ̀ kí wọ́n lè fi kó àwọn ará lọ síbi tí kò séwu (wo àwòrán ìbẹ̀rẹ̀).

English: Additionally, 205 Witness families from Bunia supplied money, food, and housing to their displaced brothers, despite being of limited means.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, àwọn ìdílé Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tíye wọn jẹ́ igba ó lé márùn-ún (205) láti ìlú Bunia fi owó àti oúnjẹ ránṣẹ́, kódà wọ́n gba àwọn ará wọn sílé, bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé àwọn fúnra wọn ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ní lọ́wọ́.

English: Although there are two sizeable refugee camps in Bunia, all of the displaced publishers have been taken in by local Witnesses
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, ibùdó méjì tó tóbi déwọ̀n àyè kan wà nílùú Bunia táwọn tí ogun lé wá lè dé sí, àmọ́ gbogbo àwọn akéde tó sá kúrò ní Kóńgò làwọn ará wọn tó jẹ́ Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ní Bunia ti gbà sílé.

English: The Congo Branch Committee established a Disaster Relief Committee, which provided basic necessities to our brothers and sisters.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka orílẹ̀-èdè Kóńgò ṣètò ìgbìmọ̀ kan tó ń ṣètò ìrànwọ́ nígbà àjálù, ìgbìmọ̀ yìí sì ti pèsè àwọn ohun kòṣeémáàní fáwọn ará wa.

English: A branch representative also visited the affected brothers and provided spiritual encouragement.
Yoruba: Aṣojú kan láti ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tún bẹ àwọn ará tọ́rọ̀ kàn wò, ó sì fi ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run gbé wọn ró.

English: Despite being displaced, brothers and sisters who have fled to Bunia and other areas are gathering to worship with local congregations and are actively sharing the good news with others.
Yoruba: Bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé àwọn ará lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin tó sá lọ sí Bunia àtàwọn ibòmíì ò nílé tara wọn, síbẹ̀ wọ́n ń kóra jọ láti jọ́sìn pẹ̀lú àwọn ìjọ tó wà lágbègbè náà, wọ́n sì ń fìtara wàásù ìhìn rere fáwọn èèyàn.

English: From February to April 2018, the brothers started over 270 Bible studies with individuals in the refugee camps.
Yoruba: Láti February sí April 2018, ó lé ní igba àti àádọ́rin (270) èèyàn táwọn ará bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í kọ́ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì níbi táwọn tí ogun lé kúrò nílùú ń gbé.

English: Amidst a climate of civil unrest, there has been an ongoing Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo since August 2018.
Yoruba: Bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé nǹkan ò fara rọ lórílẹ̀-èdè Congo, tí ìjà sì ń ṣẹlẹ̀, àrùn Ebola bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í jà níbẹ̀ láti oṣù August 2018.

English: Over 1,088 cases of Ebola resulting in 665 fatalities have been reported in the areas of North Kivu and Ituri.
Yoruba: Lágbègbè North Kivu àti Ituri, ó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún kan (1,088) èèyàn tó ti kó àrùn yìí, àwọn tó sì ti pa jẹ́ ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́fà ó lé márùndíláàádọ́rin (665).

English: Sadly, this outbreak has affected our brothers.
Yoruba: Ó dùn wá pé àrùn yìí jà dé ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ará wa.

English: The Congo (Kinshasa) branch reports that, among Jehovah’s Witnesses, ten adults and two children have died from the disease.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́físì wa ní Congo (Kinshasa) sọ pé, àrùn yìí pa ẹni mẹ́wàá tó ti dàgbà àti ọmọdé méjì láàárín àwọn ará.

English: Another brother was infected with the disease but recovered.
Yoruba: Àrùn náà ran arákùnrin kan, àmọ́ ara rẹ̀ ti kọ́fẹ pa dà.

English: In order to educate the brothers about disease prevention, the Congo (Kinshasa) branch received approval from the Coordinators’ Committee to prepare a special video and discourse.
Yoruba: Ká lè kọ́ àwọn ará ní bí wọ́n ṣe lè dènà àrùn yìí, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní Congo (Kinshasa) gba àyè lọ́dọ̀ Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùṣekòkáárí láti ṣe fídíò kan pẹ̀lú àsọyé kan.

English: The video offered practical suggestions such as the installation of handwashing stations, a measure that all congregations have implemented.
Yoruba: Fídíò náà kọ́ni láwọn àbá tó wúlò, irú bíi pé kí wọ́n láwọn ibi téèyàn ti lè fọwọ́ káàkiri, ìyẹn la sì ṣe ní gbogbo ìjọ.

English: These practical measures have helped to reduce the spread of the disease.
Yoruba: Àwọn àbá tó wúlò yìí ti jẹ́ ká lè dín bí ààrùn náà ṣe ń gbilẹ̀ kù.

English: As a result, two public health officials were moved to send the branch office letters of appreciation for the exemplary conduct and cooperation of Jehovah’s Witnesses during the Ebola disease outbreak.
Yoruba: Ohun tá a ṣe yìí mú kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ètò ìlera méjì kọ̀wé ìmọrírì sí ẹ̀ka ófíìsì wa torí àpẹẹrẹ tó dáa àti ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ tí wọ́n rí láàárín àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà lásìkò tí àrùn Ebola fi ń jà.

English: In many cities, our brothers have been quarantined in their homes for weeks at a time.
Yoruba: Ìgbà kan wà tí àwọn ará wa kan ò lè jáde nílé fún ọ̀pọ̀ ọ̀sẹ̀ láwọn ìlú kan.

English: To reduce further the possible spread of disease during this volatile time, the branch office has asked 12 circuits to postpone their regional conventions.
Yoruba: Kódà, torí kí àrùn yìí má bàa túbọ̀ ràn lásìkò náà, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ní kí àyíká méjìlá sún àpéjọ àgbègbè wọn síwájú.

English: To ensure that the brothers still receive their spiritual food, the branch has arranged for affected congregations to watch a recorded video of the convention program in their Kingdom Halls.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wá ṣètò pé kí àwọn ará tó wà láwọn ìjọ tọ́rọ̀ náà kàn wo fídíò àpéjọ àgbègbè tá a ti gbà sílẹ̀ ní Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba wọn, kí wọ́n má bàa pàdánù oúnjẹ tẹ̀mí.

English: Eritrea is the center point of some of the most intense persecution of Jehovah’s Witnesses in modern times.
Yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè Eritrea jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn ibi tí wọ́n ti ń ṣe inúnibíni tó gbóná janjan sí àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà láwọn ọdún àìpẹ́ yìí.

English: As of September 17, 2019, three of the brothers, Paulos Eyasu, Isaac Mogos, and Negede Teklemariam, have been incarcerated for 25 years.
Yoruba: Ní September 17, 2019, àwọn arákùnrin mẹ́tẹ̀ẹ̀ta wọ̀nyí, Paulos Eyasu, Isaac Mogos, àti Negede Teklemariam ti wà lẹ́wọ̀n fún ọdún mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dọ́gbọ̀n.

English: In addition, 39 other brothers and 10 of our sisters are imprisoned.
Yoruba: Láfikún sí i, àwọn arákùnrin wa mọ́kàndínlógójì (39) àtàwọn arábìnrin mẹ́wàá míì ní wọn ti jù sẹ́wọ̀n.

English: All of our brothers and sisters currently in prison have never been charged, appeared in court, or sentenced.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin wa tí wọ́n wà lẹ́wọ̀n báyìí ni ìjọba ilẹ̀ náà kò gbọ́rọ̀ wọn lọ ilé ẹjọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni ilé ẹjọ́ kankan ò dá wọn lẹ́bi.

English: They do not know when they will be released.
Yoruba: Wọn ò mọ ìgbà tí wọ́n máa dá wọn sílẹ̀.

English: Four brothers have died while in prison, and three died after they were released because of the harsh conditions they suffered.
Yoruba: Àwọn arákùnrin mẹ́rin ló ti kù sínú ọgbà ẹ̀wọ̀n, nígbà tí àwọn mẹ́tà míì kú lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n dá wọn sílẹ̀, torí ìyà tí wọ́n fi jẹ wọ́n nígbà tí wọ́n wà lẹ́wọ̀n.

English: Persecution in Eritrea intensified on October 25, 1994, about a year and a half after Eritrea became an independent country from Ethiopia.
Yoruba: Inúnibíni ní Eritrea bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí gbóná sì i ní October 25, 1994 tó jẹ́ nǹkan bí ọdún kan ààbọ̀ lẹ́yìn tí orílẹ̀ èdè Eritrea gbòmìnira lọwọ́ orílẹ̀ èdè Ethiopia.

English: The new president declared that Eritrean-born Jehovah’s Witnesses were no longer considered citizens primarily because they stood firm to their Christian neutrality.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ orílẹ̀ èdè tuntun níbẹ̀ sọ pé gbogbo àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ orílẹ̀ èdè Eritrea tí wọ́n jẹ́ Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà, ní wọn kìí ṣe ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ orílẹ̀ èdè náà mọ́, kìkì ní torí pé, wọ́n dúró láìyẹsẹ̀ lórí ìpinnu wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bí Kristẹni láti má ṣe dá sí tọ̀tún tòsì.

English: The president also stripped them of basic civil rights.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ náà tún fi àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ tí wọ́n ní dù wọ́n.

English: Among other restrictions, Jehovah’s Witnesses are not able to receive a full secular education, own a business, or travel outside of the country.
Yoruba: Lára àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ tí wọ́n tún fi dù wọ́n ni pé àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kò lè lọ sílé ìwé, wọn ò lè dá okòwò tiwọn sílẹ̀ tàbí rìnrìn àjò kúrò lórílẹ̀ èdè náà.

English: In recent years, prominent human rights bodies have expressed increasing concern over Eritrea’s blatant disregard for international human rights standards, including cases involving our fellow Witnesses.
Yoruba: Láwọn ọdún àìpẹ́ yìí, àwọn ẹgbẹ́ ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn tó lórúkọ láwùjọ ti sọ léraléra pé ó ń ká àwọn lára bí ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdè Eritrea ṣe fọwọ́ rọ́ ìlànà nípa ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn lágbàáyé sẹ́yìn tí wọ́n sì ń fojú àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí gbolẹ̀.

English: Eritrea has failed to implement the recommendations issued by these authorities.
Yoruba: Ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdè Eritrea ti kọ̀ jálẹ̀ láti tẹ̀ lé ohun tí àwọn àjọ yìí sọ..

English: See: “SPECIAL REPORT: The Persecution of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Eritrea”
Yoruba: Wo: “ÀKÀNṢE ÌRÒYÌN: Wọ́n Ń Ṣenúnibíni Sáwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà Lórílẹ̀-Èdè Eritrea”

English: We will continue to inform government officials and others in authority about the situation in Eritrea.
Yoruba: Àá máa bá a lọ láti máa sọ fún àwọn aláṣẹ ìjọba àtàwọn míì tó wà nípò àṣẹ nípa bí nǹkan ṣe rí ní Eritrea.

English: On Sunday, March 10, Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 crashed shortly after taking off from Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia.
Yoruba: Ní Sunday, March 10, ọkọ̀ òfúrufú 302 ti Ethiopian Airlines gbéra ní Addis Ababa tó jẹ́ olú ìlú orílẹ̀-èdè Etiópíà, àmọ́ kò pẹ́ lẹ́yìn tó gbéra tó fi ko jàǹbá.

English: All 157 people on board were killed.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àwọn mẹ́tàdínlọ́gọ́jọ (157) tó wà nínú ẹ̀ ló sì kú.

English: Sadly, one of our sisters, Rosemary Mumbi, was among those killed in the plane crash. We are deeply saddened to hear of this tragic loss.
Yoruba: Ó dùn wá pé arábìnrin wa kan tó ń jẹ́ Rosemary Mumbi wà lára àwọn tó kú nínú jàǹbá ọkọ̀ náà. Ìròyìn ikú arábìnrin yìí dùn wá gan-an.

English: Sister Mumbi was 66 years old and a full-time minister in the Roma Manzoni Inglese Congregation in Rome, Italy.
Yoruba: Ẹni ọdún mẹ́rìndínláàádọ́rin (66) ni Arábìnrin Mumbi, ó sì máa ń lo èyí tó pọ̀ jù lára àkókò rẹ̀ lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ ìwàásù, ìjọ Roma Manzoni Inglese ló wà ní ìlú Rome, lórílẹ̀-èdè Ítálì.

English: To reach seldom-worked territories in Gabon, the Cameroon branch organized a special campaign from June 1 to August 31, 2019.
Yoruba: Láti lè dé àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ tí a kì í sábà ṣe lórílẹ̀-èdè Gabon, ẹ̀ka ilé iṣẹ́ wa lórílẹ̀-èdè Cameroon ṣètò ìwàásù àkànṣe láti June 1 sí August 31, 2019.

English: The focus was to reach the residents of the ten most populated cities: Franceville, Koulamoutou, Lambaréné, Libreville, Makokou, Moanda, Mouila, Oyem, Port-Gentil, and Tchibanga.
Yoruba: Àfojúsùn náà jẹ́ láti wàásù dé ọ̀dọ́ àwọn tó ń gbé làwọn ìlú ńlá mẹ́wàá tí èrò pọ̀ sí jùlọ, ìyẹn Franceville, Koulamoutou, Lambaréné, Libreville, Makokou, Moanda, Mouila, Oyem, Port-Gentil, àti Tchibanga.

English: The campaign was an international effort, as it included 400 volunteers from Belgium, Canada, France, and the United States.
Yoruba: Láti onírúurú orílẹ̀-èdè làti kọ́wọ́ ti iṣẹ́ ìwàásù yìí, torí pé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́rin (400) àwọn olùyọ̀ǹda-ara-ẹni ló wá láti Belgium, Kánádà, France, àti orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà.

English: Over two million people reside in Gabon.
Yoruba: Èèyàn tó lé ní mílíọ̀nù méjì ló ń gbé lórílẹ̀-èdè Gabon.

English: While an estimated 80 percent of the population speak the official language, French, an estimated 30 percent also speak Fang as their mother tongue.
Yoruba: Àwọn tó tó ìdá mẹ́jọ nínú mẹ́wàá ló ń sọ èdè Faransé tó jẹ́ èdè àjùmọ̀lò, tí ìdá mẹ́ta nínú mẹ́wàá sì lè sọ èdè Fang tó jẹ́ èdè ìbílẹ̀ wọn.

English: Therefore, the campaign was conducted in both languages.
Yoruba: Torí náà, èdè méjèjì la lò láti wàásù.

English: A Fang-speaking person interested in the Bible, who lives in the Bissegue quarter of Libreville, responded: “This was the very first time I have listened to the message of God in my own language!”
Yoruba: Ẹnìkan tó ń sọ èdè Fang, tó nífẹ̀ẹ́ Bíbélì, tó sì ń gbé lágbègbè Bissegue nílùú Libreville sọ pé: “Ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ nìyí tí màá gbọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run lédè mi!”

English: One sister who participated said: “This campaign has truly manifested the love and unity of Jehovah’s organization.
Yoruba: Arábìnrin kan tó kópa nínú ìwàásù náà sọ pé: “Iṣẹ́ ìwàásù yìí jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ ìfẹ́ àti ìṣọ̀kan tó wà nínú ètò Jèhófà.

English: On January 15, 2019, at least 21 people were killed in an attack on a hotel and office complex in Nairobi, Kenya.
Yoruba: Ní January 15, 2019, ó kéré tán, èèyàn mọ́kànlélógún (21) ló kú nígbà táwọn adigunjalè wá sí hòtẹ́ẹ̀lì àti ọ́fíìsì kan ní ìlú Nairobi, lórílẹ̀-èdè Kenya.

English: The Kenya branch reports that no publishers were killed or injured in the attack, which took place some seven kilometers (four mi) from the branch office.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní Kenya ròyìn pé kò sí ìkankan nínú àwọn akéde tó kú tàbí tó fara pa nígbà ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí. Ibi tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí ti wáyé tó ìrìn kìlómítà méje (máìlì mẹ́rin) sí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa.

English: More than ten brothers and sisters are employed at the Dusit complex, the location of the siege.
Yoruba: Ó ju mẹ́wàá lára àwọn ará wa tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ nínú ọgbà Dusit, táwọn adigunjalè náà ti ṣọṣẹ́.

English: At the time of the attack, seven were not at work; the rest were safely evacuated.
Yoruba: Lásìkò táwọn adigunjalè náà wá, méje lára àwọn ará náà ò sí níbi iṣẹ́; àwọn èèyàn tó kù sì jáde níbẹ̀ ní àlàáfíà.

English: Among those evacuated were one brother and one sister who hid for 12 hours during the siege.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin kan àti arábìnrin kan tó fara pa mọ́ fún wákàtí méjìlá wà lára àwọn tí wọ́n kó jáde níbẹ̀ ní àlàáfíà.

English: Jehovah’s Witnesses released the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in the Luo language at a regional convention in Kisumu, Kenya, on August 30, 2019.
Yoruba: Ní August 30 2019, àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà mú Bíbélì Mímọ́ ti Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lédè Luo ní àpéjọ agbègbè tó wáyé nílùú Kisumu, lórílẹ̀-èdè Kẹ́ńyà.

English: Brother Remy Pringle, a member of the Kenya Branch Committee, released the Bible on the first day of the convention.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Remy Pringle, tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka lórílẹ̀-èdè Kẹ́ńyà ló mú Bíbélì yìí jáde lọ́jọ́ àkọ́kọ́ àpéjọ náà.

English: A total of 2,481, including those tied in at two other conventions, were in attendance.
Yoruba: Àwọn tó wá sí àpéjọ náà, pa pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn tó wà níbi àpéjọ àgbègbè méjì míì tí àtagbà ètò náà dé, jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì, ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́rin àti mọ́kànlélọ́gọ́rin (2,481).

English: The translation work took about three years to complete.
Yoruba: Nǹkan bí ọdún mẹ́ta ni wọ́n fi ṣiṣẹ́ lórí ìtúmọ̀ Bíbélì yìí kó tó parí.

English: One member of the translation team said: “It will have a huge impact on brothers and sisters who have yearned to see the complete New World Translation in Luo.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè tó ṣiṣẹ́ náà sọ pé: “Ó máa nípa tó pọ̀ lórí àwọn arákùnrin àti arábìnrin tí wọn ti ń fojú sọ́nà fún Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun lódindi lédè Luo.

English: Most families in our congregations could not afford the complete Bible for everyone in their household, and so it will be a blessing for each to have a copy.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ìdílé tá a jọ wà nínú ìjọ ni kò le ra odindi Bíbélì fún gbogbo àwọn tó wà nínú ìdílé wọn. Torí náà, ìbùkún lèyí jẹ́ fún wọn láti ní ẹ̀dà kọ̀ọ̀kan.

English: Also, the modern language used in this translation will make personal and family study more faith strengthening.”
Yoruba: Ìyẹn nìkan kọ́, èdè òde òní tá a fi túmọ̀ Bíbélì yìí á mú kó rọrùn láti lóye, bákan náà, á mú kí ìgbàgbọ́ wa túbọ̀ lágbára bá a ṣe ń lò ó fún ìdákẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti ìjọsìn ìdílé.”

English: The New World Translation has been translated, in whole or in part, into 184 languages, including 25 complete revisions based on the 2013 edition.
Yoruba: A ti túmọ̀ Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun lódindi tàbí ní apá kan sí èdè mẹ́rìnlélọ́gọ́sàn-án (184), mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dọ́gbọ̀n (25) nínú wọn jẹ́ àtúnṣe lódindi, tá a gbé ka ẹ̀dà Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tá a tún ṣe lọ́dún 2013.

English: We are sure that this release will assist the approximately 1,800 Luo-speaking publishers in the Kenya branch territory to continue drawing close to Jehovah.
Yoruba: Akéde tó tó nǹkan bí ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àti ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ (1,800) ló ń sọ èdè Luo ní Kẹ́ńyà, ó sì dá wa lójú pé Bíbélì tá a ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ mú jáde yìí á ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti túbọ̀ sún mọ Jèhófà.

English: It will also help in the efforts to preach effectively to the over 5 million people who speak Luo.
Yoruba: Á tún ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti wàásù fún àwọn èèyàn tó lé ní mílíọ̀nù márùn-ún tó ń sọ èdè Luo.

English: A new Bible school facility was dedicated in Eldoret, Kenya, on November 9, 2019.
Yoruba: Ní November 9, 2019, a ya ilé tuntun kan tá a kọ́ fún ilé ẹ̀kọ́ ètò Ọlọ́run sí mímọ́ ní Eldoret, lórílẹ̀-èdè Kẹ́ńyà.

English: Brother Bengt Olsson, a member of the Kenya Branch Committee, gave the dedication talk before a crowd of 1,199, including some 500 special full-time servants who had traveled from various parts of the country to attend.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Bengt Olsson tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka orílẹ̀-èdè Kẹ́ńyà ló sọ àsọyé ìyàsímímọ́ náà. Àwọn ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àti igba ó dín kan (1,199) títí kan ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún (500) àwọn òjíṣẹ́ alákòókò kíkún tí wọ́n wá láti onírúurú ibi lórílẹ̀-èdè náà ló pésẹ̀ síbẹ̀.

English: The 433-square-meter facility (4,660 sq ft) will host classes for the School for Kingdom Evangelizers (SKE) and the School for Circuit Overseers and Their Wives.
Yoruba: Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Àwọn Ajíhìnrere Ìjọba Ọlọ́run (SKE) àti Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Àwọn Alábòójútó Àyíká Àtàwọn Ìyàwó Wọn la fẹ́ máa lo ibẹ̀ fún.

English: At least four SKE classes are expected to graduate annually from the facility.
Yoruba: Ó kéré tán, àwùjọ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ SKE mẹ́rin la retí pé á máa kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ yege níbẹ̀ lọ́dọọdún.

English: Àwọn ilé tí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ń lò tẹ́lẹ̀ àmọ́ tá a ti tún ṣe la sọ di ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí. Ilé táwọn míṣọ́nnárì ń gbé tẹ́lẹ̀ la sọ di ibi tí wọ́n á ti máa fọṣọ, ilé ìdáná àti ilé ìjẹun.
Yoruba: Àwọn ilé tí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ń lò tẹ́lẹ̀ àmọ́ tá a ti tún ṣe la sọ di ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí. Ilé táwọn míṣọ́nnárì ń gbé tẹ́lẹ̀ la sọ di ibi tí wọ́n á ti máa fọṣọ, ilé ìdáná àti ilé ìjẹun.

English: A sì sọ Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan di kíláàsì táwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ á máa lò. April 1, 2019 la bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ yìí, a sì parí èyí tó pọ̀ jù níbẹ̀ ní September 9.
Yoruba: A sì sọ Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan di kíláàsì táwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ á máa lò. April 1, 2019 la bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ yìí, a sì parí èyí tó pọ̀ jù níbẹ̀ ní September 9.

English: Commenting on the school’s significance, Brother Olsson states: “The territory in East Africa has tremendous potential for growth. We are certain that the training provided to the students in the schools will play an important role in caring for future increase, as people stream to the mountain of Jehovah.”
Yoruba: Nígbà tí Arákùnrin Olsson ń sọ bí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí ṣe ṣe pàtàkì tó, ó sọ pé: “Ẹ̀rí fi hàn pé ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn tó ń gbé ní Ìlà Oòrùn Áfíríkà ni wọ́n fẹ́ mọ Ọlọ́run. Ó dá wa lójú pé ìdálẹ́kọ̀ọ́ táwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ máa gbà nílé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí á mú kí wọ́n túbọ̀ já fáfá láti ran ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn lọ́wọ́ kí wọ́n lè rọ́ wá sórí òkè Jèhófà.”

English: Madagascar is recovering from the destructive Cyclone Ava, which struck the country on January 5, 2018. Officials have reported that at least 51 people died and thousands were displaced.
Yoruba: Ní January 5, 2018, ìjì líle Cyclone Ava kọlu orílẹ̀-èdè Madagásíkà. Àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba ròyìn pé nǹkan bí èèyàn mọ́kànléláàádọ́ta [51] ló kú sínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún èèyàn ló sì ti di ẹni tí kò nílé lórí mọ́.

English: Initial assessments from the branch office in Madagascar indicate that no brothers were killed by the storm.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn tá a gbọ́ láti ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wà ní Madagásíkà jẹ́ ká mọ̀ pé kò sí ọ̀kankan nínú àwọn ará wa tó kú sínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà.

English: However, at least 45 homes have been damaged or destroyed, as well as 6 Kingdom Halls.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ilé márùndínláàádọ́ta [45] ló ti bà jẹ́, títí kan Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mẹ́fà.

English: The storm also destroyed local crops, which serve as the livelihood for many of the publishers in the country.
Yoruba: Ìjì yẹn tún ba ohun ọ̀gbìn jẹ́, ohun tí púpọ̀ nínú àwọn ará wa sì fi ń gbọ́ bùkátà ara wọn nìyẹn.

English: A Disaster Relief Committee was formed to care for the immediate needs of the affected publishers, which included providing food supplies, clothing, and temporary shelters.
Yoruba: A ṣètò pé kí Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù bójú tó àwọn ará tí àjálù náà bá, wọ́n pèsè oúnjẹ, aṣọ, wọ́n tún ṣètò ibi táwọn ará lè forí pamọ́ sí fún ìgbà díẹ̀.

English: Two brothers from the branch office also traveled to the disaster area and held a special meeting with all the families affected by the cyclone to give scriptural encouragement.
Yoruba: Àwọn arákùnrin méjì láti ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tún rìnrìn àjò lọ síbẹ̀ láti ṣe ìpàdé àkànṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn tí àjálù náà dé bá, wọ́n fi Bíbélì gbé wọn ró.

English: The Governing Body facilitates disaster relief efforts, including the relief work in the aftermath of this cyclone, using funds donated to the Witnesses’ global ministry work.
Yoruba: Owó táwọn ará wa kárí ayé fi ṣe ìtìlẹyìn fún iṣẹ́ kárí ayé ni Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí lò láti pèsè ìrànwọ́ fáwọn ará wa tí àjálù dé bá kárí ayé, irú èyí tó ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Madagásíkà.

English: We pray that Jehovah will continue to be a secure refuge for our brothers and sisters in Madagascar during this time.
Yoruba: Àdúrà wa ni pé kí Jèhófà máa báa lọ láti jẹ́ orísun ààbò fáwọn ará wa ní Madagásíkà lásìkò tó nira yìí.

English: Listen to the experiences of brothers and sisters in Malawi who participated in the recent letter-writing campaign.
Yoruba: Gbọ́ ìrírí àwọn arákùnrin àti arábìnrin wa ní Màláwì, tí wọ́n kọ lẹ́tà nítorí àwọn ará wa ní Rọ́ṣíà.

English: Several of them reflect on a similar campaign involving their country, which occurred in the 1970’s.
Yoruba: Àwọn kan sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìgbà tí irú ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Rọ́síà ṣẹlẹ̀ lórílẹ̀-èdè wọn, láwọn àkókò kan láàárín ọdún 1970 sí 1979.

English: Sorry, the media player failed to load. Download This Video
Yoruba: Máà bínú, ètò tó o fi ń wo fídíò kò ṣiṣẹ́. Wa Fídíò Yìí Jáde

English: On April 25, 2019, Cyclone Kenneth struck northern Mozambique.
Yoruba: Ní April 25, 2019, ìjì líle kan tí wọ́n pè ní Kenneth jà ní àríwá orílẹ̀-èdè Mòsáńbíìkì.

English: This is the second cyclone to hit the country after Cyclone Idai caused widespread devastation in March.
Yoruba: Ìgbà kejì nìyí tí ìjì líle tún jà léyìn Ìjì Líle Idai tó jà lóṣù March lórílẹ̀-èdè náà.

English: This latest storm caused severe flooding and landslides, which destroyed homes, washed out roads, and further damaged the area’s already unstable infrastructure.
Yoruba: Ìjì tó jà kẹ́yìn yìí fa omíyalé tó pọ̀, ó ba ọ̀pọ̀ ilé àti ọ̀nà jẹ́, kódà ńṣe ló mú kí nǹkan túbọ̀ nira lágbègbè tó ti jà.

English: Some 300 publishers live in the province of Cabo Delgado, but none were injured or killed by the storm.
Yoruba: Nǹkan bíi ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́ta (300) akéde ló ń gbé ní agbègbè Cabo Delgado, àmọ́ kò sí ìkankan lára wọn tí ìjì líle náà ṣe lẹ́se tàbí tó pa.

English: However, 9 of our brothers’ homes were destroyed and 16 sustained damage.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ìjì náà ba mẹ́sàn-án lára ilé àwọn ará wa jẹ́ kọjá àtúnṣe, ó sì tún ba ilé mẹ́rìndínlógún (16) míì jẹ́ díẹ̀.

English: Additionally, one Kingdom Hall was destroyed and three sustained damage.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, ó ba Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan jẹ́ pátápátá, ó sì tún ba mẹ́ta míì jẹ́ díẹ̀.

English: The circuit overseer in the area, a Local Design/Construction field representative, and two brothers from a remote translation office were able to visit all of the affected congregations and offer needed support.
Yoruba: Alábòójútó àyíká tó wà lágbègbè náà àti aṣojú kan láti Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Yàwòrán Ilé Tó sì Ń Kọ́ Ọ pẹ̀lú arákùnrin méjì láti ọ́fíìsì àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè lọ sọ́dọ̀ gbogbo àwọn ìjọ tí àjálù náà kàn, wọ́n sì fún wọn ní ìṣírí.

English: On January 12, 2019, our brothers in Nigeria hosted a special meeting at the Benin City Assembly Hall in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Ní January 12, 2019, àwọn ará wa lórílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ṣe àkànṣe ìpàdé kan ní Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ tó wà ní ìlú Benin.

English: During the event, Geoffrey Jackson, a member of the Governing Body, announced the release of the revised New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in Isoko and Yoruba.
Yoruba: Nínú ìpàdé náà, Arákùnrin Geoffrey Jackson, ọ̀kan lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí kéde pé a ti mú Bíbélì Mímọ́ ti Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tá a tún ṣe jáde ní èdè Isoko àti Yorùbá.

English: A total of 60,672 people tied in to the program.
Yoruba: Àwọn tó wà níbi ìpàdé náà àtàwọn tó wò ó láwọn ibi tá a ta àtagbà rẹ̀ sí jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́ta, ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́fà àti méjìléláàádọ́rin (60,672).

English: Satellite locations included 106 Kingdom Halls and 9 Assembly Halls in Nigeria, as well as venues in the neighboring country of Benin.
Yoruba: A ta àtagbà ìpàdé náà sí Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mẹ́rìndínláàádọ́fà (106) àti Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ mẹ́sàn-án ní Nàìjíríà àti láwọn ibì mélòó kan lórílẹ̀-èdè Benin.

English: Brother Jackson with a family at the Benin City Assembly Hall in Nigeria
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Jackson àti ìdílé kan ní Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ tó wà ní ìlú Benin lórílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà

English: Brother Gad Edia at the Nigeria branch office reports: “It took three years and two months to complete the Isoko translation of the Bible, and three years and three months to translate the Yoruba edition.”
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Gad Edia tó wà ní ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ní Nàìjíríà sọ pé: “Ọdún mẹ́ta àti oṣù méjì ni wọ́n fi túmọ̀ Bíbélì yìí sí èdè Isoko, ó sì gba ọdún mẹ́ta àti oṣù mẹ́ta kí wọ́n tó parí rẹ̀ lédè Yorùbá.”

English: He concludes: “In Nigeria, over 5,000 Witnesses speak Isoko and well over 50,000 speak and read Yoruba. When the brothers received their revised translations, one person described the audience’s reaction as an ‘explosion of delight.’ So we can say with confidence that the effort was well worth it!”
Yoruba: Ó wá sọ pé: “Ní Nàìjíríà, ó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún (5,000) àwọn ará tó ń sọ èdè Isoko, àwọn tó ń sọ èdè Yorùbá tí wọ́n sì ń kà á lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà àádọ́ta (50,000). Nígbà táwọn ará gba Bíbélì tá a tún ṣe yìí, ẹnì kan sọ bó ṣe rí lára àwọn tó wà níbẹ̀ pé ‘ìdùnnú ṣubú layọ̀.’ Torí náà, a lè fi gbogbo ẹnu sọ pé ìsapá náà tó bẹ́ẹ̀, ó jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ!”

English: To date, Jehovah’s Witnesses have made the New World Translation available in whole or in part in 179 languages.
Yoruba: Ní lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí, àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ti mú Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lódindi tàbí lápá kan ní èdè mọ́kàndínlọ́gọ́sàn-án (179).

English: Extreme rains in southwest Nigeria from July 6 through July 12, 2017, caused flooding in the states of Lagos, Niger, and Oyo. News reports indicate that at least 18 people have died as a result.
Yoruba: Òjò rọ̀ gan-an ní gúúsù ìwọ̀ oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà láti July 6 sí July 12, 2017, ó sì mú kí omi yalé àwọn èèyàn ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó, Niger àti Ọ̀yọ́. Ìròyìn tá a gbọ́ ni pé, ó kéré tán, èèyàn méjìdínlógún [18] ni ẹ̀mí wọn ti lọ sí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí.

English: The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Nigeria has confirmed that none of Jehovah’s Witnesses have been killed or injured during this disaster, though four were displaced.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ní Nàìjíríà ti wádìí, wọ́n sì ti rí i pé Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kankan ò kú sínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí, ìkankan ò sì fara pa, bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé mẹ́rin nínú wọn ò nílé lórí mọ́.

English: Additionally, two of the Witnesses’ homes sustained damage and another one was destroyed.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, ilé Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà méjì ló bà jẹ́, ilé ẹnì kan sì wà tó bà jẹ́ pátápátá.

English: Witnesses in Nigeria are providing relief aid to their fellow worshippers as well as their non-Witness neighbors, a number of whom also were displaced or lost homes.
Yoruba: Àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà ní Nàìjíríà ń ṣèrànwọ́ fáwọn ará wọn àtàwọn aládùúgbò wọn tí kì í ṣe Ẹlẹ́rìí, táwọn kan nínú wọn náà ò nílé lórí mọ́.

English: Heavy seasonal rains have triggered severe flooding in Nigeria primarily in the central and southern regions of the country.
Yoruba: Òjò àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá ti fa omíyalé lọ́pọ̀ ibi ní àárín gbùngbùn orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà àti láwọn agbègbè tó wà ní gúúsù.

English: Water levels in the Benue and Niger rivers, the two major waterways in the country, have overflowed their banks, displacing thousands of people and leaving over 100 dead.
Yoruba: Odò Benue àti odò Niger, àwọn odò méjèèjì tó la orílẹ̀-èdè náà já ti kún kọjá ààlà wọn, èyí ti lé ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn kúrò níbi tí wọ́n ń gbé, ó sì lé ní ọgọ́rùn-ún (100) èèyàn tó pa.

English: Initial reports indicate that none of our brothers have been killed or injured.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn tá a kọ́kọ́ gbọ́ sọ pé kò sí ìkankan lára àwọn ará wa tó bá àjálù náà lọ tàbí tó fara pa.

English: However, the flooding has displaced at least 2,000 publishers, and over 1,000 of these are in need of relief aid.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, ó kéré tán, ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì (2,000) akéde ni omíyalé náà lé kúrò níbi tí wọ́n ń gbé, ó sì ju ẹgbẹ̀rún kan (1,000) lára wọn tó nílò ìrànlọ́wọ́.

English: The majority of those who fled their homes have found shelter in homes of fellow Witnesses located in safe areas.
Yoruba: Èyí tó pọ̀ jù lára àwọn tó sá kúrò nílé wọn yìí ló ti ń gbé lọ́dọ̀ àwọn ará láwọn agbègbè tí àjálù náà ò dé.

English: A Disaster Relief Committee has been established to coordinate relief aid and to provide spiritual encouragement.
Yoruba: A ti ní kí Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ láti pèsè àwọn nǹkan tí àwọn ará nílò, kí wọ́n sì fún wọn níṣìírí nípa tẹ̀mí.

English: Two members of the Nigeria Branch Committee, along with the circuit overseer and brothers working in the Service Department and Local Design/Construction Department, have visited the publishers in the affected areas to provide support.
Yoruba: Méjì lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka ní Nàìjíríà àti alábòójútó àyíká kan pẹ̀lú àwọn arákùnrin tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní Ẹ̀ka Iṣẹ́ Ìsìn àti Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Yàwòrán Ilé Tó sì Ń Kọ́ Ọ lọ ṣèbẹ̀wò sọ́dọ̀ àwọn akéde tó wà láwọn agbègbè tọ́rọ̀ kàn, láti ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́.

English: Despite the challenges brought on by this disaster, our heavenly Father, Jehovah, continues to be a “fortress in the time of distress.”
Yoruba: Bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé àjálù yìí ti fa ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìṣòro, Baba wa ọ̀run, Jèhófà, ṣì ‘ni odi ààbò wa ní àkókò wàhálà.

English: At the end of September 2018, Jehovah’s Witnesses in Rwanda reached a milestone in their efforts to share the Bible’s message in the languages of their branch territory: the inauguration of translation work into Rwandan Sign Language (RWS).
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ pẹ́ táwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ti ń sọ Ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run fáwọn èèyàn Rùwáńdà, àmọ́ èyí tí wọ́n ṣe ní September 2018 tún ṣàrà ọ̀tọ̀ : Wọ́n bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í túmọ̀ àwọn ìwé tó dá lórí Bíbélì sí Èdè Adití Lọ́nà ti Rùwáńdà (RWS).

English: These efforts will benefit some 113 deaf brothers and sisters in Rwanda and will better equip publishers to preach to the over 30,000 deaf and hard-of-hearing people in the country.
Yoruba: Ohun tí wọ́n ṣe yẹn máa mú káwọn mẹ́tàléláàádọ́fà (113) arákùnrin àti arábìnrin tó jẹ́ adití túbọ̀ lóye ẹ̀kọ́ Bíbélì, á sì jẹ́ kí wọ́n túbọ̀ já fáfá láti wàásù fáwọn adití àtàwọn tí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ gbọ́rọ̀, tó lé lẹ́gbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgbọ̀n (30,000) lórílẹ̀-èdè náà.

English: The RWS translation team has translated the brochure Listen to God and Live Forever, the short video Why Study the Bible?, and most of the tracts that are part of our Teaching Toolbox.
Yoruba: Àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè RWS yìí ti túmọ̀ ìwé Tẹ́tí sí Ọlọ́run Kó O Lè Wà Láàyè Títí Láé, wọ́n túmọ̀ fídíò kúkúrú Kí Nìdí Tó Fi Yẹ Kó O Kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì? àti ọ̀pọ̀ ìwé àṣàrò kúkúrú tó wà nínú Àpótí Ìkọ́nilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wa.

English: These publications will be made available on our official website in the coming weeks.
Yoruba: A máa gbé àwọn ìtẹ̀jáde yìí sórí ìkànnì wa láìpẹ́.

English: The RWS translation team works in a facility that is just a five-minute walk from the Rwanda branch office in Kigali.
Yoruba: Inú ilé kan tí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ jìnnà sí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa nílùú Kigali làwọn atúmọ̀ èdè RWS yìí ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ wọn, kódà kò ju ìrìn ìṣẹ́jú márùn-ún lọ.

English: The team consists of two brothers, one of whom is deaf, and two sisters.
Yoruba: Mẹ́rin làwọn atúmọ̀ èdè náà, ọkùnrin méjì àti obìnrin méjì, odi sì ni ọ̀kan lára àwọn arákùnrin náà.

English: Each member of the translation team is proficient in sign language and completed a four-week-long training course designed to assist them in learning the principles of translation.
Yoruba: Àwọn mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin ló ti gba ìdálẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ọlọ́sẹ̀ mẹ́rin tó ń jẹ́ kéèyàn mọ àwọn ìlànà tó rọ̀ mọ́ títúmọ̀ èdè.

English: The Rwandan Sign Language translation office, located a short distance from the Rwanda branch office.
Yoruba: Ọ́fíìsì àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè náà rèé, kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ jìnnà sí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì orílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà.

English: One of the RWS translators, Rwakibibi Jean Pierre, explains why sign language presents obstacles not present when translating into a language that has a written alphabet: “Deaf people communicate ideas visually by using their hands and facial expressions, so sign-language translators translate text to video by employing a special technique called idea mapping.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Rwakibibi Jean Pierre tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè RWS ṣàlàyé ohun tó fà á tó fi máa ń ṣòro láti túmọ̀ sí èdè adití tá a bá fi wé títúmọ̀ sáwọn èdè míì tó ṣeé kà, Ó ní: “Ọwọ́ àti ojú làwọn tó jẹ́ adití fi máa ń bá ara wọn sọ̀rọ̀, torí náà fídíò la máa ń lò láti mú káwọn adití lóye ọ̀rọ̀ tí wọ́n kọ sínú ìwé.

English: Using a whiteboard, we convert the English text into drawings that act as a guide as we express the ideas of the original text in sign language.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tá a bá ti lóye ohun tí òǹkọ̀wé sọ lédè òyìnbó, àá ya onírúurú àwòrán sórí pátákó ìkọ̀wé funfun kan, kó lè rọrùn fún wa láti fara ṣàpèjúwe ohun tí òǹkọ̀wé ń sọ lédè adití.

English: To ensure the clarity and accuracy of the finished product, an outside panel of deaf Witnesses reviews the translated materials and offers feedback.”
Yoruba: Kó lè dá wa lójú pé ohun tí òǹkọ̀wé ń sọ gan-an la gbé jáde àti pé a ò fi irú pe ìrù, a sábà máa ń pe àwọn ará tó jẹ́ adití láti ṣàyẹ̀wò rẹ̀ kí wọ́n sì sọ èrò wọn nípa ẹ̀.”

English: Mr. Augustin Munyangeyo, board chairman of the Rwanda National Union of the Deaf.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Augustin Munyangeyo tó jẹ́ ọ̀gá àgbà àjọ Rwanda National Union of the Deaf.

English: Mr. Augustin Munyangeyo, board chairman of the Rwanda National Union of the Deaf, a national nongovernmental organization that advocates for the rights of deaf Rwandans, comments on the Witnesses’ RWS translation work: “We deeply commend Jehovah’s Witnesses for providing religious education using the Bible and videos prepared in Rwandan Sign Language.”
Yoruba: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Augustin Munyangeyo tó jẹ́ ọ̀gá àgbà àjọ àdáni kan tó ń bójú tó ọ̀rọ̀ àwọn adití lórílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà, ìyẹn Rwanda National Union of the Deaf, sọ bó ṣe mọyì iṣẹ́ táwọn atúmọ̀ èdè yẹn ń ṣe. Ó sọ pé: “A dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ẹ̀yin Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà gidigidi fún iṣẹ́ ribiribi tẹ́ ẹ̀ ń ṣe. Ẹ̀yin lẹ̀ ń jẹ́ káwọn adití mọ Ọlọ́run torí pé ẹ̀ ń ṣe ìwé Bíbélì àti fídíò lédè Adití lọ́nà ti Rùwáńdà.”

English: To date, Jehovah’s Witnesses translate into over 90 sign languages worldwide, and have produced a free app, JW Library Sign Language®, that also allows users to access Bible-based publications in more than 90 sign languages.
Yoruba: Tá a bá kà á ní ení, èjì, èdè adití táwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ń túmọ̀ ìwé wa sí láwọn ibi ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ láyé ti lé ní àádọ́rùn-ún (90), yàtọ̀ síyẹn, a tún ní ètò ìṣiṣẹ́ kan ta á dìídì ṣe fún àǹfààní gbogbo èèyàn láìbéèrè kọ́bọ̀, ìyẹn JW Library Sign Language®, oríṣiríṣi ìtẹ̀jáde tá a gbé karí Bíbélì ló wà ní àwọn èdè adití tó lé láàádọ́rùn-ún (90) yẹn.

English: The availability of these many sign-language publications assists our brothers and sisters worldwide to declare the good news “to every nation and tribe and language and people.”—Revelation 14:6, footnote.
Yoruba: Báwọn ìtẹ̀jáde yìí ṣe wà lónírúurú èdè adití mú kó ṣeé ṣe fáwọn ará wa lọ́kùnrin àti lóbìnrin níbi gbogbo láyé láti wàásù ìhìn rere fún “gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè àti ẹ̀yà àti èdè àti èèyàn.”​—Ìfihàn 14:​6, àlàyé ìsàlẹ̀.

English: One year before the RWS translation work began, the Rwanda branch held the first Pioneer Service School in RWS from September 4 to 9, 2017.
Yoruba: Lọ́dún tó ṣáájú ọdún tí wọ́n bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í túmọ̀ àwọn ìtẹ̀jáde wa sí RWS, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì orílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà ṣètò Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Àwọn Aṣáájú-Ọ̀nà ní ọ̀sẹ̀ September 4 sí 9, 2017.

English: The class, which was made up of 23 students, learned how to become more effective when teaching deaf and hard-of-hearing individuals about the Bible.
Yoruba: Èdè Adití Lọ́nà ti Rùwáńdà ni wọ́n fi ṣe ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà, ìyẹn sì ni àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀. Àwọn mẹ́tàlélógún (23) ló wá sílé ẹ̀kọ́ náà, wọ́n sì kọ́ bí wọ́n ṣe lè túbọ̀ mọ̀ọ̀yàn kọ́, pàápàá bí wọ́n ṣe lè kọ́ àwọn adití lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì, títí kan àwọn tí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ gbọ́rọ̀.

English: The pioneer school instructors for the RWS class followed the curriculum outlined in a sign-language translation of the book “Fully Accomplish Your Ministry.”
Yoruba: Ìlànà ẹ̀kọ́ nípa béèyàn ṣe lè kọ́ àwọn adití lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ làwọn olùkọ́ ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà tẹ̀ lé. A ti tẹ àwọn ìlànà yìí sínú ìwé kan tá a pè ní “Ṣàṣeparí Iṣẹ́ Òjíṣẹ́ Rẹ ní Kíkún.”

English: The students used a supplemental workbook developed specifically for teaching the Bible in sign language.
Yoruba: A tún ṣe ìwé ilé ẹ̀kọ́ kan lákànṣe fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́, èyí táá jẹ́ kí wọ́n lóye ẹ̀kọ́ Bíbélì, kí wọ́n sì lè fi kọ́ni lédè adití.

English: For example, it conveys main points through illustrations instead of written text, and is designed to allow students to draw in their own illustrations as memory aids.
Yoruba: Bí àpẹẹrẹ, àwòrán la fi gbé àwọn kókó pàtàkì inú ẹ̀kọ́ Bíbélì jáde dípò ọ̀rọ̀, a sì tún fàyè sílẹ̀ fáwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ láti ya àwòrán tiwọn fúnra wọn, èyí táá mú kí wọ́n lè máa rántí ẹ̀kọ́ tí wọ́n kọ́.

English: The Pioneer Service School began in the United States in December 1977 and since then has gradually extended worldwide.
Yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà la ti kọ́kọ́ ṣe Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Àwọn Aṣáájú-Ọ̀nà ní December 1977, kẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ̀rẹ̀ ó di ohun tá à ń ṣe nígun mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin ayé.

English: During the 2018 service year, pioneer schools were conducted in 83 lands.
Yoruba: Lọ́dún iṣẹ́ ìsìn 2018 nìkan, ìyẹn láti September 2017 sí August 2018, ilẹ̀ mẹ́tàlélọ́gọ́rin (83) ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ la ti ṣe ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà.

English: Brother Ricardo Braz, one of the instructors, interviews a student, Brother Nyandwi Jean de Dieu, during the Pioneer Service School.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Ricardo Braz, tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn olùkọ́ Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Àwọn Aṣáájú-Ọ̀nà ń fọ̀rọ̀ wá akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kan lẹ́nu wò, ìyẹn Arákùnrin Nyandwi Jean de Dieu.

English: The 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi in Rwanda was one of the fastest-moving and most horrific genocides in modern history.
Yoruba: Ìpẹ̀yàrun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ sáwọn ẹ̀yà Tutsi lórílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára èyí tó tíì yára kánkán tó sì tíì bani lẹ́rù jù lọ nínú ìtàn òde òní.

English: The United Nations estimates that some 800,000 to 1,000,000 were murdered in about 100 days.
Yoruba: Àjọ Ìṣọ̀kan Àgbáyé tiẹ̀ fojú bù ú pé láàárín ọgọ́rùn-ún (100) ọjọ́ péré, ó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ (800,000) sí mílíọ̀nù kan (1,000,000) èèyàn tí wọ́n pa.

English: The majority of victims were Tutsi, but Hutu who refused to support the killings were also marked for slaughter.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀yà Tutsi gan-an ni wọ́n dájú sọ, àmọ́ wọ́n tún pa àwọn ẹ̀yà Hutu tí kò bá wọn lọ́wọ́ sí ìpẹ̀yàrun náà.

English: This meant that every one of the 2,500 Jehovah’s Witnesses in Rwanda faced mortal danger.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí pé gbogbo àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tí iye wọn jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì àti ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta (2,500) tó wà ní Rùwáńdà ni ẹ̀mí wọn wà nínú ewu.

English: About 400 of our Rwandan brothers and sisters perished in the genocide, most of them Tutsi.
Yoruba: Àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin tó tó nǹkan bí irínwó (400) ní Rùwáńdà ló kú nígbà ìpẹ̀yàrun náà, èyí tó sì pọ̀ jù lọ lára wọn jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Tutsi.

English: But Hutu Witnesses also died because it was unthinkable for them to harm others or to abandon their Christian brothers and sisters to the killers.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí míì tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu kú torí pé wọ́n kọ̀ láti pa ẹlòmíì lára àti pé wọ́n fẹ́ dá ẹ̀mí arákùnrin tàbí arábìnrin wọn sí.

English: Brother Charles Rutaganira, a Tutsi who survived the genocide 25 years ago, still vividly recalls that Sunday morning when he was certain that he would be killed—and how self-sacrificing love saved his life.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Charles Rutaganira tó jẹ́ ara ẹ̀yà Tutsi mórí bọ́ nígbà ìpẹ̀yàrun tó wáyé lọ́dún márùndínlọ́gbọ̀n (25) sẹ́yìn, ó sọ pé òun rántí àárọ̀ ọjọ́ Sunday kan tóun ti gbà pé wọ́n máa pa òun, àmọ́ àwọn arákùnrin rẹ̀ gba ẹ̀mí rẹ̀ là torí pé wọ́n ní ìfẹ́ ìfara-ẹni-rúbọ.

English: When about 30 attackers swarmed his house, he was in disbelief.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù ba arákùnrin Rutaganira gan-an nígbà tí nǹkan bí ọgbọ̀n èèyàn ya bo ilé rẹ̀.

English: He says: “Most of them were my neighbors. We said hello to each other every day.”
Yoruba: Ó sọ pé: “Aládùúgbò mi ni ọ̀pọ̀ lára wọn. Ojoojúmọ́ la máa ń ríra wa.”

English: But when the mob came to his house that morning, he saw that they had changed.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ nígbà táwọn jàǹdùkú yìí wá sílé ẹ̀ láàárọ̀ ọjọ́ yẹn, ó rí i pé wọ́n ò rí bóun ṣe mọ̀ wọ́n tẹ́lẹ̀ mọ́.

English: “Their eyes were red and filled with hate.
Yoruba: Ó sọ pé “Ojú wọn pọ́n, wọ́n sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í wò òun tìkà-tẹ̀gbin.

English: They looked like animals eager to devour their prey.”
Yoruba: Wọ́n rí bí àwọn ẹranko tó ń wá ẹran tí wọ́n fẹ́ pa jẹ.”

English: The mob assaulted Brother Rutaganira with machetes, spears, and clubs studded with nails—simply because he was a Tutsi.
Yoruba: Àwọn jàǹdùkú náà fi àdá ṣá Arákùnrin Rutaganira, wọ́n fi ọ̀kọ̀ gún un, wọ́n sì fi ọ̀pá tó ní ìṣó lára gbá a, kò sí ìdí méjì ju pé ó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Tutsi.

English: Then, they dragged him out to the street and left him there to die.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà, wọ́n wọ́ ọ sójú títì, wọ́n sì fi í síbẹ̀ kó lè kú.

English: As he lay there semiconscious and bleeding, a crew with shovels came by to bury his body.
Yoruba: Ó ti fẹ́ẹ̀ kú tán níbi tí wọ́n wọ́ ọ sí, ẹ̀jẹ̀ sì ń dà lára ẹ̀ gan-an, kò pẹ́ sákòókò yẹn láwọn òṣìṣẹ́ kan kó ṣọ́bìrì wá síbẹ̀ kí wọ́n lè sin òkú ẹ̀.

English: Apparently, one of them recognized Brother Rutaganira as a peaceful Christian man and asked, “Why did they kill this Jehovah’s Witness?” No one replied.
Yoruba: Ó jọ pé ọ̀kan lára wọn mọ Arákùnrin Rutaganira sí Kristẹni tó jẹ́ èèyàn àlàáfíà, ó wá béèrè pé “Kí nìdí tí wọ́n fi pa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà yìí?” Kò sẹ́ni tó dá a lóhùn.

English: Just then, a heavy rain began to fall and they left.
Yoruba: Kò pẹ́ sígbà yẹn ni òjò ńlá kan bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í rọ̀, bí wọ́n ṣe kúrò níbẹ̀ nìyẹn.

English: Samuel Rwamakuba, a Hutu brother who lived nearby, heard about Brother Rutaganira and sent his son in the pouring rain to carry him to their home.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí Arákùnrin Samuel Rwamakuba tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára ẹ̀yà Hutu tó ń gbé nítòsí gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ sí Arákùnrin Rutaganira, ó ní kọ́mọ òun ọkùnrin lọ gbé arákùnrin náà wá sílé òun nínú òjò tó lágbára yẹn.

English: Two other Hutu brothers braved the dangerous streets to bring medicine and bandages.
Yoruba: Láìka bí ìgboro ṣe léwu lákòókò yẹn sí, àwọn arákùnrin méjì míì tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu fìgboyà jáde, wọ́n sì lọ mú oògùn àti aṣọ tí wọ́n fi máa ń di ọgbẹ́ wá.

English: The killers came looking for Brother Rutaganira.
Yoruba: Àwọn apààyàn yẹn wá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í wá Arákùnrin Rutaganira.

English: On locating him at a Hutu home, the leader threatened: “We will solve this problem tomorrow morning.”
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n rí i nílé ẹnì kan tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu, olórí wọn bá halẹ̀ pé: “Gbogbo yín la máa wá pa láàárọ̀ ọ̀la.”

English: All the Hutu brothers knew they could die for their acts of kindness toward a Tutsi.
Yoruba: Àwọn Arákùnrin tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu yẹn mọ̀ pé wọ́n lè pa àwọn torí ẹ̀yà Tutsi kan tí wọ́n ṣàánú.

English: According to Brother Rutaganira: “If someone was supposed to be killed and you tried to save his life, they definitely would kill you and kill him at the same time.”
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Rutaganira sọ pé: “Tó o bá lọ dá ẹ̀mí ẹni kan tí wọ́n fẹ́ pa sí, ìwọ àtẹni náà ni wọ́n jọ máa pa.”

English: As a Hutu, Brother Rwamakuba might have been able to flee and pass the roadblocks, which were manned day and night by armed militias.
Yoruba: Torí pé ẹ̀yà Hutu ni Arákùnrin Rwamakuba, ó ṣeé ṣe kó má ṣòro fún un láti sá lọ kó sì gba ibi táwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ tó dìhámọ́ra ti gbégi dínà tí wọ́n sì ń ṣọ́ ojú ọ̀nà látàárọ̀ ṣúlẹ̀.

English: But he refused to abandon his wounded Tutsi brother, telling him: “I will not leave you.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ kò fi arákùnrin ẹ̀ tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Tutsi tó ti ṣèṣe yìí sílẹ̀, ó sọ fún un pé: “Mi ò ni fi ẹ́ sílẹ̀.

English: Where you die, I will die.”
Yoruba: Ibi tó o bá kú sí lèmi náà máa kú sí.”

English: Early the next day, a battle with opposition soldiers broke out in the streets and the killers fled.
Yoruba: Láàárọ̀ ọjọ́ kejì, àwọn sójà bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í bá àwọn apààyàn yẹn jà, bí gbogbo wọn ṣe sá lọ nìyẹn.

English: After Brother Rutaganira recovered from his wounds, he returned to find many in his congregation mourning the senseless murder of loved ones and suffering from emotional and physical trauma, including torture and rape.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí ọgbẹ́ ara Arákùnrin Rutaganira san, ó pa dà sílé kó lè lọ bá àwọn ará ìjọ rẹ̀ tó ń ṣọ̀fọ̀ àwọn olólùfẹ́ wọn tí wọ́n pa láìnídìí, ọpọ̀ lára wọn ló ní ìdààmú ọkàn àti ìrora tó lágbára torí bí wọ́n ṣe fìyà jẹ wọ́n, tí wọ́n sì fipá bá àwọn míì lò pọ̀.

English: “The first few months after the genocide were especially difficult,” Brother Rutaganira recalls.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin  Rutaganira sọ pé: “Nǹkan nira gan-an lẹ́yìn oṣù díẹ̀ tí ìpẹ̀yàrun yẹn dáwọ́ dúró.”

English: But with love and understanding, Hutu and Tutsi brothers and sisters helped one another to heal.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ torí pe àwọn arákùnrin tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu àti Tutsi nífẹ̀ẹ́ ara wọn, wọ́n sì fòye bára wọn lò, ó jẹ́ kí wọ́n lè ran ara wọn lọ́wọ́ láti borí ìbànújẹ́ tí wọ́n ní.

English: “They worked hard not to have any hypocrisy or distinction or division among them,” he says.
Yoruba: Ó sọ pé: “Wọ́n ṣiṣẹ́ kára kó má bàa sí àgàbàgebè tàbí èrò ‘ẹ̀yà tèmi lọ̀gá,’ tàbí ìyapa láàárín wọn.”

English: In April 2019, an exhibition at the National Center for Civil and Human Rights in Atlanta, Georgia, told the stories of brothers and sisters who survived and those who died during the genocide in Rwanda
Yoruba: Ní April 2019, wọ́n ṣe àfihàn kan ní Ojúkò Tó Wà fún Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọnìyàn ní ìlú Atlanta lórílẹ̀-èdè Georgia tó níṣe pẹ̀lú ìtàn àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin tó la ìpẹ̀yàrun tó wáyé lórílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà já àtàwọn tó kú

English: Despite their deep distress, Witnesses throughout Rwanda resumed their Christian meetings and preaching work.
Yoruba: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ìdààmú ọkàn bá àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà káàkiri orílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà, wọ́n bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í lọ sáwọn ìpàdé Kristẹni, wọ́n sì ń wàásù.

English: They found many in desperate need of spiritual comfort.
Yoruba: Wọ́n rí ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn tó nílò ìtùnú àti ìrètí lójú méjèèjì.

English: Some people were tormented by the horrific losses they suffered.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ni wọ́n fìyà jẹ gan an torí bí wọ́n ṣe pa àwọn èèyàn wọn nípa ìkà.

English: Others were tortured by their own consciences because of the terrible deeds they had committed.
Yoruba: Ṣe ni ẹ̀rí ọkàn àwọn ẹlòmíì ń dá wọn lẹ́bi torí ohun burúkú tí wọ́n ṣe.

English: Many in Rwanda felt betrayed—by their neighbors, by their leaders, and especially by their churches.
Yoruba: Ó dun ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn lórílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà gan an torí báwọn aládùúgbò wọn, àwọn olóṣèlú, pàápàá jùlọ báwọn aṣáájú ẹ̀sìn ṣe já wọn kulẹ̀.

English: (See the box “ The Churches’ Role in the Genocide in Rwanda.”)
Yoruba: (Wo àpótí náà “ Bí Àwọn Oníṣọ́ọ̀ṣì Náà Ṣe Kópa Nínú Ìpẹ̀yàrun Tó Ṣẹlẹ̀ Ní Rùwáńdà.”)

English: Yet, among Rwandans, the peaceful conduct of Jehovah’s people stood out.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará Rùwáńdà kíyè sí i pé àlàáfíà wà láàárín àwọn èèyàn Jèhófà, ohun tó sì mú kí wọ́n ṣàrà ọ̀tọ̀ nìyẹn.

English: A Catholic Tutsi schoolteacher and her six children were hidden by a Witness family she hardly knew.
Yoruba: Ìdílé Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kan fi olùkọ́ ilé ìwé Kátólíìkì kan tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Tutsi àtàwọn ọmọ rẹ̀ mẹ́fà pamọ́, bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé olùkọ́ náà ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ ìdílé náà rí.

English: She says: “I have a grand appreciation for Jehovah’s Witnesses. . . .
Yoruba: Olùkọ́ náà sọ pé: “Mo bọ̀wọ̀ fáwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà gan an. . . .

English: Most people saw that they did not get involved with the genocide.”
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ló mọ̀ pé wọn ò lọ́wọ́ sí ìpẹ̀yàrun náà.”

English: After the horrors of the genocide, Rwandans filled the Kingdom Halls.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn tí ìpẹ̀yàrun náà parí, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará Rùwáńdà rọ́ wá sínú Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba.

English: On average, every publisher conducted three Bible studies.
Yoruba: Ní ìpíndọ́gba, akéde kọ̀ọ̀kan darí ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì mẹ́ta.

English: During the 1996 service year, the number of Witnesses in Rwanda increased more than 60 percent, as people yearned for the healing balm of the Kingdom message.
Yoruba: Láàárín ọ́dún iṣẹ́ ìsìn 1996, ìdá ọgọ́ta nínú ọgọ́rùn-ún ni àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà ní Rùwáńdà fi pọ̀ sí i, ìdí ni pé ìwàásù táwọn èèyàn gbọ́ ń tù wọ́n nínú, wọ́n sì nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí i.

English: For many, especially survivors, the 25th anniversary of the genocide is a time of deep reflection.
Yoruba: Ọdún yìí ló pé ọdún márùndínlọ́gbọ̀n (25) tí ìpẹ̀yàrun yẹn wáyé, ọpọ̀ èèyàn ló ń ronú jinlẹ̀ nípa ìpẹ̀yàrun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ náà, pàápàá jùlọ àwọn tó là á já.

English: Brother Rutaganira and other eyewitnesses remain convinced that Christlike love is far more powerful than racial hatred.
Yoruba: Ó dá Arákùnrin Rutaganira àtàwọn míì tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yẹn ṣojú wọn lójú pé ojúlówó ìfẹ́ Kristẹni lágbára ju ìkórìíra tó wà láàárín àwọn ẹ̀yà lọ.

English: “Jesus Christ taught his true followers to love one another more than themselves,” Brother Rutaganira says.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Rutaganira sọ pé, “Jésù Kristi kọ́ àwọn ọmọ ẹ̀yìn rẹ̀ olóòótọ́ pé kí wọ́n nífẹ̀ẹ́ ọmọnìkejì wọn ju ara wọn lọ.

English: “I am alive today because this kind of love is a reality among Jehovah’s people.”—John 15:13.
Yoruba: Ìdí tí mo fi wà láàyè lónìí ni pé irú ìfẹ́ yìí wà láàárín àwọn èèyàn Jèhófà lóòótọ́.”​—Jòhánù 15:13.

English: “Rwanda is an overwhelmingly Christian country,” states the book Christianity and Genocide in Rwanda, with about 90 percent of the population claiming church membership.
Yoruba: Ìwé Christianity and Genocide in Rwanda sọ pé, ìdá àádọ́sàn-án nínú ọgọ́rùn-ún èèyàn tó ń gbé ní Rùwáńdà ló ń lọ sí Ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì, ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí pé ó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ jẹ́ gbogbo èèyàn ló sọ pé Kristẹni làwọn ní Rùwáńdà.

English: According to author Timothy Longman, during the genocide many Hutu—including priests and pastors—killed Tutsi members of their own churches.
Yoruba: Òǹṣèwé kan tórúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Timothy Longman sọ pé, nígbà ìpẹ̀yàrun yẹn, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì, títí kan àwọn aṣáájú ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu ló pa àwọn ọmọ ìjọ wọn tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Tutsi.

English: He asked: “Why . . . did loyalty to their church and to their fellow believers not prevent Catholics from killing fellow Catholics and Protestants from killing fellow Protestants?”
Yoruba: Ó béèrè pé: “Tí wọ́n bá jẹ́ olóòótọ́ sí ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì wọn àtàwọn onígbàgbọ́ bíi tiwọn, kí . . . nìdí táwọn Kátólíìkì fi ń pa Kátólíìkì, táwọn Pùròtẹ́sítáǹtì sì fí ń pa Pùròtẹ́sítáǹtì?”

English: The role of Rwanda’s churches in the ethnic slaughter has deep historical roots.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ ti pẹ́ táwọn oníṣọ́ọ̀ṣì ti ń kópa nínú ìjà kẹ́lẹ́yàmẹ̀yà.

English: For decades before, church leaders had collaborated with political authorities to maintain power, in part, by creating and stoking ethnic tensions.
Yoruba: Ní ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún ṣáájú ìpẹ̀yàrun yẹn, àwọn aṣáájú ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì àtàwọn olóṣèlú ní Rùwáńdà gbìmọ̀ pọ̀ kí wọ́n má bà a kúrò nípò àṣẹ.

English: Hence, Professor Longman wrote: “The Christian message received in Rwanda was not one of ‘love and fellowship.’”
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára ọ̀nà tí wọ́n lò ni pé, wọ́n gbin ẹ̀mí ẹ̀tanú àti kẹ́lẹ́yàmẹ̀yà sọ́kàn àwọn èèyàn. Síbẹ̀, Ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n Longman kọ̀wé pé: “Lórílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà, àwọn aṣáájú ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì ò kọ́ àwọn èèyàn lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa ‘ìfẹ́ àti bí wọ́n ṣe lè fara rora pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹlòmíì.’”

English: When Hutu extremists took power, clergy support continued.
Yoruba: Nígbà táwọn tó gbin ẹ̀mí ìkórìíra sọ́kàn àwọn ẹ̀yà Hutu lòdì sí ẹ̀yà Tutsi dórí àlééfà, ńṣe làwọn aṣáájú ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì ń tì wọ́n lẹ́yìn.

English: When the genocide began, religious leaders issued no condemnation but rather urged their members to obey the government.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí ìpẹ̀yàrun náà bẹ̀rẹ̀, dípò káwọn aṣáájú ẹ̀sìn yìí dẹ́bi fún ìwà ipá àti ẹ̀tanú tó gbilẹ̀, ṣe ni wọ́n sọ fáwọn ọmọ ìjọ wọn pé kí wọ́n ṣe ohunkóhun táwọn olóṣèlú bá ní kí wọ́n ṣe.

English: “Many church members concluded that the church leaders endorsed the killing,” said Professor Longman.
Yoruba: Ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n Longman sọ pé “Èrò ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn tó ń lọ sí ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì ni pé àwọn aṣáájú ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì ló fọwọ́ sí ìpẹ̀yàrun náà.

English: He cited examples of killers who even paused to pray at the altar before going out to kill.
Yoruba: Ó tiẹ̀ sọ àpẹẹrẹ àwọn apààyàn kan tí wọ́n máa ń kọ́kọ́ gbàdúrà lórí pẹpẹ ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì kí wọ́n tó jáde lọ pààyàn.

English: The human rights report Rwanda: Death, Despair, and Defiance concluded: “The genocide in Rwanda has dramatically shown up the moral and spiritual bankruptcy of the hierarchies of all the major churches.”
Yoruba: Ìtẹ̀jáde tó ń jẹ́ Rwanda: Death, Despair, and Defiance sọ nínú ìròyìn tí wọ́n gbé jáde pé “Ìpẹ̀yàrun tó wáyé ní Rùwáńdà fi hàn lọ́nà tó ṣe kedere pé àwọn aṣáájú ìsìn tó wà ní ọ̀pọ̀ ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì kò níwà rere, wọn ò sì mọ Ọlọ́run.”

English: As Rwandan church leaders went on trial for genocide, one news report observed: “Only Jehovah’s Witnesses are accused of nothing.”
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n gbé àwọn aṣáájú ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì ní Rùwáńdà lọ sílé ẹjọ́ torí pé wọ́n lọ́wọ́ sí ìpẹ̀yàrun, àwọn oníròyìn kan kíyè sí i pé: “Àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà nìkan ni wọn ò fi ẹ̀sùn èyíkéyìí kan.”

English: In explaining the Witnesses’ behavior, professor of theology J. J. Carney notes that “nonviolence is a central tenet of their community.”
Yoruba: Nígbà tí J. J. Carney tó jẹ́ ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n nínú ẹ̀kọ́ ìsìn ń ṣàlàyé nípa ìwà àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà, ó sọ pé “ọ̀kan pàtàkì lára ohun táwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà gbà gbọ́ ni pé ìwà ipá kò dára.”

English: Genocide scholar John Roth points to the Witnesses’ “refusal to put allegiance to a State ahead of allegiance to God.”
Yoruba: John Roth tó jẹ́ ọ̀mọ̀wé nípa ìpẹ̀yàrun sọ pé, àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà gbà pé ó ṣe pàtàkì kéèyàn ṣègbọràn sí Ọlọ́run ju kéèyàn ṣègbọràn sáwọn olóṣèlú.”

English: Brother Tharcisse Seminega, whose family survived with the help of Hutu Witnesses, gives yet another reason for the peaceful and life-saving acts of his fellow believers: Christlike love.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Tharcisse Seminega, táwọn ará tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Hutu dáàbò bo ìdílé rẹ̀ sọ ohun míì tó mú káwọn onígbàgbọ́ bíi tiẹ̀ jẹ́ èèyàn àlàáfíà tó sì mú kí wọ́n máa ṣiṣẹ́ ìgbẹ̀mílà: Ojúlówó ìfẹ́ Kristẹni ni.

English: “It is only this kind of love that has the power to immunize the heart and mind against the toxin of hatred,” he says.
Yoruba: Ó sọ pé “Irú ìfẹ́ yìí nìkan ló lágbára láti dáàbò bo ọkàn àti ìrònú èèyàn lọ́wọ́ oró ẹ̀tanú.”

English: Widespread heavy rainstorms struck northern Rwanda on October 26 and 29, 2019, affecting several families of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Yoruba: Ní October 26 àti 29, 2019, òjò oníjì líle ṣọṣẹ́ ní ibi tó pọ̀ ní apá àríwá orílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà, ó sì kan ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà.

English: Tragically, the 13-year-old daughter of a Witness couple in the Musanze District of the Northern Province was swept away in the floodwaters and died.
Yoruba: Ó dùn wá pé omi gbé ọmọbìnrin kan tó jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́tàlá (13) lọ. Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà làwọn òbí ẹ̀, àdúgbò Musanze ní apá Àríwá ni wọ́n sì ń gbé.

English: In the Ngororero District of the Western Province, one Witness family suffered the destruction of their home and nine families lost their crops.
Yoruba: Ní agbègbè Ngororero tó wà ní apá Ìwọ̀ Oòrùn, ilé àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí kan bà jẹ́, ìdílé mẹ́sàn-án ló sì pàdánù irè oko wọn.

English: The Rwanda branch office is coordinating relief efforts in the region, including material aid and spiritual assistance.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Rwanda ń pèsè ìrànwọ́ fún àwọn tí àjálù bá ní agbègbè yẹn, wọ́n sì ń pèsè ohun tí wọ́n nílò nípa tara àti nípa tẹ̀mí.

English: We pray that Jehovah will comfort the hearts of our brothers who are suffering from this tragedy.—2 Thessalonians 2:16, 17.
Yoruba: Àdúrà wa ni pé kí Jèhófà tu àwọn ará tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí kàn nínú.​—2 Tẹsalóníkà 2:16, 17.

English: From August 16 to 18, 2019, our brothers held the first regional convention in Rwandan Sign Language (RWS) in Kigali, Rwanda.
Yoruba: Ní August 16 sí 18, 2019, àwọn arákùnrin wa ṣe àpéjọ agbègbè lédè adití ti Rùwáńdà nílùú Kigali, lórílẹ̀-èdè Rùwáńdà, ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tírú ẹ̀ máa wáyé rèé.

English: The peak attendance was 620, and 8 deaf individuals were baptized.
Yoruba: Ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́fà àti ogún (620) èèyàn ló wà sí àpéjọ náà, àwọn adití mẹ́jọ ló sì ṣèrìbọmi.

English: The audience signing one of the Kingdom songs
Yoruba: Àwọn tó wá sí àpéjọ náà ń fi èdè adití kọ orin Ìjọba Ọlọ́run

English: Two public officials attended the convention on Sunday: Mr. Jean Damascène Bizimana, a member of the board of directors of the Rwanda National Union of the Deaf, and Mr. Emmanuel Ndayisaba, executive secretary of the National Council of Persons with Disabilities.
Yoruba: Àwọn àlejò láti iléeṣẹ́ ìjọba méjì ló wà ní àpéjọ yìí lọ́jọ́ Sunday, àwọn ni: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Jean Damascène Bizimana tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn olùdarí Ẹgbẹ́ Àwọn Adití Ilẹ̀ Rùwáńdà àti Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Emmanuel Ndayisaba tó jẹ́ akọ̀wé àgbà fún Àjọ Tó Ń Bójú Tó Àwọn Aláàbọ̀ Ara lórílẹ̀-èdè Rwanda.

English: Additionally, the Ukwezi newspaper covered the convention program on Sunday and published a positive report online.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, iléeṣẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn tó ń jẹ́ Ukwezi náà wà níbẹ̀ lọ́jọ́ Sunday, wọ́n sì gbé ìròyìn tó wúni lórí jáde lórí ìkànnì wọn.

English: A sister interprets the convention program for a deaf-blind individual using tactile signing
Yoruba: Arábìnrin kan ń túmọ̀ ìtòlẹ́sẹẹsẹ àpéjọ náà fún ẹnì kan tó fọ́jú tó sì tún yadi. Ó ń fi ọwọ́ ṣe àmì ohun tí wọ́n sọ sí i lọ́wọ́

English: Mr. Bizimana commented: “This convention was excellent! To see deaf people from different areas of the country united together — thank you.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Bizimana sọ pé: “Àpéjọ yìí ti dáa jù! Ẹ wo bí àwọn adití láti onírúurú agbègbè lórílẹ̀-èdè yìí ṣé jọ wà papọ̀ — Ẹ ṣeun.

English: We very much thank Jehovah’s Witnesses for supporting communication for the deaf.
Yoruba: A dúpẹ́ gan-an lọ́wọ́ àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà fún bí wọ́n ṣe ń ti èdè àwọn adití lẹ́yìn.

English: Government authorities should come to see such a unifying event and imitate it.”
Yoruba: Ó yẹ káwọn aláṣẹ ìjọba wa wo irú àpéjọ tó ń fi bí àwọn èèyàn ṣe wà níṣọ̀kan báyìí hàn, kí wọn sì ṣe irú rẹ̀.”

English: Over the past two years, there have been two additional milestones in the RWS field.
Yoruba: Lọ́dún méjì sẹ́yìn, àwọn ohun mánigbàgbé méjì kan tún wáyé láàárín àwọn tó ń sọ èdè adití tí Rùwáńdà.

English: In September 2017, the Rwanda branch held the first Pioneer Service School in RWS.
Yoruba: Ní September 2017, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Rùwáńdà ṣe ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn aṣáájú-ọ̀nà lédè adití ti Rùwáńdà fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́.

English: One year later, in September 2018, the branch officially began translating our publications into RWS.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó tún di September 2018, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí tú àwọn ìtẹ̀jáde wa sí èdè adití ti Rùwáńdà.

English: Brother Jean d’Amour Habiyaremye, who served as the branch representative for the sign-language convention, stated: “We are very happy to see the progress in the RWS field, which includes this recent regional convention.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Jean d’Amour Habiyaremye, tó jẹ́ aṣojú tí ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì rán wá sí àpéjọ àwọn adití yìí sọ pé: “A láyọ̀ láti rí ìtẹ̀síwájú tó ń bá iṣẹ́ ìwàásù láàárín àwọn tó ń sọ́ èdè adití ti Rùwáńdà, títí kan àpéjọ agbègbè yìí.

English: The theme of the program, ‘Love Never Fails!’ is seen in practice with the way Jehovah’s Witnesses display love to all people, including deaf individuals.”
Yoruba: Àkòrí àpéjọ náà ni ‘Ìfẹ́ Kì Í Yẹ̀ Láé!,’ a sì rí i pé lóòótọ́ ni àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà fi ìfẹ́ yìí hàn sí gbogbo èèyàn títí kan àwọn adití.”

English: The progress in this sign-language field gives clear evidence of Jehovah’s continued rich blessing!—Psalm 67:1.
Yoruba: Bí iṣẹ́ ìwàásù ṣe ń tẹ̀síwájú láàárín àwọn tó ń sọ èdè adití jẹ́ ẹ̀rí tó ṣe kedere pé Jèhófà ń bù kún wa!​—Sáàmù 67:1.

English: On the morning of August 14, 2017, flooding and landslides severely damaged shops, roads, and homes throughout Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city.
Yoruba: Láàárọ̀ August 14, 2017, àkúnya omi àti ilẹ̀ yíya ba àwọn ṣọ́ọ̀bù, àwọn ojú ọ̀nà àtàwọn ilé jẹ́ nílùú Freetown, tó jẹ́ olú ìlú Siria Lóònù, jàǹbá yìí kọjá sísọ.

English: Over 400 people are confirmed dead and approximately 600 more are missing.
Yoruba: Ó lé ní ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́rin [400] èèyàn tí wọ́n ti rí pé ó kú, nǹkan bí ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́fà [600] àwọn míì ni wọn ò sí tíì mọ ibi tí wọ́n wà.

English: Officials fear that additional rains forecasted could cause further devastation.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù ń ba àwọn aláṣẹ pé àwọn òjò míì tí wọ́n ti gbọ́ pé ó máa rọ̀ tún máa fa àjálù kún èyí tó wà nílẹ̀.

English: The branch office in Sierra Leone reports that no Jehovah’s Witnesses were killed or injured in this disaster.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tó wà lórílẹ̀-èdè Siria Lóònù sọ pé kò sí Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kankan tó kú tàbí tó fara pa nínú àjálù yìí.

English: However, two families were displaced.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, ìdílé méjì ni omi gbalé wọn.

English: Local congregation elders are providing pastoral support to their fellow Witnesses.
Yoruba: Àwọn alàgbà ìjọ tó wà lágbègbè náà ń fi ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run gbé àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà bíi tiwọn ró.

English: Additionally, the elders have been distributing information outlining safety precautions in the event of further flooding.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, àwọn alàgbà náà ń sọ ohun táwọn èèyàn lè ṣe láti dáàbò bo ara wọn tí àkúnya omi bá tún ṣẹlẹ̀.

English: Media Contacts:
Yoruba: Agbẹnusọ fún Àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà:

English: International: David A. Semonian, Office of Public Information.
Yoruba: Kárí Ayé: David A. Semonian, Office of Public Information.

English: Dates: September 6-8, 2019
Yoruba: Déètì: September 6 sí 8, 2019

English: Location: FNB Stadium in Johannesburg, South Africa
Yoruba: Ibi Tí A Ti Ṣe É: Gbọ̀ngàn Ìwòran FNB ní ìlú Johannesburg, South Africa

English: Program Languages: English, Sesotho, Zulu
Yoruba: Èdè: Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, Sesotho, Zulu

English: Peak Attendance: 58,149
Yoruba: Àwọn Tó Wá: 58, 149

English: Total Number Baptized: 476
Yoruba: Àwọn Tó Ṣèrìbọmi: 476

English: Number of International Delegates: 6,000
Yoruba: Àwọn Tó Wá Láti Ilẹ̀ Òkèèrè: 6,000

English: Invited Branches: Bolivia, Britain, Central Europe, Congo (Kinshasa), Finland, Hong Kong, Hungary, Israel, Japan, Kenya, Korea, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, Paraguay, Peru, Uganda, United States, Zambia, Zimbabwe
Yoruba: Àwọn Ẹ̀ka Ọ́fíìsì Tá A Pè: Bòlífíà, ilẹ̀ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, Central Europe, Kóńgò (Kinshasha) Finland, Hong Kong, Hungary, Ísírẹ́lì, Japan, Kẹ́ńyà, Kòríà, Làìbéríà, Madagásíkà, Màláwì, Paraguay, Peru, Uganda, Amẹ́ríkà, Sáńbíà, Sìǹbábúwè.

English: Local Experience: The management of the Lion and Safari Park, one of the planned excursions for the delegates, explained that they had never seen so many different cultures and languages get off a tour bus without any arguing or complaining.
Yoruba: Ìrírí: Àwọn aláṣẹ ọgbà ẹranko tó ń jẹ́ Lion and Safari Park, tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára ibi tí wọ́n ṣètò fún àwọn àlejò láti gbafẹ́ lọ, ṣàlàyé pé àwọn ò tíì rí i rí kí ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn tí àṣà ìbílẹ̀ àti èdè wọn yàtọ̀ síra bẹ́ẹ̀ máa bọ́ sílẹ̀ látinú ọkọ̀ kan náà tó sì jẹ́ pé wọ́n ò bá ara wọn jiyàn, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni wọ́n ò sì bá ara wọn jà.

English: The management was thoroughly impressed with how well the visitors followed directions and cooperated with the staff, declaring: “It was a pleasure to have them!”
Yoruba: Orí àwọn aláṣẹ náà wú gan-an nígbà tí wọ́n rí i bí àwọn àlejò yẹn ṣe tẹ̀ lé ìtọ́ni tí wọ́n sì fọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ wọn, wọ́n sọ pé: “Inú wá dùn pé wọ́n wá.”

English: Jehovah’s Witnesses released the New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures in Kwanyama at a regional convention in Ondangwa, Namibia, on August 16, 2019.
Yoruba: Ní August 16, 2019, àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà mú Ìwé Mímọ́ Kristian Lédè Griki ní Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Titun jáde lédè Kwanyama níbi àpéjọ agbègbè tó wáyé ní Ondangwa, lórílẹ̀-èdè Namibia.

English: Brother Franco Dagostini, a member of the South Africa Branch Committee, released the Bible on the first day of the convention at the Ondangwa Trade Fair Hall.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Franco Dagostini, tó jẹ́ ara Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka orílẹ̀-èdè South Africa ló mú Bíbélì yìí jáde lọ́jọ́ àkọ́kọ́ àpéjọ náà ní gbọ̀ngàn tó ń jẹ́ Ondangwa Trade Fair Hall.

English: One member of the translation team says: “The New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures will help people read and understand the Bible’s message more clearly.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè náà sọ pé: “Ìwé Mímọ́ Kristian Lédè Griki ní Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Titun yìí máa rọrùn fáwọn èèyàn láti kà, wọ́n á sì lóye àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ inú ẹ̀ lọ́nà tó ṣe kedere.

English: Our brothers and sisters will be happy to see Jehovah’s name where it ought to be.”
Yoruba: Inú àwọn arákùnrin àti arábìnrin wa máa dùn láti rí orúkọ Jèhófà ní gbogbo ibi tó yẹ kó wà.”

English: In the South Africa branch territory, there are approximately 490 Kwanyama-speaking publishers.
Yoruba: Ní ìpínlẹ̀ tí Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì South Africa ń bójú tó, nǹkan bí ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún ó dín mẹ́wàá (490) akéde ló ń sọ èdè Kwanyama.

English: These preach to an estimated 1.4 million people who speak Kwanyama, primarily in Angola and Namibia.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń wàásù fún àwọn èèyàn tó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó mílíọ̀nù kan àtààbọ̀ tó ń sọ èdè Kwanyama ní orílẹ̀-èdè Àǹgólà àti Nàmíbíà.

English: The New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures has now been translated in whole or in part into 184 languages, including 25 complete revisions based on the 2013 edition.
Yoruba: A ti mú Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lódindi tàbí lápá kan ní èdè mẹ́rìnlélọ́gọ́sàn-án (184), mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dọ́gbọ̀n (25) lára rẹ̀ sì jẹ́ odindi Bíbélì tá a tún ṣe látinú ẹ̀dà tó jáde lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì lọ́dún 2013.

English: We are joyful knowing our brothers and sisters will use this Bible to share God’s Word with many in the Kwanyama-language field.—Acts 2:37.
Yoruba: Inú wa dùn pé àwọn arákùnrin àti arábìnrin wa máa lo Bíbélì yìí láti sọ Ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́run fún ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn lédè Kwanyama.​—Ìṣe 2:37.

English: On September 6, 2019, at the international convention in Johannesburg, South Africa, the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures was released in Venda, Afrikaans, and Xhosa, languages spoken by over 16 million people.
Yoruba: Ní September 6, 2019, a mú Bíbélì Mímọ́ ti Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde ní èdè Venda, Afrikaans àti Xhosa níbi àpéjọ àgbáyé tá a ṣe nílùú Johannesburg lórílẹ̀-èdè South Africa, ó sì ju mílíọ̀nù mẹ́rìndínlógún (16) èèyàn lọ tó ń sọ àwọn èdè yẹn.

English: Brother Anthony Morris, a member of the Governing Body, announced the release to an audience of 36,865 people gathered in the FNB Stadium.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Anthony Morris, tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí ló kéde fáwọn èèyàn tó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rìndínlógójì, ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ àti márùndínláàádọ́rin (36,865) tó kóra jọ sí pápá ìṣeré FNB pé a ti mú Bíbélì náà jáde.

English: An additional 51,229 people were tied in at eight other venues, including locations in Lesotho, Namibia, and Saint Helena.
Yoruba: Àwọn èèyàn tó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mọ́kànléláàádọ́ta àti igba ó lé mọ́kàndínlọ́gbọ̀n (51,229) míì wo ìtòlẹ́sẹẹsẹ náà bó ṣe ń lọ lọ́wọ́ ní ibi mẹ́jọ ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ ti wọ́n ta àtagbà ètò náà sí, títí kan orílẹ̀-èdè Lesotho, Namibia àti Saint Helena.

English: Commenting on the unique features of the Bibles, one translator excitedly said: “We are all going to start our Bible reading afresh with the language that touches our hearts!” Another translator noted: “Most importantly, [the newly released Bible] will help us to draw closer to Jehovah because it uses God’s name repeatedly.”
Yoruba: Nígbà tí atúmọ̀ èdè kan ń sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ohun tó ṣàrà ọ̀tọ̀ nínú Bíbélì náà, ó sọ pé: “Inú wa dùn gan-an pé a lè ka Bíbélì látòkèdélẹ̀ ní èdè tó wọni lọ́kàn!” Atúmọ̀ èdè míì sọ pé: “Ní pàtàkì jùlọ, [Bíbélì tá a ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ mú jáde yìí] máa jẹ́ ká lè sún mọ́ Jèhófà torí pé léraléra ló lo orúkọ Ọlọ́run.”

English: The Bibles will also greatly enhance our brothers’ ministry. One member of the Xhosa translation team stated: “The revised New World Translation will help in the ministry.
Yoruba: Bíbélì yìí tún máa ran àwọn ará wa lọ́wọ́ nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń wàásù. Ọ̀kan lára àwọn tó túmọ̀ èdè Xhosa sọ pé: “Bíbélì Ìtúmọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tá a tún ṣe yìí máa ràn wá lọ́wọ́ nínú iṣẹ́ ìwàásù.

English: People will hear clearly what the Bible teaches without having each and every word explained.”
Yoruba: Àwọn èèyàn máa gbọ́ ohun tí Bíbélì fi kọ́ni lọ́nà tó ṣe kedere láìsì pé à ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ń ṣàlàyé ìtumọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ kọ̀ọ̀kan.”

English: An Afrikaans translator added: “Now you can just read the scripture and the Bible explains itself.”
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn atúmọ̀ èdè Afrikaans fi kún un pé: “Ní báyìí, ó ti ṣeé ṣe láti ka Bíbélì kó sì yé ẹ yékéyéké.”

English: We rejoice that our brothers have easy-to-read Bibles that will help them to draw closer to our God.—James 4:8.
Yoruba: Inú wa dùn pé àwọn ara wa ní Bíbélì tó rọrùn-ún ka, táá sì jẹ́ kí wọ́n sún mọ́ Ọlọ́run wa.​—Jémíìsì 4:8.

English: Heavy rains hit the eastern coast of South Africa in late April 2019.
Yoruba: Òjò tó rinlẹ̀ gan-an rọ̀ lọ́wọ́ ìparí oṣù April 2019 láwọn ibi tó kángun sí ìlà oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdè South Africa.

English: The prolonged rains caused flooding and mudslides in several areas in and around Durban, KwaZulu-Natal province.
Yoruba: Òjò àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá náà fa omíyalé àti àbàtà láwọn ibì kan ní ìlú Durban àti ní agbègbè KwaZulu-Natal.

English: News reports indicate that at least 70 people have died.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn fi hàn pé ó kéré tán, àádọ́rin (70) èèyàn ló kú.

English: The South Africa branch reports that no brothers or sisters were injured or killed.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní South Africa sọ pé kò sí ìkankan lára àwọn ará wa tó kú tàbí tó fara pa nínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà.

English: However, the homes of at least 19 families were damaged by mudslides or flooding.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, ó kéré tán, ilé àwọn ìdílé mọ́kàndínlógún (19) ni omíyalé àti àbàtà náà bà jẹ́.

English: Floodwaters also damaged at least three Kingdom Halls.
Yoruba: Omíyalé náà tún ba Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mẹ́ta jẹ́ ó kéré tán.

English: Under the direction of the Disaster Relief Committee, Local Design/Construction volunteers are investigating the extent of the damage to each home.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù ti ṣètò àwọn ará tó yọ̀ǹda ara wọn láti ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Yàwòrán Ilé Tó sì Ń Kọ́ Ọ kí wọ́n lè ṣèwádìí bí ilé kọ̀ọ̀kan ṣe bà jẹ́ tó.

English: Where the safety of the brothers is at risk, arrangements are being made to accommodate them elsewhere.
Yoruba: Láwọn ibi tí ẹ̀mí àwọn ará ti wà nínú ewu, wọ́n ṣètò láti kó wọn lọ síbòmíì.

English: We are confident that Jehovah will continue to support our brothers and sisters in South Africa as they face these challenging circumstances.—Psalm 34:19.
Yoruba: Ó dá wa lójú pé Jèhófà ò ní yéé ran àwọn ará wa ní South Africa lọ́wọ́ bí wọ́n ṣe ń kojú ìṣòro tó le gan-an yìí.—Sáàmù 34:19.

English: Heavy and prolonged rainfall in Togo during the 2019 rainy season has led to significant flooding on the outskirts of Lomé, Togo.
Yoruba: Òjò àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá tó wáyé lórílẹ̀-èdè Tógò ní àsìkò òjò ọdún 2019 fa àkúnya omi ní ibi púpọ̀ láwọn ìgbèríko ìlú Lome, lórílẹ̀-èdè Tógò.

English: Two hundred and fifty-seven publishers from seven different congregations have been affected.
Yoruba: Àwọn akéde ọgọ́rùn-ún méjì ó lé mẹ́tàdínlọ́gọ́ta (257) tó wà ní ìjọ méje ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ ló fara gbá nínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà.

English: Relief efforts are underway.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tó ń bójú tó orílẹ̀-èdè náà ti ń pèsè ìrànwọ́ fún àwọn akéde yìí.

English: In some of the affected areas, water levels in buildings reached up to one meter (3 ft 3 in), forcing 51 of our brothers and sisters to evacuate their homes.
Yoruba: Láwọn ibì kan tí àkúnya omi náà ti ṣẹlẹ̀, omi náà fẹ́ẹ̀ mu èèyàn dé ìbàdí, èyí mú kó pọndandan kí àwọn ará tó jẹ́ mọ́kànléláàádọ́ta (51) sá kúrò nílé.

English: Publishers nearby have opened their homes to care for the needs of those displaced.
Yoruba: Àwọn akéde tó wà nítòsí ti gba àwọn ará yìí sílé, wọ́n sì ń bójú tó wọn.

English: Floodwaters contaminated some of the water sources in the area.
Yoruba: Àgbàrá òjò ti ba díẹ̀ lára àwọn omi tó ṣeé lò ní agbègbè yẹn jẹ́.

English: The Benin Branch Committee, which oversees the work in Togo, has arranged to distribute necessary relief supplies through the circuit overseer and local elders.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka Benin tó ń bójú tó iṣẹ́ wa ní Tógò ti ṣètò pé kí alábòójútó àyíká àtàwọn alàgbà pín àwọn nǹkan táwọn ará wa lè lò fún wọn.

English: These supplies include water purification tablets, disinfectant, and bleach.
Yoruba: Lára ẹ̀ ni oògùn tó ń pa kòkòrò inú omi, kẹ́míkà apakòkòrò àti kẹ́míkà tí wọ́n fi ń sọ aṣọ di funfun tí wọ́n ń pè ní bleach.

English: We pray for Jehovah’s blessing on our brothers in Togo as they demonstrate self-sacrificing love for one another.—John 13:34, 35.
Yoruba: A gbàdúrà pé kí Jèhófà bù kún àwọn ará wa ní Tógò bí wọ́n ṣe ń fi ìfẹ́ ìfara-ẹni-rúbọ hàn síra wọn.—Jòhánù 13:34, 35.

English: On March 17, 2019, Brother Kenneth Cook, a member of the Governing Body, released the revised edition of the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in the Shona language at a special event held at the Harare Assembly Hall in Zimbabwe.
Yoruba: Ní March 17, 2019, Arákùnrin Kenneth Cook tó jẹ́ ara Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí mú Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tá a tún ṣe jáde lédè Shona níbi àkànṣe ìpàdé kan tí wọ́n ṣe ní Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ Harare lórílẹ̀-èdè Sìǹbábúwè.

English: The release of the Bible is the culmination of a three-year translation project.
Yoruba: Ọdún mẹ́ta sẹ́yìn ni iṣẹ́ ìtúmọ̀ Bíbélì tá a mú jáde yìí bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: Nearly 2,500 brothers and sisters were present at the Assembly Hall for the Bible release.
Yoruba: Nǹkan bí ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì ààbọ̀ (2,500) àwọn ará ló wá sí Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ náà fún àkànṣe ìpàdé yìí.

English: An additional 43,000 were tied in to the event from 295 Kingdom Halls and 4 Assembly Halls.
Yoruba: A ta àtagbà rẹ̀ sí ọgọ́rùn mẹ́ta ó dín márùn-ún (295) Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba àti Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ mẹ́rin, iye àwọn tó sì wá síbẹ̀ tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́tàlélógójì (43,000).

English: One brother said: “I look forward to using the revised Bible in the ministry.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin kan sọ pé: “Ó wù mí kí n ti máa lo Bíbélì tá a tún ṣe náà lóde ẹ̀rí.

English: The language is simple and refreshing, which encourages one to read more.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ rọrùn, ó sì dùn mọ́ni, èyí kìí jẹ́ kéèyàn fẹ́ gbé e sílẹ̀ tó bá ń kà á.

English: We thank Jehovah for this gift.”
Yoruba: Ọpẹ́ ni fún Jèhófà torí ẹ̀bùn yìí.”

English: This edition will benefit the 38,000 publishers who serve in the Shona field.
Yoruba: Bíbélì tá a tún ṣe yìí máa wúlò gan-an fún ẹgbẹ̀rún méjìdínlógójì (38,000) àwọn ará tó ń sọ èdè Shona.

English: Additionally, it will assist them in preaching to the over 9,000,000 individuals who speak the language, approximately 80 percent of Zimbabwe’s population.
Yoruba: Tá a bá pín mílíọ̀nù mẹ́sàn-án (9,000,000) èèyàn tó ń gbé ní Sìǹbábúwè sọ́nà mẹ́wàá, àwọn tó ń sọ èdè Shona tó nǹkan bí ìdá mẹ́jọ, torí náà Bíbélì yìí máa mú kó rọrùn fáwọn ará láti wàásù.

English: Every Bible release gives evidence of Jehovah’s blessing on the worldwide translation efforts.
Yoruba: Bíbélì kọ̀ọ̀kan tá à ń mú jáde ń fi ẹ̀rí hàn pé Jèhófà ń bù kún iṣẹ́ ìtumọ̀ tá à ń ṣe kárí ayé.

English: We are happy that his Word is being made available in the native languages of more and more readers.—Acts 2:8.
