Yoruba: Ní Friday, September 28, ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ tó lágbára wáyé ní erékùṣù Sulawesi lórílẹ̀-èdè Indonéṣíà.

English: The earthquake, and a tsunami that followed, has killed over 1,300 people, the majority of whom were in the city of Palu in Central Sulawesi.
Yoruba: Ó ju ẹgbẹ̀rún kan ó lé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́ta (1,300) èèyàn tí ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ náà àti omíyalé tó tẹ̀ lé e pa, púpọ̀ lára wọn ló ń gbé ní ìlú Palu ní àárín erékùṣù Sulawesi.

English: The Indonesia branch office, located in Jakarta, reports that all 80 publishers living in the affected area have been accounted for.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tó wà ní ìlú Jakarta ní Indonéṣíà sọ pé kò sí ìkankan tó kú lára ọgọ́rin (80) àwọn ará wa tó wà níbi tí àjálù yìí ti ṣẹlẹ̀.

English: A few publishers sustained injuries and needed to be treated at a hospital.
Yoruba: Àwọn díẹ̀ ló fara pa, wọ́n sì ní láti lọ sílé ìwòsàn.

English: One brother’s home was destroyed by the disaster and several other homes of Witnesses were severely damaged.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí ba ilé arákùnrin wa kan jẹ́ pátápátá, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará wa míì sì wà tó ba ilé wọn jẹ́ gan-an.

English: The building that the Palu Congregation uses to hold their meetings was also damaged.
Yoruba: Ilé tí Ìjọ Palu ti ń ṣèpàdé náà tún bà jẹ́.

English: The Disaster Relief Desk at the branch office is working with the circuit overseer and nearby congregations to coordinate the relief efforts.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù ní ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn alábòójútó àyíká àtàwọn ìjọ tó wà nítòsí láti ṣètò bí wọ́n ṣe máa ran àwọn ará lọ́wọ́.

English: Since the publishers in the affected area have limited food, water, and other necessities, the branch has arranged for three congregations to supply these items to their brothers in Palu.
Yoruba: Torí pé àwọn ará tó wà níbi tí àjálù náà ti ṣẹlẹ̀ ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ní oúnjẹ, omi àtàwọn nǹkan míì tó ṣe pàtàkì, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ṣètò ìjọ mẹ́ta tí á máa pèsè àwọn nǹkan yìí fáwọn ará tó wà ní Palu.

English: Local elders are caring for the publishers’ spiritual, emotional, and physical needs.
Yoruba: Àwọn alàgbà ń pèsè ìrànlọ́wọ́ tẹ̀mí fáwọn ará, wọ́n ń tù wọ́n nínú, wọ́n sì ń jẹ́ kí wọ́n rí ohun tí wọ́n nílò láti gbé ẹ̀mí wọn ró.

English: A member of the Branch Committee, the overseer of the Local Design/Construction Department, and the circuit overseer for the area will also be visiting the affected publishers to provide comfort and support.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin tó jẹ́ alábòójútó Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Yàwòrán Ilé Tó sì Ń Kọ́ Ọ, tó sì tún jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Ẹ̀ka pẹ̀lú alábòójútó àyíká ibẹ̀ máa dé ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ará tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà kàn kí wọ́n lè tù wọ́n nínú, kí wọ́n sì fún wọn níṣìírí.

English: We pray for our brothers and sisters in Indonesia, knowing that Jehovah will continue to be their “refuge and strength” during this time of distress.
Yoruba: À ń gbàdúrà fún àwọn ará wa ní Indonéṣíà, torí a mọ̀ pé Jèhófà á máa jẹ́ “ibi ìsádi àti okun” fún wọn lásìkò wàhálà yìí.

English: Torrential rains pounded the eastern province of Papua, Indonesia, on March 16, 2019.
Yoruba: Òjò tó rọ̀ ní agbègbè Papua tó wà ní ìlà oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdè Indonesia ní March 16, 2019 kọjá wẹ́rẹwẹ̀rẹ.

English: The rains triggered a flash flood that killed more than 100 people and washed away several homes.
Yoruba: Òjò yìí fa omíyalé, àwọn tó pa lé ní ọgọ́rùn-ún kan (100), ọ̀pọ̀ ilé ló sì gbá lọ.

English: The Indonesia branch reports that many of our brothers living in the town of Sentani, located in the province of Papua, have been impacted by this disaster.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní Indonesia sọ pé omíyalé yìí náà dààmú ọ̀pọ̀ lára àwọn ará tó ń gbé ní ìlú Sentani lágbègbè Papua.

English: Sadly, one of our brothers died when his home was swept away in the flood.
Yoruba: Ó dùn wá pé arákùnrin wa kan kú nígbà tí omi gbé ilé rẹ̀ lọ.

English: Three other homes of Witness families were severely damaged.
Yoruba: Omi náà sì tún ba ilé mẹ́ta míì tó jẹ́ ti àwọn ará wa jẹ́.

English: More than 40 publishers have been evacuated, and most are now staying with local Witnesses.
Yoruba: Ó ju ogójì (40) akéde tó ní láti kúrò níbi tí wọ́n ń gbé, ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ará lèyí tó pọ̀ jù nínú wọ́n sì ń gbé báyìí.

English: A Disaster Relief Committee has been formed to organize the relief work.
Yoruba: A ti dá Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù sílẹ̀ láti pèsè ohun táwọn ará nílò.

English: Branch representatives, along with the circuit overseer in the area, have visited the affected regions to provide spiritual comfort.
Yoruba: Àwọn aṣojú ẹ̀ka àti alábòójútó àyílá tó wà lágbègbè náà lọ sáwọn apá ibi tí àjálù náà ti ṣẹ̀lẹ̀ láti fún àwọn ará ní ìṣírí látinú Bíbélì.

English: They are also evaluating the extent of relief aid needed.
Yoruba: Wọ́n sì tún wo bí ìránlọ́wọ́ táwọn ará nílò ṣe máa pọ̀ tó.

English: Our prayers are with all the brothers who have been affected by this disaster.
Yoruba: À ń rántí gbogbo àwọn ará tí àjálù yìí ṣẹlẹ̀ sí nínú àdúrà wa.

English: We long for the day in the near future when Jehovah will “swallow up death forever” and “wipe away the tears from all faces.
Yoruba: A retí pé láìpẹ́, Jèhófà máa “máa gbé ikú mì títí láé,” á sì “nu omijé kúrò ní ojú gbogbo èèyàn.

English: Typhoon Trami, a Category 1 storm, struck southern Japan on Sunday evening, September 30, 2018, bringing high winds and heavy rainfall.
Yoruba: Ìjì líle kan tí wọ́n pè ní Trami jà ní gúúsù ilẹ̀ Japan nírọ̀lẹ́ ọjọ́ Sunday, September 30, 2018. Ọwọ́ ìjì náà lágbára gan-an, òjò tó sì rọ̀ pọ̀ púpọ̀.

English: The storm reduced intensity as it continued north over the weekend, eventually reaching Tokyo by Monday, October 1.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ìjì náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í rọlẹ̀ kó tó dé apá àríwá lópin ọ̀sẹ̀ náà. Nígbà tó fi máa dọjọ́ Monday, October 1, ó dé ìlú Tokyo.

English: Three people were killed, some 200 were injured, and over 1.3 million homes were left without power.
Yoruba: Èèyàn mẹ́ta ló kú, nǹkan bíi igba (200) ló fara pa, ó sì lé ní mílíọ̀nù kan àti ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́ta (1,300,000) ilé tí ìjì náà ba iná wọn jẹ́.

English: According to reports from circuit overseers, the island of Okinawa, in southern Japan, was the most affected.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn tá a gbọ́ látọ̀dọ̀ àwọn alábòójútó àyíká fi hàn pé erékùṣù Okinawa, ní gúúsù ilẹ̀ Japan ni ìjì náà ti ba nǹkan jẹ́ jù.

English: The initial investigation from the three circuits in Okinawa and surrounding areas revealed that none of our brothers were killed but nine suffered injuries.
Yoruba: Àyẹ̀wò àkọ́kọ́ tí wọ́n ṣe láwọn àyíká mẹ́tẹ̀ẹ̀ta tó wà ní Okinawa àtàwọn ibi tó wà nítòsí fi hàn pé kò sí ìkankan lára àwọn ará wa tó kú nínú àjálù yìí, àmọ́ àwọn mẹ́sàn-án fara pa.

English: The typhoon also damaged some 120 homes of our brothers and 5 Kingdom Halls on the island of Okinawa.
Yoruba: Ìjì líle náà tún ba nǹkan bí ọgọ́fà (120) ilé àwọn ará wa jẹ́ àti Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba márùn-ún ní erékùṣù Okinawa.

English: An additional 41 Kingdom Halls sustained damage as the storm passed through other regions of Japan.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, ọwọ́ ìjì yìí ba Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mọ́kànlélógójì (41) jẹ́ káàkiri àwọn agbègbè míì nílẹ̀ Japan.

English: Local circuit overseers and members of the Local Design/Construction Department are continuing their investigation to determine the extent of the damage and organize the spiritual and material relief needed.
Yoruba: Àwọn alábòójútó àyíká tó wà láwọn agbègbè yìí àtàwọn tó wà ní Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Yàwòrán Ilé Tó sì Ń Kọ́ Ọ ṣì ń ṣèwádìí kí wọ́n lè mọ bí àwọn nǹkan tó bà jẹ́ ṣe pọ̀ tó, wọ́n sì ń ṣètò bí àwọn ará á ṣe máa jọ́sìn Ọlọ́run nìṣó, kí wọ́n sì tún pèsè àwọn ohun tí wọ́n nílò fún wọn.

English: Our prayers continue to be with our fellow worshippers affected by this storm and other natural disasters that have recently struck Japan.
Yoruba: À ń gbàdúrà fún àwọn ara wa tí ìjì líle yìí kàn àtàwọn àjálù míì tó wáyé nílẹ̀ Japan.

English: We trust that our heavenly Father will continue to comfort the hearts of our brothers and make them firm.
Yoruba: Ó dá wa lójú pé Baba wa ọ̀run máa tu ọkàn àwọn ará wa yìí lára, á sì mú kí wọ́n mọ́kàn le.

English: Over 47,000 of our brothers and sisters live in the regions of western Japan that were devastated by floods in July 2018.
Yoruba: Ó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́tàdínláàádọ́ta (47,000) àwọn ará wa tó ń gbé láwọn agbègbè tó wà ní ìwọ̀ oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdè Japan tí omíyalé ti ṣọṣẹ́ lóṣù July 2018.

English: Soon after the disaster, some 4,900 volunteer relief workers swung into action to clean and repair damaged homes of Witnesses and Kingdom Halls.
Yoruba: Kò pẹ́ lẹ́yìn náà tí àwọn ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rin ó lé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́sàn (4,900) tó yọ̀ǹda ara wọn láti ṣèrànwọ́ fi bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́, wọ́n palẹ̀ ìdọ̀tí mọ́ kúrò nínú ilé àwọn ará àtàwọn Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba tó bà jẹ́, wọ́n sì tún wọn ṣe.

English: Volunteers remove debris from the Kingdom Hall pictured in the lead image.
Yoruba: Àwọn ará yọ̀ǹda ara wọn láti palẹ̀ ìdọ̀tí mọ́ kúrò nínú Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba tó wà lókè.

English: Under the direction of three Disaster Relief Committees, our brothers and sisters have cleaned and repaired nine Kingdom Halls that were damaged by floodwaters.
Yoruba: Àwọn Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù ṣètò bí àwọn ará ṣe palẹ̀ ìdọ̀tí mọ́ kúrò nínú Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mẹ́sàn-án tí omíyalé náà bà jẹ́, wọ́n sì tún àwọn Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba náà ṣe.

English: An additional Kingdom Hall is in the process of being repaired.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, àtúnṣe ń lọ lọ́wọ́ lórí Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan.

English: Also, 184 homes of Witnesses have been repaired or stabilized, and another 11 homes are scheduled to be repaired this year.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, ilé mẹ́rìnlélọ́gọ́sàn-án (184) àwọn ará wa ni wọ́n ti parí àtúnṣe rẹ̀ tàbí tí wọ́n ti tún ṣe díẹ̀ kó lè ṣeé gbé, àwọn ilé mọ́kànlá míì sì wà tí wọ́n ṣètò láti tún ṣe lọ́dún yìí.

English: Before and after photographs of a Kingdom Hall in Ehime.
Yoruba: Àwòrán Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan ṣáájú àti lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n tún un ṣe.

English: The Abe family from Ehime pictured after the brothers completed repairs on their flood-damaged home.
Yoruba: Àwòrán ìdílé Abe láti agbègbè Ehime lẹ́yìn táwọn ará parí títún ilé wọn tí omíyalé bà jẹ́ ṣe.

English: Taro and Keiko Abe, who have three children, were one of the families in Ehime who received assistance.
Yoruba: Ìdílé Taro àti Keiko Abe wà lára àwọn tí wọ́n ràn lọ́wọ́, ọmọ mẹ́ta ni wọ́n bí, agbègbè Ehime ni wọ́n sì ń gbé.

English: Just three days after the family’s house was flooded, brothers from the local circuit arrived and started to repair their home, which included replacing the damaged flooring.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ mẹ́ta péré lẹ́yìn tí omíyalé ba ilé wọn jẹ́, àwọn ará láti àyíká ibẹ̀ dé, wọ́n sì tún ilé náà ṣe, kódà wọ́n tún ilẹ̀ ilé náà ṣe torí omíyalé ti bà á jẹ́.

English: Additionally, local Witnesses donated new beds and desks for the children.
Yoruba: Kò mọ síbẹ̀ o, àwọn ará lágbègbè náà tún fún àwọn ọmọ wọn ní àwọn bẹ́ẹ̀dì àtàwọn tábìlì tuntun.

English: On September 20, 2018, Governing Body member Geoffrey Jackson, who was in Japan for an assignment, took the opportunity to deliver an encouraging talk at a special meeting originating in a Kingdom Hall in Okayama.
Yoruba: Ní September 20, 2018, Arákùnrin Geoffrey Jackson tó jẹ́ ara Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí wá sí orílẹ̀-èdè Japan fún iṣẹ́ kan, ó sì fìyẹn sọ àsọyé kan níbi ìpàdé àkànṣe láti fún àwọn ará níṣìírí, Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan ní ìlú Okayama ni wọ́n ti ṣèpàdé náà.

English: The combined total of 36,691 brothers and sisters, which included some who were affected by typhoons and earthquakes that occurred during the same period in Japan, listened as Brother Jackson explained how Jehovah always cares for and comforts His people in all their trials.
Yoruba: Àpapọ̀ iye àwọn ará tó wá sípàdé náà jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rìndínlógójì ó lé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́fà àti mọ́kànléláàádọ́rùn-ún (36,691), lára wọn wá láti àwọn ibi tí ìjì líle àti ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ ti ṣọṣẹ́ nígbà kan náà lẹ́nu àìpẹ́ yìí ní Japan, wọ́n gbọ́ bí Arákùnrin Jackson ṣe ṣàlàyé bí Jèhófà ṣe máa ń bójú tó àwọn èèyàn Rẹ̀, tó sì máa ń tù wọ́n nínú lásìkò wàhálà.

English: Brother Jackson also took time to speak consolingly to individual victims of the disaster.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Jackson tún fi àsìkò náà bá ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan àwọn tí àjálù náà kàn sọ̀rọ̀ ìtùnú.

English: Along with our brothers and sisters in Japan, we are grateful to be a part of Jehovah’s organization, which demonstrates love in action and reflects the care of our heavenly Father.—2 Corinthians 1:3, 4.
Yoruba: Àwa àtàwọn ará wa ní Japan ń dúpẹ́ pé a wà nínú ètò Jèhófà, tó ń fìfẹ́ ṣe nǹkan, tó sì jẹ́ ká mọ bí ọ̀rọ̀ wa ṣe jẹ Baba wa ọ̀run lọ́kàn tó.—2 Kọ́ríńtì 1:3, 4.

English: Brother Geoffrey Jackson, a member of the Governing Body, meets with a sister in Okayama who was affected by the flooding that devastated western Japan in July 2018.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Geoffrey Jackson tó wà lára Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí wà pẹ̀lú arábìnrin kan ní Okayama tí omíyalé ti ba nǹkan jẹ́ ní ìwọ̀ oòrùn Japan lóṣù July 2018.

English: At least 169 people have been killed in western Japan, and more than 255,000 households are still without water after torrential rains caused destructive flooding and landslides.
Yoruba: Ó kéré tán, èèyàn mọ́kàndínláàádọ́sàn-án (169) ló ṣòfò ẹ̀mí ní ìwọ̀ oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdè Japan, kódà títí di báyìí, ó lé ní 255,000 agboolé tí ò rí omi tó dáa lò látàrí òjò àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá tó fa omíyalé àti ilẹ̀ tó ya.

English: Although none of Jehovah’s Witnesses were killed in this disaster, 200 were evacuated and one sister was injured.
Yoruba: Bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé kò sí Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kankan lára àwọn tó bá ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà lọ, a kó ọgọ́rùn-ún méjì (200) lára wa kúrò níbi tí wọ́n ń gbé tẹ́lẹ̀, arábìnrin wa kan sì ṣèṣe.

English: The injured sister was treated at a hospital and is now recovering.
Yoruba: Wọ́n tọ́jú arábìnrin wa tó fara pa yìí nílé ìwòsàn, ara rẹ̀ sì ti ń balẹ̀ báyìí.

English: At least 103 homes of our brothers were damaged, and one was completely destroyed.
Yoruba: Ó kéré tán ilé mẹ́tàlélọ́gọ́rùn-ún (103) àwọn ará wa ló bà jẹ́, kódà ọ̀kan tiẹ̀ wà tó jẹ́ pé ńṣe ló bà jẹ́ pátápátá.

English: Also, 11 Kingdom Halls and an Assembly Hall were damaged by the floodwaters.
Yoruba: Kò mọ síbẹ̀ o, omíyalé yìí tún ba Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mọ́kànlá àti Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ kan jẹ́.

English: Four Disaster Relief Committees (DRCs) have been formed to provide comfort and Scriptural encouragement to the affected brothers and sisters, as well as immediate practical help, which includes supplying food, clothing, and clean water.
Yoruba: A dá ìgbìmọ̀ mẹ́rin sílẹ̀ tó ń ṣètò ìrànwọ́ nígbà àjálù, kí wọ́n lè tu àwọn ará tọ́rọ̀ kàn nínú, kí wọ́n fún wọn níṣìírí nípa tẹ̀mí, kí wọ́n sì pèsè àwọn ohun tí wọ́n nílò lójú ẹsẹ̀, irú bí oúnjẹ, aṣọ àti omi tó ṣeé mu.

English: The DRCs will also organize long-term relief efforts, which will involve cleaning, disinfecting, and repairing the damaged homes of our brothers.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìgbìmọ̀ yìí á sì tún ṣètò ìrànlọ́wọ́ táwọn ará máa nílò lẹ́yìn náà, irú bí wọ́n ṣe máa fọ ilé àwọn ará, tí wọ́n á da oògùn apakòkòrò sí i, tí wọ́n á sì tún àwọn ibi tó bà jẹ́ níbẹ̀ ṣe.

English: We pray for our brothers and sisters affected by this disaster in Japan as we look forward to the time when Jesus will use his power to rid the earth of all disasters permanently.
Yoruba: À ń gbàdúrà fún àwọn ará wa tí àjálù yìí dé bá nílẹ̀ Japan bá a ṣe ń retí ìgbà tí Jésù máa fi agbára rẹ̀ fòpin sí gbogbo àjálù tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ láyé pátápátá.​

English: "A magnitude 6.7 earthquake struck Hokkaido, the northern island of Japan, on September 6, 2018.
Yoruba: "Ní September 6, 2018, ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ tó lágbára wáyé ní Hokkaido, erékùṣù kan ní gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdè Japan.

English: The earthquake killed 41 people and caused massive power outages, limiting public transportation and communications on the island.
Yoruba: Ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ náà gbẹ̀mí èèyàn mọ́kànlélógójì (41), ó sì ba iná ìjọba jẹ́ gan-an, èyí mú kó ṣòro láti rí ọkọ̀ èrò wọ̀, ó sì tún mú kó ṣòro láti kàn sí àwọn tó wà ní erékùṣù náà.

English: The branch office in Japan reports that although none of our brothers or sisters were killed, seven were injured in the earthquake.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní Japan so pé bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé kò sí ìkankan lára àwọn ará wa tó bá ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ náà lọ, àwọn ará wa méje ló fara pa.

English: A total of 100 homes of Witnesses and 4 Kingdom Halls were damaged.
Yoruba: Ọgọ́rùn-ún (100) ilé àwọn ará wa àti Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mẹ́rin ló bà jẹ́.

English: Soon after the earthquake, under the direction of the branch office, publishers supplied our brothers in the affected areas with food, water, and other necessities.
Yoruba: Gẹ́rẹ́ lẹ́yìn ìmìtìtì ilẹ̀ náà, ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ṣètò pé kí àwọn ará kó oúnjẹ, omi àtàwọn nǹkan míì tó ṣe pàtàkì lọ fún àwọn ará tó wà lágbègbè tí àjálù yìí ti ṣẹlẹ̀.

English: A Disaster Relief Committee was formed to organize the long-term relief efforts.
Yoruba: A ṣètò Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù láti wá bí àwọn ará wa níbẹ̀ ṣe máa rí àwọn nǹkan tí wọ́n máa nílò lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

English: We pray that Jehovah will continue to give our brothers and sisters affected by this earthquake peace of mind and heart.—Philippians 4:6, 7."
Yoruba: Àdúrà wa ni pé kí Jèhófà máa fún àwọn ará wa tó wà níbi tí àjálù yìí ti ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ìbàlẹ̀ ọkàn.—Fílípì 4:6, 7."

English: "On August 28, 2019, heavy rainfall in the Kyushu region of Japan caused widespread flooding.
Yoruba: "Ní August 28, ọdún 2019, òjò àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá tó rọ̀ ní àgbègbè Kyushu lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan fa àkúnya omi tó lágbára gan-an.

English: Overflowing rivers and the potential for landslides led to evacuation orders for over 800,000 people.
Yoruba: Ṣe làwọn odò kún àkúnya, àwọn àgbègbè míì sì léwu torí pé ó ṣeé ṣe kí àwọn òkè ya lulẹ̀. Ìdí nìyẹn tí wọ́n fi sọ fún àwọn èèyàn tó ju ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ (800,000) pé kí wọ́n kúrò lágbègbè yẹn.

English: The Japan branch reports that 82 publishers were displaced.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì tó wà lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan ròyìn pé, àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin méjìlélọ́gọ́rin (82) ló fi ilé wọn sílẹ̀.

English: According to the latest report, a total of 40 homes of our brothers were damaged and one Kingdom Hall sustained minor damage.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn tó dé kẹ́yìn sọ pé ogójì (40) ilé àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin ló bà jẹ́ àti Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan tí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ bà jẹ́ púpọ̀.

English: The branch has established a Disaster Relief Committee to care for the affected publishers.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì náà dá Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù sílẹ̀ kí wọ́n lè bójú tó àwọn akéde tí àjálù náà kàn.

English: Circuit overseers, along with local elders and publishers, are caring for the immediate spiritual and physical needs of our brothers.
Yoruba: Àwọn alábòójútó àyíká, àwọn alàgbà àtàwọn akéde pèsè ìtùnú àti ìṣírí látinú Bíbélì, wọ́n sì fún wọn láwọn nǹkan míì bí oúnjẹ àti aṣọ.

English: We are grateful that love is moving so many to respond to the needs of our fellow believers.—2 Corinthians 8:4."
Yoruba: Inú wa dùn pé ìfẹ́ ń mú kí ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ran àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin wa lọ́wọ́.​—2 Kọ́ríńtì 8:4."

English: "From September 21 to 23, 2019, Typhoon Tapah struck southern Japan with powerful winds and rain.
Yoruba: "Ní September 21 sí 23, 2019, ìjì líle tí wọ́n ń pè ní Tapah rọ́ lu apá gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdè Japan pẹ̀lú atẹ́gùn àti òjò tó lágbára.

English: The storm caused flight cancellations, railway suspensions, and left over 30,000 homes without electricity.
Yoruba: Ìjì yìí ò jẹ́ káwọn ọkọ̀ òfúrufú àtàwọn ọkọ̀ ojú irin lè rìn, kódà, àwọn ilé tó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgbọ̀n (30,000) ni ìjì náà ba iná mànàmáná wọn jẹ́.

English: In Okinawa and Kyushu, more than 50 people were injured.
Yoruba: Ní ìlú Okinawa àti Kyushu, àwọn tó ju àádọ́ta (50) lọ ló fara pa.

English: The Japan branch office reports that five publishers were injured, including one sister who was hospitalized.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Japan ròyìn pé àwọn akéde márùn-ún ló fara pa, wọ́n sì ní láti gbé arábìnrin kan lára wọn lọ sílé ìwòsàn.

English: Over 50 homes of our brothers sustained damage.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, ilé àwọn arákùnrin wa tó bà jẹ́ lé ní àádọ́ta (50).

English: A Disaster Relief Committee and responsible brothers are responding to the immediate physical and spiritual needs of the affected publishers.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù àti àwọn arákùnrin tó tóótun ti ń bójú tó ohun táwọn ará yìí nílò nípa tara àti nípa tẹ̀mí.

English: The Japan branch will continue to monitor the effects of this typhoon and provide needed support.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Japan á máa báa lọ láti ṣàyẹ̀wò àwọn ohun tí ìjì yìí bà jẹ́, wọ́n á sì máa pèsè ìrànwọ́ táwọn ará nílò.

English: We pray that our brothers in Japan continue to rely on Jehovah for comfort during this trial.—Psalm 94:19."
Yoruba: Àdúrà wa ni pé kí àwọn ará wa ní Japan máa bá a lọ láti gbára lé Jèhófà, Ọlọ́run ìtùnú ní àkókò wàhálà yìí.​—Sáàmù 94:19."

English: "On Tuesday, September 4, 2018, western Japan suffered the effects of what is being reported as the most powerful typhoon to hit the country in over two decades.
Yoruba: "Ní Tuesday, September 4, 2018, ìjì líle kan jà ní ìwọ̀ oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdè Japan, ó ti lé lógún ọdún tírú ẹ̀ ti jà kẹ́yìn nílẹ̀ náà.

English: Authorities ordered a massive evacuation, and as anticipated, the deadly typhoon caused widespread damage.
Yoruba: Àwọn aláṣẹ ní kí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ kúrò níbi tí wọ́n wà. Bó sì ṣe máa ń rí lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà, ohun tí ìjì líle náà bà jẹ́ kì í ṣe kékeré.

English: The Japan branch has confirmed that no Jehovah’s Witnesses died.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní Japan sọ pé kò sí Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kankan tó bá ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà lọ.

English: However, at least 15 brothers and sisters were injured, and at least 538 homes were damaged.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ó kéré tán, àwọn ará mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dógún (15) ló fara pa, ilé tó sì bà jẹ́ tó ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún àti méjìdínlógójì (538), ó kéré tán.

English: Initial assessments also indicate that 44 Kingdom Halls have been damaged.
Yoruba: Àyẹ̀wò àkọ́kọ́ tí wọ́n ṣe fi hàn pé Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba mẹ́rìnlélógójì (44) ló bà jẹ́.

English: The Osaka and Sakai Disaster Relief Committees are collaborating to care for the relief work, which will include repairing the damaged homes as well as the important work of shepherding.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ Tó Ń Ṣètò Ìrànwọ́ Nígbà Àjálù, tó wà ní ìlú Osaka àti ní Sakai ti jọ ń ṣiṣẹ́ lórí bí wọ́n á ṣe ṣèrànlọ́wọ́, títí kan bí wọ́n á ṣe tún àwọn ilé tó bà jẹ́ ṣe, tí wọ́n á sì bẹ àwọn tọ́rọ̀ náà kàn wò.

English: We are thankful that Jehovah is aware of the difficulties our fellow worshippers are facing and is giving them support by means of the brotherhood.—Psalm 34:19."
Yoruba: A dúpẹ́ pé Jèhófà mọ ìṣòro tí àwọn ará wa ń ní, ó sì ń lo ẹgbẹ́ ará láti ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́.—Sáàmù 34:19."

English: "On Saturday, April 13, 2019, Brother Stephen Lett of the Governing Body released the revised Japanese-language edition of the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures.
Yoruba: "Ní Saturday, April 13, 2019, Arákùnrin Stephen Lett tó jẹ́ ara Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí mú Bíbélì Mímọ́ ti Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tá a tún ṣe jáde lédè Japanese.

English: The revision was released during a special meeting held at the Noevir Stadium Kobe in Kobe, Japan, with 20,868 in attendance.
Yoruba: Inú àkànṣe ìpàdé kan tí wọ́n ṣe ní Gbọ̀ngàn ìwòran tí wọ́n ń pè ní Noevir Stadium Kobe ní ìlú Kobe lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan la ti mú Bíbélì náà jáde, àwọn ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ogún ó lé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ àti méjìndínláàádọ́rin (20,868) ló sì wá síbẹ̀.

English: The program was livestreamed to eight Assembly Halls and many Kingdom Halls in the branch territory.
Yoruba: A ta àtagbà ìpàdé náà sí Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ mẹ́jọ àti ọ̀pọ̀ Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba káàkiri àwọn agbègbè tó wà lábẹ́ ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Japan.

English: Later that day and the next day, a video recording of the meeting was shown at Kingdom Halls for those who were not tied in to the original program.
Yoruba: Àwọn ará tí kò láǹfààní láti wo ìpàdé náà bó ṣe ń lọ lọ́wọ́ wò ó lọ́sàn-án ọjọ́ náà tàbí lọ́jọ́ kejì láwọn Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba.

English: A grand total of 220,491 were able to enjoy the special meeting over the weekend.
Yoruba: Àpapọ̀ iye àwọn tó gbádùn ìpàdé yìí lópin ọ̀sẹ̀ náà jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún méjì ó lé ogún, ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́rin àti mọ́kànléláàádọ́rùn-ún (220,491).

English: The Noevir Stadium Kobe
Yoruba: Gbọ̀ngàn ìwòran Noevir Stadium Kobe

English: We rejoice with the over 2,950 Japanese-language congregations, groups, and pregroups worldwide that now have the revised New World Translation, a powerful gift from Jehovah for personal study and for use in the ministry.—Hebrews 4:12.
Yoruba: A bá àwọn ará wa tó ń sọ èdè Japanese yọ̀ kárí ayé, láwọn ìjọ àtàwọn àwùjọ pẹ̀lú àwọn tí kò tíì di àwùjọ tí iye wọn fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́ta (2,950), pé àwọn náà ti ní Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun, ẹ̀bùn pàtàkì ló jẹ́ látọ̀dọ̀ Jèhófà, ó sì wúlò téèyàn bá fẹ́ kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti lóde ẹ̀rí.—Hébérù 4:12.

English: Brothers and sisters happy to receive their personal copy of the revised New World Translation
Yoruba: Inú àwọn ará ń dùn bí wọ́n ṣe gba Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tiwọn

English: The New World Translation has a history in Japan that goes back 45 years. In 1973, Brother Lyman Swingle, who served on the Governing Body, released the Japanese-language New World Translation of the Christian Greek Scriptures at the “Divine Victory” International Assembly in Osaka, Japan.
Yoruba: Ọdún márùndínláàádọ́ta (45) sẹ́yìn la kọ́kọ́ mú Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan.

English: During the nine years following its release, 1,140,000 copies were distributed, approximately 75 times more than the number of publishers in Japan at the time.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Lyman Swingle tó jẹ́ ara Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí nígbà yẹn ló mú Ìwé Mímọ́ Kristian Lédè Griki ní Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Titun jáde lédè Japanese ní Àpéjọ Àgbáyé “Ìsẹ́gun Àtọ̀runwá” tí wọ́n ṣe ní ìlú Osaka, lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan lọ́dún 1973.

English: In 1982, the complete New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures was released, with printing and binding done in Japan.
Yoruba: Láàárín ọdún mẹ́sàn tá a mú un jáde, a pín ẹ̀dà mílíọ̀nù kan ó lé ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ogóje (1,140,000) fáwọn èèyàn, èyí sì fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó ìlọ́po márùndínlọ́gọ́rin (75) iye àwọn akéde tó wà ní Japan nígbà náà. Lọ́dún 1982, a mú Ìwé Mímọ́ ní Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lódindi, orílẹ̀-èdè Japan la ti tẹ̀ ẹ́, ibẹ̀ náà la sì ti dì í pọ̀.

English: Now, with the release of the revised Japanese-language edition, the year 2019 marks another milestone for Bible translation by Jehovah’s people in Japan.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí tá a ti mú Bíbélì tá a tún ṣe jáde lédè Japanese, ọdún 2019 yìí jẹ́ mánigbàgbé nínú ìtàn iṣẹ́ ìtumọ̀ Bíbélì táwa èèyàn Jèhófà ṣe ní Japan.

English: The New World Translation has been translated in whole or in part into 179 languages, including 22 complete revisions based on the 2013 revised English edition."
Yoruba: A ti mú Bíbélì Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun jáde lódindi tàbí lápá kan ní èdè mọ́kàndínlọ́gọ́sàn-án (179), méjìlélógún (22) lára rẹ̀ sì jẹ́ odindi Bíbélì tá a tún ṣe látinú ẹ̀dà tó jáde lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì lọ́dún 2013."

English: "On October 25 and 26, 2019, Typhoon Bualoi battered the eastern coast of Japan. Notably, Bualoi is the third in a series of typhoons that have struck eastern Japan since September, following typhoons Faxai and Hagibis.
Yoruba: "Ní October 25 àti 26, 2019, ìjì líle kan tí wọ́n pè ní Typhoon Bualoi ṣọṣẹ́ ní apá ìlà oòrùn etíkun Japan.

English: This latest typhoon caused rivers to overflow their banks, resulting in heavy regional flooding.
Yoruba: Ohun tó gba àfiyèsí ni pé, ìjì yìí ni ìkẹta nínú àwọn ìjì tó jà ní ìlà oòrùn Japan láti September, lẹ́yìn tí ìjì líle tí wọ́n pè ní Typhoon Faxai àti Hagibis jà.

English: At least 81 homes of our brothers sustained damage.
Yoruba: Ìjì líle tó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ jà yìí mú kí àwọn odò kún àkúnya, èyí sì fa ọ̀pọ̀ omíyalé ní agbègbè náà.

English: There are no reports of fatalities among our brothers; however, one sister was injured.
Yoruba: Ó kéré tán, ilé mọ́kànlélọ́gọ́rin (81) tó jẹ́ tàwọn ará wa ló bà jẹ́.

English: The brothers and sisters in Chiba Prefecture have suffered as a result of all three typhoons.
Yoruba: A ò gbọ́ pé ará wa kankan kú, àmọ́ arábìnrin kan fara pa. Ìjì yìí ti kó àwọn arákùnrin àtàwọn arábìnrin wa tó ń gbé ní ìpínlẹ̀ Chiba sí ìdààmú gan-an.

English: Three Disaster Relief Committees (DRCs) in the affected area were already spearheading the relief efforts in connection with typhoons Faxai and Hagibis.
Yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ mẹ́ta tó ń pèsè ìrànwọ́ nígbà àjálù ló ṣètò ìrànwọ́ láwọn agbègbè yìí nígbà tí ìjì Faxai àti Hagibis jà, àwọn náà ló sì ń pèsè ìrànwọ́ báyìí lẹ́yìn tí ìjì Bualoi jà.

English: These DRCs are now also caring for those affected by Bualoi.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa tó wà ní Japan ń ti àwọn ìgbìmọ̀ yìí lẹ́yìn kí wọ́n lè pèsè ìtọ́jú ní kíákíá fáwọn ará wa.

English: The Japan branch is assisting the DRCs to care for the immediate needs of our brothers, such as providing assistance for cleaning, disinfecting, and repairing homes.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń bá wọn tún àyíká wọn ṣe, wọ́n ń pèsè àwọn oògùn tó ń pa kòkòrò, wọ́n sì ń tún àwọn ilé wọn tó bà jẹ́ ṣe.

English: Circuit overseers are coordinating efforts to encourage the brothers and sisters.
Yoruba: Àwọn alábòójútó àyíká ń ṣe gbogbo ohun tí wọ́n lè ṣe láti fún àwọn ará ní ìṣírí, kí wọ́n sì tù wọ́n nínú.

English: During this difficult time, we pray for our brothers in Japan, confident that Jehovah cares for his worshippers who are “crushed in spirit” by this series of natural disasters.—Psalm 34:18."
Yoruba: Lákòókò tí nǹkan le yìí, à ń gbàdúrà fún àwọn ará wa tó wà ní Japan, a sì mọ̀ pé Jèhófà máa bójú tó àwọn ìránṣẹ́ ẹ̀ tí “àárẹ̀ bá ẹ̀mí wọn” nítorí àjálù yìí.—Sáàmù 34:18."

English: "On September 9, 2019, powerful Typhoon Faxai made landfall near Tokyo, Japan.
Yoruba: "Ní September 9, 2019 ìjì líle tó ń jẹ́ Faxai jà nítòsí Tokyo, lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan.

English: The typhoon packed winds of up to 180 kilometers per hour (approx. 112 mph) and left 580,000 homes without electricity.
Yoruba: Afẹ́fẹ́ ìjì náà lágbára débi pé ó fẹ́ dé ibi tó jìnnà tó ọgọ́sàn-án (180) kìlómítà láàárín wákàtí kan péré, ó sì ba iná mànàmáná ilé tó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún ó lé ọgọ́rin (580,000) jẹ́.

English: At least three people were killed.
Yoruba: Ó kéré tán èèyàn mẹ́ta ló pàdánù ẹ̀mí wọn.

English: The Japan branch office reports that no publishers were killed but seven of our brothers and sisters suffered injuries.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì wa ní Japan ròyìn pé kò sí akéde kankan tó kú, àmọ́ méje lára àwọn ará wa fara pa.

English: Initial assessments indicate that the storm damaged 895 homes of our brothers, 28 Kingdom Halls, and one Assembly Hall located in Chiba.
Yoruba: Àyẹ̀wò tí wọ́n kọ́kọ́ ṣe fi hàn pé ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́jọ àti márùndínlọ́gọ́rùn-ún (895) ilé àwọn ará ló bà jẹ́, Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba méjìdínlọ́gbọ̀n (28) àti Gbọ̀ngàn Àpéjọ kan tó wà ni Chiba sì bà jẹ́.

English: The branch continues to assess Typhoon Faxai’s impact on our brothers.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì ṣì ń ṣàyẹ̀wò àwọn ohun tí ìjì náà bà jẹ́ kí wọ́n lè pèsè ohun táwọn ará nílò.

English: We pray that Jehovah, “the God who supplies endurance and comfort,” will continue to support our brothers and sisters affected by this disaster.—Romans 15:5."
Yoruba: A gbàdúrà pé kí Jèhófà, “Ọlọ́run tó ń fúnni ní ìfaradà àti ìtùnú” máa tu àwọn ará wa yìí nínú, kó sì dúró tì wọ́n lásìkò àjálù yìí.​—Róòmù 15:5"

English: "The president of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev, pardoned Teymur Akhmedov, and he was released from custody on April 4, 2018.
Yoruba: "Nursultan Nazarbayev tó jẹ́ ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè Kazakhstan ní kí wọ́n dá Teymur Akhmedov sílẹ̀, wọ́n sì mú un kúrò látìmọ́lé ní April 4, 2018.

English: Earlier, on March 27, 2018, authorities permitted Brother Akhmedov to receive urgent surgical care in a hospital in Almaty, where he is currently recuperating.
Yoruba: Ṣáájú àkókò yẹn, ní March 27, 2018, àwọn aláṣẹ gba Arákùnrin Akhmedov láyè pé kó lọ ṣiṣẹ́ abẹ pàjáwìrì nílé ìwòsàn kan tó wà nílùú Almaty.

English: Brother Akhmedov, 61, has been in prison since January 18, 2017, for merely practicing his faith.
Yoruba: Ibẹ̀ ló wà báyìí, tí ara rẹ̀ ti ń yá díẹ̀díẹ̀.

English: He is glad to finally be reunited with his family.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Akhmedov, ẹni ọdún mọ́kànlélọ́gọ́ta (61), ti wà lẹ́wọ̀n láti January 18, 2017, torí pé ó kàn ń ṣe ohun tó gbà gbọ́. Inú ẹ̀ dùn pé òun ti pa dà sílé báyìí lọ́dọ̀ àwọn mọ̀lẹ́bí òun.

English: We all rejoice that Jehovah rescued his loyal servant.—2 Samuel 22:2."
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa là ń yọ̀ torí pé Jèhófà ti gba ìránṣẹ́ rẹ̀ olóòótọ́ sílẹ̀.​—2 Sámúẹ́lì 22:2."

English: "From May 11 to November 10, 2018, Jehovah’s Witnesses in Kazakhstan invited their neighbors to seven open houses, which they held in select cities throughout the country.
Yoruba: "Bẹ̀rẹ̀ láti May 11 sí November 10, 2018, àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ní Kazakhstan pe àwọn èèyàn pé kí wọ́n wá ṣèbẹ̀wò sí Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba.

English: These events provided an opportunity for government officials, journalists, and academics, along with the public, to learn about Jehovah’s Witnesses. In total, over 1,500 people attended.
Yoruba: Lára àwọn tó tẹ́wọ́ gba ìkésíni náà ni àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba, àwọn akọ̀ròyìn, àwọn ọ̀mọ̀wé àtàwọn míì, ètò yìí sì jẹ́ kí gbogbo wọn mọ púpọ̀ sí i nípa àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà. Lápapọ̀, àwọn tó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún kan ààbọ̀ (1,500) ló lọ.

English: Locations of open houses: (1) Öskemen, (2) Qaraghandy, (3) Qostanay, (4) Semey, (5) Shymkent, (6) Taldyqorghan, and (7) Taraz.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìlú tí Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba náà wà: (1) Öskemen, (2) Qaraghandy, (3) Qostanay, (4) Semey, (5) Shymkent, (6) Taldyqorghan àti (7) Taraz.

English: The open houses were hosted at Kingdom Halls in the cities of Öskemen, Qaraghandy, Qostanay, Semey, Shymkent, Taldyqorghan, and Taraz.
Yoruba: Àwọn Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba kan ni wọ́n ṣètò pé káwọn èèyàn náà wá, àwọn Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba náà sì wà ní ìlú méje ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, ìyẹn ní ìlú Öskemen, Qaraghandy, Qostanay, Semey, Shymkent, Taldyqorghan àti Taraz.

English: Attendees enjoyed displays detailing the history of our activities in Kazakhstan, which began as far back as 1892.
Yoruba: Àwọn tó wá síbẹ̀ rí àwọn nǹkan tó jẹ́ kí wọ́n mọ púpọ̀ sí i nípa ìtàn àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ní Kazakhstan, èyí tó ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ láti ọdún 1892.

English: Displays also highlighted more modern achievements, such as the release of the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures in Kazakh in 2014.
Yoruba: Wọ́n tún rí àwọn nǹkan tó jẹ́ kí wọ́n mọ̀ nípa ohun tá à ń gbé ṣe lóde òní, irú bíi Bíbélì Mímọ́ ti Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tá a mú jáde lédè Kazakh lọ́dún 2014.

English: Brother Bekzat Smagulov, who works with the Legal Department and Public Information Desk at the Kazakhstan branch, comments on the benefits: “These open-house events were well-received by our neighbors and helped them gain an accurate picture of who we are.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Bekzat Smagulov tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Bójú Tó Ọ̀ràn Òfin àti Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Gbéròyìn Jáde ní ọ́fíìsì àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà ní Kazakhstan sọ pé: “Ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ló tẹ́wọ́ gba ìkésíni náà láti wá ṣèbẹ̀wò, ìyẹn sì ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti mọ irú ẹni tá a jẹ́ gan-an.

English: Among the notable visitors were officials from the Department of Religious Affairs and journalists from the Kazakhstan-Öskemen news outlet, the Rudnyi Altai newspaper, and the Semei Vesti newspaper.”
Yoruba: Lára àwọn tó wá síbẹ̀ ni àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ láti Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ẹ̀sìn lórílẹ̀-èdè Kazakhstan, àtàwọn akọ̀ròyìn láti ilé iṣẹ́ oníròyìn Kazakhstan-Öskemen, títí kan aṣojú láti ilé iṣẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn Rudnyi Altai àti Semei Vesti.”

English: At the open house in Taldyqorghan, the administrative center of the Almaty region, the brothers welcomed the head of the Regional Department of Religious Affairs and two other officials from the department.
Yoruba: Ẹnì kan tó jẹ́ olórí ní Ẹ̀ka Tó Ń Bójú Tó Ọ̀rọ̀ Ẹ̀sìn ní àgbègbè kan, pẹ̀lú àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ méjì míì láti ẹ̀ka yẹn wà lára àwọn tó wá sí Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba tó wà ní ìlú Taldyqorghan.

English: Also in attendance was the editor-in-chief of the Zhetysu Dialog newspaper, who later published an article based on interviews with some of the volunteers at the event.
Yoruba: A tún rí ẹnì kan tó jẹ́ olóòtú ilé iṣẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn Zhetysu Dialog, nígbà tó yá, ẹni yìí gbé àpilẹ̀kọ kan jáde nínú ìwé ìròyìn níbi tó ti ṣe ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò fún àwọn kan tó yọ̀ǹda ara wọn ní Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba náà.

English: Additionally, our brothers and sisters distributed over 560 copies of the New World Translation in both Kazakh and Russian, the principal languages of Kazakhstan.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, àwọn ará wa tún pín Bíbélì Mímọ́ ti Ìtumọ̀ Ayé Tuntun tó lé ní ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún ó lé lọ́gọ́ta (560) fáwọn èèyàn ní èdè Kazakh àti Russian, àwọn èdè tí wọ́n ń sọ jù ní Kazakhstan.

English: We appreciate the positive results of these arrangements, which bring praise to Jehovah and allow our neighbors to see our “fine works.”—Matthew 5:16."
Yoruba: Inú wa dùn pé gbogbo nǹkan lọ bó ṣe yẹ, èyí sì mú ìyìn bá orúkọ Jèhófà, ó tún jẹ́ káwọn èèyàn mọ̀ nípa “àwọn iṣẹ́ rere” wa.—Mátíù 5:16."

English: "Following an official pardon from the president of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev, Brother Teymur Akhmedov was released from custody on April 4, 2018. He had been imprisoned for a total of 441 days.
Yoruba: "Lẹ́yìn tí Ààrẹ Nursultan Nazarbayev tó jẹ́ olórí orílẹ̀-èdè Kazakhstan dá Arákùnrin Teymur Akhmedov sílẹ̀, wọ́n mú un kúrò látìmọ́lé ní April 4, 2018. Gbogbo ọjọ́ tó lò lẹ́wọ̀n jẹ́ ọgọ́rùn-ún mẹ́rin ó lé mọ́kànlélógójì (441).

English: Authorities had arrested him merely for sharing his religious beliefs with others.
Yoruba: Torí pé ó kàn ń sọ ohun tó gbà gbọ́ fáwọn míì ni àwọn aláṣẹ ṣe mú un.

English: Shortly after Teymur was released from prison, the Office of Public Information (OPI) at the world headquarters of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Warwick, New York, spoke with him and his wife, Mafiza, who have now returned to their home in Astana, the capital of Kazakhstan.
Yoruba: Kò pẹ́ lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n dá Teymur sílẹ̀ lẹ́wọ̀n tí Ọ́fíìsì Agbéròyìnjáde (ìyẹn OPI) tó wà ní oríléeṣẹ́ àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà nílùú Warwick, ìpínlẹ̀ New York, bá òun àti Mafiza ìyàwó ẹ̀ sọ̀rọ̀, àwọn méjèèjì ti pa dà báyìí sí ilé wọn nílùú Astana, tó jẹ́ olú ìlú Kazakhstan. Àwọn ohun tí wọ́n sọ la kọ sísàlẹ̀ yìí.

English: This is a condensed transcript of the conversation that has been edited for clarity.
Yoruba: A ti gé e kúrú, a sì kọ́ ọ lọ́nà tó máa jẹ́ kó ṣe kedere.

English: OPI: To begin with, we would like to learn more about you, Brother Akhmedov.
Yoruba: OPI: Arákùnrin Akhmedov, a máa kọ́kọ́ fẹ́ mọ̀ sí i nípa yín.

English: When did you become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses?
Yoruba: Ìgbà wo lẹ di Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà?

English: Teymur Akhmedov: I was baptized on October 9, 2005.
Yoruba: Teymur Akhmedov: October 9, 2005 ni mo ṣèrìbọmi.

English: Before I learned the truth, I was an atheist.
Yoruba: Kí n tó kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ òtítọ́, mi ò gbà pé Ọlọ́run wà.

English: For many years, I didn’t believe in anyone or anything.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún ni mi ò fi gba Ọlọ́run gbọ́, mi ò sì ṣe ẹ̀sìn kankan.

English: Later, when my wife started to study, I was curious about the discussions she was having with the Witnesses.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó yá, àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í kọ́ ìyàwó mi lẹ́kọ̀ọ́, ó sì wù mí kí n mo ohun tí wọ́n jọ máa ń sọ.

English: I used to stand behind the door and eavesdrop on their conversations.
Yoruba: Mo bá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í dúró sẹ́yìn ilẹ̀kùn, kí n lè máa fetí kọ́ ohun tí wọ́n ń sọ.

English: When I learned about what they were studying, I was intrigued because they talked only about kind and good things.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo mọ ohun tí wọ́n ń kọ́ ọ, ó yà mí lẹ́nu torí pé kìkì àwọn nǹkan rere-rere ni wọ́n jọ ń sọ.

English: Eventually, the Witnesses introduced me to Brother Veslav, who was originally from Poland but was serving in Kazakhstan.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó yá, àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí fi mí mọ Arákùnrin Veslav tó wá láti Poland àmọ́ tó ń gbé ní Kazakhstan.

English: During our first discussion, I told him: ‘I am going to ask you only one question.
Yoruba: Lọ́jọ́ tá a kọ́kọ́ jọ sọ̀rọ̀, mo sọ fún un pé: ‘Ìbéèrè kan ṣoṣo ni màá bi ẹ́.

English: If I’m satisfied with your answer, we’ll be friends and continue our discussions.
Yoruba: Tí ìdáhùn rẹ bá tẹ́ mi lọ́rùn, àá dọ̀rẹ́, àá sì jọ máa bá ọ̀rọ̀ wa lọ.

English: If, on the other hand, I don’t like your answer, no hard feelings but I will not continue our discussions.’
Yoruba: Àmọ́ tí mi ò bá gba ti ìdáhùn tó o fún mi, a ò ní lè jọ máa bọ́rọ̀ yìí lọ mọ́. O ò ní bínú sí mi, èmi náà ò sì ní bínú sí ẹ.’

English: I then asked Brother Veslav what happens to the dead.
Yoruba: Mo wá bi Arákùnrin Veslav léèrè ohun tó máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ sí àwọn tó ti kú.

English: He opened the Bible to Ecclesiastes 9:5 and said, ‘Read this verse and you’ll know what happens.’
Yoruba: Ó ṣí Bíbélì sí Oníwàásù 9:​5, ó sì sọ pé, ‘Tó o bá ka ẹsẹ Bíbélì yìí, wàá mọ ohun tó máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ sáwọn tó ti kú.’

English: When I read the verse, I realized that this was the truth.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo kà á, mo rí i pé òtítọ́ nìyí.

English: I agreed to meet him again and study the Bible.
Yoruba: Torí náà mo gbà pé kó máa wá, kó sì máa kọ́ mi kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì.

English: So, you studied the Bible and were eventually baptized in 2005.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ ẹ ṣe kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì nìyẹn, tẹ́ ẹ sì ṣèrìbọmi lọ́dún 2005.

English: Now let’s fast forward to the events that preceded your arrest.
Yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ ká fi ìyókù lẹ̀ ná, ká sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ káwọn aláṣẹ tó mú yín.

English: In May 2016, you met a group of men who claimed to be interested in the beliefs of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Yoruba: Ní May 2016, ẹ pàdé àwọn ọkùnrin kan tí wọ́n láwọn nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí ohun táwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà gbà gbọ́.

English: Over the course of a few months, you met with them several times to discuss the Bible.
Yoruba: Láàárín oṣù mélòó kan, ẹ máa ń lọ bá wọn jíròrò látinú Bíbélì.

English: Looking back on those conversations, was there anything they said or did that appeared suspicious?
Yoruba: Tẹ́ ẹ bá ronú pa dà sẹ́yìn sí àwọn ìgbà tẹ́ ẹ jọ máa ń jíròrò yẹn, ǹjẹ́ ẹ rántí ohunkóhun tí wọ́n sọ tàbí tí wọ́n ṣe tó mú ìfura lọ́wọ́?

English: TA: Yes, I mentioned that Bible studies like this are typically conducted with individuals rather than a group.
Yoruba: TA: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, mo sọ fún wọn pé tá a bá ń ṣe ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì, a sábà máa ń fẹ́ kó jẹ́ ẹnì kọ̀ọ̀kan làá máa kọ́ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ dípò kó jẹ́ àwọn kan tó kóra jọ.

English: I recommended that they each study separately, but every time I suggested it, they refused and said that they liked the group discussions.
Yoruba: Mo sọ pé á dáa kí kálukú wọn máa ṣe ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ yìí lọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, àmọ́ gbogbo ìgbà tí mo bá ti sọ bẹ́ẹ̀ ni wọ́n máa ń sọ pé rárá, ìjíròrò aláwùjọ yẹn làwọn fẹ́.

English: Also, on a number of occasions, they would invite others to join the study and ask me to repeat what we had already discussed on the previous visit.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ síyẹn, ẹ̀ẹ̀mélòó kan wà tí wọ́n pe àwọn míì wá síbi tá a ti ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ pé kí wọ́n wá dara pọ̀ mọ́ wa, wọ́n á sì ní kí n tún ohun tá a jíròrò nígbà tá a kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ gbẹ̀yìn sọ.

English: Mafiza Akhmedov: Once, I also sat in on their Bible study.
Yoruba: Mafiza Akhmedov: Ìgbà kan wà témi náà wà níbi tí wọ́n ti ń ṣe ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

English: I noticed that they were discussing different religions, although they had been studying for quite some time.
Yoruba: Mo kíyè sí i pé wọ́n ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ẹ̀sìn ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ó ti ṣe díẹ̀ tí wọ́n ti ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

English: I also noticed that the apartment they lived in was more expensive than most students could afford.
Yoruba: Mo tún kíyè sí i pé ilé tí wọ́n ń gbé gbówó lórí ju ilé tí ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ máa ń lè sanwó ẹ̀.

English: I commented that they lived a rather opulent life for students.
Yoruba: Mo sọ fún wọn pé ìgbésí ayé olówó tí wọ́n ń gbé yàtọ̀ sí èyí tí ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ń gbé.

English: My comments clearly made them uncomfortable.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ mo rí i pé ohun tí mo sọ bà wọ́n, ara wọn ò sì lélẹ̀.

English: When we were leaving, they pulled Teymur aside and, while I was waiting outside, told him not to bring me to the study anymore.
Yoruba: Nígbà tá à ń kúrò níbẹ̀ lọ́jọ́ yẹn, ṣe ni wọ́n pe Teymur sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ kan, èmi lọ dúró dè é níta, wọ́n sì sọ fún un pé kó má mú mi wá síbẹ̀ mọ́ nígbàkigbà tó bá fẹ́ wá kọ́ àwọn lẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

English: When did you find out that the men you were studying with weren’t interested in Jehovah’s Witnesses but were actually working with Kazakhstan’s secret police, the National Security Committee (KNB)?
Yoruba: Ìgbà wo lẹ wá mọ̀ pé kì í ṣe pé àwọn ọkùnrin tẹ́ ẹ̀ ń kọ́ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì fẹ́ràn àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà, pé àwọn ọlọ́pàá ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ ilẹ̀ Kazakhstan (ìyẹn KNB) ni wọ́n ń bá ṣiṣẹ́?

English: TA: I only learned that they were cooperating with the KNB during the court hearing.
Yoruba: TA: Ìgbà tí ìgbẹ́jọ́ bẹ̀rẹ̀ ni mo tó mọ̀ pé àwọn ọlọ́pàá KNB ni wọ́n ń bá ṣiṣẹ́.

English: What was your reaction when you were arrested and then later charged with “inciting religious discord” and advocating “[religious] superiority”?
Yoruba: Báwo ló ṣe rí lára yín nígbà tí wọ́n mú yín, tí wọ́n sì fẹ̀sùn kàn yín pé ẹ̀ ń “mú kí àwọn èèyàn kórìíra ẹ̀sìn míì” ẹ sì ń “gbé [ẹ̀sìn] kan ga ju ẹ̀sìn míì lọ”?

English: TA: Honestly, when I was arrested, I thought that they would escort me, as they said, to the police station in order to clarify the matter and then I would be released.
Yoruba: TA: Ká sòótọ́, nígbà tí wọ́n mú mi, ṣe ni mo rò pé bí wọ́n ṣe sọ, wọ́n máa mú mi lọ sí àgọ́ ọlọ́pàá kí n lè ṣàlàyé tẹnu mi, kí wọ́n sì dá mi sílẹ̀.

English: I was ready to defend myself and explain what I discussed with them.
Yoruba: Mo ṣe tán láti gbèjà ara mi, kí n sì ṣàlàyé ohun tí mo bá àwọn ọkùnrin náà sọ.

English: I was quite surprised by the turn of events, but I was not afraid.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ohun tó wá ṣẹlẹ̀ yà mí lẹ́nu, síbẹ̀ mi ò bẹ̀rù.

English: The accusations of inciting religious hatred and extremism were a big surprise to me.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kàn mí pé mò ń mú kí àwọn èèyàn kórìíra ẹ̀sìn míì, pé mo sì ń lọ́wọ́ sí iṣẹ́ agbawèrèmẹ́sìn yà mí lẹ́nu gan-an.

English: Jehovah’s Witnesses are people who share their knowledge of Jehovah and have never been associated with hatred or discord.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ nípa Jèhófà làwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà máa ń sọ, a ò sì fìgbà kankan ní ohunkóhun ṣe pẹ̀lú ìkórìíra tàbí ìyapa.

English: I was firmly convinced that I was innocent and that Jehovah would support me.
Yoruba: Ó dá mi lójú hán-ún hán-ún pé mi ò mọwọ́ mẹsẹ̀, mo sì mọ̀ pé Jèhófà máa ràn mí lọ́wọ́.

English: It’s true that I was worried, but I remembered the advice from the Bible, “throw all your anxiety on him [Jehovah], because he cares for you.”—1 Peter 5:7.
Yoruba: Òótọ́ ni pé ọkàn mi ò balẹ̀, àmọ́ mo rántí ìmọ̀ràn tó wà nínú Bíbélì, tó sọ pé, “ẹ . . . kó gbogbo àníyàn yín lé [Jèhófà], nítorí ó bìkítà fún yín.”​—1 Pétérù 5:7.

English: As things developed, on May 2, 2017, after being in pretrial detention for over three months, a district court in Astana sentenced you to a five-year prison term and added a three-year ban on your participation in Bible education activities.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó di May 2, 2017, lẹ́yìn tẹ́ ẹ ti lo ohun tó lé ní oṣù mẹ́ta ní àtìmọ́lé, ilé ẹjọ́ kan nílùú Astana rán yín lọ sí ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún márùn-ún, wọ́n sì tún fòfin dè yín pé ẹ ò gbọ́dọ̀ ṣe iṣẹ́ ìkọ́nilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì fún ọdún mẹ́ta.

English: How did that verdict affect you?
Yoruba: Báwo ló ṣe rí lára yín?

English: TA: When the court announced its decision, I resigned myself to accept the fact that I will have to serve the full term if necessary.
Yoruba: TA: Nígbà tí ilé ẹjọ́ sọ bẹ́ẹ̀, mo gbà lọ́kàn ara mi pé tó bá pọn dandan, màá lo ọdún márùn-ún tí wọ́n dá fún mi pé.

English: My attitude was: ‘If this is a test, then Jehovah is in control of the timetable and he knows when it will end.’
Yoruba: Ohun tí mo rò ni pé: ‘Tó bá jẹ́ pé àdánwò ló délẹ̀ yìí, Jèhófà ń rí gbogbo ẹ̀, ó mọ bó ṣe máa pẹ́ tó àtìgbà tó máa dópin.’

English: I was determined to wait as long as it took.
Yoruba: Torí náà, mo pinnu pé bó ti wù kó pẹ́ tó, màá dúró.

English: The correctional facility in the city of Pavlodar, Kazakhstan, where Brother Akhmedov was imprisoned.
Yoruba: Ilé tí wọ́n ti ń tún ìwà ẹni ṣe nílùú Pavlodar ní Kazakhstan, ibẹ̀ ni Arákùnrin Akhmedov ti ṣẹ̀wọ̀n.

English: We understand, though, that at the time you were imprisoned, you were battling a serious health condition. Is that correct?
Yoruba: Àmọ́ nígbà tí wọ́n fi yín sẹ́wọ̀n yẹn, a mọ̀ pé ẹ̀ ń bá àìsàn kan tó le fínra. Àbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́?

English: TA: Yes, I was sick and undergoing treatments before being imprisoned.
Yoruba: TA: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ara mi ò yá, mo sì ń gbàtọ́jú kó tó di pé wọ́n rán mi lọ sẹ́wọ̀n.

English: When I was arrested, my treatments were terminated and my disease started to progress.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ nígbà tí wọ́n ti mú mi, wọ́n dá ìtọ́jú tí mò ń gbà dúró, àìsàn tó ń ṣe mí wá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í le sí i.

English: Mafiza, how did you feel during this time?
Yoruba: Arábìnrin Mafiza, báwo lọ̀rọ̀ yìí ṣe rí lára yín lásìkò yẹn?

English: MA: I was terrified and deeply depressed.
Yoruba: MA: Ẹ̀rù bà mí gan-an, ìbànújẹ́ sì dorí mi kodò.

English: It was even difficult for me to make decisions after Teymur was imprisoned because for the 38 years that we had been married, we’d never been separated from each other.
Yoruba: Kódà, ó nira fún mi láti máa dá ìpinnu ṣe látìgbà tí wọ́n ti fi Teymur sẹ́wọ̀n, torí pé láti ọdún méjìdínlógójì (38) tá a ti ṣègbéyàwó, nǹkan kan ò yà wá rí.

English: But Teymur comforted me, saying: ‘Don’t worry! Jehovah will replace these 5 years of separation with 25 more years – even in this system of things!’
Yoruba: Àmọ́ Teymur sọ̀rọ̀ kan tó tù mí nínú, ó ní: ‘Fọkàn balẹ̀, ṣó o gbọ́? Ṣó o rí ọdún márùn-ún tá a máa fi pín yà yìí, ọdún mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dọ́gbọ̀n (25) ni Jèhófà máa fi rọ́pò ẹ̀ fún wa kí Ìjọba Ọlọ́run tó dé!’

English: What else helped you during the time your husband was imprisoned?
Yoruba: Kí lohun míì tó tún ràn yín lọ́wọ́ nígbà tí ọkọ yín wà lẹ́wọ̀n?

English: MA: The brothers and sisters really helped me.
Yoruba: MA: Àwọn ará lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin ràn mí lọ́wọ́ gan-an.

English: When Teymur was put into prison, I honestly thought that everyone would be afraid to visit me because of the circumstances surrounding Teymur’s arrest.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n fi Teymur sẹ́wọ̀n, kí n má parọ́, ṣe ni mo rò pé ẹ̀rù á máa ba gbogbo wọn láti wá wò mí torí ohun tó fà á táwọn aláṣẹ fi mú Teymur.

English: The KNB were monitoring our house and activities.
Yoruba: Kódà, àwọn ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ ń ṣọ́ ilé wa, wọ́n sì ń ṣọ́ àwọn nǹkan tá à ń ṣe.

English: Then one day, an elder and his wife came to visit, and it was a tremendous boost for me.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ lọ́jọ́ kan, alàgbà kan àti ìyàwó ẹ̀ wá wò mí, ìṣírí ńlá gbáà ló jẹ́ fún mi.

English: When I asked them, ‘Aren’t you afraid to come here?’
Yoruba: Mo bi wọ́n pé, ‘Ṣé ẹ̀rù ò bà yín láti wá síbí ni?’

English: They responded, ‘Why would we be afraid?
Yoruba: Wọ́n dáhùn pé, ‘Kí ló fẹ́ máa bà wá lẹ́rù?

English: Nowadays, the authorities can track us through our phones.
Yoruba: Níbi táyé dé yìí, kò ṣòro rárá fáwọn aláṣẹ láti rí wa mú.

English: So if they want to, they can easily find us.’
Yoruba: Tí wọ́n bá fẹ́ mú wa, kò ju kí wọ́n fi kọ̀ǹpútà wá àdírẹ́sì ibi tá a ti ń pè lórí fóònù.’

English: On a shepherding visit, the elders encouraged me to avoid being overcome by the test and be spiritually strong.
Yoruba: Àwọn alàgbà wá ṣèbẹ̀wò olùṣọ́ àgùntàn sọ́dọ̀ mi, wọ́n sì rọ̀ mí pé kí n má jẹ́ kí àdánwò tó délẹ̀ yìí kó ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sì bá mi, àmọ́ kí n jẹ́ kí ìgbàgbọ́ mi àti àjọṣe mi pẹ̀lú Jèhófà túbọ̀ lágbára.

English: Teymur, what helped you to endure this particular test and remain positive?
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Teymur, kí ló ràn yín lọ́wọ́ tẹ́ ẹ fi fara da àdánwò yìí, tẹ́ ò sì sọ̀rètí nù?

English: Brother Akhmedov chained to a hospital bed in Almaty shortly before his release.
Yoruba: Wọ́n de Arákùnrin Akhmedov mọ́ bẹ́ẹ̀dì nílé ìwòsàn ní Almaty kó tó di pé wọ́n tú u sílẹ̀.

English: Although he was initially denied medical care, authorities permitted him to have treatment when his health situation became urgent.
Yoruba: Bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé wọn ò kọ́kọ́ jẹ́ kó gbàtọ́jú, nígbà tí ìlera ẹ̀ di pé ó ń burú sí i, àwọn aláṣẹ gbà kí wọ́n tọ́jú rẹ̀.

English: TA: Prayer to Jehovah! Every day I prayed for guidance, understanding, and strength so that I could remain joyful, loyal, and faithful during my difficulty.
Yoruba: TA: Àdúrà ni! Ojoojúmọ́ ni mo máa ń gbàdúrà pé kí Jèhófà tọ́ mi sọ́nà, kó fún mi lóye, kó sì jẹ́ kí n lókun kí n lè máa láyọ̀, kí n lè jẹ́ olóòótọ́, kí n má sì bọ́hùn lásìkò ìṣòro yìí.

English: His answers to my prayers were obvious.
Yoruba: Mo sì rí bó ṣe dáhùn àdúrà mi.

English: He supported me, and I did not feel that I was alone in prison.
Yoruba: Kò fi mí sílẹ̀, torí mi ò mọ̀ ọ́n lára pé mo dá wà nínú ẹ̀wọ̀n.

English: Bible reading also assisted me.
Yoruba: Kíka Bíbélì náà ràn mí lọ́wọ́.

English: In one of the prisons, I had a Bible available to me at all times.
Yoruba: Nínú ọ̀kan lára àwọn ọgbà ẹ̀wọ̀n yẹn, Bíbélì wà lárọ̀ọ́wọ́tó mi ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: In another facility, a Bible was kept in the prison library, and I could go and read it once a week.
Yoruba: Ní ọgbà ẹ̀wọ̀n míì tí wọ́n gbé mi lọ, wọ́n fi Bíbélì kan síbi ìkówèésí ní ọgbà náà, mo sì lè lọ máa kà á lẹ́ẹ̀kan lọ́sẹ̀.

English: I also remembered the words of the brother who studied the Bible with me.
Yoruba: Mo tún rántí ọ̀rọ̀ arákùnrin tó kọ́ mi lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Bíbélì.

English: He used to say that we should not be afraid of the challenges we face. I remember asking him: ‘Why should I not be afraid?
Yoruba: Ó máa ń sọ pé kò yẹ kí ìṣòro tá à ń kojú máa dẹ́rù bà wá.

English: What if the challenge is difficult and terrifying?’
Yoruba: Mo rántí pé mo bi wọ́n pé: ‘Báwo ni mi ò ṣe ní bẹ̀rù?

English: He said that Jehovah will not allow us to be tested beyond what we can bear and he will give us the strength to overcome any trial. (1 Corinthians 10:13)
Yoruba: Tí ìṣòro yẹn bá le ńkọ́, tó sì ń dáyà já mi?’ Ó ní, Jèhófà ò ní jẹ́ ká dán wa wò kọjá ohun tá a lè mú mọ́ra, á sì fún wa lókun ká lè borí ìṣòro èyíkéyìí. (1 Kọ́ríńtì 10:13)

English: So while in prison, I never forgot that Scriptural thought.
Yoruba: Torí náà, nígbà tí mo wà lẹ́wọ̀n, mi ò gbàgbé ọ̀rọ̀ tí wọ́n fà yọ látinú Ìwé Mímọ́ yẹn.

English: How did it make you feel when you found out that the brotherhood was aware of your situation and that brothers and sisters around the world were praying for you?
Yoruba: Báwo ló ṣe rí lára yín nígbà tẹ́ ẹ gbọ́ pé gbogbo àwọn ará kárí ayé ló ti gbọ́ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ sí yín, àti pé gbogbo wọn lọ́kùnrin lóbìnrin ló ń gbàdúrà fún yín?

English: TA: I definitely felt that it was Jehovah’s hand because the organization belongs to him.
Yoruba: TA: Ó dá mi lójú pé Jèhófà ló lọ́wọ́ sí ọ̀rọ̀ yẹn torí pé òun náà ló ni ètò yìí.

English: This assured me that I wouldn’t be abandoned and one day Jehovah would rescue me.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn fi mí lọ́kàn balẹ̀ pé àwọn ará ò ní pa mí tì, àti pé lọ́jọ́ kan, Jèhófà máa kó mi yọ.

English: Interestingly, prison was actually the thing that I feared the most.
Yoruba: Kẹ́ ẹ sì máa wò ó o, ohun tó bà mí lẹ́rù jù ni kí wọ́n fi mí sẹ́wọ̀n.

English: I was terrified of prisons.
Yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rù ọgbà ẹ̀wọ̀n gan-an.

English: When I would read about our brothers in prisons, I used to pray, ‘Jehovah, please, anything but prison!’
Yoruba: Tí mo bá ń ka ìtàn àwọn ará wa tó wà lẹ́wọ̀n, ṣe ni mo máa ń gbàdúrà pé, ‘Jèhófà jọ̀ọ́, gbogbo nǹkan ni mo lè mú mọ́ra, àmọ́ bíi ti ẹ̀wọ̀n kọ́!’

English: But at the same time, I had a very strong desire to visit people in jail and talk to them about the truth.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, lẹ́sẹ̀ kan náà, ó máa ń wù mí gan-an láti lọ sọ́dọ̀ àwọn tó wà lẹ́wọ̀n, kí n lè kọ́ wọn lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ òtítọ́.

English: When I asked about engaging in prison witnessing, the brothers explained that at this time, we do not have permission to visit prisons in Kazakhstan.
Yoruba: Mo béèrè nígbà kan bóyá a lè lọ máa wàásù lọ́gbà ẹ̀wọ̀n, àmọ́ àwọn àrá ṣàlàyé pé lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ báyìí, ìjọba ò fún wa láṣẹ láti máa lọ sáwọn ẹ̀wọ̀n tó wà ní Kazakhstan.

English: So when I faced my trial, I had mixed feelings, on the one hand, I was afraid, but at the same time, I felt like my dream of being able to preach to prisoners was going to come true.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó wá di pé nǹkan yí bìrí fún mi, ẹ́rù ṣe ń bà mí náà ni mo tún ń rò ó pé ohun tó máa ń wù mí láti ṣe, ìyẹn láti máa wàásù fáwọn ẹlẹ́wọ̀n, máa wá di ṣíṣe báyìí.

English: So did you get a chance to witness to some while you were in prison?
Yoruba: Ṣé àǹfààní ẹ̀ wá yọ láti wàásù fún àwọn kan nígbà tẹ́ ẹ wà lẹ́wọ̀n?

English: TA: Yes. On one occasion, I was summoned by a law-enforcement officer who wanted to speak with me.
Yoruba: TA: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni. Ìgbà kan wà tí agbófinró kan ránṣẹ́ sí mi pé òun fẹ́ bá mi sọ̀rọ̀. Nígbà tí mo dé ọ́fíìsì ẹ̀, ó ní, ‘Mo ti mọ̀ pé Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ni ẹ́, má lọ rò ó pé o fẹ́ wàásù fún mi!’ Mo fèsì pé, ‘Mi ò ní in lọ́kàn láti wàásù fún yín.’

English: When I came into his office, he said, ‘I know that you are one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, so don’t even think about preaching to me!’ To which I replied, ‘I have no such intention.’
Yoruba: Ó wá bi mí pé, ‘Kí lorúkọ Ọlọ́run?’ Mo ní, ‘Jèhófà lorúkọ Ọlọ́run.’

English: Then he asked, ‘What is God’s name?’ I said, ‘God’s name is Jehovah.’
Yoruba: Ó tún bi mí pé, ‘Ta wá ni Jésù? Ṣé òun kọ́ ni Ọlọ́run ni?’ Mo dáhùn pé, ‘Rárá, ọmọ Ọlọ́run ni.’

English: He continued, ‘Then, who is Jesus? Isn’t he God?’ I said, ‘No, he is God’s son.’
Yoruba: Ó wá béèrè pé, ‘Kí ló wá dé táwọn Oníṣọ́ọ̀ṣì Ọ́tọ́dọ́ọ̀sì fi gbà pé òun ni Ọlọ́run?’

English: He then asked, ‘Why, then, do Orthodox Christians believe he is God?’ And I said, ‘You should ask them about that.’
Yoruba: Mo ní, ‘Àwọn náà ni wọ́n máa lè dáhùn ẹ̀.’

English: On another occasion, I was able to speak to about 40 or more people at the same time.
Yoruba: Nǹkan míì tún ṣẹlẹ̀ lọ́jọ́ kan tó jẹ́ kí n lè bá àwọn tó tó ogójì (40) tàbí jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ sọ̀rọ̀ lẹ́ẹ̀kan náà.

English: A psychologist had come to the prison to visit the inmates.
Yoruba: Dókítà kan tó jẹ́ afìṣemọ̀rònú ẹ̀dá wá ṣèbẹ̀wò sọ́dọ̀ àwọn ẹlẹ́wọ̀n.

English: We were discussing marriage when she asked what we thought about polygamy.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìgbéyàwó là ń sọ lọ́jọ́ yẹn, ló bá bi wá pé kí lèrò wa nípa kéèyàn fẹ́yàwó púpọ̀.

English: Everyone had an opportunity to share their opinion.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa la láǹfààní láti sọ èrò wa.

English: When it came time for me to speak, I said that I don’t have a personal opinion on this, but I really like the opinion of another person on this topic, which I would like to share.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n ní kí n sọ èrò mi, mo sọ fún wọn pé èmi fúnra mi ò ní nǹkan kan sọ sí i, àmọ́ á wù mí kí n sọ ohun tẹ́nì kan rò nípa ọ̀rọ̀ yìí fún gbogbo wọn.

English: Then I said: ‘That is why a man will leave his father and his mother and he will stick to his wife, and they will become one flesh.’ (Genesis 2:24)
Yoruba: Mo wá sọ pé: ‘Ìdí nìyẹn tí ọkùnrin yóò ṣe fi baba rẹ̀ àti ìyá rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ tí yóò sì fà mọ́ aya rẹ̀, wọn yóò sì di ara kan.’ (Jẹ́nẹ́sísì 2:24)

English: The psychologist asked, ‘Whose opinion is that?’ To which I replied, ‘It is the opinion of Jehovah God, the one who created mankind.
Yoruba: Dókítà náà béèrè pé, ‘Èrò ta nìyẹn?’ Mo ní, ‘Èrò Jèhófà Ọlọ́run ni, ẹni tó dá ọmọ aráyé.

English: It mentions only two people; no more.’
Yoruba: Èèyàn méjì ló sọ pé wọ́n á ṣègbéyàwó; wọn ò ju méjì lọ.’

English: She then asked, ‘Do you have any other reasons why you think that a man should have only one wife?’
Yoruba: Dókítà náà wá bi mí pé, ‘Ṣé ìdí míì wà tó o fi rò pé ìyàwó kan ṣoṣo ló yẹ kí ọkùnrin ní?’

English: I quoted Matthew 7:12, where it is written: “All things, therefore, that you want men to do to you, you also must do to them.”
Yoruba: Mo fa ọ̀rọ̀ yọ látinú Mátíù 7:​12, tó sọ pé: “Nítorí náà, gbogbo ohun tí ẹ bá fẹ́ kí àwọn ènìyàn máa ṣe sí yín, kí ẹ̀yin pẹ̀lú máa ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ sí wọn.”

English: I said: ‘These are the words of Jesus.
Yoruba: Mo ní: ‘Jésù ló sọ̀rọ̀ yìí.

English: Please ask these gentlemen who are sitting in the hall if they would like to share their wife with somebody else.
Yoruba: Ẹ jọ̀ọ́, ẹ bi àwọn ọkùnrin tó jókòó síbí bóyá ó máa wù wọ́n kí àwọn àti ọkùnrin míì jọ máa fẹ́ ìyàwó wọn.

English: If men do not want their wives to have another husband, then certainly women do not want their husbands to have multiple wives.’
Yoruba: Tó bá jẹ́ pé àwọn ọkùnrin ò fẹ́ kí ìyàwó àwọn ní ọkọ míì, nígbà náà, ó dájú pé àwọn ìyàwó náà ò ní fẹ́ kí ọkọ àwọn níyàwó míì.’

English: The psychologist said that out of all the responses she liked my answer the most.
Yoruba: Dókítà náà sọ pé nínú ọ̀rọ̀ tí gbogbo àwọn tó wà níbẹ̀ sọ, ọ̀rọ̀ tèmi lòun gbádùn jù.

English: How encouraging to know that despite your difficult circumstances, you found opportunities to preach to those around you!
Yoruba: Ìṣírí ló jẹ́ fún wa pé láìka bí nǹkan ṣe nira fún yín tó, ẹ ṣì wá àǹfààní láti wàásù fún àwọn tó wà nítòsí yín!

English: After the courts rejected multiple appeals for your release, including an appeal to Kazakhstan’s Supreme Court, it appeared that from a legal standpoint, all options had been exhausted.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn táwọn ilé ẹjọ́ kọ̀ lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà láti fọwọ́ sí i pé kí wọ́n dá yín sílẹ̀, tó fi mọ́ Ilé Ẹjọ́ Gíga Jù Lọ ti Kazakhstan pàápàá, ṣe ló dà bíi pé kò sọ́nà àbáyọ mọ́ lábẹ́ òfin.

English: Yet, you did have an opportunity to be released if you signed a confession.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, wọ́n fún yín láǹfààní láti buwọ́ lùwé kan tẹ́ ẹ bá fẹ́ kí wọ́n dá yín sílẹ̀.

English: Would you tell us about that opportunity and why you refused to sign?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ lè sọ ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ fún wa àti ìdí tẹ́ ẹ fi kọ̀ láti buwọ́ lù ú?

English: TA: Well, they actually offered the proposal a few times.
Yoruba: TA: Òótọ́ ni pé àwọn ìgbà kan wà tí wọ́n ní kí n buwọ́ lùwé.

English: Although it appeared to be an act of kindness, it was actually a document that stated I was guilty of the charges brought against me and that I apologized for my actions.
Yoruba: Ó jọ bíi pé ìrànlọ́wọ́ ni wọ́n fẹ́ ṣe fún mi, àmọ́ ohun tó wà nínú ìwé yẹn ni pé mo jẹ̀bi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kàn mí àti pé mo tọrọ àforíjì fún ohun tí mo ṣe.

English: Later, I was offered the option of writing my own confession and requesting a pardon.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó yá, wọ́n ní kí n kọ̀wé míì fúnra mi láti jẹ́wọ́ ohun tí mo ṣe, kí n sì bẹ̀bẹ̀ pé kí wọ́n tú mi sílẹ̀.

English: The authorities instructed me to write that I made a mistake by speaking to others about my beliefs but that I was now sorry for my actions and was requesting to be released because of my health condition.
Yoruba: Ohun táwọn aláṣẹ ní kí n kọ ni pé àṣìṣe ni mo ṣe bí mo ṣe bá àwọn míì sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ohun tí mo gbà gbọ́, àmọ́ pé ní báyìí, mo tọrọ àforíjì fún ohun tí mo ṣe, mo sì ń bẹ̀bẹ̀ pé kí wọ́n tú mi sílẹ̀ torí àìlera mi.

English: I refused all such confessions of guilt and told the authorities that I would rather sit in prison with a clear conscience than be released with a guilty one.
Yoruba: Mo kọ̀ láti kọ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ yẹn, mo sì sọ fáwọn aláṣẹ pé ó pé mi kí n wà lẹ́wọ̀n pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rí ọkàn tó mọ́, ju kí wọ́n tú mi sílẹ̀ àmọ́ kí ẹ̀rí ọkàn mi máa dá mi lẹ́bi.

English: We certainly appreciate your example of faith and refusal to violate your conscience.
Yoruba: A mọyì àpẹẹrẹ ìgbàgbọ́ tẹ́ ẹ ní gan-an àti bẹ́ ẹ ṣe kọ̀ láti ṣe ohun tó máa ba ẹ̀rí ọkàn yín jẹ́.

English: Eventually, though, there was an unexpected turn of events. Would you please tell us how you learned that you would be pardoned and released from prison?
Yoruba: Nígbà tó yá, ohun tá ò retí ṣẹlẹ̀. Ṣé ẹ lè sọ fún wa nípa bẹ́ ẹ ṣe mọ̀ pé ìjọba fẹ́ tú yín sílẹ̀ lẹ́wọ̀n?

English: TA: One day a guard came to my ward to inform me that I had a phone call.
Yoruba: TA: Lọ́jọ́ kan, ẹ̀ṣọ́ kan wá sí yàrá mi, ó sọ fún mi pé ẹnì kan fẹ́ bá mi sọ̀rọ̀ lórí fóònù.

English: I remember thinking, ‘Who would call me?’ When I picked up the phone, a woman introduced herself and said that she would be coming to the prison to release me.
Yoruba: Mo rò ó pé, ‘Ta ló lè fẹ́ bá mi sọ̀rọ̀?’

English: I really didn’t know how to react to the phone call.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo gbé fóònù, obìnrin lẹni náà, ó sọ bóun ṣe jẹ́ fún mi, ó sì sọ pé òun ń bọ̀ wá tú mi sílẹ̀.

English: So after she hung up, I decided to tell my son about it, since I didn’t want to shock my wife with the news or give her a false hope.
Yoruba: Kí n má parọ́, mi ò mọ ohun tí mi ò bá ṣe.

English: After I hung up the phone, the guard asked me, ‘What did they tell you on the phone?’
Yoruba: Nígbà tá a sọ̀rọ̀ tán lórí fóònù, mo pinnu pé màá sọ fún ọmọ mi ọkùnrin, mi ò fẹ́ sọ fún ìyàwó mi torí kí n má bàa kó o lọ́kàn sókè, a ò sì mọ̀ bóyá wọ́n á tú mi sílẹ̀ lóòótọ́, kí n má lọ fojú ẹ̀ sọ́nà.

English: I told him that someone must be playing a joke on me, since the woman on the phone just told me that she is coming to the prison to release me.
Yoruba: Bí mo ṣe gbé fóònù náà kalẹ̀, ẹ̀ṣọ́ yẹn bi mí pé, ‘Kí ni wọ́n sọ fún ẹ lórí fóònù?’ Mo ní ẹnì kan ló ń bá mi dá àpárá jàre, torí ṣe ni obìnrin tí mo bá sọ̀rọ̀ kàn sọ pé òun ń bọ̀ wá tú mi sílẹ̀.

English: Mark Sanderson, a member of the Governing Body, with Teymur and Mafiza Akhmedov shortly after Brother Akhmedov was released from custody.
Yoruba: Mark Sanderson, tó jẹ́ ara Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí, pẹ̀lú Teymur àti Mafiza Akhmedov lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n dá Arákùnrin Akhmedov sílẹ̀.

English: The guard replied that she was not joking and that what she said was true.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ṣọ́ yẹn sọ fún mi pé kì í ṣọ̀rọ̀ eré o, òótọ́ lobìnrin yẹn ń sọ o.

English: Mafiza, how did you react to this exciting news?
Yoruba: Arábìnrin Mafiza, báwo ni ìròyìn amóríyá yìí ṣe rí lára yín?

English: MA: When my son relayed the news to me, I also thought it was a joke. We had been waiting for this news for so long!
Yoruba: MA: Nígbà tí ọmọ mi sọ fún mi, èmi náà rò pé ó ń ṣeré ni. Ọjọ́ pẹ́ tá a ti ń retí irú ìròyìn bẹ́ẹ̀!

English: We can only imagine how you both must have felt when you were reunited over a year after Teymur was arrested!
Yoruba: Àwa ò lè mọ bínú ẹ̀yin méjèèjì ṣe máa dùn tó nígbà tí Arákùnrin Teymur pa dà sílé lẹ́yìn ohun tó lé ní ọdún kan táwọn aláṣẹ ti mú wọn lọ!

English: Now, looking back, what have you learned from this test of your faith?
Yoruba: Tẹ́ ẹ bá ronú pa dà sẹ́yìn nípa àdánwò ìgbàgbọ́ tẹ́ ẹ kojú yìí, ẹ̀kọ́ wo lẹ lè sọ pé ẹ kọ́?

English: MA: I remember how I used to cry about the situation of Brother Bahram [Hemdemov] and [Sister] Gulzira Hemdemov.
Yoruba: MA: Mo rántí bí ọ̀rọ̀ Arákùnrin Bahram [Hemdemov] àti [Arábìnrin] Gulzira Hemdemov ṣe máa ń pa mí lẹ́kún tó.

English: [Brother Hemdemov was arrested in March 2015 by authorities in Turkmenistan.
Yoruba: [Àwọn aláṣẹ ní Turkmenistan mú Arákùnrin Hemdemov ní March 2015.

English: On May 19, 2015, he was sentenced to four years in prison on fabricated charges of “inciting religious hatred” and has yet to be released.]
Yoruba: Nígbà tó di May 19, 2015, wọ́n rán an lọ sí ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún mẹ́rin lórí ẹ̀sùn èké tí wọ́n fi kàn án pé ó ń “mú kí àwọn èèyàn kórìíra ẹ̀sìn míì”, wọn ò sì tíì tú u sílẹ̀ lẹ́wọ̀n di báyìí.]

English: Even before Teymur’s arrest, I thought about how difficult it must be for Gulzira.
Yoruba: Kódà, kí wọ́n tó mú Teymur, mo ronú nípa bó ṣe máa nira tó fún Gulzira.

English: Now, I would like to hug her and send her my warm love and support.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, á wù mí báyìí kí n rí i, kí n gbá a mọ́ra, kí n sì jẹ́ kó mọ̀ pé mo nífẹ̀ẹ́ ẹ̀, mo sì wà lẹ́yìn ẹ̀.

English: Having been through this challenge with Teymur, I would like to tell her that I sympathize with her pain.
Yoruba: Torí ohun tí ojú èmi àti Teymur ti rí yìí, á wù mí kí n sọ fún Gulzira pé mo bá a kẹ́dùn torí ohun tójú tiẹ̀ náà rí.

English: I know that, like me, she depends on the support of Jehovah and the brothers.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ pé bíi tèmi, Jèhófà àtàwọn ará lòun náà gbára lé.

English: I am very grateful to all of the brothers who supported us, the brothers in our congregation and in all the congregations around the world, the Governing Body, the lawyers, and our sons.
Yoruba: Ọpẹ́ púpọ̀ lọ́wọ́ gbogbo àwọn ará tó tì wá lẹ́yìn, látorí àwọn ará ìjọ wa àti gbogbo ìjọ kárí ayé, tó fi mọ́ Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí, àwọn agbẹjọ́rò àtàwọn ọmọkùnrin wa.

English: Brother Akhmedov holding his certificate of pardon after being released from custody.
Yoruba: Arákùnrin Akhmedov di ìwé ẹ̀rí tí wọ́n fi dá a sílẹ̀ mú lẹ́yìn tó kúrò lẹ́wọ̀n.

English: TA: I can say only one thing, everyone has tests that they must face.
Yoruba: TA: Ohun kan tí mo fẹ́ sọ ni pé gbogbo wa la máa kojú àdánwò.

English: Of course, not everyone will have a test of imprisonment.
Yoruba: Ó lè má jẹ́ gbogbo wa la máa lọ sẹ́wọ̀n.

English: For some, the test may be persecution from an unbelieving family member.
Yoruba: Àdánwò táwọn míì máa kojú lè jẹ́ inúnibíni látọ̀dọ̀ mọ̀lẹ́bí wọn tó jẹ́ aláìgbàgbọ́.

English: For others, maybe it is dealing with a brother or sister in the congregation who is difficult to get along with.
Yoruba: Ní tàwọn míì, ó lè jẹ́ arákùnrin tàbí arábìnrin kan nínú ìjọ tó ṣòroó bá lò.

English: Whatever our challenge or test, we each have a choice whether to stand by God’s principles or ignore them.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro tàbí àdánwò yòówù ká máa kojú, gbogbo wa la máa pinnu ohun tá a máa ṣe, bóyá ìlànà Ọlọ́run la fẹ́ rọ̀ mọ́ àbí ìdàkejì ẹ̀ la fẹ́ ṣe.

English: If we stand by the principles, then we can get through the test successfully.
Yoruba: Tá a bá rọ̀ mọ́ àwọn ìlànà yẹn, a máa lè borí àdánwò.

English: The best thing to do is to accept our tests and remember that Jehovah will give us the strength to get through them.
Yoruba: Ohun tó dáa jù tá a le ṣe tá a bá ń kojú àdánwò ni pé, ká gbà pé àdánwò ló délẹ̀ yìí, ká sì máa rántí pé Jèhófà máa fún wa lókun ti àá fi borí ẹ̀.

English: I am very thankful to my family and my sons, who supported me.
Yoruba: Mo dúpẹ́ gan-an lọ́wọ́ ìdílé mi àtàwọn ọmọ mi, wọ́n kú àdúrótì.

English: They used every opportunity to visit me, and it helped me to remain strong.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àǹfààní tó bá yọ ni wọ́n fi ń wá wò mí, ìyẹn ò sì jẹ́ kí n rẹ̀wẹ̀sì.

English: Additionally, I want to thank our brotherhood for all that they did.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, mo fẹ́ dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ẹgbẹ́ ará fún gbogbo ohun tí wọ́n ṣe.

English: I appreciated their prayers, and their encouraging letters.
Yoruba: Mo mọrírì àdúrà wọn àtàwọn lẹ́tà tó ń gbéni ró tí wọ́n kọ sí mi.

English: I did not feel abandoned for one minute.
Yoruba: Mi ò mọ̀ ọ́n lára pé wọ́n pa mí tì fún ìṣẹ́jú kan.

English: What has happened to me has increased my love for the brotherhood and strengthened my relationship with Jehovah."
Yoruba: Ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ sí mi ti jẹ́ kí ìfẹ́ tí mo ní sí ẹgbẹ́ ará pọ̀ sí i, ó sì ti jẹ́ kí àjọṣe tí mo ní pẹ̀lú Jèhófà lágbára sí i."

English: "On November 30, 2018, the Kyrgyzstan Ministry of Justice registered an office for Jehovah’s Witnesses in the city of Osh, the second-largest city in Kyrgyzstan.
Yoruba: "Ní November 30, 2018, Ilé Iṣẹ́ Ètò Ìdájọ́ lórílẹ̀-èdè Kyrgyzstan forúkọ ọ́fíìsì àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà ní ìlú Osh sílẹ̀, ìlú yìí ló tóbi ṣèkèjì lórílẹ̀-èdè Kyrgyzstan.

English: While our brothers have enjoyed national registration in Kyrgyzstan since 1998, after a new law on religion came into force in 2008, local authorities have routinely denied our brothers registration in cities in the southern region of the country, where Osh is located.
Yoruba: Àwọn ará wa jọlá bí ìjọba àpapọ̀ ṣe forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wọn sílẹ̀ ní Kyrgyzstan látọdún 1998, àmọ́ lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n gbé òfin kan nípa ẹ̀sìn jáde lọ́dún 2008, léraléra ni àwọn aláṣẹ tó wà láwọn ìlú ní agbègbè gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdè náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í kọ̀ láti forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wọn sílẹ̀, apá ibẹ̀ sì ni ìlú Osh wà.

English: As a result, city authorities have often viewed our brothers’ Christian meetings and public ministry as illegal.
Yoruba: Nípa bẹ́ẹ̀, ńṣe làwọn aláṣẹ ìlú bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í ka ìpàdé àwọn ará wa àti iṣẹ́ ìwàásù wọn sí ohun tí kò bófin mu.

English: On occasion, the police have raided private homes or rented facilities where our brothers were gathering for worship.
Yoruba: Láwọn ìgbà kan àwọn ọlọ́pàá ya wọnú ilé tàbí ibi táwọn ará gbà láti pé jọ sí fún jọ́sìn.

English: We rejoice that this positive development will help further establish the right for Witnesses in Kyrgyzstan to meet freely for worship and peacefully share the Bible’s message with others.—1 Timothy 2:1-4."
Yoruba: Inú wa dùn pé ìyípadà yìí máa mú kí àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà túbọ̀ lẹ́tọ̀ọ́ lórílẹ̀-èdè Kyrgyzstan láti máa pé jọ fún ìjọsìn ká sì máa báwọn èèyàn sọ̀rọ̀ nípa Bíbélì láìsí wàhálà.—1 Tímótì 2:1-4."

English: "Jehovah’s Witnesses in the capital of Mongolia, Ulaanbaatar, received a certificate from the City Council’s office on June 14, 2018, officially granting permission to renew their religious entity.
Yoruba: "Ní June 14, 2018, àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà nílùú Ulaanbaatar tó jẹ́ olú-ìlú orílẹ̀-èdè Mòǹgólíà, gba ìwé ẹ̀rí kan látọ̀dọ̀ Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú, pé ìjọba ti pa dà forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wọn sílẹ̀ lábẹ́ òfin lórílẹ̀-èdè náà.

English: Renewal certificate allowing Jehovah’s Witnesses to legally operate in Ulaanbaatar.
Yoruba: Ìwé ẹ̀rí tó jẹ́ káwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà lè máa ṣe ẹ̀sìn wọn ní Ulaanbaatar.

English: Religious organizations in Mongolia are required to renew their registrations annually, and our brothers had successfully done this since first being registered in 1999.
Yoruba: Ìjọba sọ fáwọn ẹlẹ́sìn pé ọdọọdún ni kí wọ́n máa forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wọn sílẹ̀ ní Mòǹgólíà, àtìgbà táwọn ará wa sì ti kọ́kọ́ forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wọn sílẹ̀ lábẹ́ òfin lọ́dún 1999 ni wọ́n ti ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: However, in 2015, the City Council withheld the renewal of our legal entity in Ulaanbaatar.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ lọ́dún 2015, Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú ò gbà káwọn ará wa forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wọn sílẹ̀ ní Ulaanbaatar.

English: Then, in January 2017, the City Council issued a ruling that officially annulled permission for the legal entity to carry out its religious activity.
Yoruba: Nígbà tó di January 2017, Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú sọ pe ìjọba fagi lé àǹfààní tí àwọn ará ní láti ṣe ẹ̀sìn wọn.

English: Council representatives refused to disclose the evidence they used to support their decision.
Yoruba: Àwọn tó ṣojú fún Àjọ náà ò sọ ohunkóhun tó mú kí wọ́n ṣe ìpinnu yìí.

English: The brothers decided to legally challenge the City Council’s decision.
Yoruba: Làwọn ará bá sọ pé àwọn máa gbé ọ̀rọ̀ náà lọ sílé ẹjọ́.

English: During the Administrative Court proceedings, the attorney for the City Council attempted to introduce as evidence the decision made by the Russian Supreme Court to liquidate our legal entities within Russia.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí Ilé Ẹjọ́ ń gbọ́ ẹjọ́ náà, agbẹjọ́rò Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú gbìyànjú láti fi ẹjọ́ tí Ilé Ẹjọ́ Gíga Jù Lọ ní Rọ́ṣíà dá ṣe ẹ̀rí, ìyẹn bí wọ́n ṣe sọ pé kí ìjọba gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé àwọn àjọ tá a fi forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wa sílẹ̀ lábẹ́ òfin ní Rọ́ṣíà.

English: Our attorneys argued that this ruling has been the subject of international criticism and has been challenged in international courts.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ àwọn agbẹjọ́rò wa jẹ́ kó ṣe kedere pé ọ̀pọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ni ò fara mọ́ ẹjọ́ tí ilé ẹjọ́ dá ní Rọ́ṣíà àti pé ọ̀rọ̀ náà ti dé àwọn ilé ẹjọ́ àgbáyé.

English: Additionally, the court was reminded that Russia’s ruling came after the City Council’s decisions and therefore could not be used as justification for its conclusions.
Yoruba: Wọ́n tún rán ilé ẹjọ́ létí pé ẹ̀yìn tí Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú ṣèpinnu tiwọn ni ọ̀rọ̀ ti Rọ́ṣíà wáyé, torí náà, Àjọ náà ò lè sọ pé ohun tó ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Rọ́ṣíà ló mú káwọn ṣèpinnu táwọn ṣe.

English: The Administrative Court reversed the City Council’s decision, concluding that the council had acted out of hearsay and failed to provide evidence of any harmful activity.
Yoruba: Ilé Ẹjọ́ fagi lé ìpinnu tí Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú ṣe, wọ́n ní àhesọ ọ̀rọ̀ lásán ni Àjọ náà gùn lé tí wọ́n fi ṣèpinnu, wọn ò sì rí ẹ̀rí kankan mú wá pé àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ṣe ohunkóhun tó léwu.

English: It also found that the City Council had violated the brothers’ fundamental rights, including the freedom to manifest one’s religion or beliefs.
Yoruba: Ilé Ẹjọ́ náà tún rí i pé Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú fi ẹ̀tọ́ táwọn ará wa ní lábẹ́ òfin dù wọ́n, tó fi mọ́ òmìnira láti ṣe ẹ̀sìn wọn tàbí ohun tí wọ́n gbà gbọ́.

English: Jason Wise, one of the Witnesses’ attorneys who argued the case, stated: “While fundamental rights and freedoms do not depend on State registration, it is often difficult to worship freely without registration.
Yoruba: Jason Wise, tó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn agbẹjọ́rò àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà nínú ẹjọ́ yìí sọ pé: “Bó tiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé kò di dandan kéèyàn ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ forúkọ ẹ̀sìn sílẹ̀ lábẹ́ òfin kó tó lè lo ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti òmìnira tí òfin sọ pé ó ní, síbẹ̀ kì í sábà rọrùn láti jọ́sìn fàlàlà láìkọ́kọ́ forúkọ sílẹ̀.

English: Among other things, our legal entity facilitates importing Bibles and Bible literature, owning places of worship, and renting convention facilities.
Yoruba: Ara àwọn àǹfààní tá à ń rí bá a ṣe forúkọ ẹ̀sìn wa sílẹ̀ ni pé ó ń jẹ́ kó rọrùn fún wa láti kó Bíbélì àtàwọn ìwé tó dá lórí Bíbélì wọ̀lú, ká lè ní ibi ìjọsìn, ká sì lè yá àwọn ibi tá a ti máa ṣe àpéjọ.

English: We are pleased that the Administrative Court overturned the City Council’s decision in Ulaanbaatar and recognized that such rulings would negatively affect our freedom of religion and association in Mongolia.”"
Yoruba: Inú wa dùn pé Ilé Ẹjọ́ fagi lé ìpinnu tí Àjọ Tó Ń Rí sí Ọ̀rọ̀ Ìlú ṣe nílùú Ulaanbaatar, tí wọ́n sì gbà pé irú ìpinnu bẹ́ẹ̀ máa ṣàkóbá fún òmìnira tá a ní láti ṣe ẹ̀sìn wa àti òmìnira tá a ní láti pé jọ ní Mòǹgólíà.”"

English: "Heavy monsoon rains led to floods and landslides in Nepal, displacing thousands of people and killing more than 140.
Yoruba: "Òjò àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá kan rọ̀ lórílẹ̀-èdè Nepal, ó sì fa àkúnya omi àti ilẹ̀ yíya, ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí sọ ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn èèyàn di aláìnílé, ó sì pa àwọn èèyàn tó lé ní ogóje [140].

English: The flooding damaged highways and power lines, hampering relief efforts.
Yoruba: Àkúnya omi náà ba àwọn ojú títì jẹ́, ó sì ba iná mànàmáná jẹ́, èyí wá mú kó nira láti ran àwọn tọ́rọ̀ kàn lọ́wọ́.

English: The branch office of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Japan, which also coordinates the Witnesses’ activities in Nepal, reports that no Witnesses were injured or killed in the incident.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà lórílẹ̀-èdè Japan náà ló ń bójú tó iṣẹ́ àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà ní Nepal, wọ́n sì sọ pé kò sí Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà kankan tó fara pa tàbí tó kú nínú jàǹbá náà.

English: However, at least four Witness families were forced to evacuate from their homes, which were damaged by the floodwaters.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, ó di dandan fún ìdílé àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà mẹ́rin láti filé wọn sílẹ̀, torí pé àkúnya omi tí bá àwọn ilé ọ̀hún jẹ́.

English: Local Witnesses have been caring for their fellow believers who were displaced.
Yoruba: Àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà tó wà lágbègbè náà ti ń ran àwọn ará bíi tiwọn lọ́wọ́, ìyẹn àwọn tómi gbalé wọn.

English: Media Contacts:
Yoruba: Agbẹnusọ fún Àwa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà:

English: International: David A. Semonian, Office of Public Information, +1-845-524-3000
Yoruba: Kárí Ayé: David A. Semonian, Ọ́fíìsì Agbéròyìnjáde, +1-845-524-3000

English: "On August 28, 2019, heavy rains caused the Talomo River to overflow in Davao City.
Yoruba: "Ní August 28, 2019, àrọ̀ọ̀rọ̀dá òjò kan mú kí odò Talomo kún àkúnya, omi náà sí ya wọ ìlú Davao.

English: According to government data, the subsequent flooding forced some 545 families to evacuate.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn látọ̀dọ̀ àwọn aláṣẹ fi hàn pé omíyalé tó tẹ̀ lé òjò yìí lé ìdílé tó tó nǹkan bí ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún àti márùndínláàádọ́ta (545) kúrò nílé wọn.

English: The Philippines branch office reports that 120 publishers from five congregations were impacted by this disaster.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ka ọ́fíìsì Philippines ròyìn pé ọgọ́fà (120) akéde látì ìjọ márùn-ún ni àkúnya omi yìí ṣàkóbá fún.

English: Many of the publishers had to take refuge at the local Kingdom Hall.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn akéde yìí ló fara pa mọ́ sí Gbọ̀ngàn Ìjọba.

English: Floodwaters destroyed three of our brothers’ homes and damaged four.
Yoruba: Àkúnya omi náà wó ilé mẹ́ta, ó sì ba ilé mẹ́rin tó jẹ́ ti àwọn ará wa jẹ́.

English: The branch established a Disaster Relief Committee (DRC) to care for the needs of the affected brothers and sisters.
